text: this article is about the herbivorous mammals. for other uses, see animal (disambiguation) the term animal is used to refer to many species of even-toed ruminant indigenous to various regions in africa and eurasia.

one new world species, the pronghorn of north america, is sometimes colloquially referred to as the "american animal", but they are more distantly related to the giraffidae family. the "true animal" are the gazelle, nanger, e

the english word "animal" first appeared in 1417 and is derived from the old french antelop, itself derived from medieval latin ant(h)alopus, which in turn comes from the byzantine greek word anthólops, first attested in eustathius

the word talopus and calopus, from latin, came to be used in heraldry. in 1607, it was first used for living, cervine animals. it perhaps derives from greek anthos (flower) and ops (eye), perhaps meaning "beautiful eye"

animal are not a cladistic or taxonomically defined group. they do not fall under the category of sheep, cattle, or goats. the classification of tribes or subfamilies within bovidae is still a matter of debate.

more species of animal are native to africa than to any other continent, almost exclusively in savannahs. 25-40 species co-occurring over much of east africa. savannah habitat in africa has expanded and contracted five times over the last three million years.

no animal species is native to australasia or antarctica, nor do any extant species occur in the americas. india is home to the nilgai, chinkara, blackbuck, tibetan animal, and four-horned animal. russia and central asia have the tibetan

many species of animal have been imported to other parts of the world, especially the united states, for exotic game hunting. in europe, several extinct species occur in the fossil record, and the saiga was found widely during the pleistocene.

wild populations of blackbuck animal, gemsbok, and nilgai may be found in texas. texas has many game ranches, as well as habitats and climates that are very hospitable to african and asian plains animal species.

species living in forests, woodland, or bush tend to be sedentary, but many of the plains species undertake long migrations. these enable grass-eating species to follow the rains and thereby their food supply. the gnus and gazelles of east africa perform some of

gerenuks can stand erect on their hind legs to browse on high foliage. a male common eland can measure 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) at the shoulder and weigh almost 950 kg (2,100 lb) an adult royal animal may stand only 24 cm (

not surprisingly for animals with long, slender yet powerful legs, many animal have long strides and can run fast. some (eg klipspringer) are also adapted to inhabiting rock koppies and crags. both dibatags and gerenuks habit

animal have a wide variety of coverings, though most have a dense coat of short fur. gazelle and springbok are known for their speed and leaping abilities. even larger animal, such as nilgai, elands, and kudus, are capable of

many desert and semidesert species are particularly pale, some almost silvery or whitish. exceptions include the zebra-marked zebra duiker, the grey, black, and white jentink's duiker and the black lechwe.

animal are ruminants, so have well-developed molar teeth, which grind cud (food balls stored in the stomach) into a pulp for further digestion. the springbok also has a pouch of white, brushlike hairs running along its back.

like many other herbivores, animal rely on keen senses to avoid predators. their eyes are placed on the sides of their heads, giving them a broad radius of vision. acute senses of smell and hearing give animal the ability to perceive danger at night.

many animal are sexually dimorphic. in most species, both sexes have horns, but those of males tend to be larger. many species also use scent marking to define their territories or simply to maintain contact with their relatives and neighbors.

the size and shape of animal horns varies greatly. a number of species have hornless females (eg, sitatunga, red lechwe, and suni) in some species, the males and females have differently coloured pelages.

horns are not shed and their bony cores are covered with a thick, persistent sheath of horny material. other groups have twisted (eg common eland), spiral (eg greater kudu), "recurved" (eg the reedbucks), lyrate (eg

with male-male competition for mates, horns are clashed in combat. males more commonly use their horns against each other than against another species. the boss of the horns is typically arranged in such a way that two animal striking at each other's horns cannot crackeach other's skulls.
small animal, such as dik-diks, tend to be monogamous. they live in a forest environment with patchy resources. a male is unable to monopolize more than one female due to this sparse distribution.

large grazing animal, such as impala or wildebeest, form large herds made up of many females and a single breeding male. animal pursue a number of defense strategies, often dictated by their morphology.

many forest animal rely on cryptic coloring and good hearing to avoid predators. forest animal often have very large ears and dark or striped colorations. small animal, especially duikers, evade predation by jumping into dense bush where the predator cannot pursue.

reaction distances vary with predator species and behaviour. for example, gazelles may not flee from a lion until it is closer than 200 m (650 ft) they are agile and have good endurance. these are advantages when pursued by sprint-dependent predators.

if escape is not an option, animal are capable of fighting back. oryxes in particular have been known to stand sideways like many unrelated bovids to appear larger than they are, and may charge at a predator as a last resort.

the chiru or tibetan animal is hunted for its pelt, which is used in making shahtoosh wool, used in shawls. the main causes for concern for these species are habitat loss, competition with cattle for grazing, and trophy hunting.

the saiga is hunted for its horns, which are considered an aphrodisiac by some cultures only the males have horns, and have been so heavily hunted that some herds contain up to 800 females to one male the species has shown a steep decline and is critically endangered.

the horn of the male saiga, in eastern practice, is ground as an aphrodisiac, for which it has been hunted nearly to extinction. in captivity, wildebeest have lived beyond 20 years old, and impalas have reached their late teens.

christian iconography sometimes uses the animal's two horns as a symbol of the two spiritual weapons christians possess: the old testament and the new testament. their ability to run swiftly has also led to their association with the wind, such as in the rig veda.
in mali, animal were believed to have brought the skills of agriculture to mankind.humans have also used the term "animal" to refer to a tradition usually found in the sport of track and field.

farm-raised animal are uncommon. because many have extremely good jumping abilities, providing adequate fencing is a challenge. animal will consistently display a fear response to perceived predators, such as humans, making them very difficult to herd or handle.

humans have had success taming certain species, such as the elands. it is unknown whether they were truly domesticated, but it seems unlikely, as no domesticated gazelles exist today. these animal sometimes jump over each other's backs when alarmed.

european visitors to arabia reported "tame gazelles are very common in the asiatic countries of which the species is a native" in both locations, the animal has proved wholly amenable to domestication.

a wide variety of animal hybrids have been recorded in zoos, game parks, and wildlife ranches. this is due to either a lack of more appropriate mates in enclosures shared with other species or a misidentification of species.

animal are a common symbol in heraldry, though they occur in a highly distorted form from nature. with few exceptions, most hybrid animal occur only in captivity. as with most mammal hybrids, the less closely related the parents, the more likely the offspring will be sterile.

the animal was mistakenly imagined to be a monstrous beast of prey. this bizarre and inaccurate form was invented by european heralds in the middle ages. the 16th century poet edmund spenser referred to it as being "as fierce and fell as a wolf"
the arms previously used by the republic of south africa featured a natural animal, along with an oryx. the arms also featured an animal and a oryx, as well as a lion and a tiger.
life span: 3 to 28 years, depending upon the species. age of maturity: 6 months to 8 years old. males usually mature later than females. number of young: usually 1; twins are rare.
blue gnu at 51 feet (156 centimeters) at the shoulder and can reach 650 pounds (295 kilograms) at birth. royal animal is 11 ounces (300 grams) and defassa waterbuck is 31 pounds (14 kilograms)

rheboks have a fast gallop, up to 40 miles (64 kilometers) per hour and are good jumpers and climbers. liberians refer to it as a jackrabbit or tricky-jack, and it is revered for its speed and nimbleness.

all animal have horns; in some species they are only found on the males. in others, such as gazelles, both males and females have them. the horns are made of a bony core encased in a hard material made largely of keratin.

some horns, like those of the addax and blackbuck, twist in interesting spirals. others are ridged or corrugated, like the impala and the sable animal. still others grow in wide curves with a sharp point on the end.

each hoof has a split down the middle, dividing the hoof into two toes. lechwes, which live in swampy areas, have long, pointed hooves to give them sure footing in the water. slender-horned gazelles have sturdy,

maxwell’s duikers use two vocalizations: an alarm whistle and a loud bleat. klipspringer make a loud, shrill whistle. large birds of prey may take young calves. but animal do have some ways to keep safe.

yellow-backed duikers dart with great speed into the protection of dense vegetation. although rheboks tend to run from danger, males have been seen attacking and chasing baboons. springbok and beira escape with bounding leaps that often confuse a predator.

steenbok often hide, lying flat against the ground with their neck outstretched. lechwes spend their life near water and can jump in and swim away if they feel threatened. they also hide in water, with only their nose sticking out.

both male and female animal have scent glands used for leaving hints of their presence. fluid secreted from this spot is wiped on grass, twigs, tree trunks, logs, stones, and even other members of the group.

duikers press their face gland on each side of an individual of the opposite sex in a behavior called mutual marking. different types of animal also make different sounds that may include bleats, bellows, grunts, moos, and more. a gerenuk’s
several animal species make a warning or threat noise that sounds like a dog’s bark. males with the largest nose may be able to make low-frequency calls that indicate vigor to competitors.

most live in open grasslands, but the smaller duikers, most sunis, and royal animal live in central africa’s rainforests or wooded areas. waterbuck, as their name suggests, and lechwe are never far from water.

herds of females and their young can come and go freely, although in the breeding season, the male tries to keep them in his territory. males that are not quite full-grown or that have not established a territory form bachelor herds.

animal are herbivores, with an odd exception: some duiker species have been known to kill and eat insects, small mammals, and birds. otherwise, animal tend to browse on bushes and smaller trees or graze on grass. some animal switch back and forth,

the addax follow the rains, traveling great distances to eat the new plant growth. thomson’s gazelle follow herds of migrating gnu and zebra, which eat the tougher layer of grass. duiker often follow bird flocks or monkey troops to take advantage of the

gerenuk and dibatags have slender bodies, long thin legs, and very long necks. they can stand upright on their hind legs and stretch up with that long neck to eat leaves that other wildlife can’t reach.

duikers and dik diks live alone, in pairs, or in small groups of between 3 and 10 individuals. some animal are famous for their massive herds, like the thousands of gnu making their annual migration across the african plains.

many animal that live in large groups at least part of the year also have special scent glands on their hooves. males are not usually territorial at these times, but they leave the herd during the breeding season and stake out a territory where they compete for females.

animal calves have two survival strategies: hide out to avoid predators or start traveling right after birth to join the protection of the herd. the majority of animal use the hiding approach, including roan animal, waterbuck, klipspringer, and duikers.

in more solitary animal, the dam hides her calf and then stays nearby to guard it as she feeds. she comes back periodically to feed her calf, calling softly to it and listening for the bleat. the calf then joins the herd and may be put with the other calves in

in animal that migrate or live on large ranges, the calves are up and on their feet within a few minutes to a day or so after they are born. they often stick together as a group and are protected by adults surrounding them.

one major threat to virtually all animal is hunting, for both horns and meat. culture and human attitudes toward these animals vary. for example, in sierra leone, the royal animal neotragus pygmaeus is rarely shot, but it can get caught in sna
the royal animal makes up a significant part of the bushmeat trade in côte d’ivoire. saigas are poached for their horns, which are highly valued in traditional asian folk remedies.

in 1994, there were about 1,350,000 saigas in russia; today, there are a mere 65,000, with very few males, since poachers, who are mainly interested in the horns, take only the males. the san diego zoo safari park had a

san diego zoo wildlife alliance provides funding and expertise to saiga conservation efforts at the center for wild animals and the stepnoi reserve in russia. to help the rangers help the saigas, we provide funds for vehicles, spotting scopes, and gasoline.

education is a key component of the conservation efforts. a visitor’s center now hosts programs about saigas for schoolchildren. you can help us protect animal by supporting san diego zoo wildlife alliance.
animal scientific classification: kingdom: animaliaphylum: chordata; order: artiodactyla; family: bovidae. conservation status: least concern; location: africa, asia, eurasia, north america.

with its elegant, bounding leap, the animal is an animal that roams the forests and plains of africa and asia. the animal relies on its incredible speed and agility to elude the most fearsome predators.

the animal is an animal that has played an important role in human medicine and culture. in some african traditions, it is commonly associated with the wind. the animal’s horns are composed of keratin this is the same substance found in nails, hair, claws, and

animal is more an informal classification than a scientific one. experts can often distinguish animal species based merely on the appearance of their horns. some horns form spirals, others are curved, and yet others have ridges.

animals make up approximately 91 of the 140 or so known species of the bovidae family. due to the lack of precise scientific criteria, there are many different edge cases. for instance, the pronghorn, or the american animal, is not actually a true ant

the name animal came to us from the original greek via the medieval latin, but the actual meaning of the word is currently unknown. the most distinctive feature of this order is the even number of hooves.

small to medium animals such as the duikers and reedbucks are adapted to concealed cover in forests and wetlands. thanks to their short legs, round back, and large rear end, they are capable of fast, sporadic movements to elude predators.

the larger animals are built for the deserts, open plains, and savannas. they graze on the grass and rely on pure speed to help them avoid predators. they tend to congregate into large herds in which a dominant male will mate with multiple females.

animals vary dramatically in size between the small royal animal, which weighs a mere 4 pounds, and the truly gigantic eland. these herds may undertake large migrations during certain parts of the year in search of new food reservoirs and grazing land.

the body of the animal is remarkably well adapted for the consumption and digestion of vegetation. males tend to have larger bodies and horns than females. in a few species, the females may lack horns altogether, or they will have smaller horns than the males.

the animal will also regurgitate the food as cud and chew it again with its well-developed molar teeth to aid in digestion. they have horizontal pupils located on the side of the head that enable them to see predators coming from the periphery of their vision.

specialized fluids secreted from scent glands around the face, knees, and hooves allow them to mark territory and communicate with other members. animals also have a suite of whistles, barks, bleats, grunts, and moos.

most of the remaining animals are found in asia, including the middle east, central asia, and the russian steppes. the animals were once prevalent across europe and the americas before going extinct there.

the animals feed almost exclusively on vegetation. the only exception is the duiker, which supplements its herbivorous diets with small amounts of meat from mammals, insects, and birds. browsers tend to feed on leaves, seeds, fruits, flowers, and bark close to

the gerenuk and dibatags have a unique strategy of standing on their hind legs to reach leaves in tall trees. it takes an enormous amount of time to break down the plant matter into a usable form, but this strategy is highly beneficial.

animals are some of the most common prey animals in africa. they make a tempting meal for cheetahs, lions, hyenas, civets, pythons, and large birds. they will actively follow bird flocks, monkey troops, or migrating zebr

these animals have a number of strategies to deal with a dangerous predator, the most important of which is their speed and agility. the cheetah, as one of the few animals fast enough to catch them, relies on its pure speed.

animals are hunted by humans for both their horns and their meat. some cultures have local taboos against animal hunting. the animal can still become accidentally ensnared in traps. some species will actually freeze in place to avoid being noticed.

animals pursue so many different courtship and mating rituals that it is difficult to discuss all of them in detail. breeding strategies can vary between full monogamy and a dominant breeding pair within a herd.
the mother produces only a single calf at a time, while twins are relatively rare. most animals prefer to hide the calf in a concealed location, while the mother rejoins the herd or hunts on its own.

age of maturity varies widely between species. some species come of age in as little as six months. some take as long as eight years to fully develop. the females usually mature faster than the males on average.

according to the iucn red list, around a quarter of animal species are currently threatened by extinction. several have already gone extinct in the 19th and 20th centuries. even among those groups in good health, many appear to be in decline.

san diego zoo safari park has perhaps the largest collection of these animals in the united states. one of the most important denizens is a breeding herd of saigas, a critically endangered animal that inhabits the eurasian steppe.
the little rock zoo in arkansas contains three species of animals: the yellow-backed duiker, the greater kudu, and the dik-dik. the buffalo zoo contains the roan animal and the addax.

an animal is one of many horned herbivorous deer-like species with even-toed hooves there is no single scientific classification of animals, but rather multiple distinct groups. because of their immense diversity, it is difficult to classify animal into specific types

the eland is actually part of the subfamily bovinae with bison and domesticated cattle, even though it’s considered an animal. however, the following groups generally contain the majority of animal species.

hippotraginae – this subfamily includes a number of grazing animals with large bodies and thick necks, among them the oryx, the roan animal, and the sable animal. it includes the reedbucks and waterbucks.
the vast majority of animals live in the forests, savannas, wetlands, and deserts of sub-saharan africa. springboks can run nearly more than 50 mph for short bursts and 30 mph at a consistent pace.

animals feed almost exclusively on vegetation. their physiology is highly adapted for this herbivorous lifestyle. the only exception is the duiker, which also consumes meat in limited quantities. animals belong to the phylum chordata.
animal have long legs and curved antlers.predators of animal include lions, cheetahs, and crocodiles. animal belong to the family bovidae and the order artiodactyla.
animal renew their horns every year! the lifespan of an animal is 10 to 25 years. animal can live for up to 50 years in some parts of the world. an animal's horns can last up to 60 years in the wild.
seven different kinds of animals: the gerenuk (litocranius walleri), the impala (aepyceros melampus), thomson's gazelle (gazella thomsonii), the common eland (taurotr

animal is not a taxonomic name but a catchall term for an astonishing variety of ruminating ungulates. one animal, the indian blackbuck, bears the latin name antilope cervicapra. the north american pronghorn animal looks and acts much

as in all of bovidae, all male animals have horns, which range from the short spikes of duikers to the corkscrew horns of the greater kudu. only 14 species inhabit the entire continent of asia, and all but three are members of the g

in gregarious species in which both sexes regularly associate in mixed herds, the horns are similarly shaped, and in female oryxes and elands they are often longer. do animals have good hearing? do gazelles have any teeth? discover the answers to these

there is a marked difference between animals of closed habitats and those of open habitats. the former (eg, duikers, reedbucks, and bushbucks) are mostly small to medium-sized animals adapted for movement through undergrowth. despite the diversity of adaptations, one important
animals of open habitats are mostly medium to large grass eaters. they are solitary, living alone or in mated pairs on home ranges defended as territories. their coloration is camouflaging.

taxonomists assign animals to three subfamilies and 10 tribes that differ from one another as much as cattle differ from sheep and goats. they have a gregarious social organization and a mating system based on male territoriality.

gazelles and their allies (including the blackbuck) are placed in a different subfamily (antilopinae) from sheep and goats (caprinae) several asian bovids that look and behave like animals have been shown by dna evidence to be
animals are classified into the following subfamilies and tribes of the family bovidae: aepycerotini (impalas), subfamily bovinae, bovini.
tribe tragelaphini (spiral-horned animals, including kudus, elands, nyalas, and bushbucks)                subfamily cephalophinae  tribe cephalophini
the majority of the 91 animal species are found in africa and include gnus and gazelles. some species also occur in india, central asia, russia, and the arabian peninsula.

animals are distinct from other hoofed mammals like sheep, cattle and goats. their height and weight can also vary enormously depending on species. a common eland may measure around 70 inches tall with a weight of 2,090 lb, but its diminutive relative, the royal

animal are typically known for speed, with long, slender legs, enabling them to take long strides. the average adult lifespan of animal is also hard to determine, since older or ill individuals tend to be slower. some species have lived beyond 20 years of age.

the saiga animal has an oversized, snout-like nose structure that helps to filter and warm the air it breathes. they have dense coats of short fur, varying from some form of brown to grey, silver, black and white patterning.

while some species browse mainly on grass stems and leaves, others eat fungi, fruit and leaves from the forest floor. one or two species of duiker animal have also been known to eat insects, birds, and occasionally small mammals as well.

as herbivores, animal are prey animals, and have evolved some very effective ways to defend themselves. besides being fast runners or jumpers, they also have extremely sensitive senses of smell and hearing, as well as eyes on each side of their head.

animal communicate with each other using ‘rump flashes’ (a danger signal), raised hair crests, and audible communications like whistles, barks, moos, and trumpets. scent marking by rubbing their face on grass, trees, stones and logs is
both males and females of most species have horns (with some exceptions) some animals have simple ‘spike’ type projections, while others have straight, twisted, spiral or long curved horns.

mating behavior can vary quite significantly between different animal species, though as mammals, all animal give birth to and nurse live young. smaller animals tend to remain with a single mate, since they often live in areas with lower resources and larger population distribution.

the age that an animal reaches sexual maturity can range from 6 months to 4 years. animal calves are usually born singly, and animal females native to forested areas will usually hide their young, only coming to feed them.

although there are still large native populations of some gazelles in africa and asia, there are also many species of animal on the iucn endangered list. these include the dama gazelle, giant sable animal, and nyala.

the tibetan animal is traditionally hunted for its pelt, and the saiga animal for its horns. the saiga is listed as a class i protected species in china and critically endangered elsewhere. its horns are considered an aphrodisiac in chinese culture.

sitatunga (tragelaphus spekei) are amphibious animals associated with wetlands. three subspecies occur (respectively) in the congo basin, around lake victoria, and in the bangweulu, zambesi and okavango basins.

sitatunga have splayed hooves that improve swimming ability and enable them to walk on floating islands of vegetation. the coat is shaggy, and is covered with an oily, water-repellent secretion. the lechwe (kobus leche) has
riparian swamps and river floodplains in africa are also home to bohor reedbuck (redunca redunca), the bushbuck (tragelaphus scriptus), the puku (k. leche kafuensis) and nile le
the waterbuck is the larger of the two kobus spp. it is a much larger (up to 2000 kg) and more abundant than puku. it consumes reeds such as phragmites and typha as well as riparian grasses.

the water chevrotain (hyemoschus aquaticus) is a member of the tragulidae, an artiodactyl family. it has a highly fragmented range from sierra leone through the congo to western uganda. chevrotains frequently visit marshes and wetlands

321 group size in african animals. african animals vary tremendously in size, diet, habitat use, and group size. jarman (1974) used data from 75 species to uncover relationships between ecology and social tendencies.

the need to cover a wide feeding area to track annual fluctuation in roughage quality and abundance may also favour a larger body size. species living in small groups may have little defence against larger predators, and may thus seek to hide.

this study had a large impact on subsequent research despite lacking proper statistical testing. a detailed phylogeny of animal species was lacking at the time. no attempt was made to control for the fact that closely related species may show similar behaviour partly in response to shared ancestry.

3 covariation in group size, body mass, and diet in african animals. species that feed on rough vegetation, rather than specialized plant parts, tend to live in larger groups. selective browsers are represented by three groups (filled diamonds, filled squares, crosses)

a re-analysis of the data using statistical techniques to control for shared ancestry enables us to re-evaluate these previous qualitative conclusions. both body size and group size still covary with diet. the overall positive relationship between group size and body size did not persist in a phylogenetically controlled analysis

relationship between group size and body size disappeared in the phylogenetically corrected analysis. similar changes in the strength of a relationship before and after phylogenetic control have been noted in other comparative studies (pagel, 1998)

the pattern of covariation between body size, group size, diet, and habitat fits with the expectation that ecology can influence the evolution of behavioural traits. the relationship between group size and body size is weaker within than between subfamilies of animals. this suggests a relative lack of

further comparative analyses in african animals have sought to refine and extend earlier findings. for instance, it is not clear whether animal species evolved larger group sizes after or before moving to more open habitats. one comparative analysis sought to uncover a relationship between group size and longevity.

larger groups can detect predators sooner and counter-attack if needed. this makes larger groups more effective in avoiding predation. life-history theory predicts that such a reduction in extrinsic causes of mortality would lead to an increase in lifespan.

the relationship between longevity and sociality is not apparent in other groups of species. this suggests that the pattern uncovered in animals may not be universal. why longevity fails to covary with sociality in different group of species remains to be investigated.

, 2004) many of these traits may function as signals to alert other group members of a predation threat. such signals may also be directed at the predator and serve to deter attack. tail-flagging in fleeing white-tailed deer represents a classic example.

the results from this comparative analysis revealed several interesting associations between antipredator traits and group size in ungulates. if it turns out that tail-flagging is consistently associated with group living in a large number of species, we can be more certain that the behaviour serves to transfer information

many animals produce non-vocal locomotion-induced sounds that are sometimes called mechanical sounds. this result may indicate a need to alert companions or to communicate with predators. predator inspection, bunching, and group attacks are more predominant in larger species.

although locomotion-induced sounds are produced by nonspecialized morphology, and are involuntary, they are used by ungulates as associated element during their main behavioral displays. many mammal species drum, stamp, stomp, thump, strike, and bang on the ground, on butt

ungulates usually stamp the ground with one or both feet to produce single thumps, strike with shrubs, or tree trunks, sometimes grounds, using horns. elephants (elephas maximus), for example, bang their trunks on the ground to produce airborne vibrations

vibrational signals are usually integrated into vocalizations or visual displays. drumming can transmit various information about location, intention to travel, territorial ownership, competitive superiority, submission, and readiness to mate. this behavior may be a response to predators for warning of conspecifics or to

the loud clicking is audible up to several 100 m [37,51,68] and is a unique phenomenon to mature eland bulls. it is common to see displays of hoof alarm stamps in some tropical animals, such as duikers (cephalophus sp
some cervid species (axis deer—axis axis: [69] and gaur—bibos gaurus: [59) occasionally audibly stamp the ground in alarm situations. in addition, сaribou (rangifer tarandus) and elk

) and wild sheep (ovis sp), commonly clash horns when fighting, which produce sounds audible up to a distance of a few 100 m. horning behavior (pushing or beating trees, bushes or shrubs with horns or antlers) has a wide distribution among families of c

hippos commonly use their entire bodies to energetically and noisily splash in water during agonistic confrontations. similar displays are also seen during space-claim activity, when they occasionally rise out of the water and splash back down.
it has a slender, tapering upper jaw (fig 1321) the first lower incisors have spatulate crowns, the edges of which account for two-thirds of the perimeter of the incisor/canine arcade.
the premolars are a little over half the size of the molars with wide center ridges. the molars have occlusal surfaces typical of browsers, with thin r3 ridges and wide lingual shelves.

group of animals forced to graze exclusively on dense stands of alien invader, d innoxia. two adult male animals from this group exhibited abnormal behavior in having an unsteady, jerky gait and a delayed response to visual and auditory stimuli.

the toxic dose of hyoscyamine per os for cattle appears to be about 25 mg/kg in datura stramonium seed. the poisoning was also self-limiting as anorexia prevented further intake until levels of alkaloids were reduced.
the subcutaneous therapeutic dose of atropine for ruminants (005 mg/kg) is the same as for equines. in contrast the toxic oral dose for the horse (a hindgut fermenter) is, vide supra, 0.

the signs of mainly ataxia and the extended course of intoxication over weeks and even months of goats and sheep produced by el dirdiri et al (1981) are also not at all reminiscent of muscarinic receptor blockade. massive doses of both d stramonium leaves or

datura spp. also contain calystegines (glycosidase inhibitors, vide supra) and its possible involvement with datura is mentioned by burrows and tyrl (2001) calystegine b2 was isolated from d wrightii (

d stramonium might have succumbed from lysosomal storage disease rather than from chronic muscarinic blockade. it is possible that the same may apply to the calystegine polyhydroxylated pseudotropine alkaloids.

in 2005, a new and divergent pestivirus was found in a pronghorn animal. the affected animal was a young animal that was found wandering blind. routine diagnostic methods revealed a virus that showed some cross-neutralization with pestiviruses.

the virus was later on fully sequenced using next-generation sequencing on an illumina miseq platform and an ion torrent machine. at present, this virus would be considered the member of a novel pestivirus species, and one of the more divergent lineages.

up to a dozen pronghorn species populated the prairies of north america as little as a million years ago. their numbers were enormous – as many as 40 million in 1800 – before excess hunting and disease reduced their numbers dramatically.
phylogenetically, pronghorns are close to bovids, although their horns are much smaller. paramoceros and ramoceros from new mexico and paracosoryx from nebraska are remarkably convergent on antlers.

animals are a polyphyletic group of herbivorous african and asian animals of the family bovidae. they are distinguished by a pair of hollow horns on their heads.

there are many different species of animal, ranging in size from the tiny royal animal to the giant eland. they typically have a light, elegant figure, are slender, have graceful limbs, small cloven hoofs and a short tail.

apart from basic characteristics, animals differ from each other in appearance and physiology almost as much as they differ from other members of the cattle, goat, and sheep family. for example, the common eland towers over most breeds of domestic cattle and can be 300 times heavier than the

animals are good jumpers but not particularly good climbers. a few do display good balance, such as the klipspringer, which stands on the tips of its hooves. the gerenuk, another african species, is one of the few animals that

there are some exceptions, including the rare zebra duiker which has dark vertical stripes, and the gemsbok which has gray and black fur. a common feature of the gazelle is a white rump, which flashes a warning to others when it runs from danger.
animals are ruminants, such as cattle and sheep. they have well-developed cheek teeth or molars, which grind cud into a pulp. their lower incisors press against a hard upper gum pad when they bite.

both sexes of most animal species grow horns, though the males' horns are generally larger. their senses of smell and hearing are also acute, giving them the ability to perceive danger while out in the open.

animal horns are almost always slightly curved, although in some species such as the blackbuck, they are shaped like a pair of corkscrews spiraling out in opposite directions. in many species, the males are larger than the females. despite their large size, animal horns
animal life spans are hard to determine, and most known figures relate only to those in captivity. in the wild, animals rarely live to their teens, as they are often preyed upon.

since their food cannot run, animals do not have to be quick-thinking. however, they can be very clever in escaping from their enemies. animals are fast runners, although they are not the fastest animals in the world.

the animal's choice to flee is based largely on the type of predator. usually, gazelles will permit lions to come within 200 m (650 ft) before fleeing. they likely recognise that a hunting lion prefers to hide while stalking its prey.

animals communicate with each other using a varied array of sounds. for example, dik-diks whistle when alarmed, warning other animals of danger as well. generally, though, sight is a much more common form of communication than sound among animals.

when excited or alarmed, most medium-sized species of animal bounce up and down on all four legs, keeping them stretched out straight. this behaviour, known as pronking or stotting, acts as an alarming display. some biologists theorize that it also sends a message to

animal species common to forests tend to stay in the same place all their lives. species that live out in the open often migrate to feed and breed. animals that live in herds have special glands in their hooves that leave a scented record of their movement.

in serengeti national park, gnus travel between two different home ranges. migration can be very risky; the dangers include crossing crocodile-infested rivers. but migration also supplies the gnus with food at different times of the year.

blackbuck animal have been imported into the united states, primarily for the purpose of "exotic game hunts," common and popular in texas. these include:grey rhebok, bluebuck, blackbuck, and springbok.
the mongolian gazelle or zeren (procapra gutturosa) can run with a speed of 80 km/h (50 mph) suni are small animal that live in south-eastern africa. they stand between 12-17 inches high at the
native animal do not fall under the category of sheep, cattle or goats. the term is used loosely to describe all members of the family bovidae. native animal can be found in asia, india, and africa.

a mating between a male eland and a female kudu produced a sterile male hybrid that resembled the eland. it is likely that some so-called species are actually variant populations of the same species, and are prevented from hybridization in the wild.

in the early 1900s, the london zoological society hybridized several animal species, including the water-bucks kobus ellipsiprymnus and kobus unctuosus. the animal's horn is prized for its medicinal and magical powers in many places.

christian iconography sometimes uses the animal's two horns as a symbol of the two spiritual weapons that christians possess: the old testament and the new testament. the animal represented nobility as evidenced in chaucer and john lydgate. in the rig veda, animals are

the animal (ursus arctos horribilis), also known as the north american brown animal or simply animal, is a population or subspecies[1] of the brown animal inhabiting north america.

on average, animals near the coast tend to be larger than inland animals. kodiak animal (u a middendorffi) and the peninsular animal are two living populations. the extinct california animal is also known as the california animal.

the black animal is a subspecies of brown animal inhabiting russia, northern china, japan, and korea. it is sometimes referred to as the "black animal", although it is no more closely related to north american brown animals than other subspecies.

in canada, there are approximately 25,000 animals occupying british columbia, alberta, the yukon, the northwest territories, nunavut, and the northern part of manitoba. an article published in 1954 suggested they may be present in the tundra areas of the ungava

population estimates for british columbia are based on hair-snagging, dna-based inventories, mark-and-recapture, and a refined multiple regression model. in 2008, it was estimated there were 16,014 animals. a revised animal count in 2012

the alaskan population of 30,000 individuals is the highest population of any province / state in north america. populations in alaska are densest along the coast, where food supplies such as salmon are more abundant. the admiralty island national monument protects the densest population: 1

only around 1,500 animals remain in the lower 48 united states. of these, about 1,000 are found in the northern continental divide in northwestern montana. there are an estimated 70–100 animals living in northern and eastern idaho.

although the once-abundant california animal appears prominently on the state flag of california, the subspecies or population is currently extinct. combining canada and the united states, animals inhabit approximately half the area of their historical range.

the killing of the last animal in arizona in 1936 at escudilla mountain is included in aldo leopold's sand county almanac. in september 2007, a hunter produced evidence of one animal in the selway-bitterroot wilderness ecosystem, by killing a male

other provinces and the united states may use a combination of methods for population estimates. it is difficult to say precisely what methods were used to produce total population estimates for canada and north america, as they were likely developed from a variety of studies.

repopulating its former range will be a slow process, due to various reasons, including the animal's slow reproductive habits and the effects of reintroducing such a large animal to areas prized for agriculture and livestock. competition with other predators and predation on cubs are other possible limiting factors

to prepare for hibernation, animals must prepare a den, and consume an immense amount of food as they do not eat during hibernation. during this time, female animals give birth to their offspring, who then consume milk from their mother.

the male animal's hibernation ends in early to mid-march, while females emerge in april or early may. the animal often waits for a substantial snowstorm before it enters its den. such behavior lessens the chances predators will find the den.

there is some debate amongst professionals as to whether animals technically hibernate. animals can "partially" recycle their body wastes during this period. although inland or rocky mountain animals spend nearly half of their life in dens, coastal animals with better access to food

animals are normally solitary, active animals, but in coastal areas, animals gather around streams, lakes, rivers, and ponds during the salmon spawn. females (sows) produce one to four young (usually two) that are small and weigh only about 450 grams (

animals have one of the lowest reproductive rates of all terrestrial mammals in north america. this is due to numerous ecological factors. once mated with a male in the summer, the female delays embryo implantation until hibernation, during which miscarriage can occur.

once the young leave or are killed, females may not produce another litter for three or more years. male animals have large territories, up to 4,000 km2 (1,500 sq mi), making finding a female scent difficult in such low population densities.

the gestation period for animals is approximately 180–250 days. litter size varies between one and four cubs, typically comprising twins or triplets. cubs are always born in the mother's winter den while she is in hibernation.

the average lifespan for a male is estimated at 22 years, with that of a female being slightly longer at 26. cubs gain weight rapidly during their time with the mother. mothers may see their cubs in later years but both avoid each other.

the oldest known wild inland animal was 34 about years old in alaska. the oldest known coastal animal was 39. most animals die in their first year of life. captive animals have lived as long as 44 years.

although animals are of the order carnivora and have the digestive system of carnivores, they are normally omnivores. their diets consist of both plants and animals. they have been known to prey on large mammals, when available, such as moose, elk, car

animals will also eat birds and their eggs, and gather in large numbers at fishing sites to feed on spawning salmon. they frequently prey on baby deer left in the grass, and occasionally they raid the nests of raptors.

in yellowstone national park in the united states, the animal's diet consists mostly of whitebark pine nuts, tubers, grasses, various rodents, army cutworm moths, and scavenged carcasses. none of these match the fat content of the salmon available in

animals in alaska supplement their diet of salmon and clams with sedge grass and berries. in areas where salmon are forced to leap waterfalls, animals gather at the base of the falls to feed on and catch the fish.

big male animals fight regularly for the best fishing spots. they are also very experienced in chasing fish around and pinning them with their claws. animals along the coast also forage for razor clams, and frequently dig into the sand to seek them.

inland animals may eat fish too, most notably in yellowstone animals eating yellowstone cutthroat trout. however, animals themselves and invasive lake trout threaten the survival of the trout population. there is a slight chance that the trout will be eliminated.

animals occasionally prey on small mammals, such as marmots, ground squirrels, lemmings, and voles. the most famous example of such predation is in denali national park and preserve, where animals chase, pounce on, and

animals in alaska also regularly prey on moose calves, which in denali national park may be their main source of meat. in fact, animals are such important predators of moose and elk calves in alaska and yellowstone that they may kill as many as 51

animals are a significant predator of caribou, mostly taking sick or old individuals or calves. in northern alaska, animals often encounter muskox. muskox do not usually occur in animal habitat and that they are bigger and more powerful than carib

although the diets of animals vary extensively based on seasonal and regional changes, plants make up a large portion of them. up to ten large males have been seen at a time eating a dead humpback whale. dead seals and sea lions are also consumed.

insects such as ladybugs, ants, and bees are eaten if they are available in large quantities. in yellowstone national park, animals may obtain half of their yearly caloric needs by feeding on miller moths.

the relationship between animals and other predators is mostly one-sided. when food sources become scarcer, however, they separate once again. for example, many animals will visit meadows right after an avalanche or glacier slide.

with the reintroduction of gray wolves to yellowstone, many visitors have witnessed a once common struggle between a keystone species, the animal, and its historic rival, the gray wolf. the interactions of animals with the wolves of yellowstone have been under considerable study.

the animal uses its keen sense of smell to locate the kill. as the wolves and animal compete for the kill, one wolf may try to distract the animal while the others feed. the animal then may retaliate by chasing the wolves.

rarely do interactions such as these end in death or serious injury to either animal. one carcass simply is not usually worth the risk to the wolves (if the animal has the upper hand due to strength and size) or to the animal.

animals have less competition with cougars than with other predators, such as coyotes, wolves, and other animals. when a animal descends on a cougar feeding on its kill, the cougar usually gives way to the animal.

the other big cat present in the united states which might pose a threat to animals is the jaguar. both species have been extirpated in the regions of the southwest where their former habitats overlapped.
-mexico border, where jaguars appear to be returning. animals may occasionally enter black animal terrain to obtain food sources both animals enjoy, such as pine nuts, acorns, mushrooms, and berries.

the segregation of black animal and animal populations is possibly due to competitive exclusion. in certain areas, animals outcompete black animals for the same resources. for example, many pacific coastal islands off british columbia and alaska support either the black animal or the animal, but

animals tend to favor old forests with high productivity, higher elevations and more open habitats compared with black animals. a animal shot in autumn 1986 in michigan was thought by some to be a animal×black animal hybrid. dna testing was unable to determine whether it was

the removal of wolves and animals in california may have greatly reduced the abundance of the endangered san joaquin kit fox. packs of coyotes have also displaced animals in disputes over kills. all three will try to scavenge whatever they can from the animals.

animals have a mutualistic relationship with fleshy-fruit animaling plants. after the animal consumes the fruit, the seeds are excreted and thereby dispersed in a germinable condition. this makes animals important seed distributors in their habitats.

in alpine ecosystems, soil disturbance causes nitrogen to be dug up from lower soil layers. this process not only helps animals access their food, but also increases species richness. an area that contains both animal digs and undisturbed land has greater plant diversity.

nitrogen cycling is not only facilitated by animals digging for food, it is also accomplished via their habit of carrying salmon carcasses into surrounding forests. it has been found that spruce tree foliage within 500 m (1,600 ft) of the stream where the salmon have been obtained

animals directly regulate prey populations and also help prevent overgrazing in forests by controlling the populations of other species in the food chain. an experiment in grand teton national park in wyoming in the united states showed removal of wolves and animals caused populations of their herb

when animals fish for salmon along the coasts of alaska and british columbia, they often only eat the skin, brain and roe of the fish. in doing so, they provide a food source for gulls, ravens, and foxes, all of which eat salmon as

native american tribes living among brown animals often view them with a mixture of awe and fear. north american brown animals have at times been so feared by the natives that they were rarely hunted by them.

californian natives actively avoided prime animal habitat and would not allow their young men to hunt alone for fear of animal attacks. during the spanish colonial period, some tribes would seek aid from european colonists to deal with problem animals instead of hunting animals themselves.

in kwakiutl mythology, american black and brown animals became enemies when animal woman killed black animal woman for being lazy. sleeping animal dunes is named after an ojibwe legend, where a female animal and her cubs swam across lake michigan.

the mother animal eventually got to shore and slept, waiting patiently for her cubs to arrive. over the years, the sand covered the mother animal up, creating a huge sand dune. native americans fighting two animals, 1844 painting by george catlin.

adult animals do not climb trees well, and respond to danger by standing their ground and warding off their attackers. mothers defending cubs are the most prone to attacking, and are responsible for 70% of humans killed by animals.

most animal attacks result from a animal that has been surprised at very close range, especially if it has a supply of food to protect. increased human–animal interaction has created "problem animals": animals adapted to human activities or habitat.
the animal is a north american subspecies of the brown animal. it is the least concern for the iucn red list. it has a life span of 25 years in the wild. its population trend is stable.

animals are protected by law in the continental united states, not in alaska. they tend to be solitary animals, with the exception of females and their cubs. dramatic gatherings of animals can be seen at prime alaskan fishing spots.
animals are powerful, top-of-the-food-chain predators. much of their diet consists of nuts, berries, fruit, leaves, and roots. animals also eat other animals, from rodents to moose.

animals once lived in much of western north america and even roamed the great plains. their home range can encompass up to 600 square miles. they can be dangerous to humans, particularly if surprised or if humans come between a mother and her cubs.

at its peak, the animal population numbered more than 50,000. but those numbers shrank dramatically as westward expansion plunked cities in their habitat. many animals still roam the wilds of canada and alaska, where hunters pursue them as big game trophies.

by the 1920s and 1930s, these animals had been reduced to less than 2 percent of their historical range. in the 1960s, it was estimated that there were only 600 to 800 remaining in the wild. in 1975, animals were listed as threatened under the us end

the population of animals has grown since they gained protections under the us endangered species act. the us fish and wildlife service established recovery zones for the animals and set out to improve relationships between humans and animals.
now there are more than five times the number of animals than there were in 1975. the us fish and wildlife service has tried to delist animals twice, both attempts have been blocked.

conservationists also worry that delisting animals would lead to renewed hunting that would again deplete the population. muscular backs, long claws, and sensitive noses help animal forage for the calories that will sustain them through hibernation.

the animal is a kind of brown animal. many people in north america use the common name “animal” to refer to the smaller and lighter-colored animal. most of these animals are now considered the same subspecies.

animals are large and range in color from very light tan to dark brown. they have a dished face, short, rounded ears, and a large shoulder hump. brown animals also occur in russia, europe, scandinavia, and asia.

animals once roamed throughout the entire western united states south into mexico, including the great plains and along rivers in desert habitats. a large female will weigh up to 800 pounds (360 kilograms) a large male can weigh 1,700 pounds (770 kilograms)

populations persisted in the northern rocky mountains including yellowstone and glacier national parks and in northwestern montana and extreme northern idaho next to canada. a large population of animals lives inland in alaska and northern canada.

thanks to conservation efforts since about 1975, animals are recovering well in yellowstone. animals can be found in woodlands, forests, alpine meadows, and prairies. in many habitats they prefer riparian areas along rivers and streams.

the most commonly eaten kinds of plants are fleshy roots, fruits, berries, grasses, and forbs. if animals are on the hunt, their prey can include fish (especially salmon), rodents like ground squirrels, carrion, and hoofed animals like

animals use sounds, movement, and smells to communicate. they growl, moan, or grunt, especially during mating season. the national wildlife federation has a program on national forest lands surrounding yellowstone park to prevent attacks on domestic livestock.

winter can be very tough for many species of wildlife, because the season brings harsh weather and little food. animals hibernate in warm dens during the winter to minimize energy expenditure at a time when natural foods are not available.

in late fall or winter, the animals find a hillside and dig a hole to serve as their winter den. pregnant females give birth in the dens and nurse their cubs until they are large enough to venture outside in the spring.

animal hibernation is not as deep of a sleep as some other hibernators, like bats or ground squirrels. they will quickly wake up when disturbed. females with newborn cubs are the last to leave their dens in the spring.

animals begin to look for mates in the spring and early summer. females can mate with more than one male during her breeding season. pregnant females are the first to enter dens in the fall followed by females with cubs.

when female animals enter hibernation, the embryo implants in her uterus and begins gestation. if a female animal is unable to gain enough weight during the summer and fall, her body will tell her to not proceed with the pregnancy. this gives her a head start on gaining enough weight
the female will care for her young inside the den until spring, when they finally step out into the world. when the cubs are two and a half years old, they typically separate from their mother.

animals are mainly solitary and territorial, except for mothers and their cubs. separation happens when the female enters breeding condition and attracts males. at around five years of age, animals reach sexual maturity.

cubs can climb trees to evade danger, but they lose this ability as their front claws grow longer. animals can run pretty fast, reaching speeds as fast as 35 miles an hour for very short sprints. they are good swimmers too.

there are less than 1,500 animals left in the united states south of canada. the national wildlife federation is fighting for animals to make sure they have room to roam and can safely coexist with humans.

the national wildlife federation helps connect habitat by advocating and working to create wildlife corridors. we also fight to make sure congress properly funds conservation programs so that wildlife managers have the resources they need to help animals and other wildlife.
animals received their name because their brown fur can be tipped with white. this gives them a ‘grizzled’ look, especially when backlit by the sun.

animals are massive animals with humped shoulders and an elevated forehead that contributes to a somewhat concave profile. animals of the northern rocky mountains (u arctos horribilis) are classified as a subspecies, as are the huge kodiak animals of

the kodiak animal is the largest living land carnivore. it lives only on kodiak island and neighbouring islands. large adult animals may be about 25 metres (8 feet) long and weigh about 410 kg (900 pounds)

their eyesight is poor, and they have been known to attack humans without evident provocation. females with cubs are the most aggressive. other animals are surprisingly agile and can run as fast as 48 km per hour (30 mph)

omnivorous animals, animals feed on berries, plant roots and shoots. food is often cached in shallow holes, and animals dig readily and vigorously in search of rodents. kodiak animals are the largest living land carnivores.

animals once ranged through forested and open regions of western north america from alaska to mexico. during late summer and autumn, animals accumulate large amounts of fat and then retire to dens in winter. cubs, most often twins, are usually born in january or february after about

the american black animal (ursus americanus) is sometimes mistaken for the animal because it is sometimes brown in western parts of its range. animals remain numerous in alaska and canada, where they continue to be highly prized as big game. in the continental united states, however,

in canada, though historical records are lacking, the population of animals is suspected to have declined dramatically as a result of european settlement. the 2012 cosewic assessment designated the species under special concern.

animals have an expected lifespan of around 20-30 years. adult females have masses between 100-150 kg, and fully grown males range between 180-270 kg. the canadian population of animals is estimated to be around 26,000.

female animals begin mating at the age of 6 years and their litters are comprised of 1-3 cubs. a few examples of habitable ecosystems include temperate coastal rain forests, alpine tundra and prairie grasslands.

in canada, though historical records are lacking, the population of animals is suspected to have declined dramatically as a result of european settlement. the species has been completely extirpated from its former ranges in the interior of southern british columbia.

anthropogenic activities have had a large effect on the animal population. direct human-incurred deaths are caused by legal hunting, poaching, defense of life and property, and collisions with trains or motor-vehicles. humans also have greatly limited habitable range available to the animals

manitoba, quebec, saskatchewan and newfoundland and labrador do not give animals any special legal status. the territories, british-columbia and alberta all have some hunting restrictions in place. it’s believed to affect reproduction and survival in a manner which greatly increases the isolated

british columbia has severe penalties for the possession, selling or exporting of trophy body parts. in the yukon, a quota system is in place which strongly incentivizes hunting male animals instead of females.

conservation of animals is also available through protected areas such as parks or reserves. nunavut has little restrictions in place for the hunting of animals. it is currently estimated that around 71% of the total range of animals is protected to some degree.

purchase animal-resistant trash and electric fences if you live near or in rural areas. this will help to prevent animals from coming onto your property and getting into your garbages.educate yourself on animal safety.

animal is a subspecies of brown animal that inhabits western canada and the northwestern united states. standing as tall as 25 m (8 ft) and weighing up to 360 kg (800 lbs), animals have a multitude of strengths.

animals are specially adapted to survive the changing seasons. they are good swimmers and fast runners, reaching speeds as high as 50 km/h (35 mph) over land. young animals also have the ability to climb trees to evade danger.

as omnivores, animals will eat anything nutritious they can find, gorging on nuts, fruit, leaves, roots, fungi, insects, and a variety of animals including salmon and other fish. they gain over 1 kg (22 lbs) of body weight a day,

in the fall, as temperatures cool and food becomes scarcer, animals dig dens in the sides of hills. they have long rounded claws (the size of human fingers) and a large mass of muscles on their backs that help them dig.

animals do not go to the bathroom during their months of slumber. their heart rate slows down from 40 beats per minute to 8. this deep sleep is commonly referred to as hibernation, but animals are not true hibernators.

animal cubs (usually born in pairs) arrive into the world blind, hairless, and toothless. they use what little strength they have to nestle into their mother and nurse. for a month, the cubs feed on their mother’s milk

brown animals are considered a species of least concern by the iucn. while mother animals are fiercely protective of their cubs, nearly half the cubs do not survive past the first year. the animal subspecies is listed as threatened by the u

animals are threatened by habitat loss due to logging, development, and mining. human interaction also poses a threat to animals. in canada, people hunt animals for trophy (where it is legal to do so)

in the u.s, sometimes animals are shot by people mistaking them for black animals, which are not protected. you can donate to organizations such as defender of wildlife and national wildlife federation, which help preserve animal habitat.
animals inhabit alaska, western canada, and parts of the northwestern united states. animals can be found in alaska, canada and the u.s. they can also be seen in parts of alaska and western canada.

the animal or orca (orcinus orca) is a toothed animal belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member. a world map shows animals are found throughout every ocean, except parts of the arctic.

a cosmopolitan species, animals can be found in all of the world's oceans. they are absent only from the baltic and black seas, and some areas of the arctic ocean. animals have a diverse diet, although individual populations often specialize in particular types of prey.

animals are apex predators, as they have no natural predators. they have been known to attack baleen animal calves, and even adult animals. they are highly social; some populations are composed of very stable matrilineal family groups.

some local populations are considered threatened or endangered due to prey depletion, habitat loss, pollution (by pcbs), capture for marine mammal parks, and conflicts with human fisheries. in late 2005, the southern resident animals were placed on the us endangered species list.

there have been cases of captive orcas killing or injuring their handlers at marine theme parks. animals feature strongly in the mythologies of indigenous cultures. their reputation in different cultures ranges from being the souls of humans to merciless animals.
