although the term "orca" is increasingly used, english-speaking scientists most often use the traditional name "animal" the genus name orcinus means "of the kingdom of the dead" or "belonging to orcus"

since the 1960s, "orca" has steadily grown in common use. the species is more closely related to other oceanic dolphins than to other animals. they are sometimes referred to as "blackfish", a name also used for other animal species.
orcinus orca is the only recognized extant species in the genus orcinus. it is one of many animal species originally described by carl linnaeus in his landmark 1758 10th edition of systema naturae.

the animal is one of 35 species in the oceanic dolphin family, which first appeared about 11 million years ago. although it has morphological similarities with the false animal, the pygmy animal and the pilot animals, its closest extant relatives are the snubfin dolphins

the three to five types of animals may be distinct enough to be considered different races, subspecies, or possibly even species. in contrast, a 2019 phylogenetic study found the orca to be the second most basal member of the delphinidae.

orca will be split into a number of different species or at least subspecies over the next few years. research off the west coast of canada and the united states in the 1970s and 1980s identified the following three types.

british columbia and washington resident populations are amongst the most intensively studied marine mammals anywhere in the world. researchers have identified and named over 300 animals over the past 30 years. female residents characteristically have rounded dorsal fin tips that terminate in a sharp corner.

transients generally travel in small groups, usually of two to six animals. female transients are characterized by more triangular and pointed dorsal fins than those of residents. the grey or white area around the dorsal fin, known as the "saddle patch", often contains some black colouring in

transients roam widely along the coast; some individuals have been sighted in both southern alaska and california. transients are also referred to as bigg's animal in honour of cetologist michael bigg. third population of animals in northeast pacific discovered in 1988.

they have mostly been encountered off the west coast of vancouver island and near haida gwaii offshores. they typically congregate in groups of 20–75, with occasional sightings of larger groups of up to 200.

offshores appear to be smaller than the others, and females are characterized by dorsal fin tips that are continuously rounded. animal mother and calf extend their bodies above the water surface, from pectoral fins forward, with ice pack in background.

other populations have not been as well studied, although specialized fish and mammal eating animals have been distinguished elsewhere. as with residents and transients, the lifestyle of these animals appears to reflect their diet. fish-eating animals in alaska and norway have resident-like social structures, while

type a looks like a "typical" animal, a large, black-and-white form with a medium-sized white eye patch, living in open water and feeding mostly on minke animals. two dwarf species were described during the 1980s by soviet researchers, but most

it has a large white eye patch. most of the dark parts of its body are medium grey instead of black. it has a dark grey patch called a "dorsal cape" stretching back from its forehead to just behind its dorsal fin.

type d was identified based on photographs of a 1955 mass stranding in new zealand and six at-sea sightings since 2004. like type b, it is primarily white and medium grey, with a dark grey dorsal cape and yellow-tinged patches. its only observed prey is the antarctic

it is recognizable by its small white eye patch, narrower and shorter than usual dorsal fin, bulbous head (similar to a pilot animal), and smaller teeth. its geographic range appears to be circumglobal in sub-antarctic waters between latitudes 40°s and 60°s

mitochondrial dna sequences support the theory that these are recently diverged separate species. more recently, complete mitochondrial sequencing indicates the two antarctic groups that eat seals and fish should be recognized as distinct species.

there are seven identified ecotypes inhabiting isolated ecological niches. of three orca ecotypes in the antarctic, one preys on minke animals, the second on seals and penguins, and the third on fish. mammal-eating animals in different regions were long thought

the first split in the orca population occurred an estimated 700,000 years ago. research has supported a proposal to reclassify the antarctic seal- and fish-eating populations and the north pacific transients as a distinct species. such a designation would mean that each new species becomes subject

males typically range from 6 to 8 metres (20 to 26 ft) long and weigh in excess of 6 tonnes. females are smaller, generally ranging from 5 to 7 m (16 to 23 ft) and weighing about 3 to 4 tonnes (30 to 3 tonnes)

the skeleton of the animal is of the typical delphinid structure, but more robust. its integument is characterized by a well-developed dermal layer with a dense network of fascicles of collagen fibres. calves at birth weigh about 180 kg (400 lb)

the white colouration stretches through the entire lower jaw and narrows between the flippers. just in front of this region, the white area extends into lateral flank patches. the tail fluke is also white on the underside while the eyes have white patches behind them.

being the most distinctively pigmented cetacean, adult animals are seldom confused with any other species. juveniles can be confused with false animals or risso's dolphins. both albino and melanistic orcas have been documented.

adult males have longer lower jaws than females, as well as larger occipital crests. dorsal fins also exhibit sexual dimorphism, with males about 18 m (59 ft) high, more than twice the size of the female's.

the animal's teeth are very strong, and its jaws exert a powerful grip. the firm middle and back teeth hold prey in place. the front teeth are inclined slightly forward and outward to protect them from powerful jerking movements.

orcas have exceptionally sophisticated echolocation abilities. they detect the location and characteristics of prey and other objects in the water by emitting clicks and listening for echoes. the mean body temperature of the orca is 36 to 38 °c (97 to 100 °f)

an individual animal can often be identified from its dorsal fin and saddle patch. variations such as nicks, scratches, and tears on the dorsal fin are unique. the pulse is about 60 heartbeats per minute when the orca is at the surface.

photographic identification has enabled the local population of animals to be counted each year rather than estimated. it has enabled great insight into life cycles and social structures. animals are one of the most endangered marine mammals in the world.

due to their enormous range, numbers, and density, relative distribution is difficult to estimate. animals prefer higher latitudes and coastal areas over pelagic environments. areas which serve as major study sites for the species include the coasts of iceland, norway, the valdes peninsula of argentina,

40 individuals per 100 km2) in the northeast atlantic around the norwegian coast, in the north pacific along the aleutian islands, the gulf of alaska and in the southern ocean off much of the coast of antarctica. they are considered "common" (020–040 individuals per

they are reported as seasonally common in the canadian arctic, including baffin bay between greenland and nunavut. regularly occurring or distinct populations exist off northwest europe, california, patagonia, the crozet islands, marion island, southern australia and new zealand. the

over 50 individual animals have been documented in the northern indian ocean. they have been sighted, though more infrequently, in the mediterranean, the arabian sea, the gulf of mexico, banderas bay on mexico's west coast and the caribbean.

the modern status of the species along coastal mainland china and its vicinity is unknown. a wide-ranging population is likely to exist in the central pacific. distinct populations may also exist off the west coast of tropical africa.

a small year-round population is known to exist in the strait of gibraltar, mostly on the atlantic side. animals also appear to regularly occur off the galápagos islands. in the antarctic, animals are believed to venture into the denser pack ice.

with the rapid arctic sea ice decline in the hudson strait, their range now extends deep into the northwest atlantic. occasionally, animals swim into freshwater rivers. they have been documented 100 mi (160 km) up the columbia river in the united states.

worldwide population estimates are uncertain, but recent consensus suggests a minimum of 50,000 (2006) each summer, the same individuals appear off the coasts of british columbia and washington. transient pods have been sighted from southern alaska to central california.

japan's fisheries agency estimated in the 2000s that 2,321 animals were in the seas around japan. four dorsal fins are visible, three of which curve backward at the tip. resident (fish-eating) animals are typical of resident females.

animals hunt varied prey including fish, cephalopods, mammals, seabirds, and sea turtles. they are sometimes called "wolves of the sea", because they hunt in groups like wolf packs. different populations or ecotypes may specialize, and some can have a

some populations in the norwegian and greenland sea specialize in herring and follow that fish's autumnal migration to the norwegian coast. salmon account for 96% of northeast pacific residents' diet, including 65% of large, fatty chinook.

on average, a animal eats 227 kilograms (500 lb) each day. while salmon are usually hunted by an individual animal or a small group, herring are often caught using carousel feeding. animals force the herring into a tight ball by releasing bursts of bubbles or flashing

carousel feeding has only been documented in the norwegian animal population, as well as some oceanic dolphin species. with sharks, orcas may herd them to the surface and strike them with their tail flukes. bottom-dwelling rays are cornered, pinned to the ground

competition between animals and white sharks is probable in regions where their diets overlap. the arrival of orcas in an area can cause white sharks to flee and forage elsewhere. orcas appear to target the liver of sharks.

in cases where blue animals are attacked, as many as 50 animals will join the hunt to successfully kill the larger animal. groups even attack larger cetaceans such as minke animals, grey animals and, rarely, sperm animals or blue animals.

animals generally attack young or weak animals. when hunting a young animal, a group chases it and its mother to exhaustion. eventually, they separate the pair and surround the calf, drowning it by keeping it from surfacing.

rarely, large animal pods can overwhelm even adult female sperm animals. adult bull sperm animals, which are large, powerful and aggressive when threatened, and fully grown adult blue animals are not believed to be prey for animals.

devastation of great animal populations by unfettered whaling has possibly reduced their availability for animals. animals have expanded their consumption of smaller marine mammals, thus contributing to the decline of these as well.

other marine mammal prey species include nearly 20 species of seal, sea lion and fur seal. walruses and sea otters are less frequently taken. often, to avoid injury, animals disable their prey before killing and eating it.

in steeply banked beaches off península valdés, argentina, and the crozet islands, animals feed on south american sea lions and southern elephant seals. animals even beaching temporarily to grab prey before wriggling back to the sea.

animals can then release the animal near juvenile animals, allowing the younger animals to practice the difficult capture technique on the now-weakened prey. animals "spy-hop" to locate weddell seals, crabeater seals, leopard seals, and pengu

animals have also been observed preying on terrestrial mammals, such as deer swimming between islands off the northwest coast of north america. animal cannibalism has also been reported based on analysis of stomach contents, but this is likely to be the result of scavenging remains dumped by wh

resident animals have never been observed to eat other marine mammals. animals in many areas may prey on cormorants and gulls. a captive animal at marineland of canada discovered it could regurgitate fish onto the surface, attracting sea gulls, and then eat

day-to-day animal behaviour generally consists of foraging, travelling, resting and socializing. animals frequently engage in surface behaviour such as breaching (jumping completely out of the water) and tail-slapping.

animals are notable for their complex societies. only elephants and higher primates live in comparably complex social structures. due to orcas' complex social bonds, many marine experts have concerns about how humane it is to keep them in captivity.

resident animals live with their mothers for their entire lives. these family groups are based on matrilines consisting of the eldest female (matriarch) and her sons and daughters. the average size of a matriline is 55 animals.

matrilineal groups are highly stable individuals separate for only a few hours at a time, to mate or forage. with one exception, a animal named luna, no permanent separation of an individual from a resident matriline has been recorded.

dna testing indicates resident males nearly always mate with females from other pods. clans, the next level of resident social structure, are composed of pods with similar dialects, and common but older maternal heritage.
clan range: alaska, new england/mid-atlantic, pacific islands, southeast, west coast. animals can weigh up to 11 tons and reach 32 feet. clan range: 30 to 90 years.

the animal, also known as orca, is the ocean’s top predator it is the largest member of the delphinidae family, or dolphins. members of this family include all dolphin species, as well as other larger species.

they are one of the most recognizable marine mammals, with their distinctive black and white bodies. animals occur in a wide range of habitats, in both open seas and coastal waters. scientific studies have revealed many different populations with several distinct ecotypes.

historic threats to animals included commercial hunting and culling to protect fisheries. live capture of animals for aquarium display and marine parks no longer occurs in the united states. but it continues to remain a threat globally.

all animal populations are protected under the marine mammal protection act. only two populations receive additional special protections under federal law. efforts to establish critical habitat, set protective regulations, and restore prey stocks are essential to conservation.

noaa fisheries is committed to the conservation of animals. the southern resident animal is one of noaa fisheries' species in the spotlight initiative. this initiative includes animals considered most at risk for extinction and prioritizes recovery efforts.

several different populations and ecotypes of animals are found throughout the world. it is estimated that there are around 50,000 animals globally. approximately 2,500 animals live in the eastern north pacific ocean.

the population of at1 transients, a stock of transient animals in the eastern north pacific, has been reduced from 22 to 7 animals since the 1989 exxon valdez oil spill. noaa fisheries designated this stock as depleted under the mmpa in 2004.

following live-capture in the 1960s for use in marine mammal parks, 71 animals remained in 1974. there was some growth in the population in the 1970s and 1980s, with a peak of 98 animals in 1995. the population experienced a decline of almost 20 percent in the

in 2003, noaa fisheries began a research and conservation program with congressional funding to address the dwindling population. southern residents were listed as endangered in 2005 under the esa and a recovery plan was completed in 2008. animals are mostly black on top with white patches near the eyes.
animals are highly social, and most live in social groups called pods. adult males develop disproportionately larger pectoral flippers, dorsal fins, tail flukes, and girths than females.

animals rely on underwater sound to feed, communicate, and navigate. pod members communicate with each other through clicks, whistles, and pulsed calls. each pod in the eastern north pacific possesses a unique set of calls.

although the diet of animals depends to some extent on what is available where they live, it is primarily determined by the culture (ie, learned hunting tactics) of each ecotype. for example, one ecotype of animal in the us pacific northwest (called residents) exclusively eats

animals are most abundant in colder waters like antarctica, norway, and alaska. they are also found in tropical and subtropical waters. the most well-studied animal populations occur in the eastern north pacific ocean.

offshore animals have the largest range of any community, and often occur more than 9 miles offshore. transient animals also occur throughout the eastern north pacific, and are often seen in coastal waters.

average lifespan for male animals is about 30 years. females typically live about 50 years, but can live up to at least 90 years in the wild. female animals reach sexual maturity when they are between 10 and 13 years old.

calves nurse exclusively for at least a year, but remain in close association with their mother for the first two years. there is no distinct calving season, so birth can take place in any month. the birth rate for animals is not well understood.

animals are at high risk of becoming entangled in fishing gear. once entangled, animals may drag and swim with attached gear for long distances. events such as these result in fatigue, compromised feeding ability, or severe injury, which may ultimately lead to death.

without enough prey, animals might experience decreased reproductive rates and increased mortality rates. this threat is especially important for southern resident animals because some populations of their preferred prey, chinook salmon, are also threatened or endangered.

despite modern pollution controls, chemical contamination through the food web continues to threaten animals. these contaminants can harm animals’ immune and reproductive systems. some of these contaminants persist in the marine environment for decades and continue to threaten marine life.

oil spills can also have an indirect impact on animals by affecting the abundance of prey species. the bioaccumulation of certain contaminants, like those found in oil, in the food web can be seen in apex predators like animals.

noise interference from vessels interrupts animals’ ability to use sound, which in turn disturbs their feeding, communication, and orientation. increased vessel noise causes southern resident animals to call louder, expending more energy in the process.
orcas, or animals, are the largest of the dolphins and one of the world's most powerful predators. orcas live between 50 and 80 years in the wild, with a life span of 50 to 80 years.

orcas use echolocation to communicate and hunt. they travel underwater until they encounter objects, then bounce back, revealing their location, size, and shape. each pod has distinctive noises that its members will recognize even at a distance.

they're at the top of the food chain and have very diverse diets, feasting on fish, penguins, and marine mammals such as seals, sea lions, and even animals. they are known to grab seals right off the ice.

there appear to be both resident and transient pod populations of orcas. resident pods tend to prefer fish, while transient pods target marine mammals. all pods use effective, cooperative hunting techniques that some liken to the behavior of wolf packs.

mothers give birth every three to ten years, after a 17-month pregnancy. they give birth to one baby at a time, which may nurse for up to two years. in some pods, the juvenile may stay with the pod it was born into its entire life.

they have evolved to swim up to 40 miles a day, foraging for food and exercising. however, it's become increasingly clear that orcas do not thrive in captivity. whether they're born in the wild or in captivity, all orcas born have the same innate drive.

orcas have been seen to develop stereotypies, also known as zoochosis. usually related to stress and inappropriate habitats, stereotypic behavior has been documented in orcas in scientific research since the late 1980s.

captive-born orcas are often transferred between facilities, breaking up social relationships. the stress of social disruption is compounded by the fact that orcas in captivity don’t have the ability to escape conflict with other orcas.

national geographic travels to prince william sound in alaska to meet with researchers who are studying the lingering effects of the catastrophic exxon valdez oil spill on the local orca population. watch the video to find out what researchers are looking for.
animals, also known as orcas, are an iconic species, long revered by various aboriginal cultures. the species has recently made even more famous by films like ‘blackfish’ and ‘free willy’

animals are highly distinctive and easily recognisable. there are at least eight different recognised forms differing in external colouring and appearance, feeding habits and ecology. two unnamed subspecies are recognized off the west coast of north america – mammal-eating ‘transient’ and fish

animals are found all over the world. although they are more densely concentrated in colder regions where their large prey species are more abundant, they appear to roam temperate and tropical areas as well. animals are native to the following countries and territories: algeria, angola, angu

‘resident’ animals off the coast of british columbia, canada, feed on fish – predominantly salmon. these are some of the best-studied animals in the world, as they have a restricted and predictable home range. but their dependence on salmon stocks, which

they feed predominantly on marine mammals, including dolphins, seals, and animals. animals off the coast of norway feed on herring and other fish. those in patagonia (argentina) are known to beach themselves in the process of taking sea lion pups.

animals live in tightly bonded family groups. females typically give birth to their first calf at 12-14 years, and have one of the longest gestation periods known for animals and dolphins at 15-18 months. calves usually nurse for up to one year, and begin to supplement

females give birth to an average of 5 calves over a period of 25 years. they then enter into a period where they no longer have calves, but play an important role in the family group – “babysitting” the calves of other females.

one of the most important tools for studying animals is photo-identification. nearly every individual animal is recognizable by the scarring and shapes of their dorsal fins. animal groups also have distinct ‘languages’, and even groups with overlapping ranges.

although animals, with their bulk and strength appear to be less susceptible to bycatch in fisheries gear than other species of animals and dolphins, fishermen often perceive them as a threat. animals have no known natural predators except possibly other animals.

animals were actively hunted in a norway, japan, the soviet union and the antarctic through until the 1980’s. animals are now only taken in small numbers for food (or as a population control measure) in coastal fisheries in japan, greenland, indonesia, and the

the eight currently recognized forms17 range so widely over so many different habitats that their population status is difficult to assess. in 2006, it was estimated that the worldwide poulation of animals was at least 50,0002.

eastern north atlantic as well as the eastern north pacific populations are included in appendix ii of cms. the eastern north atlantic is part of the eastern north pacific, which is also included in cms.

the animal is easy to identify by its size and its striking coloration. despite the fact that this cetacean is a powerful carnivore, there is no record of its having killed humans in the wild.
the largest males attain a length of more than 10 metres (328 feet) and a weight of about 9,800 kg (about 10 metric tons or 11 short [us] tons), whereas females reach about 8.

males have proportionally larger appendages, with flippers up to 2 metres (66 feet) long. flipper length among females is 11–13 percent of body length. the dorsal fin of older males is very tall (up to 1.8 feet)

the skull is a metre or more in length and holds the largest brain of all the dolphins, averaging 56 kg (123 pounds) the muscles that close the mouth are enormous, and within the jaws is a set of more than 40 interlocking curved teeth. females and young males have a

the circumstances under which menopause evolved in animals are a matter of debate. it may have emerged in response to increases in the mortality of offspring from older generations during times when mothers and daughters bred simultaneously. some scientists argue that younger females in the pod tend to focus on the success

the older females, tending to focus on the success of the overall pod, may be more willing to share food with the rest of the pod. this could reduce the amount of food that could be given to their own offspring.

this small mammal was about 4 metres long (131 feet) and had 14 teeth—more like a typical dolphin. this implies that the ancestors of the present-day animal diverged from other cetaceans during the miocene epoch.

although the taxonomy of the animal is clear at the genus level and at the family level (delphinidae), relationships between animals and other toothed animals are ambiguous. the false animal (pseudorca crassidens), pygmy animal

evidence suggests that o orca is in the process of diverging into two species in the north atlantic. animals were formerly referred to as grampuses, but that term is now a synonym for risso’s dolphin.

one population, characterized by relatively small individuals with a maximum length of 66 metres (217 feet) and significant tooth wear, preys on fish, seals, and other animals. the other population is thought to feed solely on animals and other dolphins.

mammal-eating populations inhabiting the gulf of alaska, the eastern aleutian islands, and the eastern bering sea. animals located along the west coast of north america between the queen charlotte islands and california.

three populations of animals, known as the southern residents, transients, and offshores, regularly occur in washington. the southern residents are listed as federal endangered species, but all three populations are state endangered species.

high levels of chemical contaminants, noise and disturbance from vessels and other human activities, as well as large oil spills all have the potential to negatively impact the health and status of all three populations. marine mammals are protected under the marine mammal protection act.

animals are the largest member of the oceanic dolphin family. species may weigh up to 11 tons and length may be up to 32 feet. they are mostly black with white eyebrow patch, and white underside extending from throat to tail.

all animals become sexually mature at about 12 to 16 years of age. the southern resident population feeds primarily on chinook salmon, chum salmon to a lesser extent, and occasionally other fish. transient animals feed on seals and other marine mammals. offshore animals primarily feed on sharks

animals are distributed nearly worldwide. in washington, they occur in most of the state's marine waters. the estimated maximum lifespan is 80 to 90 years for females and 50 to 60 years in males. the calving interval is about three to eight years.

the southern resident population has shown an overall declining trend since 1995, falling from 98 animals to 81 animals as of july 2015 they are the population of greatest concern. only small portions of both transient and offshore populations normally occur in washington at any one time.

transient animals are part of a single population ranging from southeastern alaska to california. while numbers have been relatively stable since 2001, they remain 17 percent below their recent peak size recorded in 1995. the west coast transient population has shown considerable growth since the 1970s.

climate change will likely impact all three ecotypes of animals (southern residents, transients, offshores) in washington. offshore animals are estimated at 300 individuals and have a stable population trend.

rising sea level may submerge or render unsuitable some traditional pinniped rookeries and haulouts. changes in marine food webs, alterations in freshwater habitats occupied by salmon (for southern residents), and rising sea level could affect salmon.

southern resident animals are specialists on chinook salmon, which are themselves vulnerable to climate change. this species is identified as a species of greatest conservation need (sgcn) under the state wildlife action plan (swap)

the wdfw swap is part of a nationwide effort by all 50 states and five us territories to develop conservation action plans for fish, wildlife and their natural habitats. the swap identifies opportunities for species' recovery before they are imperiled and more limited.

all three populations of animal occurring in washington carry heavy loads of environmental contaminants. the phs program is the agency's main means of sharing fish and wildlife information with local governments, landowners, and others.

threat: depleted populations of chinook salmon reduce prey availability for the southern residents. action needed: rebuild depleted populations through multiple restoration activities, including management of habitat, harvest, hydropower, and hatcheries.

threat: high levels of chemical contaminants continue to exist in southern resident animals and may be causing health impacts.action needed: minimize pollution levels in aquatic habitats. large oil spills could harm animal populations through negative impacts to health.

various management activities have been taken since 2004 that directly or indirectly benefit animals in washington. these include the preparation of conservation plans and enforcement of animal-watching regulations. however, expanded actions will very likely be needed to achieve recovery of the southern residents.

for other uses, see animal (disambiguation) animal is a word used to refer to a species of animal. animal is also the name of a genus and a species in the scientific community.

animals are large, semiaquatic rodents in the genus castor native to the temperate northern hemisphere. they are native to europe and patagonia, but missing populations in mongolia and northwestern china.

animals are the second-largest living rodents after the capybaras. they have stout bodies with large heads, long chisel-like incisors, brown or gray fur, hand-like front feet, webbed back feet and flat, scaly tails.

animals build dams and lodges using tree branches, vegetation, rocks and mud; they chew down trees for building material. their infrastructure creates wetlands used by many other species, and because of their effect on other organisms, they are considered a keystone species.

animals hold territories and mark them using scent mounts made of mud, debris and castoreum, a urine-based substance excreted through the animal's castor sacs animals can also recognize their kin by their anal gland secretions.
castoreum has been used in medicine, perfume and food flavoring. animal pelts have been a major driver of the fur trade. both species are listed as least concern by the iucn red list of mammals.

etymology, taxonomy, evolution, and evolution are listed in a list of words used in the english language. the list includes words such as "etymology," "taxonomy," "evolution," and "characteristics and adaptations"

the name "animal" is the source for several names of places in europe. the ultimate origin of the word is from an indo-european root for "brown" the genus name castor has its origin in the greek kastor.

carl linnaeus coined the genus castor in 1758;[5] he also coined the specific (species) epithet fiber. the eurasian animal has a more elongated skull with a more triangular nasal bone opening, lighter fur color and a narrower tail.

the eurasian has 48 chromosomes, versus the north american's 40. the difference in chromosome numbers prevents them from interbreeding. 25 subspecies have been classified for c. they were not shown conclusively to be separate species until chromosome evidence became available in the 1970s.
castorinae (modern animals) die gartenlaube (1858) b 068 white backgroundjpg. image taken from page 108 of 'report of an expedition down the zuni and colorado rivers by captain l. fiber.

animals belong to the rodent suborder castorimorpha, along with heteromyidae (kangaroo rats, kangaroo mice, pocket mice and spiny pocket mice), and the gophers. modern animals are the only extant members of the family castor

basal castorids had features such as: more complex occlusion between the cheek teeth, parallel upper tooth rows, premolars close to the molars in size, the presence of a third set of premolars (p3), and an elongated snout.
in the early miocene (about 24 mya), castorids evolved a semiaquatic lifestyle. members of the subfamily palaeocastorinae appeared in late oligocene north america.
castoroides is estimated to have had a length of 19–22 m (62–72 ft) and a weight of 90–125 kg (198–276 lb) fossils of one genus in castoroidinae, dipoides, have been found near assembl

the genus castor likely originated in eurasia. dam and lodge-building likely developed from bark eating and allowed animals to survive in the harsh winters of arctic latitudes. there is no conclusive evidence for this behavior occurring in non-castor species.

mitochondrial dna studies place the common ancestor of the two living species at around 8 mya. castor may have competed with members of castoroidinae, which led to niche differentiation. the eurasian animal may have descended from c praefiber.

they have a head-body length of 80–120 cm (31–47 in), with a 25–50 cm (98–197 in) tail. males and females are almost identical externally. their bodies are streamlined like marine mammals and their robust build allows them to pull heavy loads

animals have massive skulls adapted for withstanding the forces generated by their powerful chewing muscles. guard hairs are 5–6 cm (20–24 in) long and typically reddish brown, but can range from yellowish brown to nearly black. underfur is 2–3 cm (

animals have one premolar and three molars on each side of the upper and lower jaws, 20 teeth in total. the incisors' outer enamel is very thick and colored orange due to the presence of iron compounds.

the eyes, ears and nostrils are arranged so that they can remain above water when the rest of the body submerges. the nostrils and ears have valves that close underwater while nictitating membranes cover the eyes. unusual among mammals, the epiglottis is contained in

the animal's front feet are dexterous, allowing them to grasp and manipulate objects and food, as well as dig. a animal's lips can close behind the incisors, allowing for chewing in water. the fore foot, hind foot, and tail of a animal are
animals can swim at 8 km/h (50 mph) only their webbed hind feet are used while the front feet are tucked under the chest. animals are awkward on land but can move quickly when frightened.

the animal's distinctive tail consists of a conical, muscular, hairy base; and a flat, scaly end that makes up two-thirds of the appendage. the tail has multiple functions; it provides support for the animal when it is upright (such as when chewing down
the animal's sex organs are inside the body, and the male's penis has a cartilaginous baculum. they have a single opening, a cloaca, that contains the genital, digestive and excretory openings.
the animal's feces take the form of balls of sawdust, which it deposits into the water. female animals have four mammary glands; these produce milk with 19 percent fat, higher than in other rodents.

anal glands produce an oily substance which animals rub on their fur to make it waterproof. this plays a role in individual and family recognition. anal secretions are darker in females than males among eurasian animals.

the cerebellum is well developed, giving the animal coordination in three-dimensional space (such as underwater) the neocortex is dedicated mainly to touch and hearing. touch is more advanced in the lips and hands than the whiskers and tail.

animals can hold their breath for as long as 15 minutes. they typically remain underwater for no more than five or six minutes. dives generally last less than 30 seconds and are usually shallow. animal tissue contains less myoglobin than fully aquatic mammals.

the iucn red list of mammals lists both animal species as least concern. animals also have a high tolerance for carbon dioxide in their body. when surfacing, the animal can replace 75 percent of the air in its lungs in one breath.

the species was introduced to finland in 1937. the north american animal was trapped and almost extirpated because its fur was highly sought after. the introduced population in finland has been moving closer to the range of the native eurasian animal as of 2019.

the eurasian animal's range is not contiguous but fragmented. it was historically widespread throughout eurasia, but overhunting had greatly reduced its range by the early 20th century. the introduced population in tierra del fuego is estimated at 35,000–50,000

animal populations now range from spain and france, through central and eastern europe and into scandinavia and russia. beginning in 2009, animals have been reintroduced successfully to parts of great britain. in 2020, the total animal population in europe was estimated at over one million.

animals live in freshwater ecosystems such as rivers, streams, lakes and ponds. they require a year-round supply for swimming, diving, floating logs, protection of lodge entrances and safety from land-dwelling predators.

animals prefer areas with flatter terrain and diverse vegetation close to the water. north american animals colonize an area where trees are around 60 m (200 ft) from the water but can harvest trees several hundred meters away. animals also prefer wider streams over narrower ones.

dispersing animals will use certain habitats temporarily before arriving at their final destinations. these include small streams, temporary swamps, ditches and even backyards. these sites lack important resources, so the animals do not remain there for long.

during the spring and summer, they mainly feed on herbaceous plant material. during the fall and winter, they eat more bark and cambium of woody plants. tree and shrub species used include aspen, birch, oak, dogwood, willow and alder
animals usually live up to 10 years. felids, canids and bears may prey upon them. many populations of eurasian animal do not make rafts but forage on land during winter.

their parasites include the bacteria francisella tularensis, which causes tularemia. the protozoan giardia duodenalis causes giardiasis (animal fever) they have also been recorded with the rabies virus.

animals can fell trees 15 cm (59 in) wide or less in under 50 minutes. without such material, animals dig burrows into a bank to live. construction begins in late summer or early fall, and they repair them whenever needed.

the sound of running water appears to stimulate dam-building, and the sound of a leak in a dam triggers them to repair it. tree branches are cut and carried through land and water using the powerful jaw and neck muscles. other building materials, like mud and rocks, are carried under

animals pile on more material until the dam settles into a compact slope. they align these in the direction of the water's flow at an angle of around 30 degrees. heavy rocks weigh down the poles, and grass is stuffed between them.
animals make two types of lodges: bank lodges and open-water lodges. animal dams appear to be more effective than human-made concrete dams. lake-dwelling animals do not need to build dams[56]

the more complex freestanding, open-water lodges are built over a platform of piled-up sticks. the roof is sealed up with mud apart from an air vent at the top. both types are accessed by underwater entrances.

north american animals build more open-water lodges than eurasian animals. animal lodges built by first-time settlers are typically small and sloppy. more experienced families can build structures that are 6 m (20 ft) in diameter and 2 m (6 ft 7 in)

during the summer, animals tend to use bank lodges that are cooler than the surrounding air. they use open-water lodges during the winter, whose temperature is similar to that of the surrounding water.

animals in some areas will dig canals connected to their ponds. the canals fill up with groundwater and increase accessibility of river resources. these canals can stretch up to 1 m (3 ft 3 in) wide, 05 m (1 ft 8 in) deep and over 0

it has been hypothesized that animals' canals are not only transportation routes but an extension of their "central place" around the lodge and/or food cache. animals create trails or "slides" as they drag wood, which then make it easier for the animals to transport

the animal works as an ecosystem engineer and keystone species as its activities can have a great impact on the landscape and biodiversity of an area. aside from humans, no other extant animal appears to do more to shape its environment. when building dams, animals alter the paths of streams

animal dams have a tendency to raise the water table, both in mineral soil environments and in wetlands such as peatlands. when animals returned to an area, 160% more open-water was available during droughts than in previous years when they were absent.

animals can increase the productivity of freshwater ecosystems by accumulating nitrogen in sediments. animal activity can affect the temperature of the water. in northern latitudes, ice thaws earlier in the warmer animal-dammed waters.

one study in the adirondacks found that animal engineering leads to a 33 percent increase in the number of herbaceous plant species on river banks. another study in semiarid eastern oregon found that the width of riparian vegetation on stream banks increased several-fold as animal

animal ponds act as a refuge for river bank plants during wildfires. introduced animals at tierra del fuego have been responsible for destroying the indigenous forest. unlike many trees in north america, trees in south america rarely regenerate when cut down.

damming typically leads to an increase of lentic (slow or motionless water)-dependent species, like dragonflies, oligochaetes, snails and mussels. animal floodings create an increase in dead trees which benefit terrestrial invertebrates like drosophila flies

the positive effects of animal dams on fish appear to outweigh the negative effects, such as inhibition of migration. animal ponds have been shown to be beneficial to frog populations by protecting areas for larvae to mature in warm water.

animals help waterfowl by creating increased areas of water. the widening of the riparian zone associated with animal dams has been shown to increase the abundance and diversity of birds. fish-eating birds use animal ponds for foraging.
as trees are drowned by rising animal impoundments, they become ideal nesting sites for woodpeckers. animal-caused ice thawing in northern latitudes allows canada geese to nest earlier.

animals are mainly nocturnal and crepuscular and spend the daytime in their shelters. in northern latitudes, animal activity is decoupled from the 24-hour cycle during the winter and may last as much as 29 hours. large herbivores such as deer

the basic unit of animal social organization is the family. a family is composed of an adult male and an adult female in a monogamous pair and their offspring, both from the current and previous years' litters.

adult animals mate with their partners, though partner replacement appears to be common. mutual grooming and play fighting reinforces bonds between family members, and aggressive behavior amongst them is uncommon. large families have been recorded living in one lodge.

females may have their first estrus cycle of the season in late december and peak in mid-january. they may enter estrus two to four times per season; each cycle lasts 12–24 hours. mating typically takes place in the water but may also occur in the

newborn animals are precocial and fully furred and can open their eyes within a few days. their mother is the primary caretaker, while their father maintains the territory. older siblings from a previous litter also play a role.

animals nurse for the first two or three months but can eat solid food within their first week. eventually, animal kits explore outside the lodge and forage on their own but may follow an older relative and cling to their tails.

animals typically disperse from their parental colonies when the winter snow melts. they may remain with their parents for an extra year or more during times of food shortage, high population density, or drought. animals are sexually mature at 15–3 years of age.

long-distance dispersals are not uncommon when previous colonizers have already exploited local resources. animals are able to travel greater distances when they have access to free-flowing water. individuals meet their mates during the dispersal stage and the pair travel together.

animals mark their territories by constructing scent mounds made of mud and scented with castoreum. animals are generally intolerant of intruders and fights may result in deep bites to the flanks, tail and rump.

a territory-holder will investigate and become familiar with the scents of its neighbors. animals are also more tolerant of individuals that are their kin. they recognize them by using their keen sense of smell to detect differences in the composition of anal gland secretions.

animals within a family greet each other with whines. kits will attract the attention of adults with mews, squeaks and cries. defensive animals produce a hissing growl and gnash their teeth. tail slaps, which involve an animal hitting the water surface with its

cnn.com will feature ireporter photos in a weekly travel snapshots gallery. please submit your best shots of new zealand for next week. visit cnn.com/travel next wednesday for a new gallery of snapshots.
animals are famously busy, and they turn their talents to reengineering the landscape as few other animals can. adults normally ignore those of juveniles, who have not yet learnanimal behaviors.

domelike animal homes, called lodges, are also constructed of branches and mud. felling and gnawing trees with their strong teeth and powerful jaws, they create massive log, branch, and mud structures.

animals are among the largest of rodents. they are herbivores and prefer to eat leaves, bark, twigs, roots, and aquatic plants. they use their large, webbed rear feet like swimming fins and their paddle-shaped tails like rudders.

there are two species of animals, which are found in the forests of north america, europe, and asia. these animals are active all winter, swimming and foraging in their ponds even when a layer of ice covers the surface.
follow a animal family and its kits for a year in the rocky mountains and learn about their habits and habitat. animal (castor canadensis) is a species of rodent.
animals are the largest rodents in north america and eurasia and the second largest rodents worldwide. their bodies extend up to 80 cm (31 inches) long and generally weigh 16–30 kg (35–66 pounds)

ecologists often refer to animals as “ecosystem engineers” because of their ability to alter the landscapes in which they live. massive chisel-shaped incisor teeth have orange outer enamel because iron has replaced calcium.

the fur-lined lips close behind the incisors, blocking water from the mouth and lungs and allowing the animal to cut, peel, and carry branches underwater. the hind feet are quite large, and the five digits are connected by webbing, which makes them useful as paddles

fur consists of a grayish to brown layer of short, fine, and dense underfur that keeps water from reaching the skin. over this layer are long, coarse, glossy guard hairs ranging in colour from yellowish brown through reddish brown to black. the distinctive tail is sc
anal glands secrete oil through skin pores to hair roots. from there it is distributed with the front feet and grooming claws over the whole body to keep the fur sleek, oily, and water-repellent.

animals build dome-shaped island lodges built of branches plastered with mud. in marshes, lakes, and small rivers, animals may instead construct bank lodges. in large rivers and lakes they excavate bank dens with an underwater entrance beneath tree roots.

in winter the moist walls freeze, adding insulation and making the lodge impenetrable to predators. one or more tunnel entrances open below the water’s surface into a spacious central chamber above water level. an entry tunnel leads to the nest chamber above the waterline.

learn about the unintended side effect of conserving animals. learn about a toxic downside to saving animals in the wrangell mountains. take a look at a animal pond in alaska's saint elias national park and preserve.

the dam impedes the flow of the stream and increases the depth of the water that surrounds the lodge. dams also create additional wetland habitat for fish and waterfowl and contain or impede the downstream movement of oil spilled into rivers. despite the environmental services these dams provide, land

during winter animals store some fat at the base of their tail, but they maintain body temperature primarily by huddling in the insulated lodge and being less active. slow swimmers, animals can remain submerged for up to 15 minutes and propel themselves primarily with the webbed hind feet

their diet consists of the soft cambium layer beneath bark, as well as the buds, leaves, and twigs of certain trees. shrubs, saplings, and trees are felled by animals, cut into portable lengths, and dragged along mud slides or floated through

animals are monogamous, mating between january and march in the north and november or december in the south. one litter per year of one to nine (usually four) kits is born in the spring after a gestation of 105 days animals communicate by postures, vocalization, scent

american animals (c canadensis) occur throughout forested parts of north america to northern mexico, including the southwestern united states and peninsular florida. animals were at the heart of the fur trade during colonial times and contributed significantly to the westward settlement and development of north

eurasian animals were once found throughout temperate and boreal forests of the region (including britain) except for the mediterranean area and japan. american animals have been introduced into finland, where they are flourishing.

efforts to reestablish the eurasian species began in sweden in the early 1920s. eurasian animals have been reintroduced throughout europe, western siberia, western china, mongolia, the kamchatka peninsula, and near the amur river in the russian far east.

most were terrestrial burrowers, such as palaeocastor, known by fossils from late oligocene–early miocene sediments. they probably lived in upland grasslands in large colonies, excavated extensive burrow systems.
fossils indicate that it had a body length of two metres and was about the size of a black bear. it is thought to have been about the age of a modern-day polar bear.

animals are widely distributed across the us and are known for their dam-building behavior. these dams provide them protection from predators, but the impacts of their dam building can occasionally bring them into conflict with humans.

animals have webbed hind feet, large incisor teeth, and a broad, flat tail. the tail of a large animal may be 15 inches long and 6 inches wide. it is covered with leathery scales and sparse, coarse hairs.

when diving after being frightened, a animal loudly slaps the water with its tail. the sound warns all animals in the vicinity that danger is near, and perhaps serves to frighten potential predators. on land, the tail acts as a prop when a animals is sitting or

the tail stores fat, and because it is nearly hairless, releases body heat, helping the animal to regulate its body temperature. once among the most widely distributed mammals in north america, animals were eliminated from much of their range in the late 1800s because of unregulated trapping.

the animal is classified as a furbearer (wac 220-400-020) a trapping license and open season are required to trap and harvest a animal. visit the furbearer trapping seasons and rules page for more information.

the owner, the owner’s immediate family, an employee, or a tenant of property may trap or kill a animal on that property if the animal is threatening human safety or causing property damage. in such cases, no special trapping permit is necessary for the use of live

to remove or modify a animal dam you must have a hydraulic project approval (hpa) there are no exceptions for emergencies and no provisions for verbal approval. all special trapping permit applications must be in writing on a form.

a permit application can be obtained from your wdfw regional office or from the hydraulic project approval (hpa) web page. a 24-hour hotline 360-902-2537 is available for emergency calls during nonworking hours.
animals are found where their preferred foods are in good supply. in areas where deep, calm water is not available, animals will create ponds by building dams across creeks or other watercourses.

in winter, deer and elk frequent animal ponds to forage on shrubby plants that grow where animals cut down trees for food or use to make their dams and lodges. weasels, raccoons, and herons hunt frogs and other prey along the marsh
the animal’s incisors (front teeth) are harder on the front surface than on the back, and so the back wears faster. this creates a sharp edge that enables a animal to easily cut through wood.

animals eat leaves, inner bark, and twigs of aspen (a favorite food), alder, birch, cottonwood, willow, and other deciduous trees. these may be burrows in a riverbank or the more familiar lodges built in the water

coniferous trees, such as fir and pine, are eaten occasionally. more often, animals will girdle and kill these trees to encourage the growth of preferred food plants, or use them as dam building material. animals have large, sharp, upper and lower incis

fermentation by special intestinal microorganisms allows animals to digest 30 percent of the cellulose they ingest. animals eat bark and stems from a food “cache” they have anchored to the bottom of the waterway for winter use.

diagram showing where the food cache is in relation to the dam and the lodge. animals construct nesting dens for shelter and for protection against predators. these may be burrows in a riverbank or the more familiar lodges built in the water or on the shore.

animals flood areas for protection from predators, for access to food supply, and to provide underwater entrances to their den. flooded areas also wet the soil and promote the growth of favored foods. animals living on water bodies that maintain a constant level do not build dams.

the feel and sound of flowing water stimulate animals to build dams. they vary in size from a small accumulation of woody material to structures 10 feet high and over 165 feet wide. animals routinely let a leak in a dam flow freely, especially during times of high waters.
in cold areas, dam maintenance is critical. dams must be able to hold enough water so the pond won’t freeze to the bottom, which would eliminate access to the winter food supply.

freestanding lodges are built in areas where the bank or water levels aren't sufficient for a safe bank den. one or more underwater openings lead to tunnels that meet at the center of the mound, where a single chamber is created.

animals breed between january and march, and litters of one to eight kits (average four) are produced between april and june. a mated pair of animal will live together for many years, sometimes for life.
the female nurses the kits until they are weaned at 10 to 12 weeks of age. the kits then go off on their own in search of mates and suitable spots to begin colonies, which may be several miles away.
because of their size, behavior, and habitat, animal have few enemies. the colony is usually made up of the adult breeding pair, the kits of the year, and kits of the previous year or years.

other identified causes of death are severe winter weather, winter starvation, disease, water fluctuations and floods, and falling trees. in washington, from 1991 to 2000, an annual average of 5,289 animals were trapped.
animals live up to 12 years in the wild. they do not hibernate, but are less active during winter. animals spend most of their time in the lodge or den.

look for signs of animals during the day; look for the animals themselves before sunset or sunrise. approach a animal site slowly and downwind. look for a v-shaped series of ripples on the surface of calm water.

animals are able to remain underwater for at least 15 minutes by slowing their heart rate. animals have a broad, flat tail that doesn’t show behind them when swimming. muskrats have a thin tail that is either held out of the water or sways back and

animals cut down trees, shrubs, and other available vegetation for food and building materials. they face the aggressor, rear up on their hind legs, and hiss or growl loudly before lunging forward to deliver extremely damaging bites.

there will be a pile of wood chips on the ground around the base of recently felled trees. limbs that are too large to be hauled off are typically stripped of bark over the course of several days. the cut on small wood usually involves a 45-degree cut typical of rodents

most harvesting is done within 165 feet of the water’s edge. in areas with few predators, toppled trees and other signs of feeding may be found twice that distance from the den site. animals transport woody material even farther through upstream and downstream sites.

animals construct channels or canal systems leading to their ponds, using them to float food. they are 15 to 20 inches wide, at right angles to the shoreline, and have a slicked down or muddy appearance.

animals that live in cold climates store branches of food trees and shrubs for winter use by shoving them into the mud at the bottom of ponds or streams. with receding water levels during summer, animal activity shifts toward building and maintaining channels to access new food supplies.

individual animal droppings are usually cylindrical, up to 2½ inches long. the diameter is an indication of the animal’s size, with 1 inch being average for adults. the color of fresh deposits is dark brown, with lighter-colored bits of undigested

despite an appreciation for animals and our best intentions to live with them, animals can become a problem if their eating habits, and dam or den building activity, flood or damage property. sounds also include whining, a breathy greeting noise, and loud blowing when upset.

the very presence of animals is often seen as a problem when, in fact, the animals are causing no harm. you should also determine the type of damage or problem the animals are causing. then match the most appropriate and cost-effective controls to the situation.
plant areas with sitka spruce, elderberry, cascara, osoberry (indian plum), ninebark, and twinberry. densely plant aspen, cottonwood, willow, spirea (hardhack), and red-twig dogwood

the trunks of individual large trees can be loosely wrapped with 3 foot high, galvanized welded wire fencing, hardware cloth, or multiple layers of chicken wire. animals do use plants as construction materials that they might not eat.

all plants should be protected to at least 3 feet above ground and inspected regularly. dark-colored pipe can burn trunks in full sun. wider diameter pipe or pipe with holes in it may prevent overheating problems.

surround groups of trees and shrubs with 3-foot high barriers made of galvanized, welded wire fencing or other sturdy material. preventing access to food sources may force animals to eat other nearby plants, including roses and other ornamentals.

keep the bottom of the fence flush to the ground, or include an 18-inch wide skirt on the animal side. an electric fence with two hot wires suspended 8 and 12 inches off the ground is also effective at protecting groups of plants.

commercial taste and odor repellents are most effective when applied at the first sign of damage, when other food is available, and during the dry season. control the height of water behind a animal dam to prevent flooding.

commonly this is completed by removing a one to three foot wide section (notch) out of the animal dam. this keeps the rise in the water level at a minimum by using one or more plastic pipes to continually drain the pond area.
the flow device can be constructed from plastic pipe measuring 4 to 12 inches in diameter. for leveling systems to work properly, you will have to have at least 3 feet of water in the pond area.

v-shaped, semicircular, or trapezoidal fences of woven wire mesh can prevent culverts from being plugged. large flow-control devices that include a solid framework can be covered and used as a deck or wildlife viewing spot.

diagram and instructions on building a "animal deceiver" to protect culverts from being plugged by animals. it is pointless to destroy a animal dam because animals (frequently many at one time) often begin rebuilding them immediately after they are removed. it may be

landowners may consider relocation as an alternative to lethal removal. animals may not survive relocation and those that do may move large distances. it is unlawful to take live wildlife, wild birds, or game fish from the wild without a permit issued by the director.

with a permit, animals may be relocated where animal damage mitigation efforts have failed or are infeasible, where animals are posing a public health and safety risk, or other irresolvable factors exist. permitted animal relocators may move animals to a

there is no guarantee that animals will stay where released. they may find attractive habitat and forage on nearby properties. relocation of entire family units to new habitat is strongly advised over relocation of individuals.

it may be helpful to provide animals with a pickup-truck load of aspen or other trees to use as forage and building material at the release site. this will allow them time to gather a food cache, but limit their time to explore.

lethal control may become necessary when all efforts to dissuade problem animals fail. removing animals is rarely a lasting solution since survivors have larger litters, and others will resettle good habitats.click here for more information about animal relocation.

animal may be trapped for harvest only during an open furbearer trapping season. you can hire a private individual who works directly with property owners on a fee basis to resolve problem animal situations see "legal status" below and hiring a wildlife control operator for additional information.

you may have the option to lethally remove the animal yourself – see “legal status” below. resources for trapping wildlife that are causing damage are available on the trapping nuisance wildlife page.

shooting animals that are causing property damage requires skilled marksmanship and is not recommended. bait for live traps include freshly cut tree sprouts or branches of preferred foods, apples, and commercial scents and lures.

tularemia may be transmitted to humans if they drink contaminated water, eat undercooked, infected meat, or allow an open cut to contact an infected animal. tularemia is fatal to animals and is transmitted by ticks, biting flies, and via contaminated water.

a human who contracts tularemia commonly has a high temperature, headache, body ache, nausea, and sweats. humans can also get this disease via a tick bite, a biting fly, ingestion of contaminated water, or by inhaling dust from soil contaminated with the bacteria.

animals are among the few animals that regularly defecate in water. their droppings may cause a flu-like infection when contaminated water is ingested. the technical name for this environmentally borne illness is “giardiasis”

it has never been demonstrated that the type of giardia animals carry causes giardiasis in humans. giardia cysts persist in the environment to infect a number of mammal hosts. in turn, these animals become infected and pass on more cysts to the environment.

the animal is classified as a furbearer (wac 220-400-020) a trapping license and open season are required to trap and harvest a animal. visit the furbearer trapping seasons and rules page for more information.

the owner, the owner’s immediate family, an employee, or a tenant of property may trap or kill a animal on that property if the animal is threatening human safety or causing property damage. in such cases, no special trapping permit is necessary for the use of live

to remove or modify a animal dam or install a water leveling or flow device, you must have a hydraulic project approval (hpa) there are no exceptions for emergencies and no provisions for verbal approval. all special trapping permit applications must be in writing.

a permit application can be obtained from your wdfw regional office or from the hydraulic project approval (hpa) web page. for additional information on animal dam modifications, please contact your local w dfw habitat biologist. in emergency situations (when an immediate threat to property
during normal hours, contact your nearest wdfw regional office. for confidential support call the samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local samaritans branch, see www.samaritans.org for details.
the animal is north america's largest rodent and is built for life in the water. adults can be up to four feet long and weigh over 60 pounds. animal dam is the largest dam in the world.

the animal has short front legs with heavy claws. their rear legs are longer, and they use their rear webbed feet to propel themselves through the water. it will also slap its tail against the water to signal danger or to warn away predators.
the animal waterproofs its thick fur by coating it with castoreum, an oily secretion from its scent glands. the animal has a thick layer of fat under its skin that helps keep it warm underwater.

the animal can be found throughout north america, except for most of florida, the desert southwest, central and southern mexico, and the northern most parts of alaska and canada. by the late 1800s, the animal had almost completely disappeared from new hampshire due to trapping.

animals live near rivers, streams, ponds, small lakes, and marshes. they build lodges of sticks and mud on islands, on pond banks, or on lake shores. animal dams are domed-shaped and can be up to ten feet tall.

most of the animal's diet is made up of tree bark and cambium. the floor of the chamber is a little bit above the water and is usually covered in woodchips to absorb moisture. some animals build burrows in the banks of rivers.

animals mate for life, but if one mate dies, the other one finds another mate. animals also eat other vegetation like roots and buds and other water plants the animal has a specialized digestive system that helps it digest tree bark.

gestation lasts about three months, and females have one litter of kits a year between april and june. before birth, the female makes a soft bed in the lodge. the babies' eyes are open when they are born, and they can swim within 24 hours.

animals live in family groups or colonies. a colony is made up of a breeding male and female animal and their offspring. both the male and the female take care of the young animals. animals can live to be 20 years old.

animals can have both a positive and a negative impact on the environment. when animals build dams, they create new wetland environments for other species. wetlands can help slow erosion, raise the water table, and help purify the water.

when animals abandon their lodges and dams, aquatic plants take over the pond. eventually, shrubs and other plants grow, and the area will become a meadow. the shrubs in the meadow will provide enough shade to allow tree seedlings to grow. once the trees
dams can slow the flow of water in streams and cause silt to build up, and some other species can loose habitat. dams can also cause flooding in low-lying areas.
the animal is new york state's official mammal. it is unmistakable due to its large body size (26-65 pounds, 25-35 inches) and broad flattened tail (9-10 inches long, 6 inches wide)

animals have lips that close behind the incisors which allow them to gnaw underwater. the secondary eyelids, known as a nictitating membrane, are white and form an inner eyelid additionally, their ears and nose can close while underwater.

webbed hind feet serve to compliment the extraordinary swimming ability of the animal. the second hind toe has a split nail, which appears to aid in grooming. the tissue beneath the scaly outer layer, which is actually compressed, grouped hairs, contains many blood vessels.

animal rarely leave the water for long periods of time. they can be found in wooded streams; the margins of lakes, ponds, and reservoirs; swamps and marshes. blood flows from the surface of the tail, thereby minimizing heat loss.

the animal's diet consists almost entirely of cellulose in the form of woody plant material. woody plants are nearly indigestible to mammals. animals eat the leaves, bark and twigs of trees such as aspen, willow, and red maple.

as winter draws near, animal may collect and store food items, called a raft'or feedpile, underwater near the entrance to their lodge. this food store is imperative for survival when thick ice prevents access to fresh food during new york's long winters.

colonies usually consist of the parents, the present year's offspring, and often times a representative from the previous year's litter. as a colony grows, members may undoubtedly expand their breeding and foraging territories, building dams and lodges.

home ranges or colonial territories are established and passively defended by means of scent-mounding. this is where an adult animal piles up muddy debris and marks the top with castoreum, which is washed out of the castor glands with urine.

like most rodents, animal construct an elaborate den or lodge. tail-slapping is thought to be a means for one animal in a colony to warn other animal of a potential threat. another function may be to frighten would-be predators away.

possessing the unique ability to fell trees, they use this talent to get food. it is also a source of construction material for their lodges and dams. they are cued to begin construction at the sound and motion of running water.

depending upon the type of habitat they colonize, they may create a home in a stream bank, or a lodge out in open water. these have two or more underwater entrances and the 'living quarters' of their lodge will be above the level of the surrounding water.

animal impound a variety of wetland types and streams with different forest types and gradients. this colonization converts the existing habitat to open water. it can eliminate the existing natural diversity of certain groups of organisms, such as reptiles and fish species.

their dam-building activity can cause widespread flooding of forest and agricultural lands. it may destroy actual forest stands of trees not adapted for prolonged submersion of their roots. flooding not only has the potential to change the ecology of a colonized area.

animal reproduce once a year and form lifelong breeding pairs. young are born in may or june after an average gestation time of 107 days. the number of offspring could be based on the quantity and quality of available food and habitat in any given year.

animal are more susceptible to predation by animals such as coyote, fisher, bear, and bobcat when traveling extended distances from water in search of food. their anal glands, which animal use to grease up their fur, are not functional until the third or fourth week of

sweet, smart, and playful, animals are "all-around dogs," says john cramer, president of the heartland animal club of greater kansas city. they've served many roles, including carriage dog, circus dog, and firehouse dog.

dals are one of the most instantly recognizable dog breeds, thanks to their short white coat that's covered in spots. these pups are steadfastly loyal to their humans and thrive in active households that keep their muscular bodies moving.
though animals typically have black spots, they can also be liver, blue, brindle, "lemon" or black and tan. even rarer is a tricolor animal, which hasblack and tan spots.

animal puppies are born sans-spots. their distinctive pattern starts showing up when they're around two weeks old. their coat is what makes them stand apart from the crowd. underneath those spots is a lean, muscular build.

dals are highly intelligent and hard workers, but they can tend to be timid when confronted with anything new. "working with them early in life to expose them to lots of different situations can help considerably with [their shyness]," says sarah moore.

once you get past that shy shell, dals are total goofballs and have a silly sense of humor. they're remarkably loyal to their humans, and if you're diligent about exposing them to new people, new animals, and new situations in puppyhood, animals can do

animals are good family dogs and can get along well with children and other furry friends including cats and other dogs, if well-socialized. introducing animals to children as puppies is the surest way to make sure they will grow to become appropriate family dogs.

animals thrive when they have a fenced-in yard to run around in if they're cooped up indoors for too long, they can be prone to zoomies and might chew up some pillows. they'll be happiest with an active owner.

because of their sensitive nature and how easily they can become bored, animals shouldn't be left alone for long periods of time, according to the animal club of america. "they'll attach to you," cramer says.

because of their short coats, animals can do well in warmer climates. you should never leave any dog outside in the heat. when taking your dal for a winter walk, you might want to bundle him up in a coat or sweater.

a common misconception is that because a animal's fur is so short, it's easy to manage. "they'll sit right next to me, sometimes put their head in my lap, sometimes just curl up at the end of the couch"

you should brush your dal at least once a week, preferably outside. their coats are surprisingly dense and fur flies off year-round. the dca recommends a bristle brush, rubber curry comb, or horsehair mitt.

because of his history as a working dog, your animal will often greet you in the morning with a look that says, "what are we doing today?" he needs to keep his mind active and paws moving and would love to join you on long hikes, jogs, or

"they want to go out and run and be active, so you'll want [to do] some kind of activity with them," cramer says. if he doesn't get enough exercise, this typically quiet breed can become noisy and get into trouble.

it's important to use positive reinforcement when training any breed, but especially when working with dals moore says training with treats or clicker training can be particularly effective. as they're generally healthy dogs, animal lifespans are typically 11–13 years.

according to the universities federation for animal welfare, between 15–30 percent of animals are deaf in one ear. this is a condition detectable early in life, moore says, so potential owners can preemptively learn about caring for a deaf dog.

a breed standard is the guideline which describes the ideal characteristics, temperament and appearance of a breed. breeders and judges should at all times be careful to avoid obvious conditions or exaggerations which would be detrimental in any way to the health, welfare or soundness of this breed.

if a dog possesses a feature, characteristic or colour described as undesirable or highly undesirable, it is strongly recommended that it should not be rewarded in the show ring. if a feature or quality is desirable it should only be present in the right measure.
a carriage dog of good demeanour, capable of great endurance and a fair turn of speed. outgoing and friendly, not shy or hesitant, free from nervousness and aggression. entirely free from wrinkle.

muzzle powerful, never snipy distance from nose to stop equals that from stop to occiput lips clean, fitting jaws moderately closely nose in black-spotted variety always black, in liver variety always brown.

jaws strong, with a perfect, regular and complete scissor bite. moderate size, rather wide at base, gradually tapering to rounded point. fine in texture, carried close to head. marking well broken up, preferably spotted.

length from point of shoulder to point of buttock slightly greater than height from withers to ground. shoulders well laid back, clean, muscular with length of shoulder and upper arm approximately equal. entirely free from throatiness.

ribs well sprung and carried well back. well-defined withers, powerful level back. loin strong, clean, muscular and slightly arched. nails black or white in black spotted variety, in liver spotted, brown or white.

the legs should appear straight with a degree of convergence towards the centre line at the trot. strong at insertion gradually tapering towards end, never inserted too low or too high, free from coarseness and carried with a slight upward curve, never curled. preferably spotted with

short, hard, dense; sleek and glossy in appearance. black spotted having dense black spots, liver spotted, liver brown spots; not running together but round and well defined. in size 2cm-3cm in diameter as well distributed as possible.

any departure from the foregoing points should be considered a fault. tricolours and spotting other than black or liver unacceptable. bronzing on spots undesirable in adults. some patching on ears or head not to be penalised.

the kennel club breed standard is a guide and description of the ideal for the breed. the size as described does not imply that a dog will match the measurements given. a dog might be larger or smaller than the size measurements stated in the breed standard.
