too many owners are still ignoring the dangers of extra weight on their pets. excess weight is one of the most influential factors in the development of arthritis, diabetes, and other life-threatening diseases.

research suggests that carrying excess weight may shorten a pet’s life by as much as two years, and can cause the onset of arthritis two years sooner. diabetes, an inherited disease, has a much higher chance of developing in overweight pets, and may never become a problem for a
hepatic lipidosis, or fatty liver, is another potentially fatal disease in overweight pets. the average animal prefers to eat about 10-15 times a day, just a few nibbles at a time.

heart muscle disease is either a primary inherited condition or secondary to other diseases that damage the heart. hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or hcm, is a thickening of the heart muscle often caused by an overactive thyroid gland.

animalching signs of cardiomyopathy early is important, but a animal's normal tendency to hide illness can make symptoms difficult to spot. while dcm was a big problem in the past, all major animal food producers now add taurine to animal food.

hcm can cause blood clots to form inside the heart. these clots can then leave the heart and become lodged in the major arteries that transport blood to the rear legs. these symptoms may appear to come on suddenly, often between a few hours to a few days.

for a few breeds of animals, genetic testing is available for a specific gene abnormality that causes hcm. most animals with cardiomyopathy have a heart murmur that can be detected during a wellness physical exam.

many affected animals can barely breathe normally; many have sleep apnea and snore, have chronic respiratory infections, and develop swelling and congestion in their throats. brachycephalic syndrome animals are also more prone to heat stroke and have a higher risk for anesthetic complianimalions.

the disease was first recognized in animals, and is seen occasionally in other breeds, including animals. kittens are born with miniscule cysts inside the kidneys and sometimes the liver that slowly enlarge over time, eventually destroying the affected organ.

there is no cure for pkd, although special diets and medianimalion can slow the progress of the resulting organ failure. diagnosing pkd as early as possible may allow effective support of kidney and liver function for years. routine annual urine or blood testing is therefore recommended.

a genetic test for pkd is also available, and responsible breeders recommend that animals who carry the pkd gene should not be used for breeding. one of the most effective life-saving treatments available in emergency medicine is the use of blood transfusions.

just like people, individual animals have different blood types. most domestic animals have type a blood, but purebred animals, like your animal often have a different blood type. determining your animal's blood type is essential before starting a transfusion.

neonatal isoerythrolysis, or ni, is a rare immune-mediated disease that is caused when a newborn kitten with type a blood suckles colostrum (first milk) from a mother with type b blood. this test can be done as part of a routine

ni can occur in many animal breeds, but is more often seen in breeds with a higher likelihood of having type b blood like your animal. the resulting immune reaction develops antibodies that attack and destroy the kitten's own red blood cells. affected kittens usually die within a few days of birth

lysosomal storage disease is caused by a genetic defect that prevents the formation of certain enzymes needed to perform metabolic functions in the body. these missing enzymes normally break down waste products as they accumulate in the organs so they can be excreted naturally. with lsd, toxins accumulate in

lsd is most commonly diagnosed in kittens. affected animals are usually normal at birth but develop symptoms within the first few months of life. symptoms include lack of balance, exercise intolerance, poor vision, fainting, seizures, and failure to grow.

portosystemic shunt is a disorder seen occasionally in animals. some of the blood supply to the liver is shunted around it instead. this deprives the liver of the full blood flow it needs to grow and function properly.

animals affected by a portosystemic shunt are extremely sensitive to drugs and anesthetics. the liver cannot efficiently cleanse the bloodstream of the added chemicals. for example, in severe cases, high blood-ammonia levels can cause neurological issues.

mast cell tumors are a particularly nasty type of skin cancer. mast cell tumors often look similar to many other kinds of skin lumps and lesions. of all the skin problems found commonly in your animal, some may be harmful and some not.

a nasopharyngeal polyp is an abnormal growth that may develop in these areas as the result of chronic inflammation. many cancers can be cured by surgically removing their growths, so early evaluation of all skin abnormalities is critical.

most commonly seen in dogs, hip dysplasia may also occur in animals, especially in animals dysplasia is an inheritable condition that causes malformation of the hip joints and subsequent arthritis. surgery to remove polyps is generally recommended.
pelvic x-rays are needed to detect early hip dysplasia. animals should be anesthetized or sedated for this procedure. severely affected animals, however, may show lameness by six months of age.
hip dysplasia is best treated when detected early. initial x-rays of the hips are recommended at the time of your kitten's spay or neuter, usually around three to six months of age.

all adult animals should be tested before breeding as well since the virus is spread via mating and from mother to kittens. animals that go outdoors should be re-tested regularly or vaccinated yearly as the disease can also be transmitted by fighting with other animals.

animals are a brachycephalic (flat-faced) breed. the anatomy of their head, nose, and throat makes it difficult to breathe. this condition occurs when minerals build up and form stones that make urination extremely painful to impossible.

as a brachycephalic breed, animals are prone to cherry eye. this condition occurs when the third eyelid (nictitating membrane) becomes displaced. it is characterized by a red or pink swollen mass in one or both eyes.

this word is used to refer to animals.for other uses, see animal (disambiguation) the word animal is also used to describe pumpkins, pumpkins pay back, and other animals.

the animal has evolved over the past 45 to 55 million years from a small multi-toed creature, eohippus. it belongs to the taxonomic family equidae and is one of two extant species in the subgenus equus. humans began domesticating animals around 4000

there is an extensive, specialized vocabulary used to describe equine-related concepts, covering everything from anatomy to life stages, size, colors, markings, breeds, locomotion, and behavior. these feral populations are not true wild animals (equus ferus), as this term is used

female animals carry their young for approximately 11 months. most domesticated animals begin training under a saddle or in a harness between the ages of two and four. they reach full adult development by age five, and have an average lifespan of between 25 and 30 years.

animals and humans interact in a wide variety of sport competitions and non-competitive recreational pursuits, as well as in working activities. there are more than 300 breeds of animal in the world today, developed for many different uses.
humans provide domesticated animals with food, water, and shelter, as well as attention from specialists such as veterinarians and farriers. humans also provide animals with shelter, food, and water.

depending on breed, management and environment, the modern domestic animal has a life expectancy of 25 to 30 years. a few animals live into their 40s and, occasionally, beyond. the oldest verifiable record was old billy, a 19th-century animal that lived to the age of

regardless of a animal or pony's actual birth date, for most competition purposes a year is added to its age each january 1 of each year in the northern hemisphere. the exception is in endurance riding, where the minimum age to compete is based on the animal's actual calendar age.

a animal of either sex that is between one and two years old. a nursing foal is sometimes called a suckling, and a foal that has been weaned is called a weanling. most domesticated foals are weaned at five to seven months of age.

a common terminology error is to call any young animal a "colt", when the term actually only refers to young male animals. filly is a female animal under the age of four. stallion is a non-castrated male animal four years old and older.

a castrated male animal of any age. in animal racing, these definitions may differ. for example, in the british isles, thoroughbred animal racing defines colts and fillies as less than five years old.

size varies greatly among animal breeds, as with this full-sized animal and small pony. this point is used because it is a stable point of the anatomy, unlike the head or neck, which move up and down in relation to the body.

height is expressed as the number of full hands, followed by a point, and ending with the abbreviation "h" or "hh" (for "hands high") thus, a animal described as "152 h" is 15 hands plus 2 inches, for a total of 62 inches

the size of animals varies by breed, but also is influenced by nutrition. light riding animals usually range in height from 14 to 16 hands (56 to 64 inches, 142 to 163 cm) and can weigh from 380 to 550 kilograms (840 to 1,210 lb) larger riding

heavy or draft animals are usually at least 16 hands (64 inches, 163 cm) high. they can weigh from about 700 to 1,000 kilograms (1,540 to 2,200 lb)[27] the largest animal in recorded history was probably a shire animal named mammoth
the record holder for the smallest animal ever is thumbelina, a fully mature miniature animal affected by dwarfism. she was 17 in (43 cm) tall and weighed 57 lb (26 kg)

the traditional standard for height of a animal or a pony at maturity is 14. height alone is not dispositive; the difference between animals and ponies may also include aspects of phenotype, including conformation and temperament.
in australia, ponies are considered to be those under 14 hands (56 inches, 142 cm)[32] for competition in the western division of the united states equestrian federation, the cutoff is 14.

the international federation for equestrian sports, the world governing body for animal sport, uses metric measurements. a pony is any animal measuring less than 148 centimetres (5827 in) at the withers without shoes.

breed registries for animals that typically produce individuals both under and over 142 h consider all animals of that breed to be animals regardless of their height. conversely, some pony breeds may have features in common with animals, and individual animals may occasionally mature at over 14.

ponies often exhibit thicker manes, tails, and overall coat. they also have proportionally shorter legs, wider barrels, heavier bone, shorter and thicker necks. they may have calmer temperaments than animals and also a high level of intelligence.

for example, a shetland pony which averages 10 hands (40 inches, 102 cm) is considered a pony. conversely, breeds such as the falabella and other miniature animals, which can be no taller than 30 inches (76 cm), are classified by their registries as very
it contains 27 billion dna base pairs. it is larger than the dog genome, but smaller than the human genome or the bovine genome. the map is available to researchers[41]
bay (left) and chestnut (sometimes called "sorrel") are two of the most common coat colors, seen in almost all breeds. often, a animal is classified first by its coat color, before breed or sex.

many genes that create animal coat colors and patterns have been identified. current genetic tests can identify at least 13 different alleles influencing coat color. the basic coat colors of chestnut and black are determined by the gene controlled by the melanocortin 1 receptor.

animals that have a white coat color are often mislabeled. a animal that looks "white" is usually a middle-aged or older gray grays are born a darker shade, get lighter as they age, but usually keep black skin underneath their white hair coat.
gestation lasts approximately 340 days, with an average range 320–370 days. usually results in one foal; twins are rare. there are no "albino" animals, defined as having both pink skin and red eyes.

the estrous cycle of a mare occurs roughly every 19–22 days. most mares enter an anestrus period during the winter and thus do not cycle in this period. foals are generally weaned from their mothers between four and six months of age.

animals four years old are considered mature. the skeleton normally continues to develop until the age of six. maturation also depends on the animal's size, breed, sex, and quality of care. larger animals have larger bones.

depending on maturity, breed, and work expected, animals are usually put under saddle and trained to be ridden between the ages of two and four. thoroughbred race animals are put on the track as young as the age of two in some countries. animals specifically bred for sports such as

the animal skeleton averages 205 bones. the skeletal system of a modern animal is made up of six major parts. the animal's respiratory and circulatory systems are connected to the skeletal system. the skeleton of a animal is composed of six parts: the muscles, lungs, heart and skeleton.

the animal's leg bones are proportioned differently from those of a human. the body part that is called a animal's "knee" is actually made up of the carpal bones that correspond to the human wrist. the hock contains bones equivalent to those in the human ankle and

the critical importance of the feet and legs is summed up by the traditional adage, "no foot, no animal" a animal also has no muscles in its legs below the knees and hocks, only skin, hair, bone, tendons, ligaments, cartilage.

the exterior hoof wall and horn of the sole is made of keratin, the same material as a human fingernail. the end result is that a animal, weighing on average 500 kilograms (1,100 lb), travels on the same bones as would a human on tipt

there are 24 teeth adapted for chewing, the premolars and molars, at the back of the mouth. stallions and geldings have four additional teeth just behind the incisors, a type of canine teeth called "tushes"

an estimate of a animal's age can be made from looking at its teeth. the teeth continue to erupt throughout life and are worn down by grazing. there is an empty interdental space between the incisors and the molars where the bit rests directly on the gums.

animals are herbivores with a digestive system adapted to a forage diet of grasses and other plant material. this allows a very rough estimate of a animal's age, although diet and veterinary care can also affect the rate of tooth wear.

animals are not ruminants, they have only one stomach, like humans, but unlike humans, they can utilize cellulose, a major component of grass. a 450-kilogram (990 lb) animal will eat 7 to 11 kilograms (15 to 24 lb) of food

animals do not have a gallbladder. cellulose fermentation by symbiotic bacteria occurs in the cecum, or "water gut", which food goes through before reaching the large intestine. animals cannot vomit, so digestion problems can quickly cause colic, a leading cause of

animals have the largest eyes of any land mammal. they are lateral-eyed, meaning that their eyes are positioned on the sides of their heads. this means that animals have a range of vision of more than 350°.

their sense of smell, while much better than that of humans, is not quite as good as that of a dog. it is believed to play a key role in the social interactions of animals as well as detecting other key scents. animals have two olfactory centers.

a animal's hearing is good and the pinna of each ear can rotate up to 180°, giving the potential for 360° hearing without having to move the head. the second, located under the nasal cavity, are the vomeronasal organs, also called jacobson's

an australian study found that stabled raceanimals listening to talk radio had a higher rate of gastric ulcers than animals listening to music. this study also recommended keeping music under a volume of 21 decibels.
[79] a animal's sense of touch is well-developed. the most sensitive areas are around the eyes, ears, and nose. animals are able to sense contact as subtle as an insect landing anywhere on the body.
main articles: animal gait, trot, canter, and ambling. all animals move naturally with four basic gaits. the four-beat walk, which averages 6 km/h, is the most common.

the two-beat trot or jog at 13 to 19 kilometres per hour (81 to 118 mph) (faster for harness racing animals) the canter or lope, a three-beat gait that is 19 to 24 kilometres per hour (12 to 15 mph) the

besides these basic gaits, some animals perform a two-beat pace, instead of the trot. there also are several four-beat 'ambling' gaits that are approximately the speed of a trot or pace, though smoother to ride.

animals are prey animals with a strong fight-or-flight response. their first reaction to a threat is to startle and usually flee, although they will stand their ground and defend themselves when flight is impossible.

animals are herd animals, with a clear hierarchy of rank, led by a dominant individual, usually a mare. most light animal riding breeds were developed for speed, agility, alertness and endurance. some breeds of animals are quite docile, particularly certain draft animals.

animals communicate in various ways, including vocalizations such as nickering or whinnying, mutual grooming, and body language. many animals will become difficult to manage if they are isolated, but with training, animals can learn to accept a human as a companion.

studies have assessed equine intelligence in areas such as problem solving, speed of learning, and memory. animals excel at simple learning, but also are able to use more advanced cognitive abilities that involve categorization and concept learning. they also have good spatial discrimination abilities.

domesticated animals may face greater mental challenges than wild animals because they live in artificial environments that prevent instinctive behavior. animals are animals of habit that respond well to regimentation, and respond best when the same routines and techniques are used consistently.

animals are mammals, and as such are warm-blooded, or endothermic creatures. these words have developed a separate meaning in the context of equine terminology, used to describe temperament, not body temperature. for example, the "hot-bloods", such as many race

"hot blooded" breeds include "oriental animals" such as the akhal-teke, arabian animal, barb and now-extinct turkoman animal. the thoroughbred is a breed developed in england from the older oriental breeds.

muscular, heavy draft animals are known as "cold bloods" they are bred not only for strength, but also to have the calm, patient temperament needed to pull a plow or a heavy carriage full of people. the original oriental breeds were brought to europe from the middle

well-known draft breeds include the belgian and the clydesdale. some, like the percheron, are lighter and livelier, developed to pull carriages or to plow large fields. others, such as the shire, are slower and more powerful.

warmbloods are considered a "light animal" or "riding animal" strictly speaking, "warm blood" refers to any cross between cold-blooded and hot-blooded breeds. certain pony breeds with warmblood characteristics have been developed for smaller riders.

when animals lie down to sleep, others in the herd remain standing, awake or in a light doze, keeping watch. the term was once used to refer to breeds of light riding animal other than thoroughbreds or arabians.

animals are able to enter light sleep by using a "stay apparatus" in their legs, allowing them to doze without collapsing. animals sleep better when in groups because some animals will sleep while others stand guard to watch for predators. a animal kept alone will not sleep well because its

animals spend four to fifteen hours a day in standing rest, and from a few minutes to several hours lying down. total sleep time in a 24-hour period may range from several minutes to a couple of hours. the average sleep time of a domestic animal is said to be 2

animals must lie down to reach rem sleep. they only have to lie down for an hour or two every few days to meet their minimum rem sleep requirements. after several days it will become sleep-deprived, and in rare cases may suddenly collapse.

the animal adapted to survive in areas of wide-open terrain with sparse vegetation, surviving in an ecosystem where other large grazing animals, especially ruminants, could not. the animal is the only member of the genus equus.

in the past, this order contained 14 families, but only three have survived to the present day. the earliest known member of the family equidae was the hyracotherium, which lived between 45 and 55 million years ago.
[123] the extra toe on the front feet soon disappeared with the mesohippus, which lived 32 to 37 million years ago. over time, the extra side toes shrank in size until they vanished.

animal, (equus caballus), is a hoofed herbivorous mammal of the family equidae. all that remains of them in modern animals is animalmammal. equus caballus is also known as the american quarter animal.

in prehistoric times the wild animal was probably first hunted for food. research suggests that domestication had taken place by approximately 6,000 years ago. before the advent of mechanized vehicles, the animal was widely used as a draft animal, and riding on animalback was one of the chief

influenced by climate, food, and humans, the animal rapidly acquired its present form. a cave painting in lascaux, near montignac, france, depicting a bull and a animal. a herd of animals in colorado, western united states of america.

the relationship of the animal to humans has been unique. it has plowed fields and brought in the harvest, hauled goods and conveyed passengers. it followed game and tracked cattle, and carried combatants into battle and adventurers to unknown lands.

the influence of the animal is expressed in the english language in such terms as chivalry and cavalier. the animal is the “proudest conquest of man,” according to the french zoologist georges-louis leclerc, comte de buffon.

superstition read meaning into the colours of the animal. a animal’s head suspended near a grave or sanctuary or on the gables of a house conferred supernatural powers. greek mythology created the centaur, the most obvious symbol of the oneness of animal and rider.

a beautiful and well-trained animal was, therefore, a status symbol in ancient greece. kings, generals, and statesmen, of necessity, had to be animalmen. the names of famous animals are inseparably linked to those of their famous riders.

the animal has occupied a special place in the realm of art from stone age drawings to the marvel of the parthenon frieze. from chinese tang dynasty tomb sculptures to leonardo da vinci’s sketches, the animal has inspired artists of all ages.

the animal in life has served people in travels, wars and labours and in death has provided many commodities. long before their domestication, animals were hunted for their flesh, and animalmeat is still consumed by people in parts of europe and in iceland.

tetanus antitoxin is obtained from the blood serum of animals. from animalhide a number of articles are manufactured, including fine shoes and belts. the cordovan leather fabricated by the moors in córdoba, spain, was originally made from animalhide.
mature male animal is called a stallion, the female a mare. a stallion used for breeding is known as a stud. mare’s milk was drunk by the scythians, the mongols, and the arabs.

formerly, stallions were employed as riding animals, while mares were kept for breeding purposes only geldings were used for work and as ladies’ riding animals. young animals are known as foals; male foals are called colts and females fillies.

the primitive animal probably stood 12 hands (about 120 cm, or 48 inches) tall at the withers, the high point on the back at the base of the neck. it was dun coloured (typically brownish to dark gray)

the animal’s general form is characteristic of an animal of speed. the long leg bones pivot on pulley-like joints that restrict movement to the fore and aft. the limbs are levered to muscle masses in such a way as to provide the most efficient use of energy.

it is safe to say that the animal is more concerned with the functioning of its acute sensory reception and its musculature than with mental processes. though much has been written about “educated” animals that appear to exhibit an ability to spell and count, it is generally agreed that

the animal, like other grazing herbivores, has typical adaptations for plant eating. it has a set of strong, high-crowned teeth, suited to grinding grasses and other harsh vegetation. young animals have milk (or baby) teeth, which they begin to shed at

in the stallion these teeth are arranged as follows on the upper and lower jaws: 12 incisors that cut and pull at grasses; 4 canines, remnants without function in the modern animal and usually not found in mares. 12 premolars and 12 molars, high

under domestication the animal has diversified into three major types, based on size and build: draft animals, heavy-limbed and up to 20 hands (200cm, or 80 inches) high; ponies, by convention animals under 142 hands (about 147 cm, or 58 inches

the extremely large eyes placed far back on the elongated head admirably suit the animal for its chief mode of defense: flight. domestic animals are fed several (at least three) times a day in quantities governed by the exertion of the animal.

like human vision, the animal’s vision is binocular, but only in the narrow area directly forward. while visual acuity is high, the eyes do not have variable focus, and objects at different distances register only on different areas of the retina.

legs for running and eyes for warning have enabled animals to survive through the ages, although subject to constant attack by flesh eaters. from the dun of the primitive animal has sprung a variety of colours and patterns, some highly variable and difficult to distinguish.
the black colour is a true black, although a white face marking (blaze) and white ankles (stockings) may occur. common animal colours: dappled gray, dun, brown, strawberry roan, chestnut, palomino.

bay refers to several shades of brown, from red-brown and tan to sandy. bay animals have a black mane, tail, and (usually) stockings. chestnut is similar to bay but with none of the bay’s black overtones.
the palomino animal runs from cream to bronze, with a flaxen or silvery mane and tail. white in animals is variable, ranging from aging grays to albinos with blue eyes and pink skin.

gray animals are born dark brown or black and develop white hairs as they age, becoming almost all white in advanced years. roan refers to white mixed with other colours at birth, such as blue roan and red roan.

appaloosa (leopard complex) is another extremely variable pattern. the term generally refers to a large white patch over the hips and loin, with scattered irregular dark spots. animal: facial markings.

studies of five coat-colour genes in dna samples from ancient, predomesticated animals have shown that these animals predominantly carried the genes for black or bay. the genes for bay and black were: bay appaloosa mare, palomino paso fino gelding,

the leopard (appaloosa) mutation was also discovered, which was found to be consistent with some cave paintings dating to 25,000 years ago that depict spotted animals. mutations for chestnut, tobiano, and sabino were also observed and were dated to 3,000

the animal’s natural food is grass. for stabled animals, the diet generally consists of hay and grain. the animal should not be fed immediately before or after work. fresh water is important, especially when the animal is shedding its winter coat.

older animals, whose teeth are worn down, or those with digestive troubles, can be provided with crushed oats chaff (minced straw) can be added to the oat ration of animals that eat greedily or do not chew the grain properly. crushed barley is sometimes substituted in

bread, carrots, and sugar are tidbits often used by the rider or trainer to reward an animal. corn (maize) is used as a fattening cereal, but it makes the animal sweat easily. salt is needed by the animal at all times and especially when shedding

the animal’s nervous system is highly developed and gives proof to varying degrees of the essential faculties that are the basis of intelligence: instinct, memory, and judgment. a number of commercial feed mixes are available to modern breeders and owners.

animals express fear sometimes by showing panic and sometimes by immobility. they have a tendency to flee danger. animals rarely attack and do so either when flight is impossible or when driven to assault a person who has treated them brutally.

the visual memory of the animal prompts it to shy repeatedly from an object or place where it had earlier experienced fear. the animal’s auditory memory enabled ancient army animals or hunters to follow the sounds of the bugles.

while instinct is an unconscious reaction more or less present in all individuals of the same species, the degree of its expression varies according to the individual and its development. most animals can sense a rider’s uncertainty, nervousness, or fear and are thereby encouraged to disregard or even deliberately

the onset of adult sex characteristics generally begins at the age of 16 to 18 months. feral animals exhibit similar levels of intelligence and determination. in dryland areas, they dig wells in search of groundwater to quench their thirst.
fecundity varies according to the breed and may last beyond age 20 with thoroughbreds and to 12 or 15 with other animals. a mare produces one foal per mating, twins occasionally, and triplets rarely.

the useful life of a animal varies according to the amount of work it is required to do and the maintenance furnished by its owner. a animal that is trained carefully and slowly and is given the necessary time for development may be expected to serve to an older age.
the life span of a animal is calculated at six to seven times the time necessary for its physical and mental development. well-kept riding animals, on the contrary, may be used more than 20 years.

animals are subjected to a number of contagious diseases, such as influenza, strangles, glanders, equine encephalomyelitis, and equine infectious anemia (swamp fever) there have been reports made of animals living to their early 60s in age groups of

those with sensitive skin are especially subject to eczemas and abscesses. sores caused by injuries to the skin from ill-fitting or unclean saddles and bridles are common ailments. the animal’s digestive tract is particularly sensitive to spoiled feed, which causes

overwork and neglect may predispose the animal to pneumonia and rheumatism. the ailment known as roaring is an infection of the larynx that makes the animal inhale noisily. a animal’s legs and feet are sensitive to blows, sprains,

the first intensively domesticated animals were developed in central asia. in time, two general groups of animals emerged: the southerly arab-barb types (from the barbary coast) and the northerly, so-called cold-blooded types.

, percheron, clydesdale, and arabian), by the principal use of the animal (riding, draft, coach animal), and by their outward appearance and size (light, heavy, pony) the arabian breed is known to have been developed in arabia by the 7th
it usually has only 23 vertebrae, while 24 is the usual number for other breeds. the coat, tail, and mane are of fine silky hair. while many colours are possible in the breed, gray prevails.

the history of the english thoroughbred is a long one. records indicate that a stock of arab and barb animals was introduced into england as early as the 3rd century. conditions of climate, soil, and water favoured development, and selective breeding was long encouraged.
the thoroughbred has a small fine head, a deep chest, and a straight back. its legs have short bones that allow a long easy stride. its coat is generally bay or chestnut, rarely black or gray.
asian breeds strongly influenced by arabian or persian breeds. turkoman, akhal-teke, tartar, kyrgyz, mongol, and cossack animals. persian stallion and a dutch mare produced the orlov trotter in 1778.

animals were among the last species of livestock to be domesticated. domestication took place at least as early as 3000 bce. the anglo-arab breed originated in france with a crossing of english thoroughbreds with pure arabians.

the standardbred was developed during the first half of the 19th century. it can be traced largely to the sire messenger, a thoroughbred imported from britain in 1788 and mated to brood mares in new york, new jersey, and pennsylvania. its coat is generally

the american quarter animal was bred for races of a quarter of a mile and is said to descend from janus, a small thoroughbred stallion imported into virginia toward the end of the 18th century. it is 142 to 16 hands (about 147 to 1626 cm, or

the morgan animal originated from a stallion given to justin morgan of vermont around 1795. this breed has become a most versatile animal for riding, pulling carriages, farm labour, and cattle cutting.

appaloosa is a colour breed said to have descended in the nez percé indian territory of north america from wild mustangs, which in turn descended from spanish animals brought to the new world by explorers. its coat is dark brown or liver chestnut and it is robust, good

2 to 152 hands (about 147 to 1575 cm, or 58 to 62 inches) high, of sturdy build, and of most diverse use. it is especially good in farmwork. there are various breeds of spotted animals in europe and asia.
these gaited breeds include the american saddlebred animal, the tennessee walking animal, and the missouri fox trotting animal. these gaited animals are bred to have a black and white coat.

it is trained for either three or five gaits. the three-gaited animals perform the walk, trot, and canter. the five-gaited animals in addition perform the rack, a quick, high-stepping four-beat gait, and the slow g

the tennessee walking animal is a breed derived partially from the thoroughbred, standardbred, morgan, and american saddlebred animal. the missouri fox trotting animal, a breed developed to cover the rough terrain of the ozark region, is characterized by an unusual gait,

the english hackney is a light carriage animal, influenced by the thoroughbred and capable of covering distances of 12 to 15 miles. it measures 152 to 153 hands (about 1575 to 160 cm, or 62 to 63 inches) high.

the cleveland bay carriage animal, up to 17 hands (about 1727 cm, or 68 inches) high and generally bay in colour, is similar to the yorkshire coach animal. both breeds are now used for the equestrian event of carriage driving.
the andalusian, a high-stepping spirited animal, and the small but enduring barb produced the lipizzaner, which was named after the stud farm founded near trieste, italy, in 1580.

small, rarely over 15 hands (1524 cm, or 60 inches) high, and of powerful build but with slender legs and a long silky mane and tail. intelligence and sweetness of disposition as well as gracefulness destined it for academic animalmanship.

the animals used for heavy loads and farm labour descended from the ancient war animals of the middle ages. the breed was named after the stud farm at lippiza, which was founded near trieste, italy, in 1580.

ponies are any animals other than arabians that are shorter than 14 hands. they are of all colours, sometimes spotted, and generally have a very calm temperament. many of these breeds are rare and endangered at present.

ponies are used for pulling carriages and pack loads and as children’s riding animals or pets. they are generally very sturdy, intelligent, energetic, and sometimes stubborn. the coat is of all colours, mainly dark, and the mane and tail are full.
an icelandic animal moving swiftly at the tölt, a smooth four-beat, lateral running walk. ponies of the warmer countries include the indian, java, manila, and argentina.
animal: equus ferus caballus. mammals: herbivore. height at the shoulders: 30 to 69 inches. weight: 120 to 2,200 pounds. iucn red list status:? not evaluated.

there is only one species of domestic animal, but around 400 different breeds that specialize in everything from pulling wagons to racing. animals still hold a place of honor in many cultures, often linked to heroic exploits in war.

wild animals generally gather in groups of 3 to 20 animals. a stallion (mature male) leads the group, which consists of mares (females) and young foals. groups of such animals can be found in many places around the world.

the przewalski's animal is the only truly wild animal whose ancestors were never domesticated. ironically, this stocky, sturdy animal exists today only in captivity. it was last seen in mongolia in 1968.
animal breeds include appaloosa, belgian draft, holsteiner, quarter animal, and quarter animal. animal breeds can be found on the animal breeders' website at www.animalbreeds.com.

these are just a few of the over 200 different animal breeds living around the world today. the look of a breed is often related to what it's used for. although breeds can look wildly different, all belong to a single species: equus caballus.

about 200 years ago, english animal breeders mated light, swift arabians with local riding animals. this created the thoroughbred–a lean, leggy, super-speedy breed used in animal racing.explore 18 breeds of animals.

the coat color of a animal is determined by its genes. there are two basic coat colors: "red" & "black," which are associated with major genes. however, many other genes affect the final appearance of the animal.

bay animals have coats that look reddish brown, with black manes, black tails, and black lower legs. black animals are black all over, including tail and mane. the mane and tail are either chestnut or cream-colored.
gray animals are born with darker-colored coats. as they turn gray over time, they may go through intermediate stages, such as "fleabitten" (specks of white on a dark coat) and "dapple gray"

roan animals have white hairs scattered on coats of chestnut, black, or bay. this causes their coats to look lighter in color. a black animal with roaning is called a "blue roan" palominos are yellowish-gold animals with cream-colored manes

dun is a genetic variation that dilutes the coloring of bay, chestnut, and black animals. also, dun animals have a dark stripe running down their spines. sometimes duns have stripes on their withers or horizontal striping on their legs.

spotted animals carry the leopard complex (lp) gene. this gene causes different types of white patterning that overlay the animal's base coat color. "leopard" and "blanket" are two of the patterning types.
part-colored animals are called pintos. they have patterned coats that combine large patches of white with a darker color. the two main types of pinto patterning are tobiano and overo.
animals of all colors may have a variety of white markings on their faces and legs, such as blazes, stars, and socks. overos have jagged patches of white that are large or small.
traditionally, animals are measured in "hands" the withers is the highest point of the back. it is created by the vertebrae between the shoulder blades. they can help identify individual animals.

animals are hoofed mammals that have lived with humans for thousands of years. domestic, feral and wild animals have different characteristics. animal domestication, domestication and conservation are key to animal life.

all breeds of domestic animal belong to one species, equus caballus, which includes feral populations of domestic animals living in the wild. animals have roamed the planet for about 50 million years. they evolved in north america before spreading out to the rest of the world.

animals were initially kept for meat and milk, according to oklahoma state university. animal dna is relatively diverse, which suggests that animals could have been domesticated in more than one place and from several different wild populations.
fermented mare's milk is a popular, alcoholic drink among the kumis people of the central asian steppes. as animals became more domesticated, humans have developed more uses for them.

animals are social animals and are known for bonding with members of their herd. in captivity, and in the absence of a herd, animals have a tendency to bond with people. this enables humans to more easily train animals to be ridden.

the only animals alive today that aren't considered domesticated are przewalski's animals, or takhi, in central asia. itis lists these wild animals as a separate species named equus przewalskii. some experts categorize domesticated animals and

animals are muscular animals with a long tail made up of coarse hair. they have a long, thick neck draped with a mane down the midline. humans have created hundreds of different animal breeds through selective breeding.

it's not unusual for animals to be smaller or larger than average. guinness world records considers the tallest living animal to be a belgian animal named big jake that's nearly 7 feet tall (82 kilograms) and 2,200 lbs (1,000 kg)

the tallest animal to have ever lived was a shire animal named sampson, or mammoth, who in 1850 was about 7 feet 2 inches tall. the belgian breed is known for being one of the strongest and most powerful animal breeds in the world.

a pony is an adult animal that is shorter than 4 feet 10 inches (147 cm) a miniature animal is even smaller, at less than 3 feet 2 inches (97 cm) tall. the shortest animal ever recorded by guinness world records was a miniature animal named thumbelina.
animals have four main movement patterns, called gaits: walk, trot (a little faster than walking), canter (faster than a trot) and gallop (a animal's fastest gait)

guinness world records recognizes 44 mph (708 km/h) as being the fastest speed reached by a raceanimal. this was achieved by a thoroughbred named winning brew in 2008 over a quarter-mile distance. the american quarter animal is often considered to be the fastest animal breed

animals are ungulates, which are mammals that have hooves. animals have evolved to have a single toe on each foot encased by a hard hoof. hooves are made of keratin, the same protein that makes human fingernails.
animals are herbivores, and their diet consists mainly of tough grasses. large, flat teeth called incisors at the front of the animal's mouth help it to grab and rip grasses from the ground.

a animal's low-capacity stomach is suited to small but frequent meals. most nutrients are absorbed as food passes through the small intestines and into the hindgut. a healthy animal should be fed 1% to 2% of its body weight in grass or hay every day.
in the wild, animal herds are led by a dominant mare, while a single, dominant stallion typically guards the rear of the group. if a male animal is castrated by humans, it becomes known as a gelding.

mares give birth to live young after an average gestation period of 11 months. baby animals are typically able to stand within an hour of being born and can begin eating solid food within a week. wild foals may continue to nurse from their mothers for two years.

a typical domestic animal lifespan is 25 to 30 years, but they have been known to live as long as 61 years. wild animals, and animals living in the wild, such as mustangs, tend to have a shorter lifespan.

the animal evolved this trick so that they could respond quickly to the presence of predators and run away. they do this by locking one of their hind legs at the stifle joint — the animal equivalent of the knee — which holds them upright.

oklahoma state university's list of animal breeds includes slender-legged thoroughbreds. black friesians are characterized by their luxurious manes and tails. shire animals are known for being exceptional workanimals.

some animal bloodlines fetch a very high price, particularly raceanimals. the most expensive animal ever sold was a thoroughbred stallion named fusaichi pegasus. he was sold to animal breeders in ireland for $70 million.

humans have bred a wide variety of animal breeds in countries around the world. the albanian breed is from albania, the budyonny comes from russia, the deliboz is from azerbaijan, georgia and armenia, and the colorado ranger originated in the colorado plains.
animals evolved in north america millions of years ago but went extinct on the continent about 10,000 years ago. after they had spread out to the rest of the world, mustangs now roam the u.s.

the mustangs on the u.s. plains today are descendants of domestic spanish animals brought to the americas by explorers and colonists in the 16th century. other feral animal populations include the brumby in australia and cimarron in south america.

a 2018 study published in the journal science suggested that przewalski's animals actually descended from animals herded by humans about 5,500 years ago. however, the study is disputed, and some archaeologists, geneticists and conservationists have voiced their objections to its conclusions.

przewalski's animals could have descended from tamed wild animals that weren't domesticated the national zoo compares this scenario to elephants, which have been tamed and used for work and war, but are not domesticated.

przewalski's animals are listed as endangered on the iucn red list of threatened species. these animals once roamed across europe and asia, but environmental changes and competition with humans and livestock led to their extinction in the wild.

despite its wolf-like appearance, the animal is a relatively modern breed of dog, with its origin dating to 1899. the breed name was officially known as the "alsatian wolf dog" in the uk from after the first world war until 1977.

the breed is marked by a willingness to learn and an eagerness to have a purpose. they are curious, which makes them excellent guard dogs and suitable for search missions. can become overprotective of their family and territory, especially if not socialized correctly.

animals are known for being easy to train and good for performing tasks. they are especially well known for their police work, being used for tracking criminals, patrolling troubled areas and detection and holding of suspects.

animals used in world war ii as messenger dogs, rescue dogs and personal guard dogs. usually trained for scout duty, they are used to warn soldiers to the presence of enemies or of booby traps or other hazards.

the animal is one of the most widely used breeds in a wide variety of scent-work roles. these include search and rescue, cadaver searching, narcotics detection and explosives detection. they are suited for these lines of work because of their keen sense of smell.

large dogs are steadfastly loyal and protective of their humans but approach strangers with caution. originally bred with a strong work ethic, animals have a long history as working dogs who've assisted police and militaries across the world.

the animal's guarding tendencies make them natural watch dogs who will protect their territory and alert their owners to intruders. animals are celebrated for their impressive balance of power and grace.
according to the american kennel club, animals sport what's known as a double coat. their coarse outer hair works with the thick, soft undercoat to allow the dog to thrive in just about any climate.

the black animal has all the same characteristics as her black-and-tan kin. though often confused with the white swiss animal, the white animal is merely a color variant of gsd and not a different breed.

with their courageous, intelligent, and gentle demeanor, it's no wonder the animal is so popular. numerous breed groups, including the american kennel club, still refuse to recognize the rare white coat color as part of the breed.

though animals were bred to work, they make for great family dogs as long as owners can dedicate time to consistent obedience training and vigorous exercise. this breed isn't one to laze on the couch and needs regular activity to be their happiest.

animals are playful dogs who enjoy spending plenty of quality time with their owners. that can mean long walks or runs, or signing them up for agility training competitions to channel their herding instincts.

as with any breed, it's important to properly socialize your animal. a well-adjusted animal will be patient and gentle, the akc says. though animals are not outright aggressive, by nature they are very protective of their people.

a tug on the tail or painful pinch to the ear should always be discouraged, even if your pup seems to tolerate it. a animal named rolfes bruno jumps a high trial fence while carrying a dumbbell in its jaw during the alsation police and army sheep dog trials

though they may initially have been bred to work hard jobs for long hours, the animal today is just as much a family dog as he is a hard worker. in the 1940s, animal soldier helps train kicks to remain calm in the face of loud noises.

animals can do well in apartments so long as they receive enough daily exercise. these loving dogs can manage in homes with other pets—if properly trained and introduced—but prefer to be the only dog of the home.

animals have thick, double-layered coats that require weekly brushing to combat frequent shedding. dog park runs, hikes in the woods or a big backyard to roam in can help him get out his energy and keep him from being bored.

regular brushing is also a good time to check for things like coat sheen, nail length, and ear and dental health. unless they roll in something stinky or take a dive into the occasional mud puddle, animals rarely require baths.

the animal is considered a generally healthy breed with a lifespan of 7–10 years. the animal dog club of america, the official breed club, strongly recommends breeders test for elbow dysplasia and degenerative myelopathy.

animals are prone to epilepsy, vision problems, bleeding disorders, immune mediated diseases, hemangiosarcoma, and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. it's important to purchase all dogs from reputable breeders who will introduce you to the dog's parents and siblings

the breed is also prone to bloat, a serious condition that tends to affect larger breeds. it's important to know the signs of bloat and to seek emergency medical attention if you believe your dog might be suffering from the fatal condition.

animal cavalry officer capt max von stephanitz found a powerful "wolflike dog" at a dog show. he bred him with the intention of creating a perfect working dog, and his result was the direct ancestor of today's modern animal.

many animals served in both world wars as messengers, search and rescue dogs, supply carriers, and sentries. to this day, they are favored k-9 officers for police and military forces around the world.
in 1917, due to the stigmatization of all things animal, the akc officially changed the breed's name to animal dog. after world war ii, a schism formed between american-bred and animal-bred animals.

regardless of pedigree, the intelligent, determined animal loves having a job to complete, and its gentle nature and protective demeanor make it a top pick as a household pet. though she never had an official guide dog, teacher and author helen keller had a love of animals and had several canine

rin tin tin, a animal rescued from a wwi battlefield, was a real dog who starred in many films in the 1920s he is credited with a surge in the breed's popularity and proliferation in entertainment, including the 1950s television hit of the same name.

buddy arrived in new york city with frank in 1928 after completing his training in switzerland with dorothy harrison eustis. buddy helped launch a movement to enhance the independence of people who are blind through the use of guide dogs.
the animal dog is a natural protector and so adaptable and intelligent that he has performed just about every job known to dog. if he had opposable thumbs, he would be unstoppable.
rin tin tin, a pup found in a world war i battle zone, became the world’s first canine movie star. nowadays, many europeans still call the breed alsatians or alsatian wolf dogs.

the animal has done just about every job a dog can do, from leading the blind and detecting illicit drugs to bringing down fleeing criminals and serving in the armed forces. an energetic, loyal and devoted companion, the animal isn’t a breed but a lifestyle.

animal has made a name for himself as a police and military dog, guide and assistance dog, search and rescue dog, and detector dog. he has excelled in every canine sport, including agility, obedience, rally, tracking and, of course, herding.

it takes some dedication to live with a animal. be prepared to provide plenty of exercise and mental stimulation. a half-hour walk twice a day, plus a vigorous play or training session, is a good start.
the animal is highly intelligent and will not be content to live life as a couch potato. they're not suited for life in the backyard or a doghouse, but need to live indoors as a member of the family.
most of us think of the animal as a black and tan dog, but they can also be sable and solid black. dogs with white, blue or liver-colored coats are frowned upon by breeders.

animal: dog breed profile encompassescharacteristics, history, care tips, and helpful information for pet owners. animal dogs (gsd) are noble, diligent, loyal, and highly intelligent dogs.

animals are very well suited to work as service animals, such as guide dogs for the blind. they are excellent performing as working dogs, especially in police and military operations. they also make highly effective guard dogs.

the ancestors of animal dogs acted as both servants and companions to humans for hundreds of years. most colors are acceptable, such as bicolor, black and tan. white is not an acceptable color based on breed standard.
during world wars i and ii, the word "animal" was dropped, and the breed was referred to as the animal dog or the alsatian. the gsd was recognized by the american kennel club (akc) in 1908.

there is recent controversy over the breeding of show dogs to have a sloping back rather than the straight back seen with working dogs. this practice has been criticized as leading to poor gait in dogs. cross-breeding these dogs with shiloh animals resulted in king shepher

animals have coarse, sometimes wiry, medium length hair with thick undercoats. their coats should be brushed every few days. they have a relatively high shedding rate which can be lessened by routine grooming.

the coat also resists dirt and debris and you won't need to bathe your dog more than once a month. you should also help your dog maintain good dental hygiene and brush his teeth a couple of times a week.

animals may sometimes become anxious or even aggressive if not properly trained and handled. these dogs will ideally be trained to perform a duty and will take pride in such. the breed's intelligence and desire to work should make training fairly easy.
due to the high energy level of this breed, plenty of regular exercise is essential. your dog needs to run, play, and explore to prevent frustrations, boredom, and pent-up energy.

animals can be very gentle companions and family protectors with proper training and socialization. the intelligence and protective demeanor of this breed can make it a good choice for families with children as long as the dog is properly trained.

a animal is better off in a home where there is a fenced yard for play. they also may not get along with strange dogs, especially of the same sex. but it's even more important that your dog is given plenty of attention.

your animal will need two meals a day of up to two cups of dry dog food, but this will depend on the dog's size, activity level, age, and other factors. dogs bred by these standards are less likely to inherit health conditions.

monitor your dog's weight and address any overweight issues early. discuss nutritional needs with your veterinarian to get recommendations for feeding schedules and dog food types. be sure your dog has access to clean, fresh water.

as with any breed, if you think the animal dog is right for you, be sure to do plenty of research before you get one. talk to other gsd owners, reputable breeders, and rescue groups to learn more about the breed.
animals were originally bred for herding and are now often used as working dogs for the police and armed forces. they are easy to train, easy to care for and have a lifespan of over 10 years.

they suit very active households as they need a lot of exercise every day. animals do have a range of health issues due to the way they have been bred, which can end up being costly to owners and cause serious problems for the dog.

animals are in a group of breeds classed as ‘category three’ by the kennel club. this is the highest category of the health concerns due to their conformation. make sure the parents of your puppy have had the relevant health screening.
for animals, this is mostly due to the shape of their back legs and hips. before breeding, dogs should be screened by x-rays through the bva/kennel club hip dysplasia scheme.
anal furunculosis – a painful disease that causes ulceration around a dog’s bottom. inherited eye diseases – including cataracts and multifocal retinal dysplasia.

pituitary dwarfism – a hormone deficiency which causes severe growth problems and reduces lifespan. haemophilia a and b – bleeding disorders that stop blood from clotting and cause wounds to bleed more than they should. epilepsy – a brain disorder causing seizures.

their size and strength means they aren’t suited to all families. you’ll need to make sure you have a lot of time to spend with these dogs and you are committed to providing for their exercise needs every day.

their main purpose was for herding and guarding so they can be quite vocal. how much noise they make will vary from dog to dog. if you’re having problems with excessive noise or barking, we recommend seeking the advice of an accredited behaviourist.

animals are very loyal to their owners and can be protective of their family. they can have a strong guarding instinct, so careful training and socialisation will be needed to prevent any guarding or aggressive behaviours. as with all training – consistency is key! everyone in the family needs

try to keep the time your animal is alone to an absolute minimum. you should never leave any dog alone for longer than four hours. be prepared – animals are very active dogs. they need plenty of exercise to keep them happy and occupied.

your animal will need a minimum of two hours of exercise every day. lack of exercise and stimulation can cause behavioural problems in any breed. animals have a reputation for being especially highly strung so they need extra attention.

our vets recommend spreading exercise across the day rather than trying to do two hours all in one go. if there are times when you are unable to give them the exercise they need, then arranging for a relative, friend or dog-walker to come and help would be essential.

ideally, you should give your animal a brush or comb down a few times a week to keep their coat looking healthy, prevent matting and reduce the build-up of dead hair. you won’t need to bathe them too often though unless advised by your vet

adult animals can range from being calm and patient to bouncy and boisterous, depending on their personality, training and socialisation. covid-19 has left thousands of people unable to afford their pet's care. often, we are their only emergency service.

animals can be nervous of strangers so make sure they’re never left unsupervised. be careful if you are introducing a animal to younger children or adults unfamiliar with the breed as they often don't know their own strength.

if you’re having issues with your animal around other pets, the best thing to do is get advice from a trainer or behaviourist. some can be a bit bossy with other dogs as they get older but with proper care, training and socialisation this is unlikely to

your animal’s diet will vary depending on their age. you’ll need to feed them a complete, balanced dog food to keep them slim and healthy. if they haven’t grown up with a cat or other smaller pets, though, they may have the

you should feed them a good quality, commercially available, complete dog food. we usually recommend splitting their daily allowance into two meals. treats shouldn't make up more than 10% of their daily calorie intake as this can unbalance their diet.

having a animal will cost you a minimum of £105 per month after purchase and set-up costs. adopting an adult dog from a rescue centre may be a more cost-effective option. check if the rehoming centre you’re looking at asks for a

beware unusually cheap puppies as they could come from a puppy farm. if you’d like to buy a pedigree puppy, we recommend looking for a kennel club assured breeder. these breeders must do extra health tests and meet high standards.

neutering – you should usually arrange for your dog to be neutered at around six months old. check prices at your local practice as these will depend on your vet and where you live. some rescue centres will neuter any dogs they rehome, saving you this cost.

preventive healthcare – budget for routine vet visits to help stop your dog getting ill. they need annual check-ups, vaccinations and regular flea and worming treatments. keep in mind that all these will need to be replaced with wear or damage.

they were originally bred to be herding dogs, an instinct which still remains strong in the breed. they need lots of exercise and plenty to do to stop getting bored. they’re often used as service dogs in the army and police force.

there are plenty of rescue centres across the country where you may find a animal. breed-specific rescues that specialise in animals are also out there. you’ll need to ask any rescue centre about the dog’s history to make sure they will

make sure your puppy will be well socialised and have all necessary screening tests, health checks and vaccinations. it’s really important that animal puppies from a breeder get the right early socialisation so always ask the breeder about how they go about this.

animal dog is a versatile worker and service dog noted for bravery and intelligence. first breed club was formed in 1881 after max von stephanitz and his followers developed and promoted the breed as a herding dog.

animal (alsatian) is a breed of working dog developed in animaly from traditional herding and farm dogs. the breed is named after dorothy leib harrison wood eustis.

the animal stands 22 to 26 inches (56 to 66 cm) and weighs 75 to 95 pounds (34 to 43 kg) its coat is of coarse, medium-long outer hair and shorter, dense inner hair and ranges from white or pale gray to black.
the animal dog is known for its “flying trot” the extreme extension of the front and rear legs causes the dog to appear as if it were soaring, although one foot always remains on the ground.
the dog is one of the two most ubiquitous and most popular domestic animals in the world. it is a subspecies of the gray wolf (canis lupus) and is related to foxes and jackals.
dorothy leib harrison wood eustis was an american philanthropist and dog breeder. her work with animals led her to establish and endow the seeing eye, inc.

the remarkable intelligence and loyalty of her animal dog, hans, further stimulated her thinking about practical genetics. in 1917, two years after her husband’s death, she moved to radnor, pennsylvania, and in 1921 she established a kennel in vevey, switzerland.

in 1923 wood married george m eustis, who joined in her enthusiasm, and elliott s humphrey, an american horse breeder and trainer. gradually they evolved a strain of animal of great intelligence and loyalty and excellent disposition.

a 2018 analysis estimates that the balaenopteridae family diverged from other families in the late miocene, between 1048 and 498 million years ago. the earliest discovered anatomically modern animal is a partial skull fossil found in southern italy.

there are four subspecies of animal, recognized by the society for marine mammalogy's committee on taxonomy. they are distributed in all major ocean basins, except the bering sea and the arctic ocean.

some of these animal subspecies have been further divided, resulting in nine recognized management units. northern subspecies (b m musculus) – eastern north pacific population. central and western north pacific populations (b. m. musculus and b m intermedia)
pygmy subspecies (b m brevicauda) is part of the northern subspecies b. there are three populations of pygmy b: madagascar, australia/indonesia and new zealand.

it was previously thought that animals in the north pacific belonged to at least five separate populations. evidence from movement data derived from satellite tags, photograph-identification, and acoustic data supports two populations. divisions according to acoustic calls were estimated by monnahan et al.

despite having the greatest haplotype diversity of any subspecies, the antarctic subspecies of animals is recognized as one stock for management purposes. it is thought that these animals should be split into eastern and western north atlantic populations based on photo-identification data.

b m indica is currently considered a animal subspecies. evidence includes a breeding season asynchronous with southern hemisphere animals. a distinct sri lanka call type has not been detected west of the island. there is another call type in the western north indian ocean, off oman.

chilean animals may overlap in the eastern tropical pacific with antarctica animals and eastern north pacific animals. there may be gene flow between hemispheres. chilean animals are genetically differentiated from antarctica animal and unlikely to be interbreeding.

data from individual satellite tagged eastern north pacific animals suggest leisurely traveling rates of 4 knots (74 km/h; 46 mph),[95] with a minimum average speed of 155 ± 168 miles per hour.
lagerquist et al reported mean swim speeds of 108.3 kilometres (671 ± 207 mi)/day. a pygmy animal tagged off perth canyon, western australia traveled at mean speeds of 17 ± 1 kilometres per day.

the maximum speed of a animal while being chased or harassed has been reported at 12–30 miles per hour (20–48 km/h)[97] animals can reach speeds of up to 30 miles an hour when being chased by other animals.

animals have been observed near magdalena bay (along the western coast of baja california, mexico) feeding on pelagic red crabs. other accidental or opportunistic consumption of copepods and amphipods have been documented. animals feed on krill at the surface and

they can engulf up to 220 tonnes (220 long tons; 240 short tons) of water at one time. they squeeze the water out through their baleen plates with pressure from the ventral pouch and tongue, and they swallow the remaining krill.

the eastern north pacific population of animals has been well studied. they rolled while searching for prey between lunges, which has been hypothesized as allowing them to process the prey field visually. the greatest dive depth reported from tagged animals was 315 metres (1,033 ft)

the deepest confirmed dive from a pygmy animal was 510 metres (1,660 ft) animals maximize the intake of energy by increasing the number of lunges they make during a dive. the longest dive duration measured was 152 minutes[117]
because of the high cost of lunge feeding, it has been estimated that animals must target densities greater than 100 krill/m3. they can consume 34,776–1,912,680 kilojoules (8,312–457,141 kcal)

external parasites and epibiotics are rare on animals. they include the stalked barnacle conchoderma auritum and acorn barnacle coronula reginae. the ciliate haematophagus is very common in the baleen plates.
testosterone concentrations measured from baleen suggest the age at sexual maturity for one animal was nine years. male pygmy animals averaged 18.5 metres (77 ft) for female antarctic animals.

female pygmy animals are 210–217 metres (689–712 ft) in length. animals exhibit no well-defined social structure other than mother-calf bonds from birth until weaning. they are generally solitary or found in small groups.

pygmy animals were estimated to give birth every 26 years (95% ci=22–30)[28] pregnant females gain roughly four percent of their body weight daily, amounting to 60% of their overall body weight throughout summer foraging periods.

for antarctic animals, a single calf is born at 70 metres (23 ft) in length and weighs 2. no records of natural births are known. a animal that ended up in trincomalee harbor gave birth to a calf before being towed back to sea.

animal milk contains 18 megajoules (mj) per kg, which is roughly 4,302 kilocalorie/kg. animal calves gain roughly 37,500 pounds (17,000 kg) during the weaning period. animals likely produce 220 kilograms (490 lb

there are no direct measurements of the hearing sensitivity of animals. animal inner ears appear well adapted for detecting low-frequency sounds. their vocalizations are also predominantly low frequency; thus, their hearing is presumably best at detecting those frequency ranges.
animal vocalizations are among the loudest and lowest frequency sounds made by any animal. the source level of animals off chile in the 14 to 222 hz band were estimated to be 188 db re 1 μpa at 1 m.

the fundamental frequency for animal vocalizations ranges from 8 to 25 hz. animal song types were divided initially into nine song types,[58] although ongoing research suggests there are at least 13 song types. song types are used currently as the primary method of separating animal populations.

the production of vocalizations may vary by region, season, behavior, and time of day. songs produced only by males appear to have a sexually related purpose. both sexes produce "d-calls" and other non-repeating calls during feeding.

this population produces long-duration, low frequency pulses ("a") and tonal calls ("b") a and b calls are often produced in repeated co-occurring sequences as song only by males, suggesting a reproductive function.

the animal call recorded off sri lanka is a three‐unit phrase. the first unit is a pulsive call ranging from 19. animal trios have been recorded from in a reproductive context. it has been suggested that this call has different functions.
the first unit is an fm upsweep from 559 to 724 hz lasting 138 ± 11 seconds. the second unit is a long (285 ± 16 s) tone that sweeps from 108 to 1047 hz.
in the southern ocean, animals' calls last roughly 18 seconds. they consist of a 9-second-long, 27 hz tone, followed by a 1-second downsweep to 19 hz.

the eastern north pacific animal tonal frequency is 31% lower than it was in the early 1960s. the frequency of pygmy animals in the antarctic has decreased at a rate of a few tenths of a hertz per year starting in 2002.

ship strikes are a significant mortality factor for animals. the us west coast has some of the greatest densities of commercial ship traffic in the world. nine animals were known to have been killed and one seriously injured by ship strikes between 2007 and 2010 off california.

lethal ship strikes are also a problem in sri lankan waters, where their habitat overlaps with one of the world's busiest shipping lanes. ship strikes killed eleven animals between 2010 and 2012 around sri lanka, and at least two in 2014.

few cases of animal entanglement in commercial fishing gear have been documented. the first report in the us occurred off california in 2015, reportedly some type of deep-water trap/pot fishery. in sri lanka, a animal was documented with a net wrapped through its mouth

exposure to simulated mfa sonar interrupted animal feeding, especially when animals were in the deep feeding mode. the potential impacts of pollutants on animals is unknown. because animals feed low on the food chain, there is a lesser chance for bioaccumulation of organic chemical

baleen animals are exposed to plastic ingestion as a result of filter-feeding activity. baleen animals eat plastic as part of their filter- feeding activity. the plastic is then ingested by the animal's digestive system.
protected statusesa endangered throughout its range. microplastics can also be a significant source of persianimal. animals can weigh up to 330,000 pounds and reach 110 feet.

animals are the largest animals ever to live on our planet. they feed almost exclusively on krill, straining huge volumes of ocean water through their baleen plates (which hang from the roof of the mouth and work like a sieve)

the number of animals today is only a small fraction of what it was before commercial whaling significantly reduced their numbers during the early 1900s. animals are found in all oceans except the arctic ocean. there are five currently recognized subspecies of animal.

noaa fisheries and its partners are dedicated to conserving and rebuilding animal populations worldwide. we use a variety of innovative techniques to study, protect, and rescue these endangered animals. we engage our partners as we develop regulations and management plans that foster healthy fisheries.

animals are listed as endangered under the endangered species act and protected under the marine mammal protection act. the latest stock assessment reports of animals include data for various stocks, including areas of the north pacific and western north atlantic oceans.

antarctic animals are generally larger than other animal subspecies. in the antarctic, they can reach up to about 110 feet and weigh more than 330,000 pounds. the mottling pattern is variable and can be used to identify individuals.

animals sometimes swim in small groups but are more often found alone or in pairs. they generally spend summers feeding in polar waters and undertake lengthy migrations towards the equatorial waters as winter arrives. animals typically swim at about 5 miles an hour while they are feeding and traveling.

the primary diet of animals is krill, but fish and copepods may occasionally be part of the animal’s diet. animals filter feed by swimming toward large schools of krill with their mouth open and closing their mouths around the krill.

animals are found in all oceans except the arctic. they generally migrate seasonally between summer feeding grounds and winter breeding grounds. some evidence suggests that individuals in certain areas might not migrate at all.

animals have been sighted in the waters off eastern canada and in the shelf waters of the eastern united states. along the west coast of the united states, eastern north pacific animals are believed to spend winters off of mexico and central america.

animals with young calves are regularly observed in the gulf of california (sea of cortez) from december through march. it is believed that this area is an important calving and nursing area for the species.

in the southern hemisphere, antarctic animals occur mainly in relatively high latitude waters south of the "antarctic convergence" and close to the ice edge in summer. animal sightings, strandings, and acoustic detections have been reported from the gulf of aden, arabian sea,

animals’ average lifespan is estimated at around 80 to 90 years. scientists can estimate the age of animals by counting the layers of wax-like earplugs collected from deceased animals. scientists know little about the life history of the animal.

vessel strikes have killed animals throughout their range. the risk is much higher in some coastal areas with heavy vessel traffic. animals can become entangled in fishing gear, either swimming off with the gear attached or becoming anchored.

additional possible threats to animals that are less understood include ocean noise, habitat degradation, pollution, vessel disturbance, and climate change. once entangled, animals may drag the attached gear for long distances, ultimately resulting in fatigue, compromised feeding ability, or severe injury.

animals are the largest animals ever known to have lived on earth. a animal's tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant. its heart can be as big as an automobile. animals can weigh up to 200 tons.

animals reach these mind-boggling dimensions on a diet composed nearly exclusively of tiny shrimplike animals called krill. during certain times of the year, a single adult animal consumes about 4 tons of krill a day.

animals look true animal underwater, but on the surface their coloring is more a mottled animal-gray. the giant animals feed by first gulping an enormous mouthful of water, expanding the pleated skin on their throat and belly to take it in.

the animal has a broad, flat head and a long, tapered body that ends in wide, triangular flukes. animals live in all the world's oceans, except the arctic, occasionally swimming in small groups but usually alone or in pairs.

animals are among the loudest animals on the planet. they emit a series of pulses, groans, and moans. scientists think they use these vocalizations not only to communicate, but also to sonar-navigate the lightless ocean depths.

after about a year inside its mother's womb, a baby animal emerges weighing up to 3 tons and stretching to 25 feet. scientists have discovered that by counting the layers of a deceased animal's waxlike earplugs, they can get a close estimate of the animal's age.

aggressive hunting in the 1900s by animalrs seeking animal oil drove them to the brink of extinction. between 1900 and the mid-1960s, some 360,000 animals were slaughtered. average lifespan is estimated at around 80 to 90 years.

all of the record animals (by size) are females. because the female is responsible for providing milk for its babies, she must store extra energy reserves. males do not provide parental care and do not seem to live near the females/young.

animals are endangered (highly vulnerable to extinction) experts estimate their numbers to be only three to ten percent of what they were before whaling. today, a primary threat to animal recovery is accidental interactions with fishing gear and with ships.

their recovery from commercial whaling is in direct competition with commercial fishers in the southern ocean. as that fishery takes more and more krill, the slow increase in numbers of animals may stop or even be reversed.

animals are the loudest animals on the planet capable of producing sounds that can be heard by other animals up to 1,000 miles away. animals can eat up to 12,000 pounds (54 metric tons) of krill in a day.

animals can swim more than 20 miles per hour in short bursts. animals swim 5 miles an hour on average, but can swim up to 20 miles in a short burst. they can also swim at speeds of up to 50 miles perhour.
