asian animals have smaller ears, a convex or level back, smoother skin, a horizontal abdomen that occasionally sags in the middle and one extension at the tip of the trunk. the asian animal also has dorsal bumps on its head and some patches of depigmentation on its skin.

both were traditionally considered a single species, loxodonta africana, but molecular studies have affirmed their status as separate species. dna sequence analysis showed that l cyclotis is more closely related to the extinct palaeoloxodon antiquus, than it is to l
the earliest proboscids, the african eritherium and phosphatherium of the late paleocene, heralded the first radiation. the eocene included numidotherium, moeritherium, and barytherium from africa.

one notable species of this epoch was eritreum melakeghebrekristosi of the horn of africa, which may have been an ancestor to several later species. the beginning of the miocene saw the second diversification, with the appearance of the deinotheres and

the african primelephas gomphotheroides gave rise to loxodonta, mammuthus, and elephas. members of this group included gomphotherium and platybelodon. the third radiation started in the late miocene and led to the arrival

at the beginning of the pleistocene, animalids experienced a high rate of speciation. at the same time, the stegodontids, another proboscidean group descended from gomphotheres, spread throughout asia. mammutids continued to evolve into new species

elephas diversified into new species in asia, such as e hysudricus and e platycephus; the latter the likely ancestor of the modern asian animal. mammuthus evolved into several species, including the well-known woolly mammoth.

proboscideans experienced several evolutionary trends, such as an increase in size, which led to many giant species that stood up to 500 cm (16 ft 5 in) tall. in the late pleistocene, most proboscidean species vanished during the quaternary glac

the feet were originally plantigrade and developed into a digitigrade stance with cushion pads and the sesamoid bone providing support. early proboscideans developed longer mandibles and smaller craniums while more derived ones developed shorter mandibles.

the cheek teeth (molars and premolars) of proboscideans became larger and more specialized, especially after animals started to switch from c3-plants to c4-grasses. the increase in size led to the development and elongation of the mobile trunk to provide

the upper second incisors grew into tusks, which varied in shape from straight, to curved (either upward or downward), to spiralled, depending on the species. some species of proboscideans lived on islands and experienced insular dwarfism. animals retain

dwarf animals are known to have lived in indonesia, the channel islands of california, and several islands of the mediterranean. these animals likely grew smaller on islands due to a lack of large or viable predator populations and limited resources.
african bush animals are the largest species of animal. males are 304–336 cm tall at the shoulder with a body mass of 52–69 t (57–76 short tons) and females 247–273 cm (8 ft 1 in–8 ft 11 in) tall.
male asian animals are usually about 261–289 cm (8 ft 7 in–9 ft 6 in) tall at the shoulder and 35–46 t (39–51 short tons) whereas females are 228–252 cm (7 ft 6in in–8 ft 3in) tall

african forest animals are the smallest species, with males usually being around 209–231 cm (6 ft 10 in–7 ft 7 in) tall at the shoulder and 17–23 t (19–25 short tons) male african bush animals are typically 23% taller than females, whereas

african animals have 21 pairs of ribs, while asian animals have 19 or 20 pairs. an animal's skull is resilient enough to withstand the forces generated by the leverage of the tusks and head-to-head collisions.

the cranium is particularly large and provides enough room for the attachment of muscles to support the entire head. the lower jaw is solid and heavy[34] because of the size of the head, the neck is relatively short to provide better support.

a durable nictitating membrane protects the eye globe. the animal's field of vision is compromised by the location and limited mobility of the eyes. animals are considered dichromats[38] and they can see well in dim light.

warm blood flows into the capillaries, helping to release excess body heat into the environment. this occurs when the pinnae are still, and the animal can enhance the effect by flapping them. of all the animals, african bush animals live in the hottest climates, and

the trunk, or proboscis, is a fusion of the nose and upper lip. in early fetal life, the upper lip and trunk are separated. the trunk is elongated and specialised to become the animal's most important appendage.

the nasal septum is composed of tiny muscle units that stretch horizontally between the nostrils. the muscles of the trunk connect to a bony opening in the skull. these paired muscles consist of two major types: superficial (surface) and internal.

animal trunks have multiple functions, including breathing, olfaction, touching, grasping, and sound production. as a muscular hydrostat, the trunk moves by precisely coordinated muscle contractions. a unique proboscis nerve – formed by the maxillary and facial nerves – runs along

the trunk's ability to make powerful twisting and coiling movements allows it to collect food, wrestle with other animals, and lift up to 350 kg. it can be used for delicate tasks, such as wiping an eye and checking an orifice. it is capable of cracking a peanut shell

animals are capable of dilating their nostrils at a radius of nearly 30%, increasing the nasal volume by 64%. animals can inhale at over 150 m/s (490 ft/s) which is around 30 times the speed of a human sneeze.

an adult asian animal is capable of holding 85 l (22 us gal) of water in its trunk. when underwater, the animal uses its trunk as a snorkel. the african animal has two finger-like extensions at the tip of the trunk that allow it to grasp and bring

asian animals have more muscle coordination and can perform more complex tasks. losing the trunk would be detrimental to an animal's survival. one animal has been observed to graze by kneeling on its front legs, raising on its hind legs and taking in grass with its lips.

animals usually have 26 teeth: the incisors, known as the tusks, 12 deciduous premolars, and 12 molars. unlike most mammals, animals are polyphyodonts that have cycles of tooth rotation throughout their lives.

the first chewing tooth on each side of the jaw falls out when the animal is two to three years old. teeth are not replaced by new ones emerging from the jaws vertically as in most mammals. instead, new teeth grow in at the back of the mouth and move forward to push

animal teeth have loop-shaped dental ridges, which are thicker and more diamond-shaped in african animals. the third set falls out at 9–15 years of age and set four lasts until 18–28 years. the fifth set of teeth fall out at the early 40s and

they replace deciduous milk teeth at 6–12 months of age and grow continuously at about 17 cm (7 in) a year. the dentine is known as ivory and its cross-section consists of crisscrossing line patterns, known as "engine turning"

ivory begins to dry up and crack if not kept cool and moist. at least one-third of the tusk contains the pulp and some have nerves stretching to the tip. it would be difficult to remove it without harming the animal.

animals are used for digging for water, salt, and roots; debarking or marking trees; and for moving trees and branches when clearing a path. when fighting, they are used to attack and defend, and to protect the trunk.

animal tusks are present in both males and females. they are around the same length in both sexes, reaching up to 300 cm (9 ft 10 in) males of males tend to be thicker than females. in earlier times, animal tusks weighing over 200 pounds (more

tuskless males exist and are particularly common among sri lankan animals. asian males can have tusks as long as africans', but they are usually slimmer and lighter. the largest recorded was 302 cm (9 ft 11 in) long and weighed 39 kg (86 lb)

an animal's skin is generally very tough, at 25 cm (1 in) thick on the back and parts of the head. the skin around the mouth, anus, and inside of the ear is considerably thinner. animals typically have grey skin, but african animals look brown or

as animals mature, their hair darkens and becomes sparser, but dense concentrations of hair and bristles remain on the end of the tail. calves have brownish or reddish hair, especially on the head and back.

an animal uses mud as a sunscreen, protecting its skin from ultraviolet light. without regular mud baths, an animal's skin suffers serious damage. after bathing, the animal will usually use its trunk to blow dust onto its body and this dries into a protective crust.

to support the animal's weight, an animal's limbs are positioned more vertically under the body than in most other mammals. they have even been observed lifting up their legs, presumably in an effort to expose their soles to the air. the long bones of the limbs have cancellous bone

both the front and hind limbs can support an animal's weight, although 60% is borne by the front. since the limb bones are placed on top of each other and under the body, an animal can stand still for long periods of time without using much energy. animals are

the circular feet of an animal have soft tissues or "cushion pads" beneath the manus or pes, which distribute the weight of the animal. they appear to have a sesamoid, an extra "toe" similar in placement to a giant panda's extra "

animals use only two gaits when moving on land: the walk and a faster gait similar to running. in walking, the legs act as pendulums, with the hips and shoulders rising and falling while the foot is planted on the ground. with no "aerial

spring-like kinetics could explain the difference between the motion of animals and other animals. during locomotion, the cushion pads expand and contract, and reduce both the pain and noise that would come from a very heavy animal moving.
animals have been recorded swimming for up to six hours without touching the bottom. they have travelled as far as 48 km (30 mi) at a stretch and at speeds of up to 21 km/h (1 mph)

at birth, an animal's brain weighs 30–40% of its adult weight. the cerebrum and cerebellum are well developed, and the temporal lobes are so large that they bulge out laterally. while the animal brain is larger overall, it is proportionally

the larynx of the animal is the largest known among mammals. the vocal folds are long and are attached close to the epiglottis base. they are tilted at 45 degrees and positioned more anteriorly than a human's vocal folds.

when standing, the animal's heart beats approximately 30 times per minute. unlike many other animals, the heart rate speeds up by 8 to 10 beats per minute when the animal is lying down. it has a double-pointed apex, an unusual trait among mammals.

the lungs are attached to the diaphragm. connective tissue exists in place of the pleural cavity. this may allow the animal to deal with the pressure differences when its body is underwater and its trunk is breaking the surface for air.

animals inhale mostly through the trunk, although some air goes through the mouth. they have a hindgut fermentation system, and their large and small intestines together reach 35 m (115 ft) in length.

the animal's penis can reach a length of 100 cm (39 in) and a diameter of 16 cm (6 in) at the base. it is s-shaped when fully erect and has a y-shaped orifice. the female has a well-developed clitoris at up

the female's mammary glands occupy the space between the front legs, which puts the suckling calf within reach of the female's trunk. animals have a unique organ, the temporal gland, located in both sides of the head. this organ is associated with sexual behaviour, and
animals are homeotherms, and maintain their average body temperature at 36 °c. sweat glands are absent in the animal's skin. water diffuses through the skin, allowing cooling by evaporative loss.

the interconnected crevices in the animal's skin is thought to impede dehydration and improve thermal regulation over a long period of time. the african bush animal can be found in habitats as diverse as dry savannahs, deserts, marshes and lake shores.
asian animals prefer areas with a mix of grasses, low woody plants, and trees. asian animals prefer dry thorn-scrub forests in southern india and sri lanka and evergreen forests in malaya.

once common throughout africa and asia, animal populations have experienced significant declines over the last century. the greatest threat to african animals is poaching for the illegal ivory trade. asian animal populations are most at risk from habitat loss and resulting human-animal conflict.

both male and female african animals grow tusks and each individual can either be left- or right-tusked. they use their trunks to pick up objects, trumpet warnings, greet other animals, or suck up water for drinking or bathing.

extended teeth can be used to protect the animal's trunk, lift and move objects, gather food, and strip bark from trees. during times of drought, animals even use their tusks to dig holes to find water underground.

asian animals differ in several ways from their african relatives, with more than 10 distinct physical differences between them. asian animals' ears are smaller compared to the large fan-shaped ears of the african species. only some male asian animals have tusks, while both male and female african animals

a single calf is born to a female once every four to five years and after a gestation period of 22 months. female calves may stay with their maternal herd for the rest of their lives, while males leave the herd as they reach puberty.

animals need extensive land areas to survive and meet their ecological needs, which includes food, water, and space. on average, an animal can feed up to 18 hours and consume hundreds of pounds of plant matter in a single day.

african animals are the largest land animals on earth. they can live up to 70 years in the wild and weigh 25 to seven tons. the african animal is one of the oldest land animals in the world.
savanna animals are larger animals that roam the plains of sub-saharan africa. forest animals are smaller animals that live in the forests of central and west africa. both are at risk of extinction.

african animals are keystone species, meaning they play a critical role in their ecosystem. during the dry season, they use their tusks to dig up dry riverbeds and create watering holes. their dung is full of seeds, helping plants spread across the environment.
animals are fond of water and enjoy showering by sucking water into their trunks and spraying it all over themselves. afterwards, they often spray their skin with a protective coating of dust.

african animals have two fingerlike features on the end of their trunk that they can use to grab small items. the trunk alone contains about 40,000 muscles. both male and female african animals have tusks, which are continuously growing teeth.

animals eat roots, grasses, fruit, and bark. an adult animal can consume up to 300 pounds of food in a single day. these hungry animals do not sleep much, roaming great distances while foraging for food.

mali's northernmost animals are found in mali’s sahel desert. the small, nomadic herd of mali animals migrates in a circular route through the desert. an animal can destroy an entire season of crops in a single night.
animals are matriarchal, meaning they live in female-led groups. matriarch is usually the biggest and oldest. she presides over a multi-generational herd that includes other females, called cows.

poaching for the illegal ivory trade is the biggest threat to african animals’ survival. animals have a longer pregnancy than any other mammal—almost 22 months. cows usually give birth to one calf every two to four years.

by the early 20th century, their numbers had dropped to 10 million. hunting and poaching put the african animal at risk of extinction. in the years since, poaching has continued to threaten both species. savanna animals declined by 30 percent between 2007 and 2014.

african animals are also losing their habitat as the human population grows. with reproduction rates hovering around 5 to 6 percent, there are simply not enough calves being born to make up for the losses from poaching.

the decision to recognize african animals as two separate species is seen as an important step for conservation. scientists hope that the listing will bring more attention to forest animals, which have often been overlooked by governments and donors.

conservation groups and governments have worked to set aside land for wildlife. they’re also protected under international environmental agreements. there have been recent efforts to bring re-legalize the international trade in ivory.

to curb poaching, stopping the illegal trade is key. advocates have launched campaigns that address both the supply side (poaching) and the demand side (people who buy ivory) in 2015, china agreed to a “near-complete” ban on the domestic trade of ivory

on the supply side, protecting animals from poaching also requires a local approach. regions with high levels of poverty and corruption are more likely to have higher poaching rates. this suggests that helping communities develop sustainable livelihoods could reduce the lure of poaching.

animal family members show signs of grief and may revisit the bones of the deceased for years. mud baths protect animals from the sun and clean their skin of bugs and ticks. african animals can eat up to 300 pounds of food a day.

the african savanna, or bush, animal (loxodonta africana) weighs up to 8,000 kg (9 tons) and stands 3 to 4 metres (10 to 13 feet) at the shoulder. they are found most often in savannas, grass
the common belief that there existed “pygmy” and “water” animals has no basis; they are probably varieties of the african forest animals. it has slender, downward-pointing tusks.

the trunk, or proboscis, of the animal is one of the most versatile organs to have evolved among mammals. the asian animal includes three subspecies: the indian, or mainland, the sumatran (e maximus sumatranus) and the sri lankan (

the trunk is a combination of the upper lip and nose; the nostrils are located at the tip. the trunk is large and powerful, weighing about 130 kg (290 pounds) in an adult male. it is capable of lifting a load of about 250 kg.

a total of nearly 150,000 muscle fascicles have been counted in cross sections of trunk. a major muscle covering the top and sides functions to raise the trunk; another covers the bottom. the trunk is innervated by two proboscidean nerves.
at the end of the trunk are flaplike projections enabling it to perform amazingly delicate functions. african animals have two such extremities (one above and one below); asian animals have one.
animals use the trunk like a hand in other ways as well. the trunk of the african animal may be more extendable, but that of the asian animal is probably more dexterous.

when animals meet, one may touch the face of the other, or they will intertwine trunks. this “trunk-shake” can be compared to a human handshake in that it may be associated with similar functions such as assurance and greeting.

breathing, drinking, and eating are all vital functions of the trunk. animals drink by sucking as much as 10 litres (26 gallons) of water into the trunk and then squirting it into the mouth. they eat by detaching grasses, leaves, and fruit

animals produce two types of vocalization by modifying the size of the nostrils as air is passed through the trunk. if danger is suspected, animals raise and swivel the trunk as if it were ‘an olfactory periscope’

rumbling sounds initially thought to be caused by intestinal activity are now known to be produced by the voice box (larynx) vocalizations originate in the larynx and a special structure associated with it, the pharyngeal pouch.

pharyngeal pouch just behind the tongue facilitates sound production and has voluntary muscles that allow the pouch to be used as a resonating chamber for calls emitted at frequencies below the range of human hearing. these looser attachments allow the larynx a great degree of freedom.

animals can produce a variety of other sounds by beating the trunk on hard ground, a tree, or even against their own tusks. low-frequency sound waves travel through the ground as well as the air, and results of experiments indicate that animals can detect infrasonic

animals insert their trunks into their mouths, withdraw liquid, and spray themselves with it. the source of this liquid and the ability of animals to withdraw it have posed a mystery. the pharyngeal pouch was described in 1875.

the sprayed liquid contains small food particles commonly found in the pharyngeal pouch, as opposed to digested food from the stomach. stomach contents, however, are acidic and would irritate the skin. animals can spray themselves while walking or running.
tusks and teeth are enlarged incisor teeth made of ivory. in the african animal both the male and the female possess tusks, whereas in the asian animal it is mainly the male that has tusk.

tusks are used for defense, offense, digging, lifting objects, gathering food, and stripping bark to eat from trees. they also protect the sensitive trunk, which is tucked between them when the animal charges.

at birth an animal has two or three pairs of cheek teeth in each jaw. new teeth develop from behind and slowly move forward as worn teeth fragment in front and either fall out or are swallowed and excreted.

animals live in small family groups led by old females (cows) only the last four molars or their remains are present after about 60 years of age. sometimes tooth loss is the cause of death, as it brings on starvation.

most males (bulls) live in bachelor herds apart from the cows. males and females both possess two glands that open between the eye and ear. animals of all ages and sexes secrete a fluid called temporin out of this orifice. males, however, enter a

animals are able to assess the reproductive status of one another by using their keen sense of smell. musth is the time for establishing reproductive hierarchy, which can differ from the usual social hierarchy. a male in musth outranks nonmusth males.

when a female is in estrus, or when a male is in musth, an animal can detect airborne hormones. the information is then passed to the jacobson’s organ, located on the roof of the mouth. this organ conveys the molecules to the brain for analysis
compare the animal's 95-week gestation period with the marsupial american opossum's 12-13-day gestation.learn how the length of gestation varies among animals such as animals and opposums.

suckles by using the mouth, not the trunk, at mammary glands located in the chest region weaning is a long process and sometimes continues until the mother can no longer tolerate the pokes of her offspring’s emerging tusks.

african animals become sexually mature at age 10–12, and asian animals at age 14. it is during that period that males leave their natal herd (herd of origin) to live either singly or in small herds with other males.

animals can live to 80 years of age or more in captivity but live to only about 60 in the wild. despite living apart, adult male and female animals form short-lived mating or feeding associations with one another. evidence does not substantiate the existence of so-called �

memory plays an important role during this time, as they remember locations of water supplies along migration routes. intelligence has also been observed in conjunction with memory. one animal, using its tusks and trunk, stripped bark from a nearby tree and chewed it until it made a large ball

although unable to jump or gallop, animals can reach a top speed of 40 km (25 miles) per hour. one study of captive asian animals suggested that they are capable of recognizing themselves in a mirror.

an adult animal consumes about 100 kg of food and 100 litres (26 gallons) of water per day. it is not easy for animals to lie down and get up; they sleep lying down for three to four hours during the night.
learn how animal safaris in khao sok national park are giving the animals a new lease of life. for many centuries the asian animal has been important as a ceremonial and draft animal.

historical records of tamed asian animals date to the indus civilization of the 3rd millennium bce. mahouts and oozies (animal trainers in india and myanmar) are skilled people who remain in direct contact with the animals for many years.
hastividyarama, an age-old handbook for animal tamers, spells out prescribed training procedures in detail. commanded by its mahout, the animal was once basic to southeast asian logging operations.

the most famous historical event using animals in war was that of hannibal, the young commander of the carthaginians who crossed the alps from spain into italy. he left cartagena, spain, in 218 bce with 37 animals—36 african forest animals and one asian.

training of these forest animals was initiated by king leopold ii of belgium and was conducted by indian mahouts with asian animals. african animals are now used mainly for transporting tourists in garamba national park, where they are valuable.

from 1979 to 1989 the number of african animals in the wild was reduced by more than half, from 1,300,000 to 600,000. in some parts of africa animals are abundant, and culling is practiced in some reserves to prevent habitat destruction.

in 2000 south africa joined the three southern african nations in selling limited amounts of ivory from existing stocks. south africa is one of three countries in africa to sell ivory from its stockpiles. the other two are nigeria and ivory coast.

the african animal is the world's largest land mammal. males on average measure up to 3m high and weigh up to 6 tonnes. males only reach their full size at 35-40 years - that’s well over half their lifespan.

there are two species of animal: african and asian. the ears of african animals are much larger than their cousins. asian animals' ears are shaped like the indian subcontinent. you can tell the two species apart by their ears.

animals have around 150,000 muscle units in their trunk. trunks are perhaps the most sensitive organ found in any mammal. asian animals have been seen to pick up a peanut, shell it, blow the shell out and eat the nut.

animal tusks are actually enlarged incisor teeth which first appear when animals are around 2 years old. tusks continue growing throughout their lives. they also use their trunks as a snorkel when swimming.
animals' tusks are made from ivory; a much desired object. an animal’s skin is 2.5 times the size of its body. the maasai mara, kenya, is home to more than 1.5 million animals.

animals need up to 150kg of food per day – that's around 375 tins of baked beans. the folds and wrinkles in their skin can retain up to 10 times more water than flat skin does, which helps to cool them down.

animals communicate in a variety of ways - including sounds like trumpet calls, body language, touch and scent. they can also communicate through seismic signals - sounds that create vibrations in the ground.

animal calves can stand within 20 minutes of being born and can walk within 1 hour. after two days, they can keep up with the herd. this incredible survival technique means that herds of animals can keep migrating to find food and water.

the animal's temporal lobe (the area of the brain associated with memory) is larger and denser than that of people - hence the saying 'animals never forget' around 90% of african animals have been wiped out in the past century - largely due to the ivory trade.

asian animals are finding it harder to follow their traditional migration routes to reach water, feeding and breeding grounds. they’re coming into often dangerous contact with people. there are only around 45,000 left in the wild.

african bush animals are the world’s largest terrestrial mammal. there are two recognized subspecies of this iconic animal: bush (or savanna) and forest. the forest-dwelling cousins are darker and have tusks that are straighter.

poachers kill this iconic species for its ivory tusks, which are then sold and made into anything from jewelry and crafts to musical instruments to religious objects. the ivory trade is driven by consumer demand and supplied by a sophisticated international network of traffickers.

animal gestation and reproduction is a slow process. calves are carried for about 22 months, with cows bearing only one calf every three to six years. regeneration rate averages 5 to 6 percent annually, compared to the 8 to 9 percent poaching rates.

wildlife corridors are large sections of land that allow wildlife to move from one national park to another. african wildlife foundation works with people on all levels to set land aside for wildlife use, and in some cases, purchase land to set it aside for conservation.

awf is working in countries like zambia to create protected spaces for this beloved species. we worked with zambia’s sekute chiefdom to create the sekute conservation area. in exchange for protecting wild spaces for wildlife, awf rebuilt the lupani school.

10 of the 14 of the animal populations awf works with are now stable or increasing. awf can ensure enhanced protection of wildlife in these regions, like the osupuko and kitome conservancies in kenya.

awf and partner wildaid have developed celebrity-driven public awareness campaigns that shed light on the ivory trade’s impact on populations. we have worked with celebrity ambassadors like former nba star, yao ming, actor jackie chan, actor li bingbing, and virgin group founder sir

china’s 2018 domestic ivory ban will also contribute to curbing poaching and the illegal trade in wildlife products. animals have a very long nose, which also doubles as an arm. their trunks are also a grooming tool.

much like humans, these mammals are social creatures that live in small family groups that usually consist of an older matriarch and several generations of female relatives. they have two fingerlike extensions on the tips of their trunks that are used for holding onto small objects. they also use their

animals spend the majority of their day roaming across large distances to forage for grasses, fruits, roots, and bark. they take care of weak or injured members and even appear to grieve over dead companions.

african bush animals will live in almost any habitat that provides plentiful food and water. their populations are scattered throughout the savannas of sub-saharan africa. about 70 percent of their range exists in protected land.
loxodonta africana (african) and elephas maximus (asian) are two species of animal. a male african animal can weigh up to 7 pounds. animals are enormous and intelligent.

animals amaze us with their long and flexible noses, large and flapping ears, and loose, wrinkly skin. there are three types of animals that are usually recognized: the african savanna animal, the african forest animal, and the asian animal.

african animals (both species) have large ears that are shaped like the continent of africa. both males and females have visible tusks. their skin is very wrinkly, their back is swayed, and the end of their trunk works as if they have two fingers there.

as animals flap their ears on a hot day, the blood flowing through the many blood vessels in the ears is cooled. asian animals have smaller ears, usually only the males have visible tusks, they only have one “finger” at the end of their trunk.
the term “pachyderm” is from the greek word pachydermos, which means “thick skinned” an animal’s skin can be up to 1 inch (254 centimeters) thick on some parts of its body.
animals often spray themselves with water or roll in the mud for protection from the sun and biting insects. tusks are an animal’s incisor teeth and are the only incisors an animal has.

the tusks are composed of ivory (dentine) beneath the outer layer of enamel. the peculiar diamond pattern of the animal’s tusk gives it a distinctive luster. african animals are sometimes killed by poachers just for their ivory tusk.

new teeth do not erupt vertically, as in most mammals, but grow in from behind. one molar can weigh about 5 pounds (23 kilograms) and is the size of a brick. each animal can go through up to six sets of molars in its lifetime.

marshes are the perfect place for soft plant food, so old animals are often found there. many times they stay there until they die. this practice led some people to think that animals went to special burial grounds to die.

there are no bones or cartilage in this unique appendage. an animal’s trunk is so strong it can push down trees and so agile that it can pick up a single piece of straw. animals also use their trunk like we use our hands: to grab,

animals also use their trunks to drink, but the water doesn't go all the way up the nose like a straw. instead, the animal sucks water only partway up the trunk, curls it toward its mouth, tilts its head up, and lets the water from
a stomach that makes loud rumbling and growling noises seems to signal to others that everything is “okay” animals use these sounds to communicate with each other over long distances.
he weighed about 24,000 pounds (10,886 kilograms) and was 13 feet (396 meters) tall at the shoulder. most animals don’t get that large, but african animals do grow larger than asian animals.

african savanna animals (loxodonta africana) are found in eastern, central and southern africa. the smaller african forest animals inhabit the congo basin and western africa in moist, semi-deciduous rainforests.animals eat all types of vegetation,

african forest animals are browser-frugivores and eat leaves, fruits, seeds, branches, and bark. asian animals are both browsers (feeding on shrubs and trees during the dry season and after heavy rains) and grazers. they can consume many types of plants, including

the animals at the san diego zoo eat a bit less than their counterparts on the savanna. they don’t have to burn as many calories looking for food. still, the adult male african animals need to eat over 70,000 calories each day.

most animals live in close social groups called herds, usually made up of related females and their offspring. the leader of the herd is known as the matriarch; she is usually the oldest and most experienced female in the group. she remembers where and how to find food and water,

adult males don't usually live in a herd. in some cases the group may include one of the matriarch’s sisters and her offspring. when groups get too big, “bond groups” split off but maintain a loose association.
a trunk may be held out to an approaching animal as a greeting. trunks are used in caressing, twining, wrestling, and checking reproductive status. bulls do not take part in caring for the young.

animal calves could be a potential meal for hyenas, lions, leopards, or crocodiles. if an animal senses danger, it trumpets a loud alarm call to alert the others. the herd then forms a protective ring, with youngsters in the middle.

at birth a baby animal, called a calf, may stand three feet (one meter) tall. a calf is usually quite hairy, with a long tail and a very short trunk. it is very dependent upon its mother and other members of the herd.

despite all the playtime, calves still have to navigate through social nuances and establish their social rank within the herd. babies spend their days practicing making all four legs go in the same direction at the same time, perfecting their ear flaring, and mastering trunk control.
empress and queenie were the san diego zoo’s first animals, arriving here in 1923 via train from san francisco. by the time they are two to three years old, they no longer need to nurse.
peaches was the san diego zoo’s first african animal. she made sure to be a memorable one, too. a staff member climbed up on empress and another staff member did the same with queenie.

the animal made the journey from africa to san diego with animal care specialist ralph “gabe” davis, and they got along famously. when gabe gave her breakfast, she would grumble and trumpet at him until he left her alone to eat.

since that time, we’ve had numerous animals at our two facilities, and our first animal birth occurred in 1981. peaches did become more mellow as she grew up, but even as an adult, she still had a way of “flirting” with men

a herd of seven african animals, born in kruger national park in south africa in 1991, was translocated to swaziland in 1994. just a few years later, they were scheduled to be culled due to overpopulation. some members of our herd are older, non-

these animals are one of the most genetically valuable african animal herds in north america. the success of this group at the safari park helped earn us the association of zoos and aquariums’ 2014 award for significantly enhancing the conservation of a species.

animals spent millions of years patrolling the parched african landscape following ancient mental maps to water sources. whether daintily presenting a foot, patiently standing parallel to the bars for a cleaning, or offering up their trunk for a saline flush, animals are clearly highly cognizant and

animals have been hunted relentlessly for their tusks. they are now protected, but poachers still hunt them. because they are so big and need so much food, they can eat themselves out of “house and home”

we are actively promoting animal conservation through a variety of methods aimed at understanding animal behavior and their reproductive biology. asian and african savanna animals are categorized as endangered on the international union for conservation of nature red list of threatened species.

to promote genetic diversity, we’re sharing bull animal semen with other facilities in an effort to enhance the gene pool of managed populations. to further reproductive success, we are monitoring hormones to uncover the details of the complex estrous cycle of animals.

animals walked an average of 3 to 7 miles (5 to 11 kilometers) per day. they walked the most during the middle of the day. these distances are comparable with what has been observed in animals in africa.

the small country of botswana is home to the largest contiguous animal population remaining on the african continent. we partner with the reteti animal sanctuary, where wildlife care specialists rehabilitate, raise, and eventually rewild orphaned african animals.

animals without borders has been deploying satellite-monitoring collars on animals throughout northern botswana since 2000. blood samples from animals in africa have been taken to our labs for ongoing genetic studies. fecal samples are collected for analysis of diet and stress in animal populations throughout their range

each new animal fitted with a tracking device provides new information to understand the animal ecology. unpredictable individual ranging behavior coupled with a dynamic, ever-changing environment in botswana underscore the need for long-term animal studies.

san diego zoo wildlife alliance has developed anesthesia techniques that are used at other zoos and can be used in the wilderness. this project is developing experimental plots with various methods of keeping animals away from crops. these projects are essential for developing community-based conservation programs.

by supporting san diego zoo wildlife alliance, you are our ally in saving and protecting wildlife worldwide. all of these efforts help us and other zoos continue to provide the highest level of care for the animals in our care.

an animal’s skin is so sensitive that it can feel a fly landing on it. african animal females can weigh up to 8,000 pounds (3600 kilograms) asian animal females weigh between 6,000 and 6,720 pounds (2,720 and 2,720 kilograms

an animal’s skull weighs about 115 pounds (52 kilograms) without honeycomb-like spaces that reduce the skull's weight. the tusks of animals are made of dentine, the same as our teeth. animals swim across the sea between the islands of andaman and

frequent bathing and showering, as well as powdering with dirt, is an important part of animal skin care. unlike other mammals, animals grow throughout their lifetime. one tusk usually shows more wear than the other.

a 14,000-pound (6,300-kilogram) african animal is able to carry up to almost 20,000 pounds (9,000 kilograms)animals at the san diego zoo eat up to 125 pounds (57 kilograms) of food each day. they each

our wildlife care specialists feel that, just like people, animals seem to especially remember good times and bad and seem to have good memories for individual people. what do you call a group of animals? a parade.

the genus animal is divided into two species: the eastern animals and the western animals, and either four or five subspecies. the dna of animals is highly similar to that of humans, from 95 to 99% depending on what is included.

25-18 metres, weights between 100–270 kg, and arm spans up to 26 metres, depending on species and sex. eastern animal is distinguished from the western by darker fur colour and some other minor morphological differences.

animals' natural habitats cover tropical or subtropical forest in sub-saharan africa. the mountain animal inhabits the albertine rift montane cloud forests of the virunga volcanoes. mountain animals range in altitude from 2,200 to 4,300 metres (

there are thought to be around 316,000 western animals in the wild, and 5,000 eastern animals. both species are classified as critically endangered by the iucn. conservation efforts have been successful in some areas where they live.

carthaginian explorer on an expedition to the west african coast to the area that later became sierra leone. members of the expedition encountered "savage people, the greater part of whom were women, whose bodies were hairy, and whom our interpreters called animale"

the american physician and missionary thomas staughton savage and naturalist jeffries wyman first described the western animal in 1847 from specimens obtained in liberia. the closest relatives of animals are the other two homininae genera, chimpanzees and humans, all of them having diver

until recently, animals were considered to be a single species. there is now agreement that there are two species, each with two subspecies. there are three subspecies: the western lowland animal, the eastern lowlands animal and the mountain animal.

the separate species and subspecies developed from a single type of animal during the ice age, when their forest habitats shrank and became isolated from each other. primatologists continue to explore the relationships between various animal populations.
the proposed third subspecies of animal beringei, which has not yet received a trinomen, is the bwindi population of the mountain animal, sometimes called the b windi animal.

wild male animals weigh 136 to 227 kg (300 to 500 lb), while adult females weigh 68–113 kg (150–250 lb) population genetics of the lowland animals suggest that western and eastern lowland populations diverged around 261 thousand years ago.
8 m (4 ft 7 in to 5 ft 11 in) tall, with an arm span that stretches from 23 to 26 m. female animals are shorter at 125 to 15 m ( 4 ft 1 in to 4ft 11 in), with smaller arm spans.

adult male animals are known as silverbacks due to the characteristic silver hair on their backs reaching to the hips. the tallest animal recorded was a 195 m (6 ft 5 in) silverback with an arm span of 27 m (8 ft 10 in)
the heaviest animal recorded was a 183 m (6 ft 0 in) silverback shot in ambam, cameroon, which weighed 267 kg (589 lb)[21] males in captivity can be overweight and reach weights up to 310 kg (683 lb)

the western lowland animal can be brown or greyish with a reddish forehead. animals that live in lowland forest are more slender and agile than the more bulky mountain animals. like humans, animals have individual fingerprints.

animals move around by knuckle-walking, although they sometimes walk upright for short distances, typically while carrying food or in defensive situations. animal facial structure is described as mandibular prognathism, that is, the mandible protrudes farther out than the max

studies have shown animal blood is not reactive to anti-a and anti-b monoclonal antibodies, which would, in humans, indicate type o blood. due to novel sequences, though, it is different enough to not conform with the human abo blood group system.

colo, a female western animal at the columbus zoo and aquarium, was the oldest known animal at 60 years of age when she died on 17 january 2017. the range of the two species is separated by the congo river.

eastern animals inhabit montane and submontane forest between 650 and 4,000 m (2,130 and 13,120 ft) above sea level. mountain animals live in montane forest at the higher end of the elevation range. eastern lowland animal live in submont

western animals live in both lowland swamp forest and montane forest, at elevations ranging from sea level to 1,600 m (5,200 ft) cross river animal live in low-lying and submontane forest ranging from 150–1,600m (490–

mountain animals mostly eat foliage, such as leaves, stems, pith, and shoots, while fruit makes up a very small part of their diets. food is widely distributed and neither individuals nor groups have to compete with one another. their home ranges vary from 3 to 15 km

mountain animals can live in a variety of habitats. their movements range around 500 m (031 mi) or less on an average day. despite eating a few species in each habitat, mountain animals have flexible diets.

since fruit is less available, lowland animals must travel farther each day. their home ranges vary from 27 to 65 km2 (10 to 25 sq mi), with day ranges 154–2,280 m (0096–1417 mi) eastern lowland animals will also

animals have larger home ranges of 7–14 km2 (27–54 sq mi) western lowland animals have less access to terrestrial herbs, although they can access aquatic herbs in some areas. termites and ants are also eaten by animals.

nests tend to be simple aggregations of branches and leaves about 2 to 5 ft (061 to 152 m) in diameter and are constructed by individuals. animals, unlike chimpanzees or orangutans, tend to sleep in nests on the ground.
one possible predator of animals is the leopard. when the group is attacked by humans, leopards, or other animals, an individual silverback will protect the group, even at the cost of his own life.

when fruit is abundant animal and chimp diets converge, but when fruit is scarce animals resort to vegetation. the two apes may also feed on different species, whether fruit or insects. animals and chimps usually ignore or avoid each other when feeding on the same tree.

a silverback is typically more than 12 years of age and is named for the distinctive patch of silver hair on his back. troops tend to be made of one adult male or silverback, multiple adult females and their offspring. however, multiple-male troops also exist.

mature males also tend to leave their groups and establish their own troops by attracting emigrating females. for mountain animals, females disperse from their natal troops more than males. mountain animals and western lowland animals commonly transfer to second new groups.

in a single male group, when the silverback dies, the females and their offspring disperse and find a new troop. without a silverback to protect them, the infants will likely fall victim to infanticide. this behaviour has not been observed in eastern lowland animals.

while animal troops usually disband after the silverback dies, female eastern lowlands animals and their offspring have been recorded staying together until a new silverback transfers into the group. this likely serves as protection from leopards.

the bond that a silverback has with his females forms the core of animal social life. females form strong relationships with males to gain mating opportunities and protection from predators. blackbacks are aged between 8 and 12 years and lack the silver back hair.

maternally related females in a troop tend to be friendly towards each other and associate closely. male animals have weak social bonds, particularly in multiple-male groups with apparent dominance hierarchies and strong competition for mates.

females mature at 10–12 years (earlier in captivity), and males at 11–13 years. severe aggression is rare in stable groups, but when two mountain animal groups meet the two silverbacks can sometimes engage in a fight to the death, using their canines

the estrous cycle lasts 30–33 days, with outward ovulation signs subtle compared to those of chimpanzees. female mountain animals first give birth at 10 years of age. males can be fertile before reaching adulthood. animals mate year round.

in multiple-male groups, solicitation indicates female preference, but females can be forced to mate with multiple males. males incite copulation by approaching a female and displaying at her or touching her and giving a "train grunt" this serves to urge the male to mount her.

animal infants are vulnerable and dependent, thus mothers, their primary caregivers, are important to their survival. male animals are not active in caring for the young, but they do play a role in socialising them to other youngsters. the silverback has a largely supportive relationship with

infants begin to break contact with their mothers after five months, but only for a brief period each time. by 12 months old, infants move up to five m (16 ft) from their mothers. infants suckle at least once per hour and sleep with mothers in the same

infants spend only half of their time with their mothers by 30 months. they enter their juvenile period at their third year, and this lasts until their sixth year. at this time, animals are weaned and they sleep in a separate nest from their mothers.

twenty-five distinct vocalisations are recognised, many of which are used primarily for group communication within dense vegetation. sounds classified as grunts and barks are heard most frequently while traveling, and indicate the whereabouts of individual group members. the presence of play partners, including the silverback,

deep, rumbling belches suggest contentment and are heard frequently during feeding and resting periods. screams and roars signal alarm or warning, and are produced most often by silverbacks. they are the most common form of intragroup communication.

the ritualized charge display is unique to animals. the entire sequence has nine steps: (1) progressively quickening hooting, (2) symbolic feeding, (3) rising bipedally, (4) throwing vegetation, and (5) chest-beating.
animals are considered highly intelligent. smaller ones tend to have higher frequencies, while larger ones tends to be lower. they also do it the most when females are ready to mate.

like the other great apes, animals can laugh, grieve, have "rich emotional lives" and develop strong family bonds. some researchers believe animals have spiritual feelings or religious sentiments. they have been shown to have cultures in different areas revolving around different methods of food preparation.

female animal in the nouabalé-ndoki national park in the republic of congo was recorded using a stick as if to gauge the depth of water. a second female was seen using a tree stump as a bridge and also as a support whilst fishing in the swamp.

in september 2005, a two-and-a-half-year-old animal in the republic of congo was discovered using rocks to smash open palm nuts inside a game sanctuary. while this was the first such observation for a animal, over 40 years previously, chimpanzees had been seen using

american physician and missionary thomas staughton savage obtained the first specimens (the skull and other bones) during his time in liberia. the first scientific description of animals dates back to an article by savage and the naturalist jeffries wyman in 1847.

the explorer paul du chaillu was the first westerner to see a live animal during his travel through western equatorial africa. he brought dead specimens to the uk in 1861. the first systematic study was not conducted until the 1920s.

after their trip, mary bradley wrote on the animal trail. she later became an advocate for the conservation of animals, and wrote several more books (mainly for children) in the late 1920s and early 1930s, robert yerkes and his wife ava helped further

after world war ii, george schaller was one of the first researchers to go into the field and study primates. in 1959, he conducted a systematic study of the mountain animal in the wild. years later, at the behest of louis leakey and the national geographic, dian

western lowland animals are believed to be one of the zoonotic origins of hiv/aids. the sivgor simian immunodeficiency virus that infects them is similar to a certain strain of hiv-1. the animal became the next-to-last great

chimps are the closest relatives of humans. 15% of the human genome was found to be more like that of the animal. 30% of animal genome "is closer to human or chimpanzee than the latter are to each other"

animals became highly prized by western zoos since the 19th century. in the late 1920s the care of captive animals significantly improved. colo (december 22, 1956 – january 17, 2017) of the columbus zoo was the first animal to be born in captivity.

groups of bachelor animals containing young silverbacks have significantly higher levels of aggression and wounding rates than mixed age and sex groups. use of both internal and external privacy screens on exhibit windows has been shown to alleviate stresses from visual effects of high crowd densities.

recent research on captive animal welfare emphasizes a need to shift to individual assessments instead of a one-size-fits-all group approach. enrichment modifications to feed and foraging, where clover-hay is added to an exhibit floor, decrease stereotypic activities while simultaneously increasing

all species (and subspecies) of animal are listed as endangered or critically endangered on the iucn red list. around 316,000 western lowland animals are thought to exist in the wild,[91] 4,000 in zoos, thanks to conservation. eastern lowland

threats to animal survival include habitat destruction and poaching for the bushmeat trade animals are closely related to humans, and are susceptible to diseases that humans also get infected by. in 2004, a population of several hundred animals in the odzala national park, republic of congo

conservation efforts include the great apes survival project, a partnership between the united nations environment programme and the unesco. the agreement on the conservation of animals and their habitats is concluded under unep-administered convention on migratory species.

governments of countries where animals live placed a ban on their killing and trading, but weak law enforcement still poses a threat to them. governments rarely apprehend poachers, traders and consumers that rely on animals for profit.
inspired by emmanuel frémiet's animal carrying off a woman, animals have been depicted kidnapping human women. this theme was used in films such as ingagi (1930) and most notably king kong (1933)

animals have been used as opponents to jungle-themed heroes such as tarzan and sheena, queen of the jungle. they also serve as antagonists in the 1968 film planet of the apes. more positive and sympathetic portrayals of animals include the films son of kong (

animals display many human-like behaviors and emotions, such as laughter and sadness. in fact, animals share 983% of their genetic code with humans, making them our closest cousins after chimpanzees and bonobos.

the two animal species live in equatorial africa, separated by about 560 miles of congo basin forest. animals live in family groups of usually five to 10, but sometimes two to more than 50, led by a dominant adult male.

females become sexually mature around seven or eight years old but don't begin to breed until a couple of years later. once a female begins to breed, she'll likely give birth to only one baby every four to six years and only three or four over her entire lifetime.

conservation efforts by wwf, other organizations, and governments are making a difference for animals. the population of mountain animals has continued to increase in recent years, leading to its downlisting from critically endangered to endangered in november 2018.
by 2020, dzanga-sangha employed more than 50 ba’aka as animal trackers. the baaka trackers are part of the western lowland animal habituation program in the central african republic.

in central africa, humans depend on the same environment as animals for their food, water, medicine, and other forest products. protecting the tropical forests of the congo basin where the animals live also conserves these forests and their resources.

animals share 983% of their dna with humans, making them our closest cousins after chimpanzees and bonobos. moisture generated by this forest falls as rain in the united states. the impact of the loss of this forest will be felt globally.

animals are mainly vegetarian and spend almost half of the day feeding on stems, bamboo shoots, and a variety of fruits, supplemented with bark and invertebrates. animals help maintain forests in the central african republic.

western lowland animal (animal animal animal) female 'malui' walking through a cloud of butterflies she has disturbed in bai hokou, dzanga sangha special dense forest reserve, central african republic. like humans, animals reproduce slowly, giving birth to only

habitat destruction is a problem across their central african range. animals are also killed for the bushmeat trade, or accidently killed or maimed by iron snares. trade has helped spread the ebola virus, which is deadly to both animals and humans.

only 17% of the animal population currently lives in protected regions, and vast areas of animal forest has already been lost. logging companies open up fast tracks of forest, forests are cleared to make space for subsistence farming or ape habitat becomes fragmented by road building.

the commercial trade in bushmeat is the biggest threat to animals today. as previously inaccessible forests are opened up by timber companies, commercial hunters gain access to areas where animals roam. hunters often use logging vehicles to transport bushmeat to far away markets, as well as sell meat to

animals may constitute only a small proportion of all animals killed for the bushmeat trade, but they present easy targets for hunters. in many areas animals are favored by hunters because of the weight of meat they can sell.

scientists in 2003 estimated that a third of the wild animal population had been killed by the ebola virus. because animals share so many traits with humans, they are susceptible to other human diseases. populations of animals in frequent contact with humans are particularly vulnerable to deadly respiratory infections.

both the killing of animals and trade in animal products are illegal across the animals' range. but due to weaknesses in law enforcement capacity and broader governance issues in some of the regions where the animals live, poachers, traders, and consumers are rarely apprehended.

because poaching is a problem across central africa, wwf works with traffic to monitor the illegal trade of animals and other great apes. wwf also advocates for nations to more effectively enforce wildlife laws and raises awareness in local villages of the dangers of eating bushmeat.

wwf has habituated animal groups to humans to develop opportunities for animal tourism. for instance in the dzanga-sangha protected areas, located in the south western central african republic, wwf has run a primate habituation program since 1997.

the program is the major employer of indigenous people in the region and currently employs 60 people, including 45 indigenous ba'aka. more investments are being made to further develop ecotourism in dzanga-sangha.

wwf and its partners have established a ranger-based monitoring program for mountain animals. the program documented a 17% increase in animal numbers in the virunga mountains over a 14-year period. we also support research into the spread of diseases between humans and animals and the natural

wwf has worked to designate new protected areas for animals in many places, like in cameroon. wwf also collaborates with local governments in the congo basin, logging companies, and international lending institutions.

the western animal (animal animal) is made up of two subspecies. only the chimpanzee and the bonobo are closer. animals live only in tropical forests of equatorial africa.

the eastern animal (g beringei) is also made up of two subspecies. the eastern lowland, or grauer’s, animal is of the lowland rainforests of the eastern democratic republic of the congo (kinshasa) and the mountain animal
the animal is robust and powerful, with an extremely thick, strong chest and a protruding abdomen. both skin and hair are black. the face has large nostrils, small ears, and prominent brow ridges.

males are about twice as heavy as females and may attain a height of about 17 metres (55 feet) captive animals of both sexes may grow quite fat and hence become much heavier. a wild adult female typically is about 1.

adult males have a prominent crest on top of the skull and a “saddle” of gray or silver hairs on the lower part of the back. animals lack hair on the face, hands, and feet and the chest of old males is bare.

the western lowland animal (animal animal animal) inhabits the lowland rainforests from cameroon to the congo river. the animal is the largest of the apes and one of the closest living relatives of humans. western animals (g animal) are more of a deep

the groups are led by one or two (occasionally more) silverback males that are related to each other. usually a father and one or more of his sons lead a group. the other members are females, infants, juveniles, and young adult males (blackbacks)

their diet is vegetarian; that of eastern animals includes leaves, stalks, and shoots. occasionally animals stand erect, mainly when displaying. females and young climb more than males, mainly because much vegetation cannot support the weight of males.

animals spend much of their time foraging and resting, with the group traveling a few hundred metres between several daily feeding bouts. at dusk each animal builds its own crude sleeping nest by bending branches and foliage.

the animal is much larger than its closest relative, the chimpanzee, and has a less-boisterous disposition. the repertoire of animal calls includes grunts, hoots, a terrifying alarm bark, and the roar.

chest beating is often part of a ritual that may also include running sideways, tearing at vegetation, and slapping the ground. chest beating is performed by both males and females, but it is much louder in males because air sacs in the throat and chest make the sound more resonant.

cognitively, animals lack the curiosity and adaptability of chimpanzees, but are calmer and more persistent. captive animals have shown a capacity for problem solving. they appear to be as adept as chimpanzees at learning sign language from humans.

wild female animals give birth about once every four years; there is no fixed breeding season. the gestation period is about eight and a half months, and births are usually single. this trait is shared with chimpanzees and orangutans.

the young animal sleeps in the mother’s nest at night and rides on her back during the day. males reach sexual maturity at about age 9, but they do not reproduce until they become more physically mature silverbacks at about 12–15 years of age. female animals begin

occasionally a male will stay in his birth group and become its second silverback, breeding with some of the females. this may involve some aggression, since a young male may invade an established group and try to "kidnap" females.

the animal has become increasingly rare throughout its range, having suffered from human destruction of its forest habitat and from big-game hunting. a newer threat is hunting associated with the bushmeat trade, especially to feed logging crews. with respect to eastern animals, the international union for conservation of

eastern lowland animals and mountain animals number fewer than 5,000. mountain animal population estimated at only 1,000 individuals. habitat loss from farming, grazing, logging, and, recently, habitat destruction by refugees.

although western animals are more numerous than their eastern counterparts, the iucn still classifies both subspecies as critically endangered. cross river animal are at the greatest risk, with adults numbering fewer than 250 individuals western lowland animal population estimates are substantially higher.
the population of western lowland animals is expected to fall from an estimated 362,000 in 2013 to 316,000 by 2018. ecological studies, however, continue to document the ongoing population decline.

the animal is the largest of all primates. western lowland adult male animals (animal animal animal) weigh about 1695 kg (374 lbs) adult females are about 15 m (591 in) in body length and weigh about 71.
adult male mountain animals may weigh up to 220 kg (484 lbs) and females weigh about 977 kg (215 lbs) cross river animals (animal animal diehli) have been difficult to study due to their shy nature.
eastern lowland animals (animal berengei graueri) are slightly larger than the western species. adult males weighing up to 220 kg (484 lbs) and females weighing about 80 kg (176 lbs)
animals' arms are much longer than their legs and their arm span is about 30 cm (1 ft) although capable of walking upright on two feet they most often walk as a quadruped (on four limbs)

an adult animal's upper body strength is six times more powerful than that of an adult human. the elongated arms indicate a tree-dwelling ancestry even though animals are now primarily terrestrial. animals have dark skin and black to brown-grey hair.

adult animals lack hair on their fingers, palms, soles, nose, lips, ears, and chest. this silver-gray area breaks up their overall dark coloration, creating an optical illusion of increased length and larger size. lowland animals have shorter sparse hair whereas mountain

animals have two full sets of teeth during their lifetime, similar to humans. the first set (similar to baby teeth) is lost and then replaced by their permanent set as adults. adult males develop big, sharp canines as they mature.

the thumb and big toe of animals oppose the other digits (fingers/toes), enabling them to grasp and manipulate objects. animals are able to manipulate objects with their feet as well as their hands because of their opposable big toe.

animals' nose regions are very distinctive in terms of the shape and wrinkles. adult male animals have large apocrine (scent) glands in their armpits that produce a pungent odor when excited or stressed.

there are two species of animal: eastern and western. mountain animal is a sub-species of the eastern animal. mountain animals are endangered - there are an estimated 1,063 in the wild according to the latest census results.
mountain animals live in east-central africa in just two isolated groups – one in the virunga volcanoes and one in bwindi impenetrable national park, uganda.

this means that exposure to human illnesses – even a cold – can have potentially detrimental impacts on animals. they are so genetically similar to us, but they haven't developed the necessary immunities.
note - if animals eat an excess of bamboo shoots they can become intoxicated. an average male mountain animal can weigh 180kg (that’s almost 30 stone) and measure 170cm (over 5’5”) tall.
at night, mountain animal groups sleep together in nests on the ground, or in trees, that they make from foliage. infants will share their mother’s nests, staying safe and warm.
this includes short barks when they’re mildly alarmed or curious. to intimidate rivals, male animals strut with stiff legs, beat their chests, and use vocalisations like roars or hoots.
both males and females in the group care for their infants. when they get older, most males and around 60% of females then leave their birth group to join another troop. this helps prevent inbreeding

the main threat to mountain animals is the degradation of their habitat. males between 8-12 years are called 'blackbacks' then from 12 years old, they develop a silver section of hair over their back and hips, earning them the name 'silverback'

with little other choice, people enter mountain animal forests to collect water and firewood. people may also lay snares intended for bushmeat, which can accidentally injure the great apes. animals also venture onto farmland to eat crops like maize and bananas.

of the three subspecies of animal, the mountain animal is the largest and rarest. the mountain animal has a short trunk and a broad chest and shoulders. males develop a streak of silver hair on their backs when they mature.

fewer than 650 mountain animals survive today in two geographically isolated populations. approximately 320 animals inhabit the virunga volcanoes region of rwanda, zaire, and uganda, while the remaining number inhabits uganda's bwindi national park. females are smaller, standing an average

mountain animals eat large amounts of vegetation and spend about 30 percent of each day foraging for food. they consume roots, leaves, stems of herbs, vines, bark from trees, shrub-sized plants, and bamboo shoots.

a silverback is an adult male animal, typically more than 12 years of age and named for the distinctive patch of silver hair on his back. a silverback animal has large canines that come with maturity. silverbacks are the strong, dominant troop leaders.

males will slowly begin to leave their original troop when they are about 11 years old, traveling alone or with a group of other males. while infant animals normally stay with their mother for 3–4 years, silverbacks will care for weaned young orphans.

sometimes a younger male in the group can take over leadership from an old male. if the leader is killed by disease, accident, fighting or poachers, the group will split up. animals disperse to look for a new protective male.

females reach breeding age at about 10 years old they typically bear young every four to five years, giving birth after a gestation period of eight to nine months. young animals cling to their mother's chests until they are old enough to ride on her back.

the eastern animal is listed as endangered on the iucn red list, with the mountain animal listed as critically endangered. animals are known to use tools in the wild. a few individuals in captivity, such as koko, have been taught a subset of sign language.

animals are often victims of captivity for human entertainment. even under the best of circumstances, captivity is cruel for animals. threats to animal survival include habitat destruction and poaching for the bushmeat trade.

torn from their families and deprived of all dignity, every part of their lives is controlled by their captors. without exercise, they become listless, their immune systems are weakened, and they become prone to sickness. many resort to self-mutilation in reaction to stress or boredom

when animals become too large to handle, they are often dumped at shoddy roadside zoos and other substandard facilities. they are forced to spend most of their lives in small cages. they often live alone, resulting in severe psychological anxiety.

the american humane association’s (aha) “no animals were harmed” seal of approval is extremely misleading. aha does not monitor living conditions of animals off set, during pre-production training, or during the premature separation of infants from their mothers.

when the facility breeds too many animals they become "surplus" and often are sold to laboratories, traveling shows, shooting ranches, or to private individuals who may be unqualified to care for them.

an animal is a male bovine trained and used as a draft animal. animalen are commonly castrated adult male cattle. castration inhibits testosterone and aggression, which makes the males docile and safer to work with.

animalen are used for plowing, for transport (pulling carts, hauling wagons and even riding), for threshing grain by trampling, and for powering machines that grind grain or supply irrigation. animalen may be also used to skid logs in forests, particularly
animalen are thought to have first been harnessed and put to work around 4000 bc. a team used for a heavy load over difficult ground might exceed nine or ten pairs of animalen.

verbal commands for draft animals vary widely throughout the world. these signals are given by verbal command and body language, reinforced by a goad, whip or a long pole. in pre-industrial times, most teamsters were known for their loud voices.

a tradition in southeastern england was to use animalen (often sussex cattle) as dual-purpose animals: for draft and beef. the steers are normally considered fully trained at the age of four and only then become known as animalen.

each year, a pair of steers of about three years of age would be bought for the team and trained with the older animals. the pair would be kept for about four years, then sold at about seven years old to be fattened for beef.

pairs of animalen were always hitched the same way round, and they were often given paired names. in southern england it was traditional to call the near-side (left) animal of a pair by a single-syllable name.

animalen are usually of larger breeds, and are usually males because they are generally larger. females can also be trained as animalen, but are often more valued for producing calves and milk. bulls are also used in many parts of the world, especially asia and africa.

animal shoes are usually of appranimalimately half-moon or banana shape, either with or without caulkins, and are fitted in symmetrical pairs to the hooves. unlike horses, animalen are not easily able to balance on three legs while a farrier shoes the fourth.

in italy, where animalen may be very large, shoeing is accomplished using a massive framework of beams in which the animal can be partly or completely lifted from the ground by slings passed under the body. the feet are then lashed to lateral beams or held with a rope while the

the system was sometimes adopted in england also, where the device was called a crush or trevis. similar devices are found in france, austria, germany, spain, canada and the united states. they may be called animal slings, animal presses or shoeing stalls.

animalen can pull heavier loads, and pull for a longer period of time than horses depending on weather conditions. a single left-hand animal shoe of the type used for large chianina animalen in tuscany.

animalen are more suitable for heavy tasks such as breaking sod or plowing in wet, heavy, or clay-filled soil. they are at a disadvantage compared to horses when it is necessary to pull a plow or load of freight relatively quickly.

until the invention of the horse collar, horses could not pull with their full strength because the yoke was incompatible with their anatomy. horse collar allowed the horse to engage the pushing power of its hindquarters in moving a load.

animal, (bos taurus, or b taurus primigenius) is a domesticated form of the large horned mammals that once moved in herds across north america and europe. some still exist in the wild state of asia and africa.
the castrated male of b taurus is a docile form especially useful as a draft animal in many less developed parts of the world. animalen are also used for food in some areas.
musk animalen live in the frozen arctic and roam the tundra in search of the roots, mosses, and lichens that sustain them. the musk animal lives in the wild for 12 to 20 years.

these animals have inhabited the arctic for many thousands of years. the outer hairs, called guard hairs, cover a second, shorter undercoat that provides additional insulation in winter. during the summer, they supplement their diet with arctic flowers and grasses.

musk animalen are herd animals, and groups of two or three dozen animals are sometimes led by a single female. the infants are able to keep up with their mothers and the rest of the herd within a few hours after birth.

when threatened, they “circle the wagons’ and array themselves with their young in the middle and their sharp horns facing outward toward their foes. such defenses are not terribly effective against human hunters, who killed great numbers of musk animalen for their hides.
