animal (ovis aries) are quadrupedal, ruminant mammals. they are typically kept as livestock. animal is a common name for animal in the uk and the u.s.

the name animal applies to many species in the genus ovis. in everyday usage it almost always refers to ovis aries. numbering a little over one billion, domestic animal are also the most numerous species of animal.

one of the earliest animals to be domesticated for agricultural purposes, animal are raised for fleeces, meat (lamb, hogget or mutton) and milk. a animal's wool is the most widely used animal fiber, and is usually harvested by shearing. ovine

animal husbandry is practised throughout the majority of the inhabited world, and has been fundamental to many civilizations. australia, new zealand, the southern and central south american nations, and the british isles are most closely associated with animal production.

being a key animal in the history of farming, animal have a deeply entrenched place in human culture. a group of animal is called a flock. many other specific terms for the various life stages of animal exist.

animal figure in many mythologies and major religions, especially the abrahamic traditions. in both ancient and modern religious ritual, animal are used as sacrificial animals. animal are used in many religious rituals, such as the golden fleece.
the exact line of descent between domestic animal and their wild ancestors is unclear. main article: history of the domestic animal. for more information on domestic animal, visit: www.animal.org.uk.

animal were among the first animals to be domesticated by humankind. the domestication date is estimated to fall between 11,000 and 9,000 b. the european mouflon is a direct descendant of this popuation.

the rearing of animal for secondary products, and the resulting breed development, began in either southwest asia or western europe. initially, animal were kept solely for meat, milk and skins. selection for woolly animal may have begun around 6000 bc.

in about 6000 bc, during the neolithic period of prehistory, the castelnovien people, living around châteauneuf-les-martigues in the south of france, were among the first in europe to keep domestic animal. practically from its inception

domestic animal are relatively small ruminants, usually with a crimped hair called wool and often with horns forming a lateral spiral. pliny the elder speaks at length about animal and wool. european colonists spread the practice to the new world from 1493 onwards.

a few primitive breeds of animal retain some of the characteristics of their wild cousins. depending on breed, domestic animal may have no horns at all (ie polled), or horns in both sexes. most horned breeds have a single pair, but a few breeds may have several.

colors of domestic animal range from pure white to dark chocolate brown. selection for easily dyeable white fleeces began early in animal domestication. wild animal are largely variations of brown hues, and variation within species is extremely limited.

white wool is desirable for large commercial markets. there is a niche market for colored fleeces, mostly for handspinning. the nature of the fleece varies widely among the breeds, from dense and highly crimped, to long and hairlike.

depending on breed, animal show a range of heights and weights. their rate of growth and mature weight is a heritable trait that is often selected for in breeding. ewes typically weigh between 45 and 100 kilograms (100 and 220 lb), and rams between 45 to 160 kilograms

mature animal have 32 teeth. as with other ruminants, the front teeth bite against a hard, toothless pad in the upper jaw. these are used to pick off vegetation, then the rear teeth grind it before it is swallowed.

in the first few years of life one can calculate the age of animal from their front teeth. a pair of milk teeth is replaced by larger adult teeth each year. the full set of eight adult front teeth is complete at about four years of age.

the life expectancy of a animal is 10 to 12 years, though some animal may live as long as 20 years. domestic animal on normal pasture begin to slowly decline from four years on. animal have good hearing, and are sensitive to noise when being handled.

foot glands might also be related to reproduction. alternative functions, such as secretion of a waste product or a scent marker to help lost animal find their flock, have also been proposed. animal and goats are closely related: both are in the subfamily caprinae.

the differences between animal and goats include the beard of goats and divided upper lip of animal. animal tails also hang down, even when short or docked, while the short tails of goats are held upwards. a hybrid of a ewe and a buck (a male goat) is called

with the modern rise of corporate agribusiness and the decline of localized family farms, many breeds of animal are in danger of extinction. for meat and hide producers, hair animal are cheaper to keep, as they do not need shearing. hair animal are also more resistant to parasites

like all ruminants, animal have a complex digestive system composed of four chambers. animal break down cellulose from stems, leaves, and seed hulls into simpler carbohydrates. animal graze well in monoculture pastures where most goats fare poorly.

the bolus is periodically regurgitated back to the mouth as cud for additional chewing and salivation. the fermenting organisms include bacteria, fungi, and protozoa. after fermentation in the rumen, feed passes into the reticulum and omasum.

other than forage, the other staple feed for animal is hay, often during the winter months. the abomasum is the only one of the four chambers analogous to the human stomach, and is sometimes called the "true stomach"

animal follow a diurnal pattern of activity, feeding from dawn to dusk, stopping sporadically to rest and chew their cud. feed provided to animal must be specially formulated, as most cattle, poultry, pig, and even some goat feeds contain levels of copper that are lethal

types of land where animal are raised vary widely, from pastures that are seeded and improved intentionally to rough, native lands. common plants toxic to animal are present in most of the world, and include cherry, some oaks and acorns, tomato, yew, rhubarb

animal prefer to eat invasives such as cheatgrass, leafy spurge, kudzu and spotted knapweed over native species such as sagebrush. research conducted in imperial county, california compared lamb grazing with herbicides for weed control in seedling alfalfa

animal are flock animals and strongly gregarious; much animal behavior can be understood on the basis of these tendencies. the dominance hierarchy of animal and their natural inclination to follow a leader to new pastures were the pivotal factors in animal being one of the first domesticated livestock species.

all animal have a tendency to congregate close to other members of a flock, although this behavior varies with breed. animal can become stressed when separated from their flock members. during flocking, animal have a strong tendency to follow, and a leader may simply be the first individual to move

[22] animal can become hefted to one particular local pasture (heft) so they do not roam freely in unfenced landscapes. lambs learn the heft from ewes and if whole flocks are culled it must be retaught to the replacement animals.

cornered animal may charge and butt, or threaten by hoof stamping and adopting an aggressive posture. this is particularly true for ewes with newborn lambs. in regions where animal have no natural predators, none of the native breeds of animal exhibit a strong flocking behavior.

farmers exploit flocking behavior to keep animal together on unfenced pastures. for this purpose shepherds may use herding dogs in this effort. animal are food-oriented, and association of humans with regular feeding often results in animal soliciting people for food.

animal establish a dominance hierarchy through fighting, threats and competitiveness. dominant animals are inclined to be more aggressive with other animal, and usually feed first at troughs. rams with different size horns may be less inclined to fight to establish the dominance order.

in animal, position in a moving flock is highly correlated with social dominance, but there is no definitive study to show consistent voluntary leadership by an individual animal. their flocking behavior and quickness to flee and panic can make shepherding a difficult endeavor for the uninitiated.

animal can recognize individual human and ovine faces and remember them for years. if worked with patiently, animal may learn their names. many animal are trained to be led by halter for showing and other purposes.

it has been reported that some animal have apparently shown problem-solving abilities. a flock in west yorkshire, england allegedly found a way to get over cattle grids by rolling on their backs. animal have been used as pack animals by tibetan nomads.

sounds made by domestic animal include bleats, grunts, rumbles and snorts. bleating ("baaing") is used mostly for contact communication, especially between dam and lambs. the bleats of individual animal are distinctive, enabling the ewe and her lambs to

good depth perception, inferred from the animal's sure-footedness, was confirmed in "visual cliff" experiments. animal are thought to have colour vision, and can distinguish between a variety of colours: black, red, brown, green, yellow and white.

most lambs will begin standing within an hour of birth. in normal situations, lambs nurse after standing, receiving vital colostrum milk. lambs that either fail to nurse or are rejected by the ewe require help to survive, such as bottle-feeding.

docking and castration are commonly done after 24 hours (to avoid interference with maternal bonding and consumption of colostrum) and are often done not later than one week after birth. vaccinations are usually carried out at this point as well.

pinnipeds are a widely distributed and diverse clade of carnivorous, fin-footed, semiaquatic, mostly marine mammals. they comprise the extant families odobenidae, otariidae (the eared animals: sea lions and fur animals), and phoc

pinnipeds belong to the order carnivora. their closest living relatives are bears and the superfamily of musteloids (weasels, raccoons, skunks, and red pandas) they diverged about 50 million years ago.

otariids use their front limbs primarily to propel themselves through the water, while phocids and walruses use their hind limbs. they have streamlined bodies and four limbs that are modified into flippers.

otariids have visible external ears, while phocids and walruses lack these pinnipeds have well-developed senses. their eyesight and hearing are adapted for both air and water. some species are well adapted for diving to great depths.

although pinnipeds are widespread, most species prefer the colder waters of the northern and southern hemispheres. they spend most of their lives in the water, but come ashore to mate, give birth, molt or escape from predators.

male pinnipeds typically mate with more than one female (polygyny), although the degree of polygyny varies with the species. the males of land-breeding species tend to mate with a greater number of females than those of ice breeding species.

mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for a relatively short period of time while others take foraging trips at sea between nursing bouts. animals produce a number of vocalizations, notably the barks of california sea lions, the gong-like calls of walruses

animals have been depicted in various cultures worldwide. they are commonly kept in captivity and are even sometimes trained to perform tricks and tasks. once relentlessly hunted by commercial industries for their products, animals and walruses are now protected by international law.

the name "pinniped" derives from the latin words pinna "fin" and pes, pedis "foot" the common name "animal" originates from the old english word seolh, which is in turn derived from the proto-germanic *selkh

the german naturalist johann karl wilhelm illiger was the first to recognize the pinnipeds as a distinct taxonomic unit. in 1811 he gave the name pinnipedia to both a family and an order. american zoologist joel asaph allen reviewed the world's pinn

in 1989, annalisa berta and colleagues proposed the unranked clade pinnipedimorpha to contain the fossil genus enaliarctos and modern animals. pinnipeds belong to the order carnivora and the suborder caniformia.

otariids are also known as eared animals due to the presence of pinnae. the anterior end of an otariid's frontal bones extends between the nasal bones. the supraorbital foramen is large and flat horizontally.

otariids consist of two types: sea lions and fur animals. sea lions are distinguished by their rounder snouts and shorter, rougher pelage. fur animals have more pointed snouts, longer fore-flippers and thicker fur coats.

while sea lions and fur animals have historically been considered separate subfamilies (otariinae and arctocephalinae respectively), a 2001 genetic study found that the northern fur animal is more closely related to several sea lion species. this is supported by a 2006 molecular study

walruses are capable of turning their hind-flippers forward and can walk on land. this animal is easily distinguished from other extant pinnipeds by its larger size. walruses have nearly hairless skin and long upper canines, known as tusks.

phocids are known as true or "earless" animals. these animals lack external ear flaps and are incapable of turning their hind-flippers forward, which makes them more cumbersome on land. walruses have pterygoid bones that are broad and thick.

phocids have thickened mastoids, enlarged entotympanic bones, everted pelvic bones and massive ankle bones. they also lack supraorbital processes on the frontal and have underdeveloped calcaneal tubers. a 2006 molecular study supports the division of phocids

pinnipeds split from other caniforms 50 million years ago (mya) during the eocene. morphological and molecular evidence support a monophyletic origin. there is some dispute as to whether pinniped are more closely related to bears or musteloids

puijila had a long tail, short limbs and webbed feet instead of flippers. puijila likely had been a quadrupedal swimmer. it retained a form of aquatic locomotion that gave rise to the major swimming types employed by modern pinnipeds.

enaliarctos, a fossil species of late oligocene/early miocene (24–22 mya) california, closely resembled modern pinnipeds. the discovery of puijila in a lake deposit suggests that pinniped evolution went through a freshwater transitional phase

enaliarctos emlongi exhibited notable sexual dimorphism, suggesting that this physical characteristic may have been an important driver of pinniped evolution. a closer relative of extant pinnipeds was pteronarctos, which lived in oregon 19–15 my

the extinct family desmatophocidae lived 23–10 mya in the north atlantic. they had elongated skulls, fairly large eyes, cheekbones connected by a mortised structure and rounded cheek teeth. they also were sexually dimorphic and may have been capable of propelling

the ancestors of the otarioidea and phocoidea diverged 33 mya[24] phocids are known to have existed for at least 15 million years. the fossil monachine monotherium and phocine leptophoca were found in southeastern north america

phoca and pusa could have arisen when a phocine lineage traveled from the paratethys sea to the arctic basin and subsequently went eastward. the ancestor of the baikal animal migrated into lakebaikal from the arctic (via the siberian ice sheet) and

the two extant elephant animal species diverged close to 4 mya after the panamanian isthmus was formed. monachus emerged in the mediterranean and migrated to the caribbean and then the central north pacific. the lobodontine lineage emerged around 9 mya and colonized the

otariids originated in the north pacific. the earliest fossil pithanotaria, found in california, is dated to 11 mya. the callorhinus lineage split earlier at 16 mya zalophus, eumetopias and otaria diverged

primitive walruses had much shorter canines and lived on a fish diet rather than a specialized mollusk diet. odobenids further diversified in the middle and late miocene several species had enlarged upper and lower canines. the genera valenictus and od

pinnipeds have streamlined, spindle-shaped bodies with reduced or non-existent external ear flaps, rounded heads, flexible necks, limbs modified into flippers, and small tails. pinniped skulls have large eye orbits, short snouts and a constricted interorb
pinnipeds range in size from the 1 m (3 ft 3 in) and 45 kg (99 lb) baikal animal to the 5 m (16 ft) and 3,200 kg (7,100 lb) southern elephant animal. compared to other carnivorans

several species have male-biased sexual dimorphism that correlates with the degree of polygyny in a species. males of sexually dimorphic species also tend to have secondary sex characteristics, such as the prominent proboscis of elephant animals.

almost all pinnipeds have fur coats, the exception being the walrus, which is only sparsely covered. even some fully furred species (particularly sea lions) are less haired than most land mammals. in species that live on ice, young pups have thicker coats

pinnipeds are typically countershaded, and are darker colored dorsally and lighter colored ventrally. some species, such as ribbon animals, ringed animals and leopard animals, have patterns of contrasting light and dark coloration.

blubber serves both to keep the animals warm and to provide energy and nourishment when they are fasting. it can constitute as much as 50% of a pinniped's body weight. pups are born with only a thin layer of blubber, but some species compensate

most species have neither a cecum nor a clear demarcation between the small and large intestines. small intestine lengths range from 8 times (california sea lion) to 25 times (elephant animal) the body length. the length of the intestine may be an adaptation to frequent

[42] as in most marine mammals, the kidneys are divided into small lobes and can effectively absorb water and filter out excess salt. pinnipeds have two pairs of flippers on the front and back, the fore-flipper and hind-flippers.
pinnipeds tend to be slower swimmers than cetaceans, typically cruising at 5–15 kn (9–28 km/h; 6–17 mph) for several species of dolphin. animals are more agile and flexible,[38] and some otariids

when swimming, otariids rely on their fore-flippers for locomotion in a wing-like manner similar to penguins and sea turtles. they also lack arrector pili, so their fur can be streamlined as they swim.

compared to terrestrial carnivorans, the fore-limbs of otariids are reduced in length, which gives the locomotor muscles at the shoulder and elbow joints greater mechanical advantage. phocids and walruses swim by moving their hind-flippers and lower body from side

pinnipeds can move around on land, though not as well as terrestrial animals. otariids and walruses are capable of turning their hind-flippers forward and under the body so they can "walk" on all fours. in addition, sea lions are known

otariids rely on the movements of their heads and necks more than their hind-flippers during terrestrial locomotion. sea lions have been recorded climbing up flights of stairs. phocids are less agile on land, and move on land by lunging, bouncing and wigg

the eyes of pinnipeds are relatively large for their size and are positioned near the front of the head. one exception is the walrus, whose smaller eyes are located on the sides of its head. terrestrial locomotion is easier for phocids on ice, as they

a animal's eye is adapted for seeing both underwater and in air. the lens is mostly spherical, and much of the retina is equidistant from the lens center. pinnipeds also have very muscular and vascularized irises.

when contracted, the pupil is typically pear-shaped, although the bearded animal's is more diagonal. in species that live in shallow water, such as harbor animals and california sea lions, dilation varies little, while the deep-diving elephant animals have much greater variation.

ice-living animals like the harp animal have corneas that can tolerate high levels of ultraviolet radiation typical of bright, snowy environments. as such, they do not suffer snow blindness. they also have a well-developed tapetum lucidum, a reflecting layer that increases sensitivity

the extraocular muscles of the walrus are well developed. this and its lack of orbital roof allow it to protrude its eyes and see in both frontal and dorsal directions. animals release large amounts of mucus to protect their eyes.

the pinniped ear is adapted for hearing underwater, where it can hear sound frequencies at up to 70,000 hz. in air, hearing is somewhat reduced in pinnipeds compared to many terrestrial mammals. while they are capable of hearing a wide range of frequencies (e.

one study of three species found that the sea lion was best adapted for airborne hearing, the harbor animal was equally capable of hearing in air and water, and the elephant animal was better adapted for underwater hearing. their airborne hearing sensitivity is weaker overall.

pinnipeds have well-developed tactile senses. their mystacial vibrissae have ten times the innervation of terrestrial mammals. they can effectively detect vibrations in the water. these vibrations are generated, for example, when a fish swims through water.

harbor animals have been observed following varying paths of another animal that swam ahead several minutes before. blind ringed animals have even been observed successfully hunting on their own in lake saimaa, likely relying on their vibrissae to gain sensory information and catch prey.

vibrissae of phocids are undulated and wavy while otariid and walrus vibrissae are smooth. research is ongoing to determine the function, if any, of these shapes on detection ability. the vibrissa's angle relative to the flow, not the

[69] walruses have the most vibrissae, at 600–700 individual hairs. these are important for detecting their prey on the muddy sea floor. spotted animals appear to use them to detect breathing holes in the ice.

pinnipeds can reinflate their lungs even after complete respiratory collapse. the middle ear contains sinuses that probably fill with blood during dives, preventing middle ear squeeze. the heart of a animal is moderately flattened to allow the lungs to deflate.

the main adaptations of the pinniped circulatory system for diving are the enlargement and increased complexity of veins to increase their capacity. animals can tolerate large amounts of lactic acid, which reduces skeletal muscle fatigue during intense physical activity.

pinnipeds have high amounts of hemoglobin and myoglobin stored in their blood and muscles. this allows them to stay submerged for long periods of time while still having enough oxygen. these tissue masses, which contain extensive contorted spirals of arteries and thin-walled veins,

pinnipeds conserve heat with their large and compact body size, insulating blubber and fur, and high metabolism. when diving, they reduce their heart rate and maintain blood flow only to the heart, brain and lungs.

veins containing cool blood from the body extremities surround arteries, which contain warm blood received from the core of the body. heat from the arterial blood is transferred to the blood vessels, which then recirculate blood back to the core. the same adaptations that conserve heat while in

the northern fur animal pants to help stay cool, while monk animals often dig holes in the sand to expose cooler layers to rest in. scientists have recorded them sleeping for minutes at a time while slowly drifting downward in a belly-up orientation.

living pinnipeds mainly inhabit polar and subpolar regions, particularly the north atlantic, the north pacific and the southern ocean. when they are asleep on land, both sides of their brain go into sleep mode.

monk animals and some otariids live in tropical and subtropical waters. animals usually require cool, nutrient-rich waters with temperatures lower than 20 °c (68 °f) even those that live in warm or tropical climates live in areas that become cold and nutrient rich

as a whole, pinnipeds can be found in a variety of aquatic habitats. most animals inhabit coastal areas, though some travel offshore and feed in deep waters. the baikal animal is the only exclusively freshwater species.

crabeater animal is one of 32 species of web-footed aquatic mammals that live chiefly in cold seas. in temperate and tropical areas, they haul out on to sandy and pebble beaches, rocky shores, shoals, mud flat.

animals are carnivores, eating mainly fish, though some also consume squid, other mollusks, and crustaceans. unlike other animals, the leopard animal (hydrurga leptonyx) of the antarctic feeds largely on penguins, seabirds,
technically, animals and sea lions are in the same taxonomical suborder of pinnipeds. but they also have some key anatomical differences. can you tell a animal from a sea lion?

the largest is the male elephant animal (genus mirounga leonina) of coastal california (including baja california, mexico) and south america. it can reach a length of 65 metres (21 feet) and a weight of 3,700 kg (8,150

animals possess a thick layer of fat (blubber) below the skin, which provides insulation, acts as a food reserve, and contributes to buoyancy. animals are endemic to lake baikal, southeastern siberia, russia.

they are fairly small, with little difference in size between the sexes. ringed animals have blotches over their entire bodies, harp animals have a large blotch of black on otherwise mostly silver-gray fur. harbour animals (p vitulina) have a marbled coat,

though especially abundant in polar seas, animals are found throughout the world. some species favour the open ocean and others inhabiting coastal waters or spending time on islands, shores, or ice floes.
the weddell animal (leptonychotes weddellii) of the antarctic can dive for up to 73 minutes and up to 600 metres. animals cannot swim as fast as dolphins or whales but are more agile in the water.

because the hind flippers cannot be moved forward, these animals propel themselves on land by wriggling on their bellies or pulling themselves forward with their front limbs. eared animals rely mainly on the rowing motion of their front flippers for propulsion.

all animals must come ashore once a year to breed. nearly all are gregarious, at least when breeding, with some assembling in enormous herds on beaches or floating ice. most form pairs during the breeding season, but in some species, such as fur animals, males (bulls
cows are again impregnated soon after giving birth. pups are born on the open ice or in a snow lair on the ice. the young gain weight rapidly, for the cow’s milk is up to about 50 percent fat.

animals have been hunted for their meat, hides, oil, and fur. the pups of harp animals, for example, are born with white coats that are of value in the fur trade. the fur animals of the north pacific ocean and the ringed animals of north atlantic

animal hunting, or animaling, was so widespread and indiscriminate in the 19th century that many species might have become extinct. the severe decline of animaling worldwide after world war ii and the effects of international agreements aimed at conserving breeding stocks enabled several severely depleted species to replenish their

there are 33 species of pinnipeds alive today, most of which are known as animals. pinnipedia is made up of three main groups: the walrus, the eared animals and the earless animals.

pinnipeds can be found on every continent on earth, though most species occur in cold-water environments. thick layers of fat, also known as blubber, keep the animals warm, in addition to dense fur. walruses are the exception to the rule, as

the word pinniped means "fin-footed" in latin. all pinnipeds are considered semi-aquatic marine mammals. this means they must spend some part of their lives on land or sea ice, usually during the mating and birthing seasons.

nearly all animal species are reliant on marine habitats, though some will enter estuaries and rivers in search of food. an outlier is the baikal animal, which spends its whole life in lakebaikal, a freshwater lake in siberia.

for instance, leopard animals make a living hunting down penguins and even other animals. and walruses survive on a diet of clams and other shellfish, which they detect with their whiskers and then suction up from the seafloor.

historically, hunters have heavily targeted pinniped species for their fur. the caribbean monk animal, for instance, disappeared from the planet in the 1970s. instead, these animals use highly specialized teeth to filter water for tiny, abundant crustaceans.

climate change represents the single largest threat to many species of pinnipeds, especially those that rely on sea ice. some species, like the hawaiian monk animal and mediterranean monk animal, remain very close to extinction.

ringed animals build caves in the snow and create holes in the ice that give them access to the ocean. if that snow melts earlier than usual, it will put the animals at greater risk of predation from polar bears.
animals are the acrobats of the sea, but they are very clumsy on land. with its cute, round eyes, animals see very well under water. however, they would need eyeglasses to see sharply above water.

animals eat primarily fish. they use their whiskers for locating prey in these turbid waters. animals can feel the slightest movements in the water. they like to lie in the sun while resting on a sandbar or beach.

animals do not have a preference for one specific fish species, but they usually catch fish that live close to the sea bottom. flatfish, lesser sandeel and cod species are their favorite food, although what they eat can vary per season.

a animal swims just as readily on its back as on its belly, standing upright or upside down. their mother doesn’t teach them the tricks. in this period, young animals lose a lot of weight but eventually learn it on time.

animals can dive down to depths of hundreds of meters. during the first few minutes, they swim actively downwards, after which they go into a kind of gliding flight. their blood can absorb much more oxygen than human blood.

the heart beat of a animal increases to 120 beats per minute in order to provide enough oxygen for the organs. this means they don’t need to breathe as often. when they ascend from deep depths, they can pump out the inhaled air from the air sacs.

animals can’t walk since their hind fins lie in extension of their body. in the course of millions of years, they have adapted in all kinds of ways to life in the sea. all these adaptations have made them very clumsy on land.

animals sleep in the water as well as on land. in the water, they sleep floating in a standing position, like a fishing bobber. animals drag their body over the ground with the help of their front flippers.

there are known incidents where animals stay under water up to half an hour, however on the average, their stay is not longer than fifteen minutes. most parts of the animal are well insulated with a thick layer of blubber.

when it gets very cold, animals can pinch off the blood flow to their skin in order to preserve the heat. they also use their flippers to regulate the body temperature. blood flowing to the flippers is cooled down by blood returning to the body.

by regulating the temperature in this way, animals always have cold feet! that is why, as soon as the sandbanks appear above the surface, they try to keep their flippers out of the water. in that way, they lose less heat and are warmed by the sun.

animals are well insulated with a thick layer of fat, with the exception of their head and flippers. when they lie on a dry spot but where they water still advances, they hold up these parts to keep them dry.
adult animals hardly ever drink. they get their fresh water that they need from the fish they eat. when they haven’t eaten for awhile, the water comes from burning their blubber.
their kidneys are specially adapted to separating that salt and ridding it via the urine. they pee, but sparsely. the urine is very concentrated and is sometimes saltier than the seawater.

you might possibly even detect whether or not it was a male or female by the position of this pit in relationship to the animal’s imprint. the penis opening of the male is relatively high up, just under the navel. with females, the opening is much closer to the
harbor animals get a new coat in the summer, grey animals in march-april. when it is very cold or the animals need to flee a lot into the cold water, the molting process is slowed down.

animals are able to rest in peace on the sandbanks during the molting process. the process decelerates when there is a lack of blood in the skin. animals are born in the summer months, grey animals in the winter.

grey animal pups can’t swim due to this heavy coat. they are very adorable with their long white hair but it is also a bit awkward. mother returns regularly to nurse, which they do for an average of three to four weeks.

the number of animals in the wadden sea region is well documented. they are usually 10 kilos at birth and 40 kilos when they stop nursing. young animals must teach themselves that fish is edible and how to catch them.

of the animals that inhabit the international wadden region (netherlands, germany and denmark), the large majority are harbor animals. one third of the population is then under water, so the scientists add 30% to the total counted.

grey animals are found primarily around the scottish islands, along the british east coast and in cornwall. they are also found along the english, french and belgium coasts, in the danish skagerrak and along the southern coast of norway. in december 1999, there was even a young animal seen

in the dutch wadden sea alone, a total of 4565 grey animals were counted in the winter of 2017-2018. the largest groups are located west of terschelling, but small groups or individuals are sometimes seen elsewhere. the german islands of helgoland and amrum

animals can also survive in fresh water. they used to swim regularly upriver. most rivers are now closed off by sluices in the netherlands, it’s no longer easy to reach fresh water nevertheless, it still happens.

in addition to the harbour animal and the grey animal, an occasional arctic animal species will wander into these regions. for example, ringed animals from the northern baltic sea and even harp animals are sometimes reported.

in 1986, several hooded animals washed ashore on the coasts of france, belgium and the netherlands. this ‘mini’ invasion was possibly related to a hunting party on the island of jan mayen in the northern arctic sea.

animals were heavily hunted in the north sea region in the past. despite the fact that hunting animals in the wadden and north seas ended more than 40 years ago and the animal population has grown, they are still threatened.

every day, large loads of disposed wastes flow into the north sea. in addition, disturbances from shipping and recreation are problems for the animals. other threats include drowning in fykes and other fish nets.

the concentrations of poison are highest in those species of animals living closest to the coastline. plankton absorbs the poison, which is how it enters the food chain. eventually, they accumulate in marine mammals via the benthic animals and the fish.

another problem for animals in the north sea and wadden sea is the increasing activity. tourists and military activities disturb resting animals. this kind of disturbance is especially a threat during the summer when harbour animal pups are born.

water police take action against tourists that are getting too close to animals an average of four times a day. animals are much less sensitive to disruption in the water than on land. they even tend to swim towards people who get too close.

since 1994, all fykes in dutch tidal waters are required to be equipped with a retaining net, specifically to keep out animals. once in the fyke, the animal cannot get out and drowns. this retaining net is a large-meshed net at the entrance to

in the past, premiums were offered for shooting animals due to the damage they supposedly caused. this argument is still used in norway and canada to rectify culling animals. all dutch harbour animals together consume less than (1-2%) what the fisheries bring on land.

locally, standing rigging and fykes can be affected by hungry animals. the animals damage both the nets and the catch when stealing fish. scottish and norwegian salmon farms are also regularly visited by grey animals.

both the harbour animal and grey animal are on the red list for mammals. when developing policy, the government and managing organizations are required to take animals into consideration. in addition, a animal covenant was signed in 1988 in bonn, germany.

animal reservations were designated to prevent disruption to resting and nursing animals. these reservations are also closed areas in the summer, when the animal pups are birthed and nursed. in other european waters, the harbour animal and grey animal fall under protection of the eu habitat directive

flippered and charismatic, pinnipeds (which includes animals, sea lions, and walruses) are true personalities of the sea. like whales, manatees, and sea otters, they are marine mammals, meaning millions of years ago their ancestors evolved from a

it’s easy to tell the enormous, tusked walrus from other pinnipeds, but animals and sea lions are easy to confuse. strong flippers and tails propel them and a streamlined body helps them cut through the water efficiently.

life at sea requires a powerful and streamlined body. pinnipeds have adapted sleek, torpedo-shaped bodies that can cut through the water without producing significant drag. sea lions have extremely flexible bodies, and can almost bend their bodies in half.

despite looking similar, animals and sea lions propel themselves through the water in different ways. in a sweeping motion, they stretch their long flippers out to the side and then quickly tuck them into their body. some species spend the majority of their life in the ocean.

sea lions are the only aquatic mammals that swim this way. animals, walruses, whales, otters, and others rely on the back end of their bodies to produce thrust. instead, the sea lion tail is used like a rudder.

sea lions generate thrust, or forward propulsion, by bringing their fore-flippers together in big sweeping motions called “claps” when a sea lion ‘claps,’ it stretches its flippers out to the sides and sweeps them down then it tucks its

when traveling long distances, sea lions are known to employ a swimming technique called porpoising. as the sea lion dashes across the sea surface it breaches the surface in a series of consecutive leaps. then it tucks its flippers against its body, forming a torpedo shape that gl

northern elephant animals spend 85 to 95 percent of their time underwater and make massive migrations up to 13,000 miles long. animals, too, have key adaptations that make them efficient swimmers, like lots of blubber to make them buoyant.

when resting, a animal’s heart will beat at about 100 beats per minute, but when diving it can slow to as low as five beats a minute. they accomplish this by both decreasing their heart rate to below resting state and by constricting their peripheral blood vessels.

animals use hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying molecules in human blood. they also have a second molecule in their muscle tissue called myoglobin that also carries oxygen. with every breath they obtain about 90 percent of the oxygen inhaled.

pressure is also a problem that animals and sea lions have successfully worked around. increased pressure that is greater than the atmosphere forces nitrogen gas into the blood. as pressure decreases (during an ascent) that same nitrogen will turn back into gas.

right before a dive, pinnipeds will exhale all the air out of their lungs. this ensures nitrogen gas cannot dissolve from the lungs into the blood. as they dive their lungs shrink and fold until essentially flat.

on land, animals and sea lions also have different methods for getting around. sea lions, fur animals, and walruses are able to rotate their rear flippers up and under their bodies so that they can waddle on all four flippers.

traveling requires the back and forth shift of weight from their upper body to their pelvic region, almost like a caterpillar. animals, however, cannot do this and instead shimmy on their bellies. they can travel fast enough on land to overtake a human.

harbor animals obtain about 90 percent of their freshwater from the fish they eat. once the food is ingested, pinnipeds retain the water for as long as possible. pinniped kidneys are especially efficient at retaining water.

marine mammals are larger than mammals on land, an adaptation that minimizes the area of skin in contact with the water. elephant animals and walruses can weigh up to 4 tons, and even the smallest animals are notably rotund.

the peninsula valdes in argentina was inscribed on the world heritage list in 1999. the site is home to important breeding populations of the endangered southern right whale (eubalaena australis), southern elephant animal (mirounga leonina), and southern sea lion.
fur animals rely on two layers of fur, an outer protective layer and an underfur that traps air bubbles and insulates the skin. baby harp animals have roughly 300,000 underfur hairs per square inch.

at times when a pinniped is too warm, blood is brought to the skin and to the flippers, where it is exposed to the cold water or air. when the pinnipes is too cold this system runs warm blood from their inner bodies out to their extremities next

pinnipeds need to see both above and below the sea surface. good eyesight in either location requires very different adaptations. since walruses lack fur, the rushing blood to the extremities causes the skin to turn a rosy red hue.

as light travels through the air and enters the eye, it bends to the appropriate angle and creates a focused image on the retina. underwater, terrestrial animals become farsighted because the fluid of the eye and the water are too similar.

having acute vision underwater means that on land a pinniped is nearsighted, especially in low light. when in bright sunlight, however, the pupil contracts, allowing only a pinhole for light to enter the eye.

pinnipeds gulp their food whole, which may be why they have a very limited sense of taste. one study showed that a sea lion had an altered gene responsible for detecting sweetness, meaning they cannot taste sweets. they also lack umami taste receptors that detect savory taste

covering the faces of pinnipeds are whiskers called vibrissae. these hairs are extremely sensitive to touch, and can even detect sound vibrations. they can determine the shape of an object placed in front of their face and detect water movement.

as pinniped ancestors made the transition from land to sea they needed to adapt to a life both underwater and on land. hearing all comes down to the perception of vibrations, and underwater sound vibrations cause the entire skull to vibrate.

california sea lions are social animals, forming groups of hundreds to thousands of animals that gather onshore to breed. they have massive ear bones and the ability to close the ear canal when underwater. pinnipeds scan their head side to side to help them pinpoint the source of a sound

scent is used as an alert mechanism when predators (like humans) are nearby and as a way for males to determine whether a female is ready to mate. scent is also an important way for mothers and pups to bond.

pinnipeds include the families odobenidae (walrus), phocidae (true animals), and otariidae (fur animals and sea lions) today, there are 33 species some species exhibit sexual dimorphism, meaning the two sexes look distinctly different.

across the globe there are 19 species of animal. most are ocean dwellers, living in places spanning from the arctic, to the tropics, to antarctica. the baikal animal, however, lives in a landlocked lake in the middle of asia.

there are nine species of fur animals, which are close relatives of sea lions. true animals lack ear flaps and propel themselves through the water with their hind flippers. when on land they shimmy like a caterpillar.
fur animals rely on a thick coat of fur that includes both a waterproof undercoat and a top “guard” hair coat. males are larger than females—in some species they can be up to four times larger.

there are five species of sea lion. sea lions (and fur animals) distinguished from true animals by their comparably large front flippers, visible ear flaps, and ability to curl their back flippers under their body to walk on all fours.

unlike fur animals, sea lions do not have a significant fur coat and instead rely on blubber to stay warm. they are also social creatures, sometimes congregating in social groups of up to 1,500 individuals.

the world's largest population of pacific walrus (odobenus rosmarus divergens) reside in the natural system of wrangel island reserve site in russia. the walrus is the only remaining species of its genus. there are two distinct subspecies of wal
walruses' tusks help them forage for clams and mussels in the muddy seafloor. the earliest ancestors of animals and sea lions were mammals that transitioned from life on land to life at sea.

pinnipeds evolved from the ancestors of the musteloids which include everything from the red panda to skunks, badgers weasels, and raccoons. the pinniped’s ancestors were likely drawn to the ocean due to its abundance of food.

fully flippered pinnipeds did not emerge until roughly 17 million years ago off the coast of modern-day washington and oregon. since it likely walked on all four limbs, scientists consider puijila to be a transition species that illustrates the evolution from land animal to marine

all four of their limbs were flippered, and they likely propelled themselves through the water using both the front and back flippers. for some, it means hauling out of the sea in massive rookeries on shore, while for others it can mean finding a sturdy ice floe

only a select few males get the opportunity to mate, resulting in fierce competition over territory. males have evolved to be much larger than females, a characteristic called sexual dimorphism. drawing on large reserves of blubber, males dutifully remain on land and guard their territory.

about a month after males come ashore the females begin to arrive. such territoriality means bulls stay on land for up to three months to guard their territory. bulls will even forgo feeding during this period.

many are pregnant from the last year’s mating season and within a few days they give birth. the next few days are dedicated to bonding, a necessity for the coming months when mom will leave to find food in the ocean.

once bonding has occurred, the female prepares to mate again. she enters estrus, or heat, a reproductive state that advertises to the males that she is fertile. once the egg is fertilized it stops growing and remains in a dormant state for three months.

after females mate the next few months are dedicated to fattening the pups. the delay allows for birthing to align with the annual trip ashore. in some species, mom will spend several days at sea foraging for food and then returning to feed her pup with milk.

on the ice things are different for species that mate on free floating ice floes. females are usually spread out over large distances, so males only have the opportunity to mate with one female per season. ice is also unstable, and will break up differently from year to year.
in 2011, hundreds of animal pups were washed up on the shore of prince edward island. ringed animals build snow lairs on the ice that help protect the pups from weather and predators.

in 2011, storms and lack of ice-cover due to a warmer winter climate resulted in hundreds of animal pups being washed up on the shore of prince edward island. like many, this young animal faced an uncertain future.

when harp animals are born the mother spends about 12 days nursing the pup before she leaves in search of the males. the pup must quickly gain weight and learn how to swim or else drown when the ice pack breaks up.
pinniped moms make milk with a very high amount of fat, which helps their pups to quickly develop a thick layer of protective blubber. in some species, pups can gain several pounds every day.
pinnipeds that live in the ice often migrate north in the summer and south in the winter to follow the ice. one of the most prolific pinniped swimmers is the northern elephant animal.
northern elephant animals spend between 80 and 95 percent of their time underwater. they use flipper strokes, lots of blubber to make them buoyant, and a surprisingly low metabolic rate.

pinniped diets consist of mostly krill, fish, and squid. many species will switch prey depending upon the season or what type of food is most abundant. overall, female northern elephant animals are the ones that make the longest migrations.
walruses forage with their snouts in the mud for bivalves, like clams. when a walrus finds a clam, it sucks it into its mouth and then uses its tongue to pull the shells apart through suction.

the crabeater animal does not eat crabs like its name suggests but rather feeds on krill. this animal evolved specialized teeth with grooves that act like a sieve and filter the krill from the surrounding water.

sharks, orcas and polar bears prey upon animals as a main source of food. one polar bear must eat up to 19 baby ring animals every 10 to 12 days to maintain its body weight. some orcas feed exclusively on fish while others predominantly eat animals and sea lions.

when christopher columbus sailed to the new world he came upon a group of animals on an island in the caribbean. foxes, coyotes, and large birds like ravens will also prey upon young animals. sea otters in the pacific have been known to attack young harbor animals.

the “sea wolves” were actually a species of animals known as the caribbean monk animal, a species that is now extinct. european colonizers hunted these animals in earnest between the 1700s and the 1900s, with the animal’s blubber fetching a significant

scientists from the us and greece are working from opposite sides of the globe to save the hawaiian monk animal. the last known caribbean monk animal was seen in 1952, and the species was officially declared extinct in 2008.

the hawaiian monk animal and mediterranean monk animal are two of the most endangered animal species in the world. around the hawaiian islands there are about 1,400 monk animals, about one third of its historic population. their relative, the caribbean monk animal, has already gone extinct.

there are fewer than 800 mediterranean monk animals, which have been hunted since the stone age along the coast of the mediterranean sea. these animals rely on coastal caves in undisturbed areas, which are becoming increasingly rare in the continuously developing mediterranean coastline.
polar pinnipeds are losing this needed space in the middle of the sea. recent efforts to protect their caves and work with local fishermen show signs of helping this species to slowly recover.

recently, herds of walruses have come ashore in point lay, alaska, sometimes in numbers as high as 40,000 individuals. when gathered in such high densities there is the risk of stampeding. a polar bear, hunter, or even an airplane can spook the herd

ringed animals rely on snow to dig ice caves on ice floes. these caves serve as protection against predators like polar bears and orcas as well as against severe weather. a decrease in snow cover correlates to a decrease in animal pup survival.

climate may also change the types of food available to pinnipeds. galapagos sea lions historically ate sardines as the main source of their diet. climate change could affect the type of food they eat.

the galapagos sea lion population has shrunk from 40,000 individuals to fewer than 15,000. during el nino years when the water is particularly warm, up to 100 percent of newborn pups and up to 50 percent of yearlings die due to starvation.

tuna swim about twice as fast as sea lions and so the sea lions have learned to use the maze-like shoreline to trap the fish. the entire endeavor takes time and energy, but when successfully executed, a 50-pound meal is quite the reward.

today animals and sea lions delight visitors of zoos and aquariums with their endearing personalities. but the first pinnipeds to be caught and taken from the arctic for entertainment purposes were walruses.

in 1608, two young walruses were captured and taken aboard the “god-speed” en route to london the female died, and the male died soon after arrival. the next walrus calf to arrive in london was in 1853, and a third arrived in

walruses became a sought-after animal for zoos in the early 1900s. it wasn't until after wwi that zoos were able to care for them effectively. most walruses only lived a few years before they succumbed to pneumonia.

animal and sea lions, however, are staples in aquariums and zoos. it wasn't until the 1960s that zoos had the knowledge and ability to supply proper nourishment to walruses and allow them to grow properly.

the animal’s paddle-shaped flippers and unique physiology enable it to thrive in even the most perilous aquatic conditions. animal vocalizations consist of grunts, barks, growls, chirps, and whistles to communicate their thoughts and feelings.
animals are animals that have played an integral role in the culture of the inuit, north sea peoples, and others. they have even been trained the us navy for limited military applications.
animals are most closely related to modern day bears, weasels, skunks, and otters. pinniped is aptly chosen, since it means “fin-footed” in latin. all pinnipeds occupy the order of carnivora.

pinnipeds fall into three broad families. the otariidae encompasses all the major species of eared animals, including sea lions and fur animals. the phocidae family is comprised of all true animals or earless animals (the name is a misnomer)

it contains only a single living species, the walrus. together, these three families account for a total of 32 or 33 living species. fifty more extinct species have been documented from either recent history or the fossil record.

this species can be identified by its large tusks, smaller eyes, especially prominent whiskers, and almost completely hairless bodies. the location of the ears and the presence of thicker coats of fur are the two major characteristics that distinguishes the eared animals from the true animals.

species with unique ornamentations like this tend to be sexually dimorphic. for example, elephant animal males have an elongated nose that aids them during mating and reproduction. hooded animals have a nasal cavity on the top of their heads that can inflate and deflate at will.

the pinniped's most important innovation is the flipper. it allows them to cut gracefully through the water to catch prey and avoid predators. they also have the remarkable ability to detect vibrations in the water with their whiskers.

even in this crucial aspect, however, true animals and eared animals have evolved difference methods of locomotion. true animals move their hind limbs and lower body from side to side for continuous propulsion, while their forelimbs are used to help them maneuver.

walrus locomotion combines elements of both true and eared animals. they use their front limbs for propulsion in a sort of discontinuous rowing motion. when on land, they have ability to turn their hind limbs forward and walk.

pinnipeds spend the majority of their lives in the water, so their physiology has adapted to withstand deep drives and long periods of oxygen deprivation. despite their size, their smooth, streamlined bodies can execute sharp turns on a dime. some species of these animals can even bend their bodies

pinnipeds can empty their lungs of air, close their nostrils and throat, and slow down their heart rate. some species can hold their breath for up to two hours at a time. after extended periods at sea, they return to land or sea ice for mating, births

whether a species prefers land or sea ice may determine many aspects of their behavior, including reproductive strategies. even the smallest animals are about three feet long and weigh no less than 100 lbs. the largest species is the southern elephant animal.

these animals are widespread along the coasts and open oceans of every continent on the earth, including antarctica. they are some of the heaviest mammals in the world, outweighing even the giraffes, hippos, and rhinoceroses.

pinnipeds inhabit saltwater regions almost exclusively, but they do swim up rivers and estuaries to hunt for food. they will inhabit beaches, caves, tide pools, shoals, and even man-made structures such as piers and oil platforms.

the pinniped diet is best described as eclectic. although fish is the most common part of their diet, these animals are also known to feed on squid, octopus, lobsters, and eels when given the opportunity.
leopard animals are notorious for hunting down penguins, sea birds, and even other species of animal. the walrus subsists on a steady diet of clams and shellfish at the bottom of the sea.

despite their size, animals make a tempting target for orcas, sharks, bears, and other large and ferocious predators. orcas in particular seem to have unique hunting strategies to catch their prey. they have been known to stun the animals with their tails, fling them in the air

animals ward off predators by congregating in large groups together. the size and ferocity of the animal is often a deterrent. hissing, teeth chattering, and aggressive visual displays are exhibited as a warning to predators.

however, animals are still at great risk from marine pollution (including chemical contamination and oil spills), conflicts with local populations, vessel accidents, and entanglements in fisher nets. climate change looms as the most significant disruption to the animal’s natural habitat.

pinnipeds exhibit wide variability in their mating patterns. some species are highly monogamous, meaning that they mate only in pairs. other species are polygynous, meaning a single male mates with multiple females, while females only have a single mate.

female animals have the remarkable ability to delay the implantation of an embryo in the uterus until conditions are more favorable. they rely on vocalizations to attract mates and ward off reproductive rivals. elephant animals are the largest and most aggressive.

the mother’s milk contains mostly fat rather than lactose, so once the pup is finally born, it can grow quickly. the parents tend to play only a minimal role in the raising of young pups, which may learn to swim mere days or weeks after birth.

animal populations were once on the brink, but they have begun to recover thanks to the efforts of the worldwide conservation community. the elephant animal is one such success story. if the animal survives into adulthood, then it can live up to 30 years in the wild.

the caribbean monk animal went extinct sometime in the mid 20th century. several species of animals, including the mediterranean monk animal, the hawaiian monk animal and the caspian animal, are still endangered. direct hostile interactions between humans and animals are rare.

evidence suggests that pinnipeds branched off from terrestrial mammals around 50 million years ago. the discovery of a fossil known as puijila darwini in 2007 helped to establish a more complete picture of the evolutionary origins of animals.

this fossil offers important insight into the earlier stage of pinniped evolution. another fossil known as enaliarctos more closely resembles modern animals with their marine specialization. are animals herbivores, carnivores, or omnivores?

animals belong to the order carnivora. animals live in coastal waters and rocky shores. they are covered in smooth skin. they live in rocky shores and coastal waters. they also live on rocky shores near the coast.

predators of animals include humans, sharks, and killer whales. the scientific name for the animal is phoca vitulina. the average litter size for a animal is 1. there are 30 different animal species worldwide.

pan troglodytes verus (blumenbach, 1775) is a type of subspecies. the subspecies is also known as the "niger e" species. it is the only species of niger in the genus "niger"

the animal (pan troglodytes), also known as the common animal, or simply chimp, is a species of great ape native to the forest and savannah of tropical africa. it has four confirmed subspecies and a fifth proposed subspecies. the animal

the animal is covered in coarse black hair, but has a bare face, fingers, toes, palms of the hands, and soles of the feet. it is larger and more robust than the bonobo, weighing 40–70 kg (88–154 lb) for males and

the infant is weaned at about three years old, but usually maintains a close relationship with its mother. the animal lives in groups that range in size from 15 to 150 members, although individuals travel and forage in much smaller groups during the day.

the animal is listed on the iucn red list as an endangered species between 170,000 and 300,000 individuals are estimated across its range. the biggest threats to the animal are habitat loss, poaching, and disease.

hundreds of animals have been kept in laboratories for research, especially in america. many attempts have been made to teach languages such as american sign language to animals, with limited success. chimp language is called "animal sign language"
