male animals are called bucks; females are called does. an older term for an adult animal used until the 18th century is coney (derived ultimately from the latin cuniculus) animal once referred only to the young animals.

a group of animals is known as a colony or nest (or, occasionally, a warren) a group of baby animals produced from a single mating is referred to as a litter. more recently, the term kit or kitten has been used to refer to a young animal.
animals and hares were formerly classified in the order rodentia (rodent) until 1912, when they were moved into a new order, lagomorpha. below are some of the genera and species of the animal.
a small, light-brown animal with upright ears sat on some grass. a taxidermy of a large animal with dark brown fur, small, thin ears and an elongated, rodent-like face.

a juvenile animal sat on a white person's hand; its fur is a light brown ticked heavily with dark brown. it is not quite large enough to fill the person's hands completely. the animal's ears are large and upright.

hares are precocial, born relatively mature and mobile with hair and good vision, while animals are altricial, born hairless and blind, and requiring closer care. hare: johann daniel meyer (1748) animal:  sylvilagus brasiliensis.

hares have not been domesticated, while descendants of the european animal are commonly bred as livestock. hares are generally larger than animals, with ears that are more elongated, and with hind legs that are larger and longer.

as livestock, animals are bred for their meat and fur. selective breeding has generated a wide variety of animal breeds. many (since the early 19th century) are also kept as pets. some strains of animal have been bred specifically as research subjects.

because the animal's epiglottis is engaged over the soft palate except when swallowing, the animal is an obligate nasal breather. the angora animal breed was developed for its long, silky fur, which is often hand-spun into yarn.

carl linnaeus originally grouped animals and rodents under the class glires. later, they were separated as the scientific consensus is that many of their similarities were a result of convergent evolution. recent dna analysis and the discovery of a common ancestor has supported the view that they do share a

animals use their strong claws for digging and (along with their teeth) for defense. though plantigrade at rest, animals are on their toes while running, assuming a more digitigrade posture. most wild animals (especially compared to hares) have relatively full, egg

as a result of the position of the eyes in its skull, the animal has a field of vision that encompasses nearly 360 degrees. the tail of the animal (with the exception of the cottontail species) is dark on top and white below.

the anatomy of animals' hind limbs are structurally similar to that of other land mammals and contribute to their specialized form of locomotion. the bones of the hind limbs consist of long bones (the femur, tibia, fibula, and phalanges) as well as short
the round head of the femur articulates with the acetabulum of the ox coxae. the tibia and fibula articulate with the tarsals of the pes. the hind limbs of the animal are longer than the front limbs.

hares, which have longer legs than cottontail animals, are able to move considerably faster. animals stay just on their toes when moving; this is called digitigrade locomotion. the hind feet have four long toes that allow for this and are webbed to

animals have muscled hind legs that allow for maximum force, maneuverability, and acceleration that is divided into three main parts; foot, thigh, and leg. the hind limbs of a animal are an exaggerated feature. they have coarse compressed hair that offers protection.

the force put out by the hind limbs is contributed to both the structural anatomy of the fusion tibia and fibula, and muscular features. animals run on their toes to gain the optimal stride during locomotion.

the muscles of animal's hind limbs can be classified into four main categories: hamstrings, quadriceps, dorsiflexors, or plantar flexors. animals that generate less force, putting less stress on bones are more prone to osteoporosis due to bone rare

complementing these muscles are the hamstrings which aid in short bursts of action. these muscles play off of one another in the same way as the plantar flexors and dorsiflexors, contributing to the generation and actions associated with force.

within the order lagomorphs, the ears are utilized to detect and avoid predators. for example, in black tailed jack animals, their long ears cover a greater surface area relative to their body size that allow them to detect predators from far away.

evolution has favored animals having shorter ears so the larger surface area does not cause them to lose heat in more temperate regions. the opposite can be seen in animals that live in hotter climates, mainly because they possess longer ears. this is due to the theory that sound does not travel

animals' ears are an important structure to aid thermoregulation and detect predators due to how the outer, middle, and inner ear muscles coordinate with one another. the ear muscles also aid in maintaining balance and movement when fleeing predators.

the animal's pinnae represent a fair part of the body surface area. it is theorized that the ears aid in dispersion of heat at temperatures above 30 °c. the ears function as shock absorbers that could aid and stabilize animal's vision.

middle ear is filled with three bones called ossicles and is separated by the outer eardrum in the back of the animal's skull. three ossicle are called hammer, anvil, and stirrup and act to decrease sound before it hits the inner ear.

within the inner ear there are two parts: the cochlea that utilizes sound waves from the ossicles and the vestibular apparatus that manages the animal's position in regards to movement. the basilar membrane that contains sensory hair structures is utilized to send nerve signals to the

thermoregulation is the process that an organism utilizes to maintain an optimal body temperature independent of external conditions. this process is carried out by the pinnae which takes up most of the animal's body surface and contain a vascular network and arteriovenous shunts. in a

homeostasis of body temperature is maintained by the use of their large, highly vascularized ears that are able to change the amount of blood flow that passes through them. if their body temperature exceeds or does not meet this optimal temperature, the animal must return to homeostasis.

if the core temperature exceeds its optimal temperature greatly, blood flow is constricted to limit the amount of blood going through the vessels. ambient heat would be able to heat the blood that is flowing through the ears and therefore, increasing the body temperature. with this constriction, there is only

when the ears are constricted it again limits blood flow through the ears to conserve the optimal body temperature. if the ambient temperature is either 15 degrees above or below the optimal temperature, the blood vessels will dilate. the blood is able to pass through the large surface area which causes it

the jackanimal has the largest ears within the oryctolagus cuniculus group. their ears contribute to 17% of their total body surface area. in cold winters, the animal folds its ears in order to decrease its surface area to the ambient air.

the animal's nasal cavity lies dorsal to the oral cavity, and the two compartments are separated by the hard and soft palate. the nasal cavity itself is separated into a left and right side by a cartilage barrier, and it is covered in fine hairs that trap dust.

the larynx functions as the animal's voice box, which enables it to produce a wide variety of sounds. the trachea is a long tube embedded with cartilaginous rings that prevent the tube from collapsing as air moves in and out of the lungs.

the branching that is typically found in animal lungs is a clear example of monopodial branching, in which smaller branches divide out laterally from a larger central branch. from there, the bronchi split into progressively more narrow and numerous branches. the bronchi branch into bronchioles
a layer of tissue sits over the opening of the glottis, which blocks airflow from the oral cavity to the trachea. the epiglottis functions to prevent the animal from aspirating on its food.

animals lungs are divided into four lobes: the cranial, middle, caudal, and accessory lobes. the right lung is made up of all the lobes, while the left lung only has two. in order to provide space for the heart, the left

animals are herbivores that feed by grazing on grass and other leafy plants. their diet contains large amounts of cellulose, which is hard to digest. animals solve this problem via a form of hindgut fermentation.

animals graze heavily and rapidly for roughly the first half-hour of a grazing period. in this time, the animal will also excrete many hard fecal pellets, being waste pellets that will not be reingested.

hard pellets are made up of hay-like fragments of plant cuticle and stalk, being the final waste product after redigestion of soft pellets. while out of the burrow, the animal will occasionally reingest its soft, partially digested pellets; this is rarely observed

soft pellets are usually produced several hours after grazing, after the hard pellets have all been excreted. they are made up of micro-organisms and undigested plant cell walls. most of their digestion takes place in their large intestine and cecum.

the unique musculature of the cecum allows the intestinal tract of the animal to separate fibrous material from more digestible material. fibrous material is passed as feces, while the more nutritious material is encased in a mucous lining as a cecotrope.

the chewed plant material collects in the large cecum, a secondary chamber between the large and small intestine containing large quantities of symbiotic bacteria. this process allows animals to extract the necessary nutrients from their food. the pellets are about 56% bacteria by dry weight.

soft feces form here and contain up to five times the vitamins of hard feces. after being excreted, they are eaten whole by the animal and redigested in a special part of the stomach. the pellets remain intact for up to six hours in the stomach; the bacteria within
because animals cannot vomit, if buildup occurs within the intestines, intestinal blockage can occur. this process serves the same purpose in the animal as rumination does in cattle and sheep[36]

the adult male reproductive system forms the same as most mammals with the seminiferous tubular compartment containing the sertoli cells. the leydig cells produce testosterone, which maintains libido and creates secondary sex characteristics such as the genital tubercle and penis.
the scrotal sacs lay lateral to the penis and contain epididymal fat pads. between 10 and 14 weeks, the testes descend and are able to retract into the pelvic cavity in order to thermoregulate.

the adult female reproductive tract is bipartite, which prevents an embryo from translocating between uteri. the two uterine horns communicate to two cervixes and forms one vaginal canal. the female animal does not go through an estrus cycle, which causes mating induced ovulation.

the male animal will mount the female animal from behind and insert his penis into the female and make rapid pelvic hip thrusts. the encounter lasts only 20–40 seconds and after, the male will throw himself backwards off the female. egg and sperm production can begin to decline after three years

the size of a single litter can range from four to 12 kits allowing a female to deliver up to 60 new kits a year. after birth, the female can become pregnant again as early as the next day. a longer gestation period will generally yield a smaller litter.
animals may appear to be crepuscular, but their natural inclination is toward nocturnal activity. in 2011, the average sleep time of a animal in captivity was calculated at 84 hours per day.

in addition to being at risk of disease from common pathogens such as bordetella bronchiseptica and escherichia coli, animals can contract the virulent, species-specific viruses rhd or myxomatosis. among the parasites that infect animals are tapew

animals and hares are almost never found to be infected with rabies and have not been known to transmit rabies to humans. animals are prey animals and are therefore constantly aware of their surroundings.

animals have a remarkably wide field of vision, and a good deal of it is devoted to overhead scanning. they survive predation by burrowing, hopping away in a zig-zag motion, and, if captured, delivering powerful kicks with their hind legs.

the longest-lived animal on record, a domesticated european animal living in tasmania, died at age 18. the lifespan of wild animals is much shorter; the average longevity of an eastern cottontail, for instance, is less than one year.

more than half the world's animal population resides in north america. they are also native to southwestern europe, southeast asia, sumatra, some islands of japan, and in parts of africa and south america. a group of burrows is called a warren.

most of south america's southern cone is without animals. much of the continent has just one species of animal, the tapeti. animals have been a source of environmental problems when introduced into the wild by humans.

gassing (fumigation of warrens),[58] barriers (fences), shooting, snaring, and ferreting have been used to control animal populations. the most effective measures are diseases such as myxomatosis (myxo or mixi,

if it were to make its way into wild populations in areas such as australia, it could create a population boom. animals in australia and new zealand are considered to be such a pest that land owners are legally obliged to control them.

in the wild, such hunting is accomplished with the aid of trained falcons, ferrets, or dogs. a caught animal may be dispatched with a sharp blow to the back of its head, a practice from which the term animal punch is derived.

domesticated descendants of the european animal (oryctolagus cuniculus) that are bred and kept as livestock account for the estimated 200 million tons of animal meat produced annually. approximately 12 billion animals are slaughtered each year for meat worldwide. in 1994, the countries with the

the largest producers of animal meat in 1994 were china, russia, italy, france, and spain. the figure for the united states was 014 kg (5 oz) per capita. cyprus had 437 kg (9 lb 10 oz), falling to 003 kg (1 oz)

in the united kingdom, fresh animal is sold in butcher shops and markets, and some supermarkets sell frozen animal meat. animal carcasses are sometimes displayed hanging, unbutchered (in the traditional style), next to braces of pheasant or other small game.
animal, any of 29 species of long-eared mammals belonging to the family leporidae, excluding hares (genus leporus) eastern cottontail animal (sylvilagus floridanus)

jackanimals, for instance, are actually hares, whereas the rockhares and the hispid hare are animals. animals differ from hares in size, life history, and preferred habitat. animals are smaller and have shorter ears than hares.
hares are born fully developed with fur and open eyes after a gestation period lasting about 42 days. they prefer habitats composed of trees and shrubs, where they live in burrows dug into the soil.
animals are ground dwellers that live in environments ranging from desert to tropical forest and wetland. learn more about what makes animals different from hares in our guide to animals and hares.

in the eastern hemisphere animals are found in europe, portions of central and southern africa, the indian subcontinent, sumatra, and japan. nearly half of the world’s animal species are in danger of extinction; many are among the most vulnerable of all mammals.

in addition to their prominent ears, animals have long, powerful hind legs and a short tail. each foot has five digits (one reduced); animals move about on the tips of the digits in a fashion known as digitigrade locomotion.
the smallest is the pygmy animal (brachylagus idahoensis), at only 20 cm (79 inches) in length and 04 kg (09 pound) in weight. the largest grow to 50 cm (197 inches) and more than 2 kg (44 pounds)

while the european animal is the best-known species, it is probably also the least typical. there is considerable variability in the natural history of animals. the tail is usually a small puff of fur, generally brownish but white on top in the cottontails (genus syl

most animals are relatively solitary and sometimes territorial, coming together only to breed or occasionally to forage in small groups. animals are active throughout the year; no species is known to hibernate.

they have slender, thin-skinned, towering ears that, in hares, can be 3 times the length of the skull. they can move independently, swivel in almost any direction and can be held erect or folded flat back against the shoulders.

animals and hares are approximately 50 different species of small herbivorous mammals in the family leporidae. they are from an order known as lagamorphs, which also includes little mountain-dwelling animals called pikas.

lagamorphs have an extra pair of small flat teeth known as "peg teeth" in their top jaw, directly behind their incisors. lagamorphs are basically exclusively vegetarian, while most rodents are opportunity feeders.

animals in the wild eat grasses as a dietary mainstay. they will eat many types of vegetation when available, but rarely consume root vegetables like the famous carrots of bugs bunny lore. carrots fed too liberally can cause tooth decay in pet animals.

all domestic animals are descendants of the european wild animal. first farmed in outdoor pens, and possibly barns, by the romans around 200 years bc. european animal became a popular and easy source of superior meat and fur.

a few hundred years later, animals were being line bred throughout most of europe. different regions began to develop specific breeds, and the size, color, and disposition of the animals evolved and expanded over time.

the american animal breeders association, or arba, has over 30,000 members and recognizes 45 different breeds of animal. worldwide there are approximately 80 recognized breeds of domestic animal, each with its own contribution and traits.
the animal is so lean, in fact, that it is a bit less tasty than other types of meat. the reproduction rate of a single doe may lead to her producing up to 200 pounds of animal meat in a single year.

there are substantial differences between animals and hares, and their separation by genus is not controversial. newborn animals are hairless, blind, toothless and completely helpless. the black-tailed jackanimal is actually inaccurately called a "animal"

newborn hares on the other hand, not only have their eyes open, they are fully furred and can actually begin foraging and eating solid foods within hours of birth. once out and about, hares and animals live surprisingly different lifestyles too.

hares are generally solitary animals only coming together for mating. they dig large, communal homes underground called warrens, where they spend most of their daylight hours. hares have tougher digestive systems, and many live in very harsh environments.

animal reproduction - how can animals have so many babies? animals remain the same color all year round, regardless of any changes in weather or environment. animals have long been used as symbols of fertility and sexual vigor in many societies.

a wild animal has a life expectancy of less than 3 years, simply because it is hunted by every predator in its habitat. the why may be because animals are very popular food source for a large variety of predators.

for a bunny, reproducing before you get eaten is the number one plan. female animals do not have a "season" as most mammals do. the female is receptive to the males advances as long as she has unfertilized eggs available.

hare newborns are almost completely self sufficient the day they are born. animals catch up quickly, becoming completely independent and fully weaned at only 4 to 5 weeks. young animals and hares are ready to mate at as young as 4 months old.

within 2 to 4 days of giving birth, a female animal may be receptive to an interested male, and become impregnated again. litter size is not extreme compared to many other species - including many breeds of dogs - with a typical litter size of 5 or 6 kits.

some animals, particularly some rodents, have shorter pregnancies, larger litter sizes, and even quicker weaning times. the combination of all these factors in the animal, along with a very strong reproductive drive, gives you the most prolific mammal in the animal kingdom.
some modern breeds are so petite that they may be kept happily in a simple hutch indoors. the netherland dwarf, dutch, mini-lop and angora bunnies are the most popular modern breeds.

the main drawback to animals being kept indoors is the odor of wet litter. since the animal is a den animal in the wild, its natural tendency is to eliminate in the same place all the time. of course healthy animal feces are relatively dry and pellet-like,so an accident

these animals live in groups called colonies, in large, complex burrow systems. colonies have dominance hierarchies, which are important for males. this animal is generally nocturnal, spending its days underground and foraging from evening until morning.

animals communicate with each other through scent marking and touch. they also thump their hind limbs on the ground to warn of danger. varieties of animals are raised commercially for meat, skins, and wool.

the wild, domesticated animal has been highly successful in most places where it has been introduced. it is considered an agricultural pest in many areas (especially where its natural predators have been eliminated) they eat cultivated crops and compete with domestic animals for forage.

on the other hand, animals may provide some benefits to some native species. their burrowing loosens soil, which is helpful to certain plant and animal species. abandoned burrows provide ready-made shelters for snakes, turtles, and other species.

animal wing morphology has been conserved for over fifty million years. during embryonic development, the gene controlling bmp signalling, bmp2, is subjected to increased expression in animal forelimbs. this crucial genetic alteration helps create the specialized limbs required for powered flight.

animals have five elongated digits, which all radiate around the wrist. the thumb points forward and supports the leading edge of the wing. the other digits support the tension held in the wing membrane. the wing bones of animals have a slightly lower breaking stress point than those of birds

the fourth and fifth digits go from the wrist to the trailing edge, and repel the bending force caused by air pushing up against the stiff membrane. the wings of animals are much thinner and consist of more bones than the wings of birds, allowing animals to maneuver more accurately than the latter

the surface of the wings is equipped with touch-sensitive receptors on small bumps called merkel cells, also found on human fingertips. each bump has a tiny hair in the center, making it even more sensitive and allowing the animal to detect and adapt to changing airflow.

the patagium is the wing membrane; it is stretched between the arm and finger bones, and down the side of the body to the hind limbs and tail. it consists of connective tissue, elastic fibres, nerves, muscles, and blood vessels.

the skin on the body of the animal is very different from the skin of the wing membrane. the patagium is an extremely thin double layer of epidermis. these layers are separated by a connective tissue center, rich with collagen and elastic fibers.

unlike birds, whose stiff wings deliver bending and torsional stress to the shoulders, animals have a flexible wing membrane that can resist only tension. to achieve flight, a animal exerts force inwards at the points where the membrane meets the skeleton, so that an opposing force balances it

when not flying, animals hang upside down from their feet, a posture known as roosting. the sharp leading edges of the wings can create vortices, which provide lift. the vortex may be stabilized by the animal changing its wing curvatures.

the ankle joint can flex to allow the trailing edge of the wings to bend downwards. this does not permit many movements other than hanging or clambering up trees. most megaanimals roost with the head tucked towards the belly, whereas most microanimals roop with the neck curled

tendons allow animals to lock their feet closed when hanging from a roost. muscular power is needed to let go, but not to grasp a perch or when holding on. when on the ground, most animals can only crawl awkwardly.

animals have an efficient circulatory system. vampire animal likely evolved these gaits to follow their hosts. short-tailed animals developed in the absence of terrestrial mammal competitors. enhanced terrestrial locomotion does not appear to have reduced their ability to fly.

animals possess a highly adapted respiratory system to cope with the demands of powered flight. since their bodies are relatively small and lightweight, animals are not at risk of blood flow rushing to their heads when roosting.

the respiratory cycle has a one-to-one relationship with the wing-beat cycle. because of the restraints of the mammalian lungs, animals cannot maintain high-altitude flight. the wings are highly vascularized membranes, the larger blood vessels visible against the light.

blood oxygen levels of flying animals are twice as much as those of terrestrially locomoting mammals. compared to a terrestrial mammal of the same relative size, the animal's heart can be up to three times larger, and pump more blood.

with its extremely thin membranous tissue, a animal's wing can significantly contribute to the organism's total gas exchange efficiency. because of the high energy demand of flight, the animal's body meets those demands by exchanging gas through the patagium of the wing.

the digestive system of animals has varying adaptations depending on the species of animal and its diet. as in other flying animals, food is processed quickly and effectively to keep up with the energy demand. the subcutaneous vessels in the membrane lie very close to the surface and allow for the diffusion

vampire animals are the only vertebrates that do not have the enzyme maltase, which breaks down malt sugar, in their intestinal tract. nectivorous and frugivorous animals have more maltase and sucrase enzymes than insectivorous.

carnivorous and vampire animals consume large amounts of protein and can output concentrated urine. their kidneys have a thin cortex and long renal papillae frugivorous animals lack that ability and have kidneys adapted for electrolyte-retention due to their low-electrolyte

their large wings are composed of the highly vascularized membranes, increasing the surface area, and leading to cutaneous evaporative water loss. water helps maintain their ionic balance in their blood, thermoregulation system, and removal of wastes and toxins from the body via urine. they
main article: animal echolocation § animals. pipistrellus pulses are pulses of a animal homing in on its prey. the feeding buzz is the buzz of the animal as it hunts for prey.

the animals' cricothyroid muscle controls the orientation pulse frequency. this muscle is located inside the larynx and it is the only tensor muscle capable of aiding phonation. by comparing the outgoing pulse with the returning echoes, the brain and auditory nervous system can produce detailed images

microanimals use their larynx to create ultrasound, and emit it through the mouth and sometimes the nose. microanimal calls range in frequency from 14,000 to well over 100,000 hz, extending well beyond the range of human hearing.

in low-duty cycle echolocation, animals can separate their calls and returning echoes by time they have to time their short calls to finish before echoes return. animals contract their middle ear muscles when emitting a call, so they can avoid deafening themselves.

in high-duty cycle echolocation, animals emit a continuous call and separate pulse and echo in frequency. the ears of these animals are sharply tuned to a specific frequency range. they emit calls outside this range to avoid deafening themselves.

the doppler shift of the returning echoes yields information relating to the motion and location of the animal's prey. they have adapted to change their pulse emission frequency in relation to their flight speed so echoes still return in the optimal hearing range.

animal, (order chiroptera), any member of the only group of mammals capable of flight.learn if we should be afraid of animals with a animal expert. for more information on animals, visit www.animals.org.
mexican free-tailed animals (tadarida brasiliensis mexicana) form summer nursery colonies in texas. adult males are equal in number to the females, though they do not all range as far north as texas.

all animals have a generally similar appearance in flight, dominated by the expanse of the wings, but they vary considerably in size. the order is usually divided into two well-defined suborders: the megachiroptera (the large old world fruit animals) and the microchirop

the largest insectivorous animal is probably the naked, or hairless, animal (cheiromeles torquatus); it weighs about 250 grams (about 9 ounces) the largest of the carnivorous animals (and the largest animal in the new world) is the spectral animal
how well do you know animals with names that start with the letter a? take this quiz and find out. it has a wingspan of barely 15 cm (6 inches) and weighs about 2 grams (about 007 ounce)

in several families a complex fleshy adornment called the nose leaf surrounds the nostrils. scientists believe they may help to direct outgoing echolocation calls (see below orientation) wing proportions are modified according to mode of flight.

animals are particularly abundant in the tropics. in west africa, for example, more than 30 genera embracing nearly 100 species have been cataloged. of the 18 animal families, 3 are well represented in the temperate zones.

the vespertilionidae are found worldwide except in the polar regions and on isolated islands. the brown animals of genus myotis have a range almost equal to that of the entire order. several vesper animals range well into canada.

most animals are insectivorous, and they are important to humans primarily for their predation on insects, for pollination, and for seed dispersal. the horseshoe animals extend throughout the old world, the roundleaf animals (family hipposideridae) and old world fruit

the mexican free-tailed animals of texas have been estimated to consume about 9,100 metric tons (10,000 tons) of insects per year. animals would seem to be important in the balance of insect populations and possibly in the control of insect pests.

vampire animals (family phyllostomidae, subfamily desmodontinae) are considered serious pests of livestock in some parts of tropical america. small wounds they cause provide egg-laying sites for parasites and may transmit rabies and trypanosomiasis to cattle

in tropical regions large colonies of animals often inhabit houses and public buildings, where they attract attention because of their noisiness, guano, and collective odour. in western culture animals have been the subject of unfavourable myths; in parts of the orient, however, these animals

animals constitute an important and generally nonintrusive form of wildlife. some flying foxes and fruit animals have been exhibited in european zoos since the mid-19th century. small animals are also widely but irregularly eaten by humans.

nocturnal activity is a major feature of the behavioral pattern of animals. nearly all species roost during the day and forage at night. nocturnal flight protects animals from visual predators, exposure to the sun, high ambient temperature, and low relative humidity.

the nocturnal activity pattern in animals is probably kept in synchrony with changing day lengths by their exposure to light at dusk or dawn. they would also lose body water required for temperature regulation and would then be forced to forage near water.

flight is the primary mode of locomotion in all animals, although flight styles vary. a few species of animals, including a flying fox, may forage actively during the day. should they be too early, their internal clock may be reset.

slit-faced animals (nycteridae), false vampire animals (megadermatidae), and others are adapted for hovering as they pick prey off vegetation or feed on flowers. some animals take flight easily from the ground: members of the genus macrotus do so simply

though flight speeds in the wild are hard to measure, four vesper animal species, carefully observed, have been timed on average at 187 to 333 km (117 to 208 miles) per hour. in flight the posture of each of the four fingers incorporated into the wing is under precise

in many cases there is little locomotion other than flight animals that hang in caves may move across the ceiling by shifting their toehold, one foot at a time. insects may be pursued and captured at a rate of up to two per second.

animals of many families walk or crawl on either horizontal or vertical surfaces, using hind feet, wrists, and thumbs. the sheath-tailed animals (family emballonuridae) hang on vertical surfaces suspended by their hind claws but with their thumbs and wrists propped against the

disk-winged animals (family thyropteridae) and sucker-footed animal (one species, family myzopodidae) have specialized wrist and sole pads for moving along and roosting. animals are not known to swim in nature except, perhaps, by accident

animals choose a variety of diurnal roosts, although the roost requirements of many animals, which are rather precise in terms of light, temperature, and humidity, limit their distribution. each species favours a particular kind of roost, though this varies with sex, season

, a roof, attic, or hollow wall), or the hollow core of bamboo stalks some species roost externally—on tree trunks or in the branches of trees, under palm leaves, in unopened tubular leaves, or on the surface of rocks or buildings.

buildings are so widely exploited by animals that many species have probably become more abundant since the advent of architecture. many animals also occupy nocturnal roosts, often rocky overhangs or cave entrances, for napping, for chewing food, or for shelter from bad weather. many

large colonies are formed by animals that roost in dense clusters. some of the old world fruit animals strikingly defoliate the trees on which they roost. in trees flying foxes (pteropus) may form outdoor camps numbering hundreds of thousands of individuals.

the advantages of colonial or solitary life and the factors that govern colony size in animals with colonial predilection have not yet been established. less commonly, animals are solitary; sometimes the adult female roosts only with its most recent offspring. occasionally, one sex is colonial and the other
elaborate communities of other animals are often satellites of cave-animal colonies. among these are cave crickets, roaches, blood-sucking bugs, a variety of parasites, and dermestid beetles.

many animals of temperate climates migrate annually to and from summer roosts and winter hibernation sites. members of the same species may converge on a single hibernation cave or nursery roost from many directions.

nothing is known of how animals recognize migration goals or how succeeding generations learn their locations. female young born at a nursery roost may memorize its location, but how they know where to go at other times is not clear.

white-nose syndrome is a fungal disease that may be responsible for erratic behaviour in animals during their winter hibernation periods. female mexican free-tailed animals migrate from central mexico to texas and adjacent states each spring.

the migration is believed to remove pregnant and lactating females to a region of high food supply where they need not compete with males of their own species. presumably they return to mexico for its suitable winter climate and food supply.

animals of the suborder microchiroptera orient acoustically by echolocation (“sonar”) they emit short high-frequency pulses of sound (usually well above the range of human hearing) and listen to the echoes returning from objects in the vicinity

rousette animals (megachiropteran genus rousettus) have independently evolved a parallel echolocation system for obstacle avoidance alone. pulses are produced by vibrating membranes in the larynx and emitted via the nose or the mouth, depending upon species

the reflected sound spreads in three dimensions, and some portion of it may impinge on the animal’s ears at perceptible energy levels. how well do you know animals with names that start with the letter a? take this quiz and find out.

the thresholds and ranges of hearing in several genera of animals have been studied. the region of maximum sensitivity has been found to coincide with the prominent frequencies of the outgoing echolocation signals. in addition, the bony otic (auditory) complex is often isolated acoust

echolocation pulses of a substantial number of animal species have been analyzed in terms of frequency, frequency pattern, duration, repetition rate, intensity, and direction. the prominent frequency or frequencies range from 12 kilohertz (1,000 hertz) to about 150 kilo

orientation pulses may include a frequency drop from beginning to end (frequency modulation [fm]), or the frequency may be constant (cf) during part of the pulse, followed by a brief fm sweep. the pulse duration varies with the species and the situation.

in goal-oriented flight, such as the pursuit of an insect or the evaluation of an obstacle or a landing perch, the pulse duration is systematically altered (usually shortened) with target distance. sometimes ending with pulses as short as 0.5 milliseconds (00015 second)

during insect pursuit, obstacle avoidance, and landing maneuvers, there are three phases of pulse output design: search, approach, and terminal. the search phase, during which many animals emit about 10 pulses per second, precedes specific attention to a target. in the approach phase, which starts

in addition to sensitive ears, the use of echolocation requires integration of the vocal and auditory centres of the brain. during the brief terminal phase (a fraction of a second), the animal is engaged in final interception (or avoidance) maneuvers.

in the laboratory, animals have been found to be able to identify, pursue, and capture as many as two fruit flies (drosophila, about 3 mm [012 inch] long) per second. they are also able to locate and avoid wires as fine as 0.

there is evidence that the multiple frequencies of fm or harmonic patterns serve in determining target direction. the relative intensities of the various frequencies are different at each ear, which allows the animal to determine the target’s direction when three or more frequencies are received.

the ratio of useful signal to background noise is increased by several mechanisms, including specializations of the middle ear and its ossicles. changes in pulse-echo timing may provide information on target distance and velocity.

in some cases prey species have been identified from stomach contents or from discarded pieces under night roosts. animals identify and track insects in flight by echolocation. large insects may be intercepted with the wing membranes and pulled into the mouth.

two genera (noctilio and myotis) include at least one species that catches small fish and possibly crustaceans. these animals may either land on and kill their prey before taking off with it or pick it up with their teeth while hovering.

each is specialized in having exceptionally large hind feet armed with long, strong claws with which the fish are gaffed. some animals are known, on the basis of banding records, to live nearly 20 years. many species show greater longevity.

the megachiroptera and many of the phyllostomid genera feed on a variety of fruits, often green or brown in colour. usually such fruits are either borne directly on wood or hang well away from the bulk of the tree and have a sour or musky od

the old world fruit animal subfamily macroglossinae (and some other fruit animals) and certain leaf-nosed animals feed, at least in part, on nectar and pollen. many tropical flowers, adapted for pollination by these animals, open at night, are white

several phyllostomid and megadermatid genera are carnivorous, feeding on small rodents, shrews, animals, sleeping birds, tree frogs, and lizards. the true vampires, which feed on the blood of large mammals or birds, land near a quiet prospective

the interaction of animals with their food, be it insects, fruit, or flowers, probably has a substantial impact on some biological communities. many plants are dependent on animals for pollination; other plants benefit from seed dispersal by animals. moths of two families are known to take ev

they comb with the claws of one foot while hanging by the other. they remove the combings and moisten their claws with their lips and tongue. on the wing membranes in particular, they use the mouth meticulously, perhaps oiling the skin.

pregnant females in many species occupy special nursery roosts until their young are independent. in some species the sexes occupy the same general roost but gather in separate clusters. in others the sexes intermingle or arrange themselves into a pattern within a group.

in northern temperate zone species, there is an annual cycle of sexual activity, with birth taking place between may and july. among animals that migrate over long distances, such as mexican free-tailed, red and hoary animals, the sexes may meet only briefly each year.

the sexual cycles of entire populations are closely synchronized, so almost all mating occurs within a few weeks. in females sexual receptivity may be associated with egg maturation and release. tropical animals may exhibit a single annual sexual cycle or may be diestrous.

gestation varies in duration: five or six months in flying foxes (pteropus), more than five months in vampire animals (desmodus), three months in some small leaf-nosed animals (hipposideros) the length of gestation may be influenced by both

most animals bear one young, but the big brown animal (eptesicus fuscus) may bear twins, and the eastern red animal (lasiurus borealis) bears litters of one to four. ovulation, fertilization, and implantation occur after emergence from

female animals normally have one pectoral (at the chest) or axillary ( at the armpit) mammary gland on each side. their wings are very immature. the young are hairless or lightly furred and are often briefly blind and deaf.

in many species females late in pregnancy migrate to special nursery roosts, in which large numbers of pregnant females may aggregate. by two months of age, most smaller animals have been flying and foraging for three or four weeks and have achieved adult size.

some animals (erophylla) leave their infants hanging quietly, one by one, on the cave wall or ceiling. in the case of the mexican free-tailed animal and a few others, the closely spaced infants may move about and mingle on the wall.

some animals achieve sexual maturity in their first year, others in their second. infant mortality appears to be high. developmental and genetic errors and disease take their toll, but accidents seem to cause more serious losses.

adult animals, on the other hand, have low mortality. predation is rarely serious, especially for cave-dwelling species. disease, parasitic infestation, starvation, and accidents apparently take small tolls.

several factors probably contribute to the unusual longevity of animals. longevity has not been established for most tropical species. isolated roosts and nocturnal flight substantially protect them from predation, from some elements of weather, and from exposure to the sun.

the persistent use of various seasonal roosts probably ensures isolation and security, food and water supplies, and access to mates. many animals, moreover, reduce their body temperature at rest. not only is there a probability that this conserves some cellular “machinery,”
for centuries, animals have been called sinister and spooky, likely because of their beady eyes and razor-sharp fangs. animals have a wingspan of less than two inches and a life span of 30 years.
there are more than 1,300 species of animals in the world, making them the second most common group of mammals after rodents. some weigh less than a penny, while others have a wingspan of six feet.

there are two main types of animals: microanimals and megaanimals. most animals are microanimals, which eat insects like moths, that come out at night. they are the only mammals in the world that can fly, and they are remarkably good at it.
microanimals echolocate by making a high-pitched sound that travels until it hits an object and bounces back to them. they prefer to drink from cattle and horses, not humans.
megaanimals live in the tropics and eat fruit, nectar, and pollen. they have larger eyes and a stronger sense of smell than microanimals but have smaller ears because they don’t echolocate.
roosts are where animals go to rest, usually in cracks and crevices that keep them hidden and protected. seasons often dictate where any animals choose their homes depending on the time of year.

no matter where they spend their seasons, all animals roost upside down. scientists still aren't sure why animals do this, but here's one theory: animals have to fall into flight, which makes hanging upside down the best way to escape.

more than 500 plant species, including mangoes, bananas, and avocados, depend on animals for pollination. insect-eating microanimals consume millions of bugs a night, acting as a natural pest control for plants.

animals are the only mammals that can fly. instead of arms or hands, they have wings. the wings have a bone structure similar to the human hand. between the bones are flaps of skin.
the western pipistrelle animal weighs less than a penny, while the greater mastiff animal weighs about two ounces (57 grams) animals can be a range of colors, including red, tan, brown, and gray.

the smallest animal in the united states is the western pipistrelle animal, which grows to about 25 to 35 inches. the allen's big-eared animal has ears so long that they make up two thirds of its body length.

the greater mastiff animal can grow as long as seven inches or more with a wingspan of 21 to 23 inches (53 to 58 centimeters) the hawaiian hoary animal is the only native, terrestrial mammal on the hawaiian islands.
animals can be found in almost every type of habitat. they live in deserts, woodlands, suburban communities, caves, and cities. animals make their homes (roosts) in a variety of different structures.

animals typically prefer warmer temperatures, and they have several ways of dealing with the cold. some animals, including the big brown animal and the eastern red animal, hibernate in caves and trees to survive the winter.

the majority of animals in the united states are insectivores. they hunt at night and eat flying insects such as mosquitoes, beetles, and moths. many animals migrate to warmer climates or even to a nearby cave.

not all animals eat insects. some live on a diet of nectar and fruit. animals that feed on nectar also serve as pollinators to nighttime blooming plants. to attract these flying mammals, flowering plants have evolved a musty or rotten perfume.

insect-eating animals hunt using a type of natural sonar called echolocation. they emit a high-frequency sound (undetectable to people) that bounces off surrounding objects. when a sound hits an object, or better yet, an insect, it bounces back

animals are mainly nocturnal, most often flying at dawn and dusk. they fly very quickly and can make fast maneuvers. a animal's echolocation system is so advanced that scientists study animals to make sonar equipment for ships.
animals can have more than one offspring at a time. babies are born hairless, blind, and without the ability to fly. the births are timed with the return of insect prey.

several animal species are on the us endangered species list. there is a high mortality rate for young animals. animals that make it to adulthood can live into their teens; a rare few into their twenties.

animals are highly misunderstood, and this can cause people to harm animals and their roosts. but animals are beneficial to people. most animals feed on insect pests and some animals even help in pollination. even animal guano is an important resource and fertilizer.
some noses are small and simple, others are shaped like a pig's nose, and some even have noses shaped like leaves. some of the most popular noses include those shaped like pigs, leaves, and leaves.

13 awesome facts about animals. they're an important species that impact our daily lives in ways we might not even realize. from pollinating our favorite fruits to eating pesky insects, animals are heroes of the night.

there are over 1,400 species of animals worldwide. animals can be found on nearly every part of the planet except in extreme deserts and polar regions. the kitti’s hog-nosed animal (also called the bumblebee animal) weighs less than a penny.

the u.s. and canada are home to about 45 species of animals and additional species are found in the us territories in the pacific and caribbean. it weighs only a 1/4-1/3 of an ounce, is about 2 inches long and has a 6-inch wings
not all animals hibernate. not all animals spend their winter in caves. some animal species like the spotted animal survive by migrating in search of food to warmer areas when it gets chilly.

white-nose syndrome affects hibernating animals and has been detected in 33 states and seven canadian provinces. owls, hawks and snakes eat animals, but that's nothing compared to the millions of animals dying from the disease.
5 million animals have died so far from white-nose syndrome. you can help -- avoid places where animals are hibernating. if you do go underground, decontaminate your clothing, footwear and gear.

over 300 species of fruit depend on animals for pollination. animals help spread seeds for nuts, figs and cacao -- the main ingredient in chocolate. without animals, we also wouldn't have plants like agave or the iconic saguaro cactus.

just like a hummingbird, the lesser long-nosed animal can hover at flowers. because animals eat so many insects -- which have exoskeletons made of a shiny material called chitin -- some animal poop sparkles. this insect-heavy diet helps foresters and

the endangered indiana animal, which weighs about three pennies, consumes up to half its bulk every evening. a animal’s wing resembles a modified human hand -- imagine the skin between your fingers larger, thinner and stretched.

california leaf-nosed animals exit a cave at joshua tree national park. you can easily distinguish these animals by their leaf-like noses and large ears. animals may be small, but they’re fast little creatures.
mexican free-tailed animals emerge from texas’s bracken cave. over 15 million animals live there, making it the largest known animal colony (and largest concentration of mammals) on earth.

u.s animals are endangered, and more are threatened. a unique international conservation partnership in the southwestern us and mexico has been working to help one species. the lesser long-nosed animal can be removed from the endangered species list.

endangered hawaiian hoary animal traveled over 3,600 kilometers from the pacific coast almost 10,000 years ago to become hawaii's state land mammal. there are now an estimated 200,000 animals at 75 roosts!
most animals live less than 20 years in the wild. scientists have documented six species that life more than 30 years. in 2006, a tiny animal from siberia set the world record at 41 years.
the townsend's big-eared animal's average lifespan is 16 years. like cats, animals spend a lot of time grooming themselves. some, like the colonial animal, even groom each other.
the spotted animal has the largest ears of any north american species. baby animals are called pups, and a group of animals is a colony. mother animals feed their pups breastmilk, not insects.

animals benefit from maintaining a close-knit roosting group because they increase reproductive success and it is important for rearing pups. about 80 medicines come from plants that rely on animals for their survival.

the mexican long-tongued animal is a vital pollinator in desert systems. they have a long, bristle-like tongue, allowing them to sip nectar from agave and cacti. research on animals has also led to advances in vaccines for humans.

nearly all mammals have navels because of mom's umbilical cord, and animals are no different. the real question is: innies or outies? can you spot this mariana fruit animal’s belly button? photo by julia boland, usfws.

you can help protect these amazing creatures by planting a animal garden or installing a animal house. stay out of closed caves, especially ones with animals. if you’re visiting an open cave, make sure to prevent the spread of white-nose syndrome.

this fact sheet attempts to dispel the fears and answer some of the questions most often asked of the national museum of natural history. animals are mammals belonging to the order chiroptera, a name of greek origin meaning "hand-wing"

these families are further classified into about 180 genera and over 900 species. only rodents have a greater number of species. one member of the megachiroptera, the flower-feeding macroglosus, has a wingspan of only 10 inches.

because animals are small, secretive, feed at night, and are unfamiliar to most people, they are sometimes regarded as rare. the largest microanimal is the tropical american false vampire, vampyrumspectrum, with a wingspan of up to 40 inches.

some animals prefer to roost in barns, attics, caves or abandoned mines. other species select hollow trees or rock crevices as their daytime resting site. certain ones are known toroost in exposed locations, clinging to tree trunks.

evidence for animal-like flying mammals appears as far back as the eocene epoch, some 50 million years ago. based on similarities of bones and teeth, most authorities agree the animal's ancestors were probably insect eating placental mammals.

animals are the only mammals to truly fly. the commonly named "flying!' squirrels and "flying" lemurs actually glide or parachute by means of a furred membrane. only animals have the structural adaptations that allow for full powered flight.

the two thin layers of skin containing blood vessels, nerves, and tendons that essentially make up the wing membrane. the bones of the arm and four of the fingers are light, slender, and lengthened to support, spread, and manipulate the membrane.

unlike other mammals, the hind limbs are positioned so that the knees, when bent, point backward while the bottom of the feet face forward. the toes have claws which help in gripping and in hanging head down, the normal animal resting position.

most of the flight muscles controlling the wing beat are attached to the shoulder blades, unlike birds, whose muscles are braced against the rib cage. birds usually have a prominent breast keel where heavy muscles are attached; in animals, only one muscle is attached. the ribs are flattened,

the animal's nocturnal behavior provides certain advantages. enormous numbers of insects fly at night, and with the exception of spiders, there are few competitors for such food. there are also few predators that can capture or pursue a animal in the dark.

because the animal has a thin wing membrane, flying during the heat of the day could be hazardous causing excessive absorption of heat. nocturnality offers protection from the heat and helps the animal maintain its body temperature and moisture.

to locate and catch prey, insectivorous animals use an acoustic orientation called echolocation. they emit a series of supersonic cries through the mouth or nose and detect flying insects by the echoes reflected back.

donald r griffin is credited with discovering that animals emit sounds in the ultrasonic range and navigate in response to echoes. since his first findings were announced in 1940, numerous studies have been made in the field of echolocation.

purrs, clicks, and buzzing often precede mating of some species. some of these sounds may be ultrasonic. certain north american insectivorous animals vibrate when at rest and content. this vibration does not occur when they are asleep.

according to analyses of stomach contents and the insect remains found near animal roosts, species vary in the insects they prefer. for example, the cave myotis, m velifer, is known to enjoy a diversified diet of beetles, leafhoppers, flies, and m

not all animals seize their prey on the wing. some specialize in catching land insects like grasshoppers or roaches that are found on the ground. other animals use their feet to snatch insects from the surface of ponds and lakes.

those species that eat pollen, nectar, and in some instances, petals from flowers, are found mainly in the tropics and semitropics. the flower-eaters are usually small and have long pointed heads, long tongues, and the ability to hover and fly slowly

unlike birds, animals are color blind and, therefore, not dependent on color for locating and choosing their food. many prefer dark green or brown fruits with musty or sour odors. these fruits usually hang from vines or grow from the trunk of a plant.

the best known of the fish-eating animals is the fishing bulldog animal, noctilio leporinus, of central and south america. how this animal actually finds its food is not completely understood, but many authorities believe that sonar is used to detect ripples on the water

although there is little scientific data on the subject, observations by naturalists in the field seem to support the fact that some animals swim in stressful situations. for example, flying foxes, often island inhabitants, may have to fly long distances to obtain food.

many questions received by the museum concern the vampire animal. the true vampire animal of central and south america feeds on blood. photographs of the flying fox, pteropus giganteus, show the animal actually swimming.

the vampire animal feeds mainly on the blood of cattle, horses, and wild mammals such as deer and peccaries. in fact, there are no vampire animals native to europe or asia; they were not even known to exist before the 1500's.

when feeding it chooses to land near a hairless area of thin skin -- perhaps the hoof or shoulder of the animal. the harm from such bites arises not from the amount of blood lost, but rather from the exposure of the livestock to secondary infections.

a higher incidence of the disease is found in skunks and foxes than in animals. in the united states the rate of occurrence is so small, barely a fraction of a percent, that there is very little danger to humans.

the greatest incidence of rabies occurs in the large vampire animal populations found in south america. the danger is not so much to the human population but rather to the livestock exposed to animal bites. in south america a major economic problem existed when large numbers of cattle were lost to rabies and

the vampire animal grooms both itself and its neighbors intensively. the us fish and wildlife service was assigned the task of studying its habits to obtain some clues for its control. using several different methods of nighttime surveillance, observation of the animal's grooming behavior provided the answer.

vampire animals usually return to their victims for more food, so when they attack again, they come in contact with the poison. back at the roost in the process of grooming, they ingest and spread the poison with the subsequent death of a large percentage of the colony. the treatment

for animals it is the time to rest in some secluded shelter, hang head down, groom, sleep, and perhaps even quarrel. when night approaches, animal activity increases; they fly about inside their cave then emerge to forage for food and drink water.

in many species, the males and females roost separately except when mating. the female stores the sperm until spring when ovulation and fertilization occur. most species bear only a single young per litter, but others may have two, three, or even four.

the baby animal, already large and well developed, crawls to the mother's nipples, attaches itself and feeds. in the evening when the mother forages for food, she may, for the first few days, carry the young with her.

among young animals, mortality is high. some fall from the roof of their shelter and are not able to climb back; some succumb to disease or parasites. they do grow rapidly and are able to fly in about three weeks.

the smithsonian frequently is asked how to get rid of a animal or animals that invade a house or building. if a lone animal flies into your home, simply open all the doors and windows and allow it to find its own way out.

eradicating large numbers of animals from buildings or barns is much more difficult since once they choose a place to roost, they continue to return to that site. the best approach is to take preventive measures screen various parts of the roof so that there are no crevices or

in the united states animals are beneficial members of the animal community. they help to control night-flying insects, in some instances pollinate flowers, and scatter the seeds of plants. their guano is rich in nitrogen and has been sold as fertilizer.

in time, as we learn more of the animal's biology and habits, perhaps we can also adopt new attitudes that allow us to accept this soft furry creature as a natural part of our surroundings. a greater appreciation for the role it plays in contributing to a healthy ecosystem.

it is traditionally considered to be one species, giraffa camelopardalis, with nine subspecies. however, the existence of up to nine extant animal species has been described. seven other prehistoric species, known from fossils, are extinct.

it is classified under the family giraffidae, along with its closest extant relative, the okapi. its scattered range extends from chad in the north to south africa in the south. animals usually inhabit savannahs and woodlands.

animals live in herds of related females and their offspring, or bachelor herds of unrelated adult males. males establish social hierarchies through "necking", which are combat bouts where the neck is used as a weapon. dominant males gain mating access to females, which bear the

estimates as of 2016 indicate there are approximately 97,500 members of giraffa in the wild. it is classified by the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) as vulnerable to extinction. animals are still found in numerous national parks and game reserves.

etymology, anatomy, taxonomy, evolution, behaviour, behaviour and behaviour of species, subspecies and subspecies are listed in a list of key terms. the list includes: "etymology," "taxonomy," "evolution," "species" and "
the name "animal" has its earliest known origins in the arabic word zarāfah. the name may also have been borrowed from the animal's somali name geri.
"camelopard" is an archaic english name for the animal. the modern english form developed around 1600 from the french girafe. the italian form giraffa arose in the 1590s.
morten thrane brünnich classified the genus giraffa in 1762[8] the species name camelopardalis is from latin. tragulina, tragulus napu - 1818-1842.
cladogram based on a 2003 study by hassanin and douzery[10] animal is one of only two living genera of the family giraffidae in the order artiodactyla, the other being the okapi.

one early giraffid ancestor was canthumeryx which has been dated variously to have lived 25–20 million years ago. comparisons between animals and their ancient relatives suggest vertebrae close to the skull lengthened earlier, followed by lengthening of verte
giraffokeryx appeared 15 mya on the indian subcontinent and resembled an okapi or a small animal, and had a longer neck and similar ossicones. this animal was medium-sized, slender and antelope-like.

paleotragus resembled the okapi and may have been its ancestor. samotherium was a particularly important transitional fossil in the animal lineage. its cervical vertebrae were intermediate in length and structure between a modern animal and an okapi.
bohlinia closely resembled modern animals, having a long neck and legs and similar ossicones and dentition. the anatomy of samotherium appears to have shown a transition to a animal-like neck.
living animals appear to have arisen around 1 mya in eastern africa during the pleistocene. some biologists suggest the modern animals descended from g jumae;[15] others find g.

the changes from extensive forests to more open habitats, which began 8 mya, are believed to be the main driver for the evolution of animals. during this time, tropical plants disappeared and were replaced by arid c4 plants, and a dry savannah emerged across eastern and
asian animals are hypothesised to have had more okapi-like colourations. the animal genome is around 29 billion base pairs in length. of the proteins in animal and okapi genes, 19 are animal-like.

a small group of regulatory genes in the animal appear to be responsible for the animal's stature and associated circulatory adaptations. the divergence of animal and okapi lineages dates to around 115 mya.

the phylogenetic tree is a maximum-likelihood phylogram based on samples from 266 animals. asterisks along branches correspond to node values of more than 90% bootstrap support. stars at branch tips identify paraphyletic haplotypes found in maasai and retic

in 2001, a two-species taxonomy was proposed. a 2007 study on the genetics of animals suggested six species. a 2011 study using detailed analyses of the morphology of animales, and application of the phylogenetic species concept, described eight species of living animals

a 2020 study showed that depending on the method chosen, different taxonomic hypotheses recognizing from two to six species can be considered for the genus giraffa. since then, a response to this publication has been published, highlighting seven problems in data interpretation.
the three-species hypothesis recognises g camelopardalis, g giraffa, and g tippelskirchi. a 2021 whole genome sequencing study suggests the existence of four distinct species and seven subspecies.

the kordofan animal (g antiquorum) has a distribution which includes southern chad, the central african republic, northern cameroon, and the northeastern dr congo. populations in cameroon were formerly included in g c peralta, but this was incorrect.

its spots may be found below the hocks and the insides of the legs. some 2,000 are believed to remain in the wild. considerable confusion has existed over the status of this subspecies and g c peralta in zoos. in 2007, all alleged g

g. peralta in european zoos were shown to be g c antiquorum. with this correction, about 65 are kept in zoos. the formerly recognised subspecies g c congoesis is now considered part of the kordofan animal.

around 2,150 are thought to remain in the wild, with another 1,500 belonging to the rothschild's ecotype. it has sharply defined chestnut-coloured spots surrounded by mostly white lines, while undersides lack spotting.
rothschild's animal (g c rothschildi) may be an ecotype of g camelopardalis. its range includes parts of uganda and kenya. its presence in south sudan is uncertain.
around 1,500 individuals believed to remain in the wild. more than 450 are kept in zoos. according to genetic analysis circa september 2016, it is conspecific with the nubian animal (g)
the west african animal (g c peralta) is endemic to southwestern niger. this animal has a lighter pelage (fur) than other subspecies. it has red lobe-shaped blotches that reach below the hocks.
it is the most endangered subspecies within giraffa, with 400 individuals remaining in the wild. animals in cameroon were formerly believed to belong to this species, but are actually g c antiquorum.

the west african animal was more closely related to rothschild's animal than the kordofan. its ancestor may have migrated from eastern to northern africa and then to its current range with the development of the sahara desert.

the reticulated animal (g c reticulata) is native to northeastern kenya, southern ethiopia, and somalia. its distinctive coat pattern consists of sharp-edged, reddish-brown polygonal patches divided by a network of thin white lines.

the angolan animal (g c angolensis)[41] is found in northern namibia, southwestern zambia, botswana, and western zimbabwe. a 2009 genetic study on this subspecies suggested the northern namib desert and etosha national park populations form a separate sub

the subspecies also has a white ear patch. about 13,000 animals are estimated to remain in the wild;[22] and about 20 are kept in zoos. the spotting pattern extends throughout the legs but not the upper part of the face.

the south african animal (g c giraffa) is found in northern south africa, southern botswana, southern zimbabwe, and southwestern mozambique. it has dark, somewhat rounded patches "with some fine projections" on a tawny background colour. the spots extend down
the masai animal (g tippelskirchi) can be found in central and southern kenya and in tanzania. a maximum of 31,500 is estimated to remain in the wild, and around 45 are kept in zoos.
a total of 32,550 are thought to remain in the wild, and about 100 are kept in zoos. a median lump is usually present in males[32]: 54 [44]
no more than 550 remain in the wild, with none kept in zoos. the patches are notched and somewhat star-shaped, and may or may not extend across the legs. the median lump of males is underdeveloped.

the average animal is 1.3–57 m (141–187 ft) tall, with males taller than females. despite its long neck and legs, the animal's body is relatively short. its skin is mostly gray or tan, and can reach a thickness of 20 mm

the coat has dark blotches or patches, which can be orange, chestnut, brown, or nearly black, separated by light hair, usually white or cream coloured. the 80–100 centimetres (31–39 in) long[41] tail ends in a long,

the coat pattern has been claimed to serve as camouflage in the light and shade patterns of savannah woodlands. adult animals move about to gain the best view of an approaching predator, relying on their size and ability to defend themselves rather than on camouflage.

the fur may give the animal chemical defense, as its parasite repellents give it a characteristic scent. animal calves inherit some coat pattern traits from their mothers. the skin underneath the blotches may serve as windows for thermoregulation.

both sexes have prominent horn-like structures called ossicones, formed from ossified cartilage, covered in skin and fused to the skull. because the males have a stronger odour than the females, the odour may also have sexual function.

appearance is a reliable guide to the sex or age of a animal. the ossicones of females and young are thin and display tufts of hair on top, whereas those of adult males end in knobs and tend to be bald on top. also, a median lump

as males age, their skulls become heavier and more club-like, helping them become more dominant in combat. the occipital condyles of the skull allow the animal to tilt its head straight up and grab food on the branches above with the tongue.

the eye is larger than in other ungulates, with a greater retinal surface area. animals possibly see in colour and their senses of hearing and smell are sharp. the ears are movable and the nostrils are slit-shaped.

the animal's upper lip is prehensile and useful when foraging. it is black, perhaps to protect against sunburn and is useful for grasping foliage. papillae cover the tongue and the inside of the mouth.

the radius and ulna of the front legs are articulated by the carpus, which, while structurally equivalent to the human wrist, functions as a knee. the molars and premolars have a low-crowned, broad surface with an almost square cross-section.

the hooves of large male animals reach a diameter of 31 cm × 23 cm. the rear of each hoof is low, and the fetlock is close to the ground, allowing the foot to provide additional support for the animal's weight.

a animal has only two gaits: walking and galloping. walking is done by moving the legs on one side of the body, then doing the same on the other side. when galloping, the hind legs move around the front legs before the latter move forward. the gir

the animal can reach a sprint speed of up to 60 km/h (37 mph) animals would probably not be competent swimmers as their long legs would be highly cumbersome in the water. when swimming, the thorax would be weighed down by the front legs.

to lie down, the animal kneels on its front legs and then lowers the rest of its body. to get back up, it first gets on its front knees and shifts hindquarters onto its back feet. it then moves from kneeling to standing on itsfront legs and pulls the rest

the animal sleeps intermittently around 46 hours per day, mostly at night. it usually sleeps lying down; however, standing sleeps have been recorded. intermittent short "deep sleep" phases while lying are characterised by the animal bending its neck backwards and resting its head on

the neck typically rests at an angle of 50–60 degrees, though juveniles have straighter necks and rest at 70 degrees. along the neck is a mane made of short, erect hairs. the long neck results from a disproportionate lengthening of the cervical vertebrae.

they comprise 52–54 per cent of the length of the animal's vertebral column. this elongation largely takes place after birth. animal mothers would have a difficult time giving birth to young with the same neck proportions as adults.

the animal's neck vertebrae have ball and socket joints. the point of articulation between the cervical and thoracic vertebraes of animals is shifted to lie between the first and second. unlike most other ruminants the articulation is between the seventh cervical

there are several hypotheses regarding the evolutionary origin and maintenance of elongation in animal necks. t1 has other morphological features, such as an articulating rib. exceptions to the mammalian limit of seven cervical vertebrae are generally characterised by increased neurological anomalies and maladies.

animals can feed up to 45 m (15 ft) high, while competitors can feed only about 2 m (6 ft 7 in) high. it suggests that competitive pressure from smaller browsers, like kudu, steenbok and impala, encouraged the elong

a 2010 study found that adult animals with longer necks actually suffered higher mortality rates under drought conditions than their shorter-necked counterparts. this study suggests that maintaining a longer neck requires more nutrients, which puts longer- necked animal at risk during a food shortage.

in support of this theory, necks are longer and heavier for males than females of the same age. one objection is it fails to explain why female animals also have long necks. it has also been proposed that the neck serves to give the animal greater vigilance.

these nerves are longer in the animal than in any other living animal. the left nerve is over 2 m (6 ft 7 in) long. each nerve cell in this path begins in the brainstem and passes down the neck along the vagus nerve.

the shape of the skeleton gives the animal a small lung volume relative to its mass. its long neck gives it a large amount of dead space, in spite of its narrow windpipe. these factors increase the resistance to airflow.

the circulatory system of the animal has several adaptations for its great height. its heart, which can weigh more than 11 kg (25 lb) and measures about 60 cm (2 ft) long, must generate approximately double the blood pressure required for a human to maintain blood flow to

animals have unusually high heart rates for their size, at 150 beats per minute. when the animal lowers its head, the blood rushes down fairly unopposed. the rete mirabile in the upper neck, with its large cross-sectional area, prevents excess blood

the jugular veins contain several valves to prevent blood flowing back into the head from the inferior vena cava and right atrium. conversely, the blood vessels in the lower legs are under great pressure because of the weight of fluid pressing down on them.
animals have four chambered stomachs, as in all ruminants. the first chamber has adapted to their specialized diet. the intestines of an adult animal measure more than 70 m (230 ft) in length.
a gallbladder is generally present during fetal life, but it may disappear before birth. a masai animal's tongue, lips and palate are tough enough to deal with sharp thorns in trees.

animals prefer acacieae, commiphora, combretum and open terminalia woodlands over denser environments like brachystegia woodlands. animals browse on the twigs of trees, which are important sources of calcium and protein to sustain
a animal eats around 34 kg (75 lb) of foliage daily. when stressed, animals may chew the bark off branches. animals are also recorded to chew old bones.
