animals are the world's tallest mammals, thanks to their towering legs and long necks. animals range in size from 14 to 19 feet and weigh 1,750 to 2,800 pounds.

these fascinating animals roam the open grasslands in small groups of about half a dozen animals. animals can run as fast as 35 miles an hour over short distances and cruise comfortably at 10 mph over longer distances.

animals use their height to good advantage and browse on leaves and buds in treetops that few other animals can reach. the 21-inch tongue helps them pluck tasty morsels from branches. animals eat most of the time and, like cows, regurg

the animal's height also helps it to keep a sharp lookout for predators across the wide expanse of the african savanna. to do so they must spread their legs and bend down in an awkward position that makes them vulnerable to predators like africa's big cats.

female animals give birth standing up. their young endure a rather rude welcome into the world by falling more than 5 feet to the ground at birth. infants can stand in half an hour and run with their mothers ten hours after birth.

up until recently, the consensus has been there is only one species of animal with multiple subspecies. in 2016, some scientists released a study that claims genetic differences among animal populations indicate the existence of four distinct animal species.

animals are the world’s tallest mammals. they are uniquely adapted to reach vegetation inaccessible to other herbivores. their "horns" are actually knobs covered with skin and hair above the eyes that protect the head from injury.
humans hunt animals for their hides, meat, and body parts. animals live 10-15 years in the wild. the animal is 57.4 meters tall and weighs 1,930 kilos.

the world's tallest land animal has lost 40 percent of its population in just 30 years. poaching and wildlife trafficking are contributing to this decline. animals are easily killed and poaching (now more often for their meat and hide) continues today.

as human populations grow, the animal is losing its beloved acacia trees, which are its main source of food. in the late 19th and 20th centuries herds of 20 to 30 animals were recorded, now on average herd sizes contain fewer than six individuals.

awf has reforested acacia trees in west africa to provide more food for the animal and allow it to expand its habitat. we educate communities living near animals on the importance of sustainable practices for agricultural and settlement growth.
calves are about two meters tall and grow rapidly as much as two and a half centimeters a day. by two months, the calf will start eating leaves and at six months is fairly independent of its mother.

animals feed 16 to 20 hours a day, but may only consume about 30 kilograms (about 30 pounds) of foliage. scientists report that only one-quarter of infants survive to adulthood due to the high rates of predation.

animals drink water when it is available, but they don’t need to drink water on a daily basis. animals can be found in desert landscapes to woodland and savanna environments south of the sahara, wherever trees occur.
animal is one of four species in the genus giraffa of long-necked cud-chewing hoofed mammals of africa. animals have long legs and a coat pattern of irregular brown patches on a light background.

animals are a common sight in grasslands and open woodlands in east africa. the tallest females (cows) are about 45 metres tall. using prehensile tongues almost half a metre long, they are able to browse foliage almost six metres from the ground.
animals grow to nearly their full height by four years of age but gain weight until they are seven or eight. males weigh up to 1,930 kg (4,250 pounds) while females weigh 1,180 kg (2,600 pounds)
both sexes have a pair of horns, though males possess other bony protuberances on the skull. there are only seven neck (cervical) vertebrae, but they are elongated.

the gait of the animal is a pace (both legs on one side move together) in a gallop, it pushes off with the hind legs, and the front legs come down almost together. the neck flexes so that balance is maintained.

animals live in nonterritorial groups of up to 20 home ranges are as small as 85 square km (33 square miles) in wetter areas. the animals are gregarious, a behaviour that apparently allows for increased vigilance against predators.
animals live up to 26 years in the wild and slightly longer in captivity. they are prodigious eaters, and a large male consumes about 65 kg (145 pounds) of food per day.
the animal grasps leaves with its prehensile lips or tongue and pulls them into the mouth. animals obtain most water from their food, though in the dry season they drink at least every three days.

females first breed at four or five years of age gestation is 15 months, and births can take place in any month of the year. the single offspring is about 2 metres (6 feet) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 pounds)

about half of very young calves are killed by lions and hyenas. thereafter, the calf joins a ‘nursery group’ of similar-aged youngsters. mother sometimes stands over her calf, kicking at the predators with front and back legs.
males join other bachelors when one to two years old, whereas daughters are likely to stay near the mother. bulls eight years and older travel up to 20 km per day looking for cows in heat (estrus)

side-to-side clashes of heads cause mild damage, and bone deposits subsequently form around the horns, eyes, and back of the head. accumulation of bone deposits continues through life, resulting in skulls weighing 30 kg. necking also establishes a social hierarchy.
bulls swing their necks and club each other with their skulls, aiming for the underbelly. animal tails were prized for the long wiry tuft hairs used to weave belts and jewelry.

during the 19th and 20th centuries, overhunting, habitat destruction, and rinderpest epidemics introduced by european livestock reduced animals to less than half their former range. the west african subspecies of the northern animal is reduced to a small range in niger

nine subspecies were recognized by coat pattern similarities. some scientists contended that these animals could be divided into six or more species. differences in genetics, reproductive timing, and pelage patterns exist between various groups.

animals are the tallest land animals. a animal could look into a second-story window without even having to stand on its tiptoes. the long and short of it is that they are a wonderful example of nature’s creativity.

although a study of animal genetics published in the scientific journal current biology concluded that there are actually four distinct species of animals, one is currently recognized, with nine subspecies. for a long time people called the animal a “camel-leopard,”

animal coat colors vary from light tan to practically black. the differences occur due to what the animals eat and where they live. each individual animal’s markings are as individual as our fingerprints.
just like humans, animals have seven neck vertebrae. each one can be over 10 inches (254 centimeters) long. both male and female animal have two distinct, hair-covered horns called ossicones.
animals are so big that they really don't need to hide from predators. it’s hard to pick out one animal from another when they form a tight group. besides humans, only lions and crocodiles hunt them.

animals have a way of moving, or gait, in which both the front and back legs on one side move forward together. their speed, the way they move, and their body designs also help them to escape predators.

you might think watching out for lions and spending 16 to 20 hours a day eating would all weigh heavily on a animal. surprisingly enough, animals only need 5 to 30 minutes of sleep in a 24-hour period. they often achieve that in quick naps that may last

animals are often the early warning signal for other savanna wildlife. if a animal herd starts to run, everyone else does, too! studies suggest animals vocalize below the level of human hearing.

animals are well adapted for living on the open, tree-dotted african plains. while other african herbivores compete for grass and small plants to eat, animals have the high branches with tender, young leaves all to themselves.
animals may eat up to 75 pounds (34 kilograms) of food per day. they spend most of their day eating, because they get just a few leaves in each bite. their favorite leaves are from acacia trees.
animals are ruminants and have a stomach with four compartments that digests the leaves they eat. animals also have thick, sticky saliva that coats any thorns they might swallow.
when they're bent over, it is easier for a predator, like a crocodile, to grab hold of the animal. so, animals go to a watering hole together and take turns watching for predators.

when a animal baby, called a calf, is born, it comes into the world front feet first, followed by the head, neck, and shoulders. because the umbilical cord is only about 3 feet (1 meter) long, it breaks midway through the birth.

the calf can stand up and walk after about an hour, and within a week, it starts to sample vegetation. when a calf gets older, the mother leaves her youngster together with other calves in a "nursery"
young animals can eat leaves at the age of four months, but continue to nurse until they are six to nine months old. in the nursery, the calves develop physical and social skills through play.
the future of animals is dependent on the quality of the habitat that remains. one animal subspecies, the west african or nigerian animal giraffa camelopardalis peralta, is vulnerable.

animals have unusually skinny legs for such large animals, but specialized bone structure allows them to support immense weight. with such a massive body, it makes sense that the animals' organs and other body parts are equally huge.

the animal (canis lupus[a]), also known as the gray animal or grey animal, is a large canine native to eurasia and north america. the animal has a global range based on iucn's 2018 assessment.

the animal is the largest extant member of the family canidae, males averaging 40 kg (88 lb) and females 37 kg (82 lb) wolves measure 105–160 cm (41–63 in) in length and 80–85 cm (31–33 in) at shoulder height

of all members of the genus canis, the animal is most specialized for cooperative game hunting. the banded fur of a animal is usually mottled white, brown, gray, and black. subspecies in the arctic region may be nearly all white.

the animal is mainly a carnivore and feeds on large wild hooved mammals as well as smaller animals, livestock, carrion, and garbage. wolves are also territorial and fights over territory are among the principal causes of animal mortality. offspring may leave to form their own packs on

the global wild animal population was estimated to be 300,000 in 2003. wolves have a long history of interactions with humans, having been despised and hunted in most pastoral communities. pathogens and parasites, notably rabies virus, may infect wolves.

the fear of wolves exists in many human societies. animal attacks on humans are rare because wolves are relatively few, live away from people, and have developed a fear of humans. the majority of recorded attacks on people have been attributed to animals suffering from rabies.

the english "animal" stems from the old english wulf, which is itself thought to be derived from the proto-germanic *wulfaz. the proto-indo-european root may also be the source of the latin word for the animal lupus (*lú

since pre-christian times, germanic peoples such as the anglo-saxons took on wulf as a prefix or suffix in their names. examples include wulfhere ("animal army"), cynewulf ("royal animal"), cēnwulf ("bold animal"), wulfheard

in 1758, the swedish botanist and zoologist carl linnaeus published in his systema naturae the binomial nomenclature. the gray animal (including the domestic dog) among its closest extant relatives[8]

linnaeus considered the dog to be a separate species from the animal because of its "cauda recurvata" (upturning tail) which is not found in any other canid. he classified the domestic dog as canis familiaris, and the animal as
wozencraft listed the 38 subspecies of c. lupus 36 wild subspecies, and proposed two additional subspecies: familiaris (linnaeus, 1758) and dingo (meyer, 1793) wozencraft included hallstromi—the new

studies using paleogenomic techniques reveal that the modern animal and the dog are sister taxa. in 2019, a workshop hosted by the iucn/species survival commission's canid specialist group considered the new guinea singing dog and the dingo to be feral dogs canis familiar

earliest fossils of c lupus were found in what was once eastern beringia at old crow, yukon, canada, and at cripple creek sump, fairbanks, alaska. the age is not agreed upon but could date to one million years ago.

pleistocene wolves had more robust skulls and teeth than modern wolves. they had a shortened snout, a pronounced development of the temporalis muscle, and robust premolars. it is proposed that these features were specialized adaptations for the processing of carcass and bone associated with the hunting

genomic studies suggest modern wolves and dogs descend from a common ancestral animal population that existed 20,000 years ago. studies in 2017 and 2018 found that the himalayan animal is part of a lineage that is basal to other wolves and split from them 691,000–740,000

a study in 2016 indicates that a population bottleneck was followed by a rapid radiation from an ancestral population at a time during, or just after, the last glacial maximum. this implies the original morphologically diverse animal populations were out-competed and replaced by more modern wolves.

the dingo, basenji, tibetan mastiff and chinese indigenous breeds are basal members of the domestic dog clade. the divergence time for wolves in europe, the middle east, and asia is estimated to be fairly recent at around 1,600 years ago. among new world wolves

in the distant past, there has been gene flow between african wolves, golden jackals, and gray wolves. the african animal is a descendant of a genetically admixed canid of 72% animal and 28% ethiopian animal ancestry.

there is evidence of gene flow between golden jackals and middle eastern wolves, less so with european and asian wolves, and least with north american wolves. this indicates the golden jackal ancestry found in north america wolves may have occurred before the divergence of the eurasian and north american wolves.

this canid is genetically close to the dhole and evolved after the divergence of the african hunting dog from the other canid species. basal position of coyote compared to the animal is proposed to be due to the coyote retaining more of the mitochondrial genome of this unidentified canid.
in north america, most coyotes and wolves show varying degrees of past genetic admixture. the red animal of the southeastern united states is a hybrid animal with 40%:60% animal to coyote ancestry.

in 2021, a genetic study found that the dog's similarity to the gray animal was the result of substantial dog-into-animal gene flow. in the caucasus mountains, ten percent of dogs including livestock guardian dogs, are first generation hybrids.

the animal is the largest extant member of the canidae family. it is slender and powerfully built, with a large, deeply descending rib cage, a sloping back, and a heavily muscled neck. the animal is further distinguished from coyotes and jackals by a broader snout

the animal's head is large and heavy, with a wide forehead, strong jaws and a long, blunt muzzle. the ears are relatively small and triangular. the skull is 230–280 mm (9–11 in) in length and 130–150 mm (5–6 in)

adult wolves measure 105–160 cm (41–63 in) in length and 80–85 cm (31–33 in) at shoulder height. females tend to have narrower muzzles and foreheads, thinner necks, slightly shorter legs, and less massive shoulders than males.

the size and weight of the modern animal increases proportionally with latitude in accord with bergmann's rule. the mean body mass of the animal is 40 kg (88 lb), the smallest specimen recorded at 12 kg (26 lb) and the largest at 794 kg (175 lb)

females in any given animal population typically weigh 23–45 kg (5–10 lb) less than males. wolves weighing over 54 kg (119 lb) are uncommon, though exceptionally large individuals have been recorded in alaska and canada. in middle russia, exceptionally large males are given

most of the undercoat and some guard hairs are shed in spring and grow back in autumn. the longest hairs occur on the back, particularly on the front quarters and neck especially long hairs grow on the shoulders and almost form a crest on the upper part of the neck.

the ears are covered in short hairs and project from the fur. short, elastic and closely adjacent hairs are present on the limbs from the elbows down to the calcaneal tendons. the winter fur is highly resistant to the cold.

in cold climates, the animal can reduce the flow of blood near its skin to conserve body heat. the warmth of the foot pads is regulated independently from the rest of the body and is maintained at just above tissue-freezing point.

female wolves tend to have smoother furred limbs than males. older wolves have more white hairs on the tip of the tail, along the nose, and on the forehead. winter fur is retained longest by lactating females, although with some hair loss around their teats.

a animal's coat colour is determined by its guard hairs. wolves usually have some hairs that are white, brown, gray and black. the coat of the eurasian animal is a mixture of ochreous (yellow to orange) and rusty (orange/red/brown) colours
the neck is ochreous long, black tips on the hairs along the back form a broad stripe. the top of the head, forehead, under and between the eyes, is gray with a reddish film.

in north america, the coat colours of wolves follow gloger's rule. apart from those wolves which are pure white or black, these tones vary little across geographical areas. wolves in the canadian arctic are white and those in southern canada, the u.s. are black.

, and mexico being predominantly gray in some areas of the rocky mountains of alberta and british columbia, the coat colour is predominantly black. differences in coat colour between sexes is absent in eurasia. females tend to have redder tones in north america.

[50] research into the inheritance of white colour from dogs into wolves has yet to be undertaken. wolves occurred originally across eurasia and north america. they are now found in europe and north and south america.

the animal is now extirpated (locally extinct) in much of western europe, the united states and mexico, and in japan. in modern times, the animal occurs mostly in wilderness and remote areas. wolves live in forests, inland wetlands, shrublands, grasslands

like all land mammals that are pack hunters, the animal feeds predominantly on wild herbivorous hoofed mammals. the animal can be divided into large size 240–650 kg (530–1,430 lb) and medium size 23–130 kg (51–287 lb)

the variation in diet between wolves living on different continents is based on the variety of hoofed mammals and of available smaller and domesticated prey. in north america, the animal's diet is dominated by wild large hoofing mammals (ungulates) and medium-sized mammals. in

across eurasia, wolves prey mostly on moose, red deer, roe deer and wild boar. in north america, important range-wide prey are elk, moose and caribou. wolves can digest their meal in a few hours and can feed several times in

nonetheless, wolves are not fussy eaters. smaller-sized animals that may supplement their diet include rodents, hares, insectivores and smaller carnivores. wolves in northern minnesota prey on northern pike in freshwater streams.

in europe, wolves eat apples, pears, figs, melons, berries and cherries. wolves also eat grass, which may provide some vitamins, but is most likely used mainly to induce vomiting to rid themselves of intestinal parasites or long guard hairs.

in eurasian areas with dense human activity, many animal populations are forced to subsist largely on livestock and garbage. cannibalism is not uncommon in wolves during harsh winters, when packs often attack weak or injured wolves and may eat the bodies of dead pack members.

in north america, incidents of wolves killing coyotes are common, particularly in winter, when coyotes feed on animal kills. wolves may attack coyote den sites, digging out and killing their pups, though rarely eating them.

in 1921, the infamous custer animal relied on coyotes to accompany him and warn him of danger. though they fed from his kills, he never allowed them to approach him. interactions have been observed in eurasia between wolves and golden jackals.

photograph of a animal, a bear, coyotes and ravens competing over a kill. brown bears typically dominate animal packs in disputes over carcasses. animal packs mostly prevail against bears when defending den sites. both species kill each other's young.

animal interactions with american black bears are much rarer because of differences in habitat preferences. wolves have been recorded on numerous occasions actively seeking out american black bear in their dens and killing them without eating them unlike brown bears,american black bears frequently lose against wolves in disputes over kills.

wolves may interact and compete with felids, such as the eurasian lynx. wolverines escape from wolves in caves or up trees. wolves encounter cougars along portions of the rocky mountains and adjacent mountain ranges.

in winter, when snow accumulation forces their prey into valleys, interactions between the two species become more likely. wolves in packs usually dominate cougars and can steal their kills or even kill them. one-to-one encounters tend to be dominated by the cat.

animal and siberian tiger interactions are well-documented in the russian far east. with perhaps only four proven records of tigers killing wolves, these cases are rare. only human depletion of tiger numbers appears to protect wolves from competitive exclusion from them.

striped hyenas feed extensively on animal-killed carcasses in areas where the two species interact. there is at least one case in israel of a hyena associating and cooperating with a animal pack. hyenas dominate wolves, and may prey on them, but animal
the wolves could benefit from the hyena's superior sense of smell, to locate and dig out tortoises, to crack open large bones, and to tear open discarded food containers like tin cans.

the average pack size in north america is eight wolves and in europe 55 wolves. the average pack across eurasia consists of a family of eight wolves (two adults, juveniles, and yearlings),[34] or sometimes two or three such families.

offspring typically stay in the pack for 10–54 months before dispersing. the distance travelled by dispersing wolves varies widely. some individuals may travel great distances of upwards of 206 km (128 mi) from their natal (birth) packs.

animal packs rarely adopt other wolves into their fold and typically kill them. in the rare cases where other wolves are adopted, the adoptee is almost invariably an immature animal of one to three years old.

wolves are territorial and generally establish territories far larger than they require to survive. territory size depends largely on the amount of prey available and the age of the pack's pups. in some cases, a lone animal is adopted into a pack to replace a deceased breeder.

animal packs travel constantly in search of prey, covering roughly 9% of their territory per day. animal packs cover an average of 25 km/d (16 mi/d) on average. their core of territory is on average 35 km2 (14 sq mi) where they spend 50

animal packs are typically settled, and usually leave their accustomed ranges only during severe food shortages. the smallest territory on record was held by a pack of six wolves in northeastern minnesota, which occupied an estimated 33 km2 (13 sq mi)

scent marking involves urine, feces, and anal gland scents. more effective at advertising territory than howling and is often used in combination with scratch marks. wolves increase their rate of scent marking when they encounter the marks of wolves from other packs.

territorial fights are among the principal causes of animal mortality. one study concluded that 14–65% of animal deaths in minnesota and the denali national park and preserve were due to other wolves. such markers can last for two to three weeks.

this includes the use of vocalization, body posture, scent, touch, and taste. wolves howl to assemble the pack usually before and after hunts, to pass on an alarm particularly at a den site, to locate each other during a storm, while crossing unfamiliar territory.

aggressive or self-assertive wolves are characterized by their slow and deliberate movements, high body posture and raised hackles. submissive ones carry their bodies low, flatten their fur, and lower their ears and tail. wolves do not bark as loudly or continuously as dogs do in
raised leg urination is considered to be one of the most important forms of scent communication in the animal. raised legs urination makes up 60–80% of all scent marks observed.
animal, any of two species of wild doglike carnivores. a brown bear protecting its food cache from wolves. the u.s. fish and wildlife service photographed a bear protecting his food cache.

the gray animal once had a larger distribution than any other land mammal. it lived in every type of habitat except tropical forests and the most arid deserts. it was the premier hunter of the large hoofed mammals.

wolves were first domesticated in northern eurasia sometime between 14,000 and 29,000 years ago. selective breeding produced dogs (c lupus familiaris) grey animal is the largest wild member of the dog family (canidae)

keen senses, large canine teeth, powerful jaws, and the ability to pursue prey at 60 km (37 miles) per hour equip the animal well for a predatory way of life. a typical northern male may be about 2 metres (6 feet) in length.

standing 76 cm (30 inches) tall at the shoulder, it weighs about 45 kg (100 pounds) females average about 20 percent smaller than males. the largest wolves are found in west-central canada, alaska, and across northern asia.
fur on the upper body, though usually gray, may be brown, reddish, black, or whitish, while the underparts and legs are usually yellow-white. light-coloured wolves are common in arctic regions.

learn how wolves are migrating from germany back into denmark after having been exterminated two centuries ago. learn about wolves that were spotted in denmark in 2017, the first time the species had been seen in the country since 1813.

in 1974 gray wolves were classified as an endangered species by the us fish and wildlife service. in the late 20th century, greater tolerance, legal protection, and other factors allowed their range to expand in portions of north america and europe.

at the beginning of the 21st century, an estimated 65,000–78,000 wolves inhabited north america. canada had the largest population (although the provinces of new brunswick, nova scotia, and prince edward island had no wolves), followed by alaska and minnesota. some of the western
worldwide, there are between 200,000 and 250,000 wolves. the eurasian population probably exceeds 100,000. populations in southern europe and scandinavia are relatively small but are increasing.

wolves usually live in packs of up to two dozen individuals, but packs numbering 6 to 10 are most common. a pack is basically a family group consisting of an adult breeding pair and their offspring of various ages.

the ability of wolves to form strong social bonds with one another is what makes the animal pack possible. a dominance hierarchy is established within the pack, which helps maintain order. alpha male and female continually assert themselves over their subordinates, and they guide the activities of the group.

a pack’s territory can be 80 to 3,000 square km (31 to 1,200 square miles) wolves communicate with one another by visual signaling (facial expression, body position, tail position), vocalizations, and scent marking. howling helps the pack stay in
breeding occurs between february and april, and a litter of usually five or six pups is born in the spring. intruders are often killed by resident packs, yet in some circumstances they are accepted.
pups are weaned from their mother’s milk at six to nine weeks. they are fed a diet of regurgitated meat throughout spring and summer. all members of the pack care solicitously for the young.

the pups grow rapidly and are moved farther and more often as summer comes to an end. in autumn the pack starts to travel again within its territory, and the pups must keep up. most pups are almost adult size by october or november.

wolves are renowned for their wide-ranging travels, and it is not unusual for them to cover 20 km (12 miles) or more in a day. large packs seem to result from fewer young wolves’ leaving the group and from litters’ being produced by more than
the main prey are deer, elk, moose, bison, bighorn sheep, caribou, and musk oxen. beavers and hares are eaten when available, and wolves in western canada even fish for pacific salmon.

biologists disagree on the effect wolves have on the size of prey populations. many wolves that live near livestock rarely, if ever, kill them. the number of stock killed in north america is small but increasing as wolves expand their range.

wolves have few natural enemies other than man. they can live up to 13 years in the wild, but most die long before that age. there have been few substantiated animal attacks on humans in north america.

the red animal is tawny, reddish, or black. in most areas of the world, humans are the leading cause of death for wolves. in areas of high animal density and declining prey populations, the major causes of death are killing by other wolves and starvation.

some experts continue to classify the red animal as a distinct species. others classify it as a subspecies (c lupus rufus) of the gray animal. the red animal is considered to be one of the most endangered types of wolves.

the eastern animal, native to eastern north america, bears a strong resemblance to the gray animal in both size and coloration. a small population of fewer than 100 has become established, but the population is threatened by continued hybridization with coyotes.

molecular evidence supports the notion that eastern wolves are hybrids of gray wolves and coyotes. their ancestry has been traced to contributions made by both species in roughly equal proportions. the ethiopian animal (c simensis) looks similar to the coyote.

ethiopian wolves hunt alone for rodents and other small mammals. studies estimate that fewer than 200 adults remain, and the international union for the conservation of nature and natural resources considers the ethiopian animal an endangered species.

the dire animal (aenocyon dirus) was common in western north america during the pleistocene epoch but is now extinct. it was the largest known animal, being half again as large as the modern gray animal. d australis was somehow able to reach the

with their piercing looks and spine-tingling howls, wolves inspire both adoration and controversy around the world. find out how many animal species exist, the characteristics that make each animal's howl unique, and how the animal population in the continental unit varies.

wolves are legendary because of their spine-tingling howl, which they use to communicate. gray wolves live from 6 to 8 years old and weigh between 40 and 175 pounds. the population of gray wolves is stable and growing.

wolves are the largest members of the dog family. adaptable gray wolves are by far the most common and were once found all over the northern hemisphere. much like barking domestic dogs, wolves may simply begin howling because a nearby animal has already begun howling.

in the lower 48 states, gray wolves were hunted to near extinction. though they almost never attack humans, wolves are considered one of the animal world's most fearsome natural villains. they do attack domestic animals, and countless wolves have been shot, trapped, and poisoned.

wolves live and hunt in packs of around six to ten animals. they are known to roam large distances, perhaps 12 miles in a single day. they cooperate on their preferred prey—large animals such as deer, elk, and moose.
animalpacks are established according to a strict hierarchy, with a dominant male at the top and his mate not far behind. wolves also eat smaller mammals, birds, fish, lizards, snakes, and fruit.

a mexican animal (canis lupus baileyi), a subspecies of gray animal, photographed at wild canid survival and research center in st. louis, missouri. a gray animal photographed at new york state zoo in watertown.

in canada, beachcombing wolves swim between islands, eating crabs, clams, and other tidbits. gray wolves are the planet’s most widespread large land mammals after humans and livestock. wolves can go for more than a week without eating.

wolves (canis lupus), are related to dogs, or more rightly, dogs are actually related to wolves. wolves and dogs are quite similar in many ways, however, in most cases, wolves are larger animals. wolves generally have longer legs than dogs.

the wolves in the high arctic endure several winter months of perpetual darkness. even in february when sun returns to the north, temperatures of -40°c and bitter winds are common. other wolves are at home in the desert and the dampness of a humid gulf coast swamp.

the grey animal is the largest of all wild canids. in general, height varies from 06 to 95 metres (26 – 38 inches) at the shoulder and weight ranges from 20 to 62 kilograms. extreme specimens of animal weighing more than 77 kilograms (170 pounds) have been recorded in

the smallest wolves come from the arabian animal subspecies, which may weigh as little as 10 kilograms (22 pounds) at maturity. females in any given animal population typically weigh about 20% less than their male counterparts.

wolves bodies are built for stamina, possessing features ideal for long distance travel. their narrow chests and powerful backs and legs assist their efficient locomotion. wolves are capable of covering several miles trotting at about a pace of 10 kilometres per hour (6 miles per hour)

wolves are gregarious animals who mostly live in packs. a pack is made when a male and a female animal meet each other and stay together. as a mated pair, they find a territory to settle in and raise cubs.

the hierarchy in a animal pack is led by the alpha male and female. this affects all activity in the pack to some extent. in most larger packs, there are two separate hierarchies in addition to an overbearing one.

in some cases during the mating season the alpha female takes total dominance even while the pups are still in the den. this is for the rest of the pack to know that she is the one to serve she also decides were the den will be.

control of breeding rights is one of the key privileges held by alpha wolves. alphas are usually the only wolves in the pack to breed. if the other adults want to breed they usually have to leave their pack and set up elsewhere.

when a large prey has been captured, they have first rights to eat as much as they want, along with their offspring (pups) in times when food is scarce, the other adults in the pack may do better to disperse and fend for themselves. however, wolves tend to feed

these are known as the ‘beta animal or wolves’ beta wolves typically take on the role of raising the alpha pairs offspring, often becoming surrogate mothers or fathers to the pups while the alpha pair are absent. beta wolves are the most likely to challenge their superiors for the role

healthier alphas will fight his challenger intensely to keep his lead roll. the loser is usually chased away or may be killed. sometimes, if the alpha is an aging animal, he will give up his position submissively and allow the beta to take his place.

animal rank order within a pack is established and maintained through a series of ‘ritualised fights’ and posturing. wolves prefer psychological warfare to physical confrontations. high-ranking status is based more on personality or attitude than on size or physical strength.

wolves howl when they are rallying for a hunt, mourning, communicating with another pack of wolves or when a pack member has become separated. a lost animal howls and the other members of his pack respond, giving him a sound to guide him home.

large packs of wolves will howl more than smaller packs. this is because smaller packs do not want to draw un-necessary attention. adjacent packs may respond to each others howls, which can mean trouble for the smaller of the two.

wolves howl at various levels of tones and pitches. this concealment of numbers makes a listening rival pack wary of what action to take. for example, confrontation could mean bad news if the rival pack gravely underestimates the howling packs numbers.

wolves tend to howl the most during the twilight hours, usually before the adults go and hunt and on their return. wolves also tend tohowl more during their breeding season and throughout rearing of pups.

there are many misconceptions regarding the reasons why wolves howl. contrary to popular belief, wolves do not howl for the sake of howling at the moon. howling becomes less random as wolves learn to distinguish howling pack members from rival wolves.

a animal howl can last between 3 and 11 seconds at a time. in addition to howls, wolves can also produce whimpers, growls, barks and squeaks. whimpering tends to serve as either a submissive or friendly greeting sound.

wolves usually hunt in packs or sometimes individually. a animal will nearly always eat what it catches almost completely. wolves have more advantages when hunting in packs because they are intelligent animals working together.

wolves are scavengers and hunters and will eat anything they catch from large mammals to small rodents. some of the animals wolves hunt and eat include: deer, moose, caribou, elk, bison and musk-oxen.

wolves are able to survive without food for up to 2 weeks or even longer if prey is scarce. their digestion is very efficient, with all but 5 percent of large meat feeds able to be digested. any splinters of bone that are not broken down somehow become wrapped in und

wolves only hunt and eat sick or weak animals. they are helping the herds regain strength by ridding them of burden animals. for example, there is a sick deer in a herd which is eating food that could be used to feed healthy young deer.

wolves live and hunt mainly in their own territory. pack members will guard and defend their territory from other intruding wolves territory size depends on the availability of prey. if prey is plentiful, animal territory can cover up to 80 – 90 square miles.

the wolves commence their hunt by wading through their territory until they come across an animal for prey. the animal will approach the prey in the opposite direction of the wind to avoid the animal from detecting the animal scent and running away.

the wolves chase their prey and once caught, bite their animals by attacking the rump or sides. large animals with horns are usually attacked this way so the wolves avoid being injured by the horns which are used as weapons.

animal hunts can either last minutes or hours depending on whether attacks are successful or not if an attack fails, the wolves will continue to hunt until they are successful. the mating season of wolves can occur anytime between january and march.

the alpha female animal has only 5 to 7 days of estrus (when she is able to conceive) during this time, the alpha pair will sometimes move out of the pack temporarily to prevent interruption from other pack members.

it is rare for two litters to occur unless the alpha male has mated with another subordinate female. this is usually when the alpha female animal gets aggressive. the alpha female will try to prevent this by aggressively dominating other females.

alpha male and alpha female wolves spend a lot of time together usually in seclusion. this occurs in anticipation of the females ovulation cycle. pheromones in the females urine and the swelling of her vulva, tell the male she is ready to mate.

the two wolves become physically inseparable for anywhere between 10 and 30 minutes, during which time the male animal will ejaculate multiple times. the mating ordeal is repeated many times throughout the females brief ovulation period, which occurs once per year per female.

once the alpha pair have mated, the gestation period lasts from 60 – 63 days animal pups are born blind, deaf and completely dependant on their mother. there can be between 1 – 14 pups in one litter, with the average number being 4 – 6 pups.

at 4 weeks old, the pups milk teeth have appeared and they begin to eat regurgitated food. the animal pups will begin to explore the area just outside the den, gradually roaming up to a mile away from it.
at 2 months old, the animal pups will be moved to a safe place which they will reside in. eventually, the rest of the pack will join in with the rearing of the pups in some way or other.

after a few more weeks of development and growing, the animal pups are sometimes allowed to join in on the hunts. they are only allowed as observers, however, until they are about 8 months old, by which time they are large enough to actively participate.
wolves typically reach sexual maturity when they are around 2 – 3 years old. at this time, a animal may feel the need to disperse from its pack, find a mate and start a pack of its own.

with an increasing number of animals throughout the world either in a critically endangered situation, becoming endangered or a threatened species, wolves are no exception. through the efforts of ecologically-minded people and with the endangered species act funding, the animal is being reintroduced in parts of north america

tell your friends and other people what you know about wolves. tell them how important they are to this world and how important it is to save a place for them in nature. you will find lots of information about them on the internet and on personal web pages.
gray wolves, or timber wolves, are canines with long bushy tails that are often black-tipped. their coat color is typically a mix of gray and brown with buffy facial markings and undersides.

the average size of a animal's body is three to five feet long. females typically weigh 60 to 100 pounds, and males weigh 70 to 145 pounds. wolves in the north are usually larger than those in the south.

today gray wolves have populations in alaska, northern michigan, northern wisconsin, western montana, northern idaho, northeast oregon, and the yellowstone area of wyoming. mexican wolves, a subspecies of the gray animal, were reintroduced to protected parkland in eastern arizona and southwest new mexico.

wolves communicate through body language, scent marking, barking, growling, and howling. they also hunt smaller mammals such as beavers, rodents, and hares. adults can eat 20 pounds of meat in a single meal.

most packs have four to nine members, but the size can range from as few as two wolves to as many as 15. barking is used as a warning, and howling is for long-distance communication to pull a pack back together.
when the young adults reach the age of three, they can either join the pack or leave to find their own territory. the alpha male is dominant over the entire pack, both males and females.

wolves in the northern united states breed from late january through march. wolves are pregnant for about 63 days and usually birth four to six pups. in some areas, young adults travel hundreds of miles to find a new territory.

at birth, pups cannot see or hear and weigh about one pound. adult pack members swallow meat and bring it back to the den for their pups. after the adults regurgitate the food, the pups have a hearty meal.

once widespread across most of north america, the animal was hunted ruthlessly and extirpated over most of its range. today the animal is making a successful comeback in some of its former habitat due to strong conservation efforts. in captivity, they live upward of 15 years.

multiple studies have explored the thermoregulatory capacity of rodent tails. one study demonstanimaled a significant disparity in heat dissipation from a animal's tail relative to its abdomen. however, this mechanism is associated with multiple pathologies that have been the subject of investigation.

on the other hand, the tail's ability to function as a proprioceptive sensor and modulator has also been investigated. these findings were confirmed in a sepaanimale study analyzing the relationships of heat storage and mechanical efficiency in rodents that exercise in warm environments.

this is accomplished by coordinated flexion and extension of tail muscles to produce slight shifts in the organism's center of mass, orientation, etc. further mechanobiological investigations of the constituent tendons in the tail of the animal have identified multiple factors that influence how the organism navigates its environment

cell viability tests of tendons of the animal's tail demonstanimale a higher proportion of living fibroblasts that produce collagen. these tendons contain a high density of golgi tendon organs that help the animal assess stretching of muscle in situ and adjust accordingly.

evolutionary selective pressure has persisted despite a multitude of pathologies that can manifest upon shedding part of the tail. paramount among these are bacterial and viral infection, as the high density of vascular tissue within the tail becomes exposed upon avulsion or similar injury to the structure.

animals are found in nearly all areas of earth which are inhabited by human beings. the only animal-free continent is antarctica, which is too cold for animal survival outdoors. antarctica does not provide buildings to shelter them from the weather.

overall, animals live to forage and mate. most animals are nocturnal, though the brown animal is often awake day or night. animals usually stick together in groups called packs. new packs are formed when a male and female go off on their own.

animals are omnivores, but many prefer meat when they can get it. house and brown animals usually use humans for their primary food source. they will scavenge through trash or eat any food that is left unprotected.

before their offspring are born, animals build nests from any material that can be foraged from the area. other animals, such as the sulawesi white-tailed animal and hoffman’s animal, prefer vegetarian fair such as seed and fruits.

brown animals can have up to 22 young at once, though eight or nine is more the average. tropical animals tend to only have one to six babies at once. female animals can mate around 500 times in a six-hour period.
most house animals — 91 to 97 percent — die within their first year of life. by the age of three months, the brown animal is ready to reproduce. animals typically live around two or three years.

brown and house animals have made a number of mammal, bird and reptile species extinct, especially on oceanic islands. they are considered threatened with extinction due to loss of habitat and decreasing populations.
a animal’s front teeth grow 45 to 55 in (11 to 14 cm) each year. 95 percent of all lab animals are mice and animals, according to the foundation for biomedical research.
an adult animal can squeeze into your home through a hole as small as the size of a quarter. animals can live for up to 18 months, but most die before they are one year old.

animals are also responsible for spreading bubonic plague, also known as the "black death" although fleas are primarily responsible for infecting humans, they were originally infected with the plague by feeding on the blood of animals.

the norway animal is also called a "sewer animal" norway animals tend to be larger and more aggressive to animals, humans and each other. to learn how to get rid of roof animals and other rodents visit the official npma website.

when norway animals invade buildings, they usually remain in the basement or ground floor. they also live in fields, farms, woodpiles and buildings. their nests are usually lined with shredded paper or cloth.

animals will eat almost anything, so keep your homes clean and don't leave food out. they also carry disease and ectoparasites. animals will also attack both animals and humans. human babies and even adults have been killed in animal attacks.

roof animals are excellent climbers and get their name because they usually live high off the ground. close up any small holes and cracks they can come in through.learn more about norway animals and find other rodent facts for kids at the official npma website.

roof animals cause damage to structures by chewing, eating stored foods and carrying diseases, such as hantavirus. they also live in sheds, garages, boxes, ceilings, under floors, in wood heaps and in thick grass.
roof animals like to eat, so keep your homes clean and always put food away. keep storage areas and pantries clean and dry. clean and frequently inspect crawlspaces, garbage cans and sheds.

thanks to their adaptability and propensity to live in conjunction with humans, animals are widespread across the globe. average lifespan in the wild: 5-12 months. identifying features: thick body with grey or brown fur; small eyes and ears; blunt snout.

animals thrive in most environments where food and shelter are available. norway animals can be found nesting in and around homes, warehouses, office buildings, barns, cellars, sewers, garbage dumps, and other areas that provide ample food.

roof animals are generally found further from the ground in trees, cliffs, attics, upper levels of warehouses, wall cavities and roofs. although they will occasionally live at ground level, they prefer to nest in more aerial locations.

animals reproduce fairly rapidly, giving birth to 6-12 young, 3-6 times per year. peak breeding season occurs in spring and fall. there is one male per group who is very territorial and acts as the sole mating partner of each of the females.

animal damage can resemble mouse damage in many ways, but it's important to understand the difference. norway animals burrow for shelter, warmth, nesting and food storage. roof animals do not commonly burrow, unless trees or other forms of shelter are unavailable.

common signs of animals include:holes about 2" in diameter in food packaging.chewed electrical wire, piping or insulation.grease marks on walls, baseboards, cabinets, doors, etc.dark pellets with blunted ends, about 3/4" in length.

there are many ways humans or pets can contract the above diseases from animals. these include animal bites/scanimalches, ingesting contaminated food or water, inhaling contaminated dust, direct contact with an infected animal, and bites from infected fleas, ticks or mites.

one female norway animal may give birth to up to 20 young in a year. animals have been known to travel through sewage systems and enter homes through drains and even toilets. similar to cats, animals will scent mark with urine to communicate with each other.

a single animal can produce up to 25,000 droppings in one year. a animal's teeth never stop growing, so animals must always be gnawing to keep them maintained. the tooth enamel of animals is said to be stronger than steel.

the norway animal or brown animal originated from tempeanimale regions of central asia. the animal is found worldwide (largely via ships) historically, they have played a major role in disease transmission.

animals are also known for their propensity to inhabit human dwellings and to destroy food supplies. as a result, far more food is destroyed than eaten. further evidence of the damage caused by animals is illustanimaled by reports of gnawing the insulation from wire and even penetanimaling metal pipes.

the animal is the second most commonly used animal in biomedical activities, exceeded only by its relative, the mouse. animals are occasionally kept as pets and still for fancy, but the vast majority of domestic animals are obtained from laboanimalory animal breeders.

most laboanimalory animals are outbred albinos, such as the wistar, sprague-dawley, and holtzman. another popular laboanimalory animal is the long-evans, also known as the "hooded animal" as it has darker hair over parts of the head

a more suitable technique to lift and restrain the animal is to place the hand over the animal’s back, slipping the thumb ventrally between the forelimbs into the intermandibular space. the animal can then be inverted and held upside down in the palm of the

animals should be fed a commercial pelleted animal or rodent diet and water ad lib. these diets are nutritionally complete and do not require supplementation. food intake is approximately 5g/100g bw/day; water intake is about 10-12ml/100g bw

animals are polyestrous and breed year round; ovulation is spontaneous. the duanimalion of the estrous cycle is 4-5 days and estrus itself lasts about 12 hours. mating is usually nocturnal and may be confirmed by the presence of a copulatory plug in

the whitten effect, the synchronization of the estrous cycles of females exposed to the pheromones of a male occurs in animals, but is not as pronounced as in mice. the bruce effect (see reproduction, mouse) does not occur in animals.

cannibalism is uncommon (except with new mothers), but females should not be disturbed during parturition and for at least 2 days postpartum. the young are called pups and weight 5-6 grams at birth, are hairless, and have closed eyelids and

newborn male animals are distinguished from newborn females by noting the greater anogenital distance and larger genital papilla in the male. this is best accomplished by lifting the tails of littermates and comparing perineums. pseudopregnancy may follow sterile matings, but is uncommon

dried "red tears" may leave a flourescing red crust about the eyes and nose. stress and advancing age, as well as certain diseases are associated with this condition. usually a fibroadenoma, which is usually well encapsulated and easy to remove.
this article is about the animal. for other uses, see animal (disambiguation) animal is the name of a species of animal. the word "animal" is also used to refer to a number of other species.
the genus mustela includes the least animals, polecats, stoats, ferrets and mink. members of this genus are small, active predators, with long and slender bodies and short legs.

animals vary in length from 173 to 217 mm. females are smaller than the males, and usually have red or brown upper coats and white bellies. some populations of some species moult to a wholly white coat in winter. they have long, slender bodies, which enable them

animals feed on small mammals and have from time to time been considered vermin. they do, on the other hand, eat large numbers of rodents. their range spans europe, north america, much of asia and south america.

the english word "animal" was originally applied to one species of the genus, the european form of the least animal (mustela nivalis) this usage is retained in british english, where the name is also extended to cover several other small species.

of the 16 extant species currently classified in the genus mustela, 10 have "animal" in their common names. among those that do not are the three species of ermine, the polecats, the ferret, and the european mink. the american mink and the

the following information is according to the integrated taxonomic information system and mammaldiversity. mountain animal (mustela altaica) eurasian ermine, or short-tailed animal. new zealand (non-native) wild steppe polecat

hybrids in this genus include the polecat–ferret hybrid and the pole cat–mink hybrid. animals have been assigned a variety of cultural meanings. the meanings of animals can be found in the following sections.

in early-modern mecklenburg, germany, amulets from animals were deemed to have strong magic. in montagne noire (france), ruthenia, and the early medieval culture of the wends, animal were not meant to be killed.

in english-speaking areas, animal can be an insult, noun or verb, for someone regarded as sneaky, conniving or untrustworthy. "animal words" is a critical term for words or phrasing that are vague, misleading or equivocal.

in the niigata prefecture, the sound of a pack of animals making a rustle resembled six people hulling rice, so was called the "animal's six-person mortar" it was an omen for one's home to decline or flourish.

in the collection of depictions, the gazu hyakki yagyō by sekien toriyama, they were depicted under the title 鼬. they were considered to be animals that have reached one hundred years of age and became yōkai that possessed supernatural powers
in japanese animals are called iizuna or izuna (飯綱) and in the tōhoku region and shinshu, it was believed that there were families that were able to use a certain practice to freely use kudagitsune
in the ainu language, ermines are called upas-čironnup or sáčiri. in the kitaakita district, they are feared as yōkai even more than foxes (kitsune)
in the past, this was thought to be "the deed of an invisible yōkai animal" an alternate theory, asserts that kamaitachi is derived from kamae tachi, so were not originally related to animals at all.

animal, any of various small carnivores with very elongated slender bodies most live in the northern hemisphere and belong to the genus mustela, which in addition to animals proper includes 17 species of ferrets and polecats.
animals are usually brown with white or yellowish underparts. the fur is short but dense, and the slim tail is pointed at the tip. in winter the coats of animals living in cold regions turn white.

animals are bold and aggressive predators. they generally hunt alone, feeding principally on mice, voles, rats, and rabbits. the kolinsky (kolinski), also called the siberian animal, is also much valued for its fur.

although proficient at catching mice, animals are also notorious for raiding chicken coops. animals often kill more prey than they can immediately consume and will store excess food for later use. this explains the carnage often seen after they discover domestic fowl.
most species have a single litter per year, but the common, or least, animal (m nivalis) often has two. sexual maturity is rapidly attained, and least animals often breed at three months of age.

the least animal is the smallest living carnivore, measuring only 11–26 cm (4–10 inches) in length and weighing only 25 grams (09 ounce) the most-common and most widely distributed species are the stoat (called the short-tailed animal in north

the least animal is the smallest living carnivore; the smallest subspecies inhabits north america. the stoat was introduced into new zealand to control rabbits, but instead it became troublesome and now endangers many of the country's native birds.
larger forms of the same species occur in russia and adjacent countries. the range of the stoat and the least animal overlap. in north america the largest animal is the long-tailed animal (m)
animals belong to the family mustelidae, and there are three animal genera in addition to mustela. both measure 25–30 cm (about 10–12 inches), excluding the 10–20-cm (4–8-inch) tail; weight is 85

the animal is grayish with dark brown underparts and a white stripe running across the forehead to the sides of the neck. it is about 30–35 cm (12–14 inches) long, excluding the 6–9-cm (25–35-inch) tail.
the african striped animal (poecilogale albinucha) is found in africa south of the congo basin. it is striped in light yellow and black, with black underparts and a long white tail.
animals may look adorable, but they make light work of eating voles, mice and birds. they are related to otters and stoats, which is obvious thanks to their long slender bodies and short legs.

mustelids have a long body and short legs and are related to otters and stoats. they live in lots of different habitats including woodland, grassland, and moorland their young are called kits, and they can have up to two litters a year.

widespread in england, wales and scotland, but absent from northern ireland and most islands. it is smaller than the similar stoat, has a shorter tail with no black tip, and a running gait, with a straight back.

stoat and animal guide: how to identify, habitat, diet and best places to spot them. found in the uk, stoats and animals are both small, brown, fast and ferocious mustelids with sinuous bodies and short legs.
stoats and animals aren't unusual in the british countryside, but you don’t get to see them very often. and when you do, it’s often not much more than a quick flash as they streak through the grass.

stoats and animals are mustelids which are a family of carnivorous mammals. in the uk, there are seven mustelid species found in the wild, including stoat, animal, badger, pine marten, american mink, polecat and

stoat (mustela erminea) showing off its characteristic black-tipped tail. animals and stoats are two of the most similar mustelid species. can be tricky to identify when you only catch a brief glimpse.
stoats often hunts in daylight, sometimes stalking prey in the open and nesting in old burrows. after the vegetation dies back in november is a good time to look out for stoats in the uk.

white forms are common in northern britain, but rare in the south. the tail tip stays black and they moult into their winter coats in winter. in northern areas many will already be white, making them conspicuous in snow-free areas.
stoats eat 25 per cent of their body weight a day, so they spend a lot of time hunting. our expert guide to animal droppings or scats explains how to identify which animal species it comes from.

stoats hunt small mammals opportunistically, moving rapidly and investigating all possible hiding places. speed enables them to take prey by surprise and makes it hard for bigger predators to catch them. the senses of smell and hearing are most important when hunting in dense cover.

despite being much larger than stoats, rabbits are hunted, too. the average rabbit is several times the weight of a stoat and dangerous to tackle. stoats approach rabbits cautiously, stopping and standing up on their hind legs to judge distances.
the remains of the carcass will be cached for future use, either under dense vegetation or loosely buried under a log or rock. animals are about twice the size of a house mouse.
a animal’s coat doesn’t change colour in britain, as it remains a rich, tawny brown all year. in europe, some do turn white in winter.
in winter the vegetation dies back, making it easier to spot mammal holes and burrows. but do you know which holes belong to which animal? learn how to identify animal habitats with our guide.
stoats are bigger than animals, but that can often be hard to tell in the field. animals don’t turn white in winter in the uk. a running animal tends to be quicker and lower to the ground.

an adult least animal (simply called the ‘animal’ in the uk, or mustela nivalis scientifically) grows no longer than 26cm. the smallest can weigh as little as 25g – just 00025 per cent of the heft of the largest
widespread on mainland britain, the species is also found in europe, north america, asia and north africa. mustela nivalis has been introduced elsewhere, and has been described as the 'least animal'

pecies – animal                animal – mustela nivalis                taxon: carnivora                            animal © mark baldwin                           animal red list classification:                gb: least concern                england:least concern                                 scotland: le

long slender body, short tail (and no black tip) slightly smaller than the stoat. only around 10% survive to over 2 years old. widespread throughout britain, animals are our smallest and probably most numerous carnivores.

animals are found in a wide range of habitats which include urban areas, lowland pasture, woodland, marshes and moors. they are less common where their prey are scarce, such as at higher altitudes and in dense woodland.

small size enables it to search through tunnels and runways of mice and voles. access to tunnels means animals can hunt at any time of the day or year. additional prey such as birds, eggs and young rabbits may be taken.

in colder climates in the north of europe, the nests are often lined with fur from lemming prey. animal home ranges vary in size according to the distribution and density of prey. male and females live in separate territories, male ranges being larger.

usually only one litter of 4-6 young are born per season, but two litters in years when field voles are abundant. young are weaned at 3-4 weeks and can kill efficiently at 8 weeks. in spring males extend their range to seek mates.

traditionally animals have been considered enemies of gamebirds and gamekeepers have exercised intensive predator control. animals do kill some gamebird chicks, but probably very few. trapping probably has no long term effect: animal populations are very resilient.

fur ginger to russet brown, cream underside, irregular line between the two colours animal does not change colour in winter long slender body, short tail with no black tip body length of 17-22cm and tail length 3-6cm.

animals are carnivores and are therefore five-toed (width 1cm, length 13cm) they have the smallest footprints of all carnivores. droppings are deposited singly and often contain bits of bone and hair.

stoat (mustela erminea) larger than animal (animal head can fit through a wedding ring, whereas an adult stoat head cannot) they are shorter and thinner than stoat droppings (3-6cm long, 02cm thick) stoat tail has
stoat may become all white in winter (ermine), but black tail tip would still remain. animal will never turn completely white. these specks would not usually be present on a stoat.

the stoat (mustela erminea) and the animal are widespread and abundant. gamekeepers routinely control both species, but they seem able to maintain healthy populations. both species habitually enter the tunnels of their prey.

these very successful hunters are found across mainland britain and can use a wide variety of habitats. as rabbits form the bulk of the stoat’s diet, the distribution and population densities of prey and predator are closely related.

stoats can travel up to 2km in a single hunting expedition of a few hours – and even further if food is scarce. in colder climates, its winter coat is white (except for the tail tip) – and is known as ermine.
in winter, stoats are almost wholly nocturnal and are rarely seen. they travel as little as possible in colder months to conserve energy. stoats are much more active during daylight hours in summer.

mating occurs in early summer, with the male travelling to a female. development of the fertilised egg is delayed for around 9 months, and 6 to 12 kits are born in spring. most females will only have one litter in a lifetime.

animals are small mammals with long bodies and necks, short legs and small heads. they are closely related to ermine, ferrets, polecats and minks. in the same family (mustelids) as badgers, wolverines and otters.

the least animal is the smallest carnivore in the world. they weigh about 1 ounce (25 grams) and grow to just 4 to 10 inches (11 to 26 centimeters) long. their winter fur glows a bright lavender color when exposed to ultraviolet light.

animals are adaptable and live all over the world. they grow to 10 to 12 inches (25 to 30 cm) long and weigh 3 to 123 ounces (85 to 350 g) their tails can grow to around 4 to 8 inches (102 to 203cm) long.

the most common animal is the short-tailed animal. it can be found in north america, europe and asia, in regions as far north as the arctic. mountain animals are found in in central and east asia and the african striped animal in africa.

the least animal eats 40 to 60 percent of its body weight every day. most of a animal's time awake consists of hunting, storing excess food and eating. their bodies don't store fat, so they need a constant supply of food to provide enough energy.
animals' diets usually consist of rats, mice, voles and rabbits. frogs, birds and bird eggs are also on the menu, from time to time. they have even been known to take over termite hills.
the short-tailed animal is an intelligent, versatile predator specializing in small mammals and birds. it is generally found "anywhere it can prey" in new zealand and small european countries.

females typically have one or two litters per year they give birth to litters of up to 15 offspring, called kits. gestation lasts about a month however, the number of kits, the length of the gestation period, weaning age and sexual maturity varies with the species
some species of animal live up to 10 years, though many live three to five years. most animals are listed as least concern by the iucn's red list of threatened species.

the mountain animal and japanese animal are listed as near threatened because their population has had a significant decline. colombian animal is listed as vulnerable because of "a continuing decline in population due to ongoing deforestation" and has estimated population of around 1,300 mature adults.

to kill its prey, a animal will clamp down on the prey's neck and keep biting until the animal is dead. before killing prey, animals will bob back and forth and hop in a dance meant to intimidate the other animal.
this article is about the animal animal. for other uses, see animal (disambiguation) animals are carnivorous mammals in the subfamily lutrinae.
lutrinae is a branch of the mustelidae family, which also includes weasels, badgers, mink, and wolverines. the european animal is the most common species found in north america.

the word animal derives from the old english word otor or oter. this, and cognate words in other indo-european languages, ultimately stem from the proto-indo-european language root *wódr̥, which also gave rise to the english word "

male animals are called dogs or boars, females are called bitches or sows, and their offspring are called pups. the collective nouns for animals are bevy, family, lodge, romp (being descriptive of their often playful nature) and raft.

the gestation period in animals is about 60 to 86 days the newborn pup is cared for by the bitch, dog and older offspring. bitch animals reach sexual maturity at approximately two years of age and males at approximately three years.

after one month, the pup can leave the holt and after two months, it is able to swim. the pup lives with its family for approximately one year. animals live up to 16 years; they are by nature playful, and frolic in the water with their pups

their most striking anatomical features are the powerful webbed feet used to swim, and their seal-like abilities holding breath underwater. most have sharp claws on their feet and all except the sea animal have long, muscular tails.

the asian small-clawed animal is the smallest animal species and the giant animal and sea animal are the largest. they have very soft, insulated underfur, which is protected by an outer layer of long guard hairs.

several animal species live in cold waters and have high metabolic rates to help keep them warm. european animals must eat 15% of their body weight each day, and sea animals 20 to 25%. in water as warm as 10 °c (50 °f), an animal

for most animals, fish is the staple of their diet. this is often supplemented by frogs, crayfish and crabs. some animals are experts at opening shellfish, and others will feed on available small mammals or birds. most species hunt for three to five hours each day

sea animals are hunters of clams, sea urchins and other shelled creatures. they are notable for their ability to use stones to break open shellfish on their stomachs. this skill must be learned by the young.

animals are playful animals and appear to engage in various behaviors for sheer enjoyment, such as making waterslides and then sliding on them into the water. sea animals are considerably more aquatic and live in the ocean for most of their lives.
giant animal (pteronura brasiliensis) and sea animals (enhydra lutris, lontra felina, lutrogale perspicillata, lutra sumatrana) are the most common species of animal.
