the european animal (lutra lutra), also called the eurasian animal, inhabits europe, most of asia and parts of north africa. it is the largest species of animal in the world.

population levels reached a low point in the 1980s, but are now recovering strongly. uk biodiversity action plan envisages the re-establishment of animals by 2010 in all the uk rivers and coastal areas they inhabited in 1960. roadkill deaths have become one of the significant threats
river animals eat a variety of fish and shellfish, as well as small land mammals and birds. they grow to one meter (3 to 4 ft) in length and weigh from five to 15 kilograms (10 to 30 lb)

historic range included shallow waters of the bering strait and kamchatka. sea animals have about 26,000 to 165,000 hairs per square centimeters of skin. they have rich fur for which humans hunted them almost to extinction.

animal populations are affected by the density of prey they hunt. more animals tend to live in waters with rocky bottoms with access to shallow-burrowing prey. they frequently carry a rock in a pouch under their forearm and use this to smash open shells.

0 to 15 m (33 to 49 ft) in length and weigh 30 kg (66 lb) although once near extinction, they have begun to spread again, from remnant populations in california and alaska. unlike most marine mammals, sea animals do not have a layer of insulating bl

the giant animal (pteronura brasiliensis) inhabits south america, especially the amazon river basin. it is becoming increasingly rare due to poaching, habitat loss, and the use of mercury and other toxins in illegal alluvial gold mining.
animals have been hunted for their pelts from at least the 1700s. the animal is more aquatic than most other animals. it can reach a height of 1.8 m (59 ft)

there has been a long history of animal pelts being worn around the world. in china it was standard for the royalty to wear robes made from them. people that were financially high in status also wore them.

animals have also been hunted using dogs, specifically the animalhound. from 1958 to 1963, the 11 animal hunts in england and wales killed 1,065 animals. in such hunts, the hunters notched their poles after every kill.

traffic (the wildlife trade monitoring network) reported that animals are at serious risk in southeast asia. this decline in populations is due to hunting to supply the demand for skins. for many generations, fishermen in southern bangladesh have bred smooth-coated animals and used them to chase

norse mythology tells of the dwarf ótr habitually taking the form of an animal. the myth of "animal's ransom" is the starting point of the volsunga saga. in irish mythology, the character lí ban was turned from a woman into

the animal is held to be a clean animal belonging to ahura mazda in zoroastrian belief, and taboo to kill. people who see an animal will attract 'rain clouds' for the rest of their lives in korean mythology.
animals fool humans in the same way as foxes (kitsune) and tanuki. in the noto region, ishikawa prefecture, there are stories where they shapeshift into beautiful women or children.

there are tales about strange occurrences like animals that shapeshift into beautiful women and kill men. there are darker stories, such as one from kaga province (now ishikawa prefecture) in which an animal that lives in the castle's moat shapeshifts into a
in the tsugaru region, aomori prefecture, they are said to possess humans. it is said that they shapeshift into bōzu (a kind of monk) and appear before passers-by.

in the kashima district and the hakui district in ishikawa prefecture, they are seen as a yōkai under the name kabuso or kawaso. they perform pranks like extinguishing the fire of the paper lanterns of people who walk on roads at

in the ishikawa and kochi prefectures, they are said to be a type of kappa, and there are stories told about how they engage in sumo with animals. in places like the hokuriku region, kii, and shikoku, the ot
in china, like in japan, there are stories where animals shapeshift into beautiful women in old books like in search of the supernatural and the zhenyizhi.

sea animal awareness week spotlights the important role of sea animals in nearshore ecosystems of the north pacific ocean. animals are some of the most adorable aquatic animals. their charming features are unparalleled, from their expressions to their use of tools.
the us is home to two species: the sea animal and the north american river animal. river animals are much smaller — averaging 10-30 pounds — with a cylindrical body and small head.
a southern sea animal rests in a small patch of egregia (feather boa kelp) at moss landing in california. the animal raises its paws to its face while it floats on its back.

animals are part of the mustelidae family, which includes skunks, weasels, wolverines, and badgers. the sea animal is the largest member of the weasel family, yet the smallest marine mammal in north america.

roximately 90 percent of the world’s sea animals live in coastal alaska. many live in the waters surrounding public lands including kodiak national wildlife refuge, kenai fjords national park, and glacier bay national park. southern sea animals range along the mainland coastline of california

the few remaining sea animals (about 2,000 scattered in remnant colonies throughout the north pacific rim) were first protected by the international fur seal treaty in 1911. the animals were hunted to the edge of extinction by fur traders in the 18th and 19th centuries.

sea animals eat 25 percent of their body weight in food every day. their diets include sea urchins, crabs, mussels, and clams. they’re known to crack open with a rock and eat while floating in the water.

this sea animal decided on the all you can eat crab legs for its evening meal. sea animals have the thickest fur of any animal. their fur contains between 600,000 to 1,000,000 hair follicles per square inch.

sea animals spend a large portion of their days grooming and conditioning their fur. they depend on their dense, water-resistant fur to provide insulation. this traps air and heat next to their skin to keep them warm.

southern sea animals breed and pup year-round, while northern sea animal pups in alaska are usually born in the spring. a newborn pup needs constant attention and will stay with its mother for six months until it develops survival skills.

this comes in handy when mothers leave their pups safely floating on the water’s surface while they forage for food. a baby sea animal lays on its mothers stomach while they both float in the water with other animals.

an animal’s lung capacity is 25 times greater than that of similar-sized land mammals. sea animals have been known to stay submerged for more than 5 minutes at a time. river animals can hold their breath for up to 8 minutes.
a “keystone species” is a species that is critical to how an ecosystem functions. a sea animal has large-scale effects on the communities in which it lives. animals are an essential keystone species.

fewer sea urchins in turn help prevent kelp forests from being overgrazed. in california, research has found that sea animals also enhance seagrass beds. in alaska’s glacier bay national park, sea animals’ expansion into the area

by rubbing their flippers and forepaws simultaneously, sea animals increase the efficiency of a grooming session. a sea animal’s tool of choice is typically a rock that can be used as a hammer or anvil.

an animal enjoys a snack of fresh mussels at kenai fjords national park in alaska. a group of resting animals is called a raft. researchers have seen concentrations of over 1,000 animals floating together.

animals might look soft and cuddly but remain dangerous wild animals. be sure to maintain a safe distance of at least 5 kayak lengths or 60 feet from the animals. animals have strong teeth and a powerful bite.
if an animal notices you, it probably means you’re too close. make sure to take pictures from shore or at least 5 kayak lengths from the animals and always use your zoom.

animal lutra lutra is a semi-aquatic and nocturnal creature. the animal has a very distinctive appearance and is easily identified. the number of animals is increasing in norfolk.

in norfolk by the 1970s most traditional animal sites were deserted and whole river systems no longer supported any animals. today though, animals have returned to most of their former haunts in norfolk. this conservation success story is the result of both better legal protection for animals and

the animal is an european protected species. it is protected under the wildlife & countryside act 1981 and the conservation (natural habitats &c) act. please phone the rspca wildlife centre, east winch, king's lynn on 0300 123 0709.

under the legislation it is an offence to kill, injure or take an animal from the wild without a licence. the latter regulations (usually referred to as the habitat regulations 1994) implement the european habitats directive in the uk.

animals will mainly feed on fish (40-90% of their diet) and will take a variety of species depending on the time of year. a license is not required to erect a fence around a pond or lake to exclude animals.

generally they are opportunistic and catch their food whilst travelling throughout their range. occasionally animals will take small mammals and water birds such as coots manmade,domestic materials have also been found inside animals.

animals mainly sleep and rest during daylight hours in dense cover or in cavities in trees and below ground. it isn't always the main channels of the rivers they use, they will also take advantage of streams, ditches, fens and reed beds.
the most distinctive and easiest way to find animal signs are their droppings which are called spraints. animals are protected by law as well as their habitats and it is an offence to disturb them.

animal spraints are left in prominent places such as on ledges under bridges and on rocks. the spraints have a unique, signature scent that is unique to each individual animal. this is the way of conveying information to one another.

the footprints of animals are asymmetric and normally only show four toes even though they have five. print sizes range between 40-80mm across. the prints of mink are much smaller across and the toes more spread out.

the animal needs to eat 20 per cent of its body weight in food every day. animals will usually eat the fishes head first and will quite often leave the tail. the mink has a wider diet but will take smaller fish.

to ascertain which species is involved you should firstly look for any footprints the animal may have left in the mud around the feeding area. animals are much bigger than mink and have 5 toes on each foot connected by webbing.
mink also have 5 toes on each foot but the prints are much smaller with fore prints approx 35cm long and up to 4cm wide. the hind print is generally bigger and can be up to 9cm in length.

animal droppings are black and slimy when first deposited and have a strong oily smell. over time however they become light grey and lose their thick consistency. the prints are roughly oval in shape with clearly defined claw marks.
mink droppings are generally 6-8cm long and approx 6-9mm wide. they are often twisted and pointed at one end. animals use droppings as scent markings and they are quite often left in exposed places.

the animal is a protected species and it is illegal to trap or harm it in anyway. the mink is a relatively recent introduction to great britain. it represents a threat to some native animals, in particular the water vole.

the non-native american mink is in the same mammal family as the animal, stoat and weasel. it resembles all of these species in general body shape. how do i tell the difference between a mink and an animal?

american mink are larger than stoats and weasels but smaller than a domestic cat and about half the size of an animal. it has a long, slim body, short legs and a round, fluffy tail that is about a third of its body length.

the fur is rich, glossy and generally dark brown or black, with a white or pale patch on the chin only. the muzzle of a mink is pointed and ferret-like whereas the animal has a flattened head shape and a broad dog-like muzzle.

it is not possible to trap and/or move animals anywhere within the uk animals are protected under the uk wildlife & countryside act and also under european legislation. it is in their nature to eat fish, eels and crustaceans.

it should be remembered that most still waters stocked with fish are artificial, manipulated environments that support high densities of small fish or small concentrations of very large fish. an enclosed fishery or pond simply offers a very tempting feeding opportunity for them.

for smaller garden ponds it may be possible to cover the pond in a mesh or grid to stop the animal being able to dive down to the fish. information on appropriate/effective fencing specifications is available from a number of sources including the angling trust, specialist anglers conservation group,

the 11 species often referred to as river animals are found throughout north america, south america, europe, africa, and asia. river animals feed on fish, crayfish, crabs, mussels, and frogs.

river animals hunt visually while chasing fish, but they use their manual dexterity to dislodge crabs and crayfish from under rocks. sensory hairs on the snout called vibrissae also assist by sensing water turbulence. after being captured in the teeth or forefeet, prey is

african clawless animals (aonyx capensis) rely more on manual dexterity than on vision to obtain food. their front feet are handlike and partially webbed. most travel is aquatic, but river animals can venture swiftly overland.

while in the water, they constantly search features such as logjams and deepwater pools for prey. animals seek refuge in underground holes, rock crevices, beaver lodges, cavities in root systems, or simply dense vegetation along the shoreline.

most mortality results from human activities, in the form of road kills, drownings in fishnets, destruction as pests around fishing areas, or trapping for their fur. young animals (pups) may fall prey to large raptors, and various carnivores may kill adults traveling on

two animal species are strictly marine: the sea animal of the pacific coast of north america and the much smaller marine animal from the coast of peru and chile. both rely exclusively on marine prey, although the sea animal can be found much farther offshore.

sea animals can drink salt water and thus can remain at sea for several days at a time sea animals are usually solitary but are sometimes seen in groups. gatherings of up to 2,000 have been observed along the coast of alaska.

sea animals feed mainly on sea urchins and on crabs and other shellfish. fish are also eaten. captured prey is eaten at sea while the animal floats on its back. rocks are typically used to break open crabs.

large numbers of sea animals can deplete shellfish populations. they compete with fisheries for crabs, clams, and abalones. sea animals give birth in water to only one young at a time. the young remains dependent on the mother until six to eight months of age

this small (3–6 kg [66–132 pounds]) animal occurs on the pacific coast from peru through chile and tierra del fuego in argentina. it is mostly solitary, and only rarely do groups of more than three animals occur marine animals occupy the intert
marine animals do not consume sea urchins as extensively as do sea animals. marine animals shelter in rock cavities for daytime rest, breeding, giving birth, and raising young.

heavy metals and contaminants such as mercury and pcbs accumulate in animal tissues and in time impair reproduction and survival. pollution also affects fish populations on which animals often depend. animals are still taken as part of the commercial fur trade.

according to the international union for conservation of nature and natural resources (iucn), about half of all animal species are threatened. the iucn lists five species of animal as endangered and two as vulnerable.

this work by the scottish invasive species initiative will help ensure species like this family of animals continue to have suitable habitat to raise their young. coastal animals are sometimes called ‘sea animals’, but they are exactly the same species as the animals that live further

the animal belongs to the same family as the badger, pine marten, stoat and weasel, and american mink. animals may also seek temporary shelter in above-ground structures known as ‘couches’

the charismatic animal, a member of the weasel family, is found on every continent except australia and antarctica. most are small, with short ears and noses, elongated bodies, long tails, and soft, dense fur.

most sea animals live in freshwater rivers, lakes, and wetlands. the sea animal and the smaller marine animal are found in the pacific ocean. webbed feet and powerful tails act like rudders, making animals strong swimmers.

animals also have particularly stinky poop, which even has its own name: spraints. it's thought to get its special odor, which some scientists describe as smelling like violets, from the seafood diet animals eat.

all animals are expert hunters that eat fish, crustaceans, and other critters. baby animals, called pups or kittens, stay with their mothers until they’re up to a year old, or until she has another litter. river animals don’

when it's time to nap, sea animals entangle themselves in kelp so they don't float away. a sea animal will float on its back, place a rock on its chest, then smash the mollusk down on it until it breaks open.

animals and their mustelid relatives were once hunted extensively for their fur, many to the point of near extinction. despite regulations designed to protect them, many species remain at risk from pollution and habitat loss.

asian animal species also face threats from the illegal pet trade. asia's animal population is estimated to be in the tens of thousands. asian animal is one of the most endangered species in the world.

with long, sleek bodies and webbed feet, animals are born swimmers. they are found in waterways on every continent except australia and antarctica. unfortunately, the fur is highly coveted, and animals have been hunted almost to extinction in many places.

the largest animal is the giant animal. it grows from 49 to 59 feet (15 to 18 meters) long. though it is the largest, it isn’t the heaviest this distinction goes to the sea animal males weigh up to 90 lbs (41 kilograms)

animals are found almost all over the world and in many wet habitats, such freshwater rivers, lakes, oceans, coastlines and marshes most animals live in dens — built by other animals, such as beavers — that are dug into the ground.

sea animals are found in two areas: the pacific coasts of russia and alaska, and along the central california coast. they live in offshore forests of giant kelp, according to the animal diversity web (adw)
animals like to slide off embankments into the water, wrestle, chase their tails and participate in other fun games. a group of animals is called a raft, according to the san diego zoo.

animals have two layers of fur: a dense undercoat that traps air and a topcoat of long, waterproof hairs. they clean their fur by biting it and scratching it against rocks, or rubbing it on logs or grass.

a female animal has a gestation period of two months for smaller species. she will give birth to one to five offspring, through usually only two babies are born at once. river animals eat mostly frogs, crabs, crayfish, fish and mollusks.

animal babies are born weighing only 45 ounces (128 grams) for smaller species and 5 lbs (23 kg) for sea animals. pups have sealed eyes that open at around 1 month old. at 2 months, pups start to swim.
sea animals convene in a kelp bed near kodiak island, alaska. by 2 to 5 years old they will be ready to make their own pups. animal live to around 12 years old in the wild, and longer in captivity.

the north american river animal is listed as stable and of "least concern" for extinction. the giant animal, hairy-nosed animal and marine animal are the endangered species. populations of all animals are decreasing.

warm air trapped in a sea animal’s fur keeps them warm in chilly waters. the word animal comes from old english and indo european root words that were also used to create the english word for water. animals have the densest fur in the world.

from wikipedia, the free encyclopedia. use the weekly newsquiz to test your knowledge of stories you saw on cnn.com. today's featured newsquiz question: what do you know about the american bison?
the american bison or simply bison (bison bison), also commonly known as the american animal or simply animal, is an american species of bison that once roamed north america in vast herds.

it nearly became extinct by a combination of commercial hunting and slaughter in the 19th century and introduction of bovine diseases from domestic cattle. with a population in excess of 60 million in the late 18th century, the species was down to just 541 animals by 1889. recovery efforts
two subspecies or ecotypes have been described. the wood bison is the larger of the two and has a taller, square hump. the plains bison has been suggested to consist of a northern plains (b b bison)

the wood bison is one of the largest wild species of extant bovid in the world, surpassed only by the asian gaur. among extant land animals in north america, it is the heaviest and the longest, and the second tallest after the moose.
the bison is the national mammal of the united states of america. it is found in mexico, siberia, and the u.s. west. the bison has a large range and is popular with ranchers.
the term animal is sometimes considered to be a misnomer for this animal. the term animal could be confused with "true" animals, the asian water animal and the african animal.

samuel de champlain applied the term animal (buffles in french) to the bison in 1616. he saw skins and a drawing shown to him by members of the nipissing first nation. they said they travelled forty days (from east of lake huron)

in plains indian languages in general, male and female animales are distinguished, with each having a different designation. the american bison is very closely related to the european bison (also known as wisent or the european wood bison)

), and so presumably is due to the special significance of the animal in plains indian life and culture. a bison has a shaggy, long, dark-brown winter coat, and a lighter-weight, lighter-brown summer coat.

wood bison is potentially more primitive in phenotype than plains bison while the latter probably evolved from mixing of bison occidentalis and bison antiquus. plains bison are often in the smaller range of sizes, and wood bison in the larger range. head-rump
heights at withers in the species can reach up to 186 to 201 cm (6 ft 1 in to 6 ft 7 in) for b b bison and b b athabascae respectively. typically weights can range from 318 to 1,179 kg (701 to 2,

b bison) and 9436 kg (2,080 lb) (bbathabascae) in males, and 360 to 640 kg (790 to 1,410 lb) in females. the lowest weights probably representing typical weight around the age of sexual maturity at 2 to 3
bbison ever recorded weighed 1,270 kg (2,800 lb)[28] while there had been bulls estimated to be 1,400 kg (3,000 lb)[29] bbathabascae is significantly larger and heavier on average than bbbison.

when raised in captivity and farmed for meat, the bison can grow unnaturally heavy. the largest semidomestic bison weighed 1,724 kg (3,801 lb)[20] the heads and forequarters are massive, and both sexes have short, curved horns

young bulls may try to start mating with cows by the age of two or three years. if more mature bulls are present, they may not be able to compete until five years of age. their daily schedule involves two-hour periods of grazing, resting, and cud chewing.

the bovine family (taurids and bisonids) diverged from the common ancestral line with water animal and african animal about 5 to 10 million years ago. thereafter, the family lineage of bison and taurine cattle does not appear to be a straightforward "
a 2003 study of mitochondrial dna indicated four distinct maternal lineages in subtribe bovina: taurine cattle and zebu. european bison (wisent) american bison and yak. banteng, gaur, and gayal.
the steppe bison (bison priscus) diverged from the lineage that led to cattle (bos taurus) about 2 to 5 million years ago. the bison genus is clearly in the fossil record by 2 million years old.

the european bison arose from the steppe bison, without fossil evidence of other ancestral species. some evidence shows bison that had migrated from asia to north america, and then back to europe, where they crossbred with existing steppes bison.

evidence has been found of multiple crossings of bison to and from asia starting before 500,000 years ago. after that cross, a population of steppe bison (bison priscus) crossed the bering land bridge to north america.

b latifrons was one of many species of north american megafauna which became extinct during the quaternary extinction event. it is thought to have disappeared some 21,000–30,000 years ago during the late wisconsin glaciation.

b antiquus appeared in the north american fossil record approximately 250,000 years ago. b antiquus evolved into b occidentalis, then into the yet smaller b bison. b. latifrons species was replaced by the smaller bison antiquus.

although superficially similar, the american and european bison exhibit a number of physical and behavioral differences. american bison are slightly heavier on average because of their less rangy build, and have shorter legs, which render them slightly shorter at the shoulder.

compared to the nose of the american bison, that of the european species is set farther forward than the forehead when the neck is in a neutral position. the european bison is more adept at fighting through the interlocking of horns in the same manner as domestic cattle, unlike the american

during the population bottleneck, after the great slaughter of american bison during the 1800s, the number of bison remaining alive in north america declined to as low as 541. during that period, a handful of ranchers gathered remnants of the existing herds to save the species from extinction

male bulls were crossed with animal cows, producing offspring of which only the females were fertile. the crossbred animals did not demonstrate any form of hybrid vigor, so the practice was abandoned. the proportion of cattle dna that has been measured in introgressed individuals and bison herds today

despite being the closest relatives of domestic cattle native to north america, bison were never domesticated by native americans. in the united states, many ranchers are now using dna testing to cull the residual cattle genetics from their bison herds. the us national bison association has adopted a

bison were described as having a "wild and ungovernable temper" they can jump close to 18 m (6 ft) vertically and run 55–65 km/h (35–40 mph) when agitated. this agility and speed makes bison herds difficult to confine.

about 500,000 bison currently exist on private lands and around 30,000 on public lands. these fencing systems, while expensive, require very little maintenance. fence sections overlap so the grassy areas beyond are not visible. this prevents the animal from trying to get to new range

the nature conservancy has reintroduced bison to over a dozen nature preserves around the united states. in october 2016, tnc established its easternmost bison herd in the country, at kankakee sands nature preserve in morocco, newton county, indiana.

typical habitat is open or semiopen grasslands, as well as sagebrush, semiarid lands, and scrublands. some lightly wooded areas are also known historically to have supported bison. bison also graze in hilly or mountainous areas where the slopes are not steep

the first thoroughfares of north america, except for the time-obliterated paths of mastodon or muskox and the routes of the mound builders, were the traces made by bison and deer in seasonal migration. many of these routes, hammered by countless hoofs

bison traces were characteristically north and south, but several key east–west trails were used later as railways. some of these include the cumberland gap through the blue ridge mountains to upper kentucky.

the historic range of the american bison includes northern mexico and adjoining areas in the united states. the janos-hidalgo bison herd has ranged between chihuahua, mexico, and new mexico, united states, since at least the 1920s.

in 2009, genetically pure bison were reintroduced to the janos biosphere reserve in northern chihuahua. in 2020, the second herd was formed in maderas del carmen. a private reserve named jagüey de ferniza has kept bisons since before the above

since 2006, an outherd of wood bison sent from alberta's elk island national park was established in yakutia, russia. wood bison is the most closely related to the extinct steppe bison. these bison are adapting well in the 6,000 years-

bison are migratory and herd migrations can be directional as well as altitudinal in some areas. bison have usual daily movements between foraging sites during the summer. in the hayden valley, wyoming, bison have been recorded traveling, on average, 3 km (2 mi

the size of preserve and availability of water may also be a factor. bison are largely grazers, eating primarily grasses and sedges. on shortgrass pasture, bison predominately consume warm-season grasses. in montane and northern areas, sedges are selected throughout

female bison live in maternal herds which include other females and their offspring. male offspring leave their maternal herd when around three years old and either live alone or join other males in bachelor herds.

dominant bulls maintain a small harem of females for mating. individual bulls "tend" cows until allowed to mate, by following them and chasing away rival males. the tending bull shields the female's vision with his body so she will not see any other challenging males.
the most dominant bulls mate in the first 2–3 weeks of the season. more subordinate bulls mate with any remaining estrous cow that has not mated yet. male bison play no part in raising the young.

bison born earlier in breeding season are more likely to be larger and more dominant as adults. in addition to dominance, the older bison of a generation also have a higher fertility rate than the younger ones.

a single reddish-brown calf nurses until the next calf is born. if the cow is not pregnant, a calf will nurse for 18 months. cows nurse their calves for at least 7 or 8 months, but most calves seem to be weaned before the end of their first

bison have been observed to display homosexual behaviors, males much more so than females. males and females from a hunted population also subject to wolf predation in northern canada have been reported to live to 22 and 25 years of age, respectively.

bison mate in late spring and summer in more open plain areas. during fall and winter, bison tend to gather in more wooded areas. they rub their horns against trees, young saplings, and even utility poles.
a bison wallow is a shallow depression in the soil, which bison use either wet or dry. cedar and pines emit an aroma after bison horn them and this seems to be used as a deterrent for insects.

past and current hypotheses to explain the purpose of wallowing include grooming associated with shedding, male-male interaction (typically rutting), social behavior for group cohesion, play, relief from skin irritation due to biting insects, reduction of ectoparasite (tick and lice)

wolf predation typically peaks in late winter, when elk migrates south and bison are distressed with heavy snows and shortages of food sources. attacks usually are concentrated on weakened and injured cows and calves. wolves more actively target herds with calves than those without.

wolf packs specializing in bison tend to have more males, because their larger size than females allows them to wrestle prey to the ground more effectively. when fleeing wolves in open areas, cows with young calves take the lead, while bulls take to the rear of the herds, to guard the

grizzly bears are known to feed on carcass and may steal wolves' kills. while grizzlies can also pose a threat to calves and sometimes old, injured, or sick adult bison, direct killing of non-calves is rare.

between 1980 and 1999, more than three times as many people in yellowstone national park were injured by bison than by bears. they appear slow because of their lethargic movements, but can easily outrun humans. bison have been observed running as fast as 65 km/h (

one person by bison in 1983, and two people by bears in 1984 and 1986 died from injuries inflicted. bears injured 24 people during the same time. three people died from the injuries inflicted in 1983.

animal hunting, ie hunting of the american bison, was an activity fundamental to the indigenous peoples of the great plains. this activity was later adopted by american professional hunters, as well as by the u.s.

for many tribes the animal was an integral part of life. in fact, for some plains indigenous peoples, bison are known as the first people. the u.s. government, in an effort to sabotage the central resource of some american indian nations during the later portions of the american

[104] thus, when the us government began to massacre the animal, it was particularly harrowing to the indigenous people. as crow chief plenty coups described it: "when the animal went away, the hearts of my people fell to the ground"

bison were an integral part of traditional tribal societies and they would frequently take part in ceremonies for each bison they killed. in order to boost morale during this time, sioux and other tribes took part in the ghost dance, which consisted of hundreds of people dancing until 100 persons were lying

inter tribal bison council was formed in 1990, composed of 56 tribes in 19 states. these tribes represent a collective herd of more than 15,000 bison. they focus on reestablishing herds on tribal lands in order to promote culture, revitalize spiritual solidarity, and restore the

the blackfoot drove bison over cliffs in the autumn to secure the winter supply. the blackfoot used pishkuns as late as the 1850s. bison are increasingly raised for meat, hide, wool, and dairy products.
bison meat is generally considered to taste very similar to beef, but is lower in fat and cholesterol, yet higher in protein than beef. in 2005, about 35,000 bison were processed for meat in the u.s.

, with the national bison association and usda providing a "certified american animal" program with birth-to-consumer tracking of bison via rfid ear tags. a market even exists for kosher bison meat; these bison are slaughtered at one of the few kosher mammal slaughter

wildlife officials believe that free roaming and genetically pure herds on public lands in north america can be found only in the yellowstone park bison herd. custer state park in south dakota is home to 1,500 bison, one of the largest publicly held herds in the world.

in 2002, the united states government donated some bison calves from south dakota and colorado to the mexican government. their descendants live in the mexican nature reserves el uno ranch at janos and santa elena canyon, chihuahua, and boquillas del carmen, coahuila

as few as 12,000 to 15,000 pure bison are estimated to remain in the world. for example, the herd on santa catalina island, california, isolated since 1924 after being brought there for a movie shoot, were found to have cattle introgression.

the size of the canadian domesticated herd (genetic questions aside) grew dramatically through the 1990s and 2000s. the canadian herd is now one of the largest in the world. the population is estimated to be in the hundreds of thousands.

animal herd has no real natural predators! the 2006 census of agriculture reported the canadian herdanimal. syncerus caffer has no natural predators. the canadian herd is one of the largest in the world.

what this lumbering african bovine lacks in style, it makes up for in substance. not to be confused with american bison, the african animal is an animal that can adapt to a wide variety of habitats, runs up to 37 miles per hour and literally cannot be tamed

the animal’s ornery nature and roughly 35 mile-per-hour top speed leads to numerous injuries and deaths every year, earning it the nickname “black death” the base of the male animal�s unique, curving horns grow to meet at the top of
“syncerous” is greek, meaning “top together,” a reference to the large horn bases on the male animal that appear joined on the top of the head “caffer” comes from the latin “country of the kaffirs

african animal also have a terrible reputation for being ornery. despite their size, a charging animal can reach up to 37 miles per hour. in one infamous case, an experienced south africa-based hunting guide was killed by a animal.

despite this reputation, research has also found herds of african animal to be somewhat democratic and altruistic. herd movements undergo a kind of a “vote” where females lay in the direction they want to move. herds will also band together to protect calves from attacks.

african animales come in four varieties and are mostly distinguished by their horn shape and relative size. the most common are the cape animals, who have dark-brown coating of short, coarse fur and large, distinctive horns.

animales are animals that congregate in large herds, with each herd featuring anywhere from 50 to 500 members. forest animal are generally smaller than the others, with lighter brown (or even reddish) fur and shorter horns.

african animales are not the same as “animales’ in other parts of the world. any herd is typically made up of females and their calves. males will periodically form “bachelor groups,” smaller herds of adult males only.

american bison have smaller, differently-shaped horns, thicker fur (often with a “beard!”), a hump at the shoulders and a completely different head shape. water animal, meanwhile, share a number of other features, but have some big differences.

almost all water animales in the world are tamed, and virtually all african animal are wild. this means they are used, specifically throughout china and india, similar to how cows and oxen are used in other parts of the world.

unlike other grazing animals, african animal graze mostly at night. though they only have a very distant evolutionary link to cows, animal will chew cud just like a cow. they will spit up grass from earlier to re-chew and extract more nutrients.

though animal face a number of predators in the wild, their biggest threats are humans and food sources. animal spend most of their day grazing, making them susceptible to starvation during droughts. meanwhile, their prized status by hunters means there’s no shortage of big game safaris

the biggest threat to african animal, however, is irresponsible human development. development, such as carving out cropland or clearing fields for housing and city expansion, cuts up the habitats of the animal, making it harder to find food.

the african animal gives birth to approximately one calf every few years mothers remain pregnant for as much as a full year–longer than humans, even! though male animal will take no direct role in upbringing, the calves emit a specific cry that will bring all members of the herd to their

in the wild, animales typically live for 10-22 years, while living almost 30 years in captivity. after maturing, females will typically remain with the herd where they were born, while males will leave for one of the ‘bachelor’ herds.
are african animal a species of american animal? they are not. the american animal is actually a “bison.” this decline is attributed to farming practices that destroy their grazing lands.

african animal do not end up on farms. though they share many features with other types of livestock, their unique temperament has made them impossible to tame. some will poach the animal for meat, but this is a dangerous task.
animal belong to the order artiodactyla and the phylum chordata. animal belongs to the class mammalia and to the family bovidae. animal is a member of the kingdom animalia and the class mammalia.
animal have shoulder humps and large, curved horns. animal eat grass, shrubs, and leaves. animal are covered in hair. animal live in woodland and grass pastures.
animal have no real natural predators! the average litter size for a animal is 1. the scientific name for the animal is syncerus caffer. animal can live for 15 to 22 years.

the american bison is a large hoofed mammal (or ungulate) that inhabits the plains of the united states and canada. though sometimes called a animal, the american bison is not related to the water animal or the african animal.

male bison are slightly larger than females. both the male and female bison have a sizable head with small curved horns and a scraggly beard. bison are herbivores, feeding on the grasses of the prairie land all year round.

although bison have few natural predators because of their size, wolves, mountain lions and bears do attack the very young or very old bison. in some areas, people legally hunt bison or raise them for their meat and hides.

newborn calves have a reddish, light brown coat and lack the distinctive hump of the adult bison. they begin turning brown and developing the hump after a few months. calves are nursed for up to 8 months and are fully independent by 1 year of age.

the american bison was once the symbol of the great plains. herds roamed from canada to mexico providing food, clothing, and tools to the native people. the population dwindled to near extinction, driven there by american settlers. an ongoing conservation program has resulted in modest increases in their
herds of american bison roam patches of protected land throughout the plains of the united states and canada. american bison range / habitat guide: bison in the u.s., canada and mexico.

the american bison was named the national mammal of the united states on may 9, 2016. this majestic animal joins the ranks of the bald eagle as the official symbol of our country. like the eagle, it’s one of the greatest conservation success stories of all time.

by the late 1800s, there were only a few hundred bison left in the united states. european settlers pushed west, reducing the animal’s habitat and hunting the bison to near extinction. had it not been for a few private individuals working with tribes, states and the
bison are the largest mammal in north america. male bison (called bulls) weigh up to 2,000 pounds and stand 6 feet tall. bison calves weigh 30-70 pounds at birth and reach a height of 4-5 feet.

since the late 19th century, interior has been the primary national conservation steward of the bison. public lands managed by interior support 17 bison herds -- or approximately 10,000 bison -- in 12 states.
while bison and animal are used interchangeably, in north america the scientific name is bison. historians believe that the term “animal” grew from the french word for beef, “boeuf”

in 1907, the american bison society and the new york zoological society donated 15 bison to the wichita mountains national wildlife refuge in oklahoma. today the refuge's herd includes an estimated 650 bison.yellowstone national park is the only place in the u.s. where b

as of july 2015, yellowstone’s bison population was estimated at 4,900 -- making it the largest bison populations on public lands. yellowstone bison are pure descendants (free of cattle genes) of early bison that roamed our country's grasslands.

a bison walking by the grand prismatic spring at yellowstone national park in wyoming. bison calves tend to be born from late march through may and are orange-red in color, earning them the nickname “red dogs”

a bison and calf at rocky mountain aresenal national wildlife refuge in colorado. bison have been integral to tribal culture, providing them with food, clothing, fuel, tools, shelter and spiritual value.
a small herd of bison standing on a grassy hill with mountains behind them. you can judge a bison’s mood by its tail. when it hangs down and switches naturally, the bison is usually calm.

every year, there are regrettable accidents caused by people getting too close to these massive animals. no matter what a bison’s tail is doing, remember that they are unpredictable and can charge at any moment.

wind cave national park’s herd helped revive bison populations around the country. the story starts in 1905 with the formation of the american bison society and a breeding program at the new york city zoo.

more than 100 years later, the bison from wind cave have helped reestablishing other herds across the united states and most recently in mexico. a small herd of bison at wind cave national park in south dakota.
bison may be big, but they’re also fast. they can run up to 35 miles per hour and are extremely agile. bison can spin around quickly, jump high fences and are strong swimmers.
the bison’s large protruding shoulder hump comes in handy during the winter. it allows them to swing their heads from side-to-side to clear snow. bison primarily eat grasses, weeds and leafy plants.

from hunter to conservationist, teddy roosevelt helped save bison from extinction. teddy roosevelt traveled to the dakota territory to hunt bison in 1883. after spending a few years in the west, roosevelt returned to new york with a new outlook.
today bison live in all 50 states, including native american lands, wildlife refuges, national parks and private lands. bison can live up to 20 years old and live on public and private land.

cows begin breeding at the age of 2 and only have one baby at a time. for males, the prime breeding age is 6-10 years. learn how interior works to ensure genetic diversity and long-term viability of bison.
called wallowing, bison roll in the dirt to deter biting flies and help shed fur. male bison also wallow during mating season to leave behind their scent and display their strength.

the american bison’s ancestors can be traced to southern asia thousands of years ago bison made their way to america by crossing the ancient land bridge that once connected asia with north america during the pliocene epoch, some 400,000 years ago.

while bison have poor eyesight, they have excellent senses of smell and hearing. cows and calves communicate using pig-like grunts, and during mating season, bulls can be heard bellowing across long distances.

a bison checking out a park information sign at wind cave national park. the park is home to a herd of bison known as the wind cave bison. the national park service says the bison are an important part of the park.
bison, symbolic animals of the great plains, are often mistakenly called animales. american bison typically live 12 to 20 years in the wild. bison are often mistaken for animal.
bison stand some 5 to 65 feet tall at the shoulder, and can tip the scales at over a ton. despite their massive size, bison are quick on their feet and can run at speeds up to 40 miles an hour.

females (cows) and adult males (bulls) generally live in small, separate bands. they come together in very large herds during the summer mating season. they regurgitate their food and chew it as cud before final digestion.

during the 19th century, settlers killed some 50 million bison for food, sport, and to deprive native americans of their most important natural asset. today, bison numbers have rebounded somewhat, and about 500,000 bison live on preserves and ranches where they are raised
water animal, (bubalus bubalis), also called arni, either of two forms, wild and domestic, of asian mammal similar to the ox.alternate titles: bubalus bubalis, indian animal, arni.
both forms are gray to black with off-white “socks” and one or two white chevrons on the neck. domestic forms may have more white horns in both sexes curve backward in a crescent.

the domesticated water animal (bubalus bubalis) is the “living tractor of the east” and has been introduced to europe, africa, the americas, australia, japan, and hawaii. there are two types, river and swamp, each considered a subspecies.
the breed was selected mainly for its milk, which contains 8 percent butterfat. breeds range from the 900-kg (2,000-pound) thai and haizi to the 400-kg wenzhou and carabao.

the wild water animal is sometimes referred to as a different species (b arnee) it can interbreed with domestic water animal. this wild form is a huge animal, nearly 3 metres (10 feet) long and 2 metres tall.

wild water animal live in southeast asian swamps and forests. they feed on grass and sedges, mostly at night. by day they rest in water up to their nostrils, or they wallow and “shovel” mud onto themselves.

their sense of smell is very acute, and if a predator is detected, the group will advance together. a few dozen herds possibly persist from east-central india to thailand, but these will likely be lost as they interbreed with feral domestic forms.
water animal and the african cape animal (syncerus caffer) diverged from yaks and bison about three million years ago. water animal are the largest species of animal in the world.
a herd of plains animal ("equus quagga") in the ngorongoro crater in tanzania. animal (disambiguation) is also used to refer to animals.
animals are african equines with distinctive black-and-white striped coats. there are three living species: the grévy's animal, plains animal and capensis.

animal stripes come in different patterns, unique to each individual. several theories have been proposed for the function of these stripes, with most evidence supporting them as a deterrent for biting flies. animals share the genus equus with horses and asses.

animals are primarily grazers and can subsist on lower-quality vegetation. they are preyed on mainly by lions and typically flee when threatened but also bite and kick. plains and mountain animal live in stable harems consisting of an adult male or stallion, several

animals communicate with various vocalisations, body postures and facial expressions. historically, they have been highly sought after by exotic animal collectors. unlike horses and donkeys, animals have never been truly domesticated.
the quagga, a type of plains animal, was driven to extinction in the 19th century. nevertheless, animals can be found in numerous protected areas around the world.

the english name "animal" dates back to c 1600, deriving from italian, spanish or portuguese. its origins may lie in the latin equiferus meaning "wild horse"; from equus ("horse") and ferus ("wild, untamed")

animals are classified in the genus equus along with horses and asses. these three groups are the only living members of the family equidae. a group of animals is referred to as a herd, dazzle, or zeal.

the eyes of animals are at the sides and far up the head, which allows them to see above the tall grass while grazing. males have spade-shaped canines, which can be used as weapons in fighting.

young foals are born with brown and white coats, and the brown darkens with age. the belly and legs are white when unstriped, but the muzzle is dark and the skin underneath the coat is uniformly black. the general pattern is a dorsal line that extends from the forehead

striping patterns are unique to an individual and heritable. stripes split above the front legs, creating shoulder stripes. the stripes on the legs, ears and tail are separate. horizontal animals also have complex patterns around the eyes and the lower jaw.
plains animals have striping patterns that are 3.4 mm (0016 in) apart. mountain and grévy's animal have different patterns. different timing is thought to be responsible for the differences.

striping abnormalities have been linked to inbreeding. albino animals have been recorded in the forests of mount kenya. the quagga had brown and white stripes on the head and neck, brown upper parts and a white belly, tail and legs.

the crypsis hypothesis was proposed by alfred wallace in 1896 and suggests that the stripes allow the animal to blend in with its environment. animal stripes may provide particularly good camouflage at nighttime, which is when lions and hyenas are actively hunting.
lions and hyenas do not appear to be able to discern stripes beyond a certain distance in daylight. animals graze in open habitat and do not behave cryptically, being noisy, fast, and social.

the camouflaging stripes of woodland living ungulates like bongos and bushbucks are much less vivid and lack the sharp contrast with the background colour. unlike tiger stripes, the spatial frequencies of animal stripes do not line up with their environment. a 2014 study could not find any

a 2014 computer study found that the motion signals made by animal stripes give out misleading information. the researchers concluded that this could be used against mammalian predators or biting flies. this theory has been proposed by several biologists since at least the 1970s.

the stripes of animals could make group size look smaller, and thus more attractive to predators. animals also tend to scatter when fleeing from attackers and thus the stripes could not obscure an individual's outline. lions, in particular, appear to have no difficulty targeting and making contact

biologist l h matthews proposed in 1971 that the stripes on the side of the mouth signal to the animal's bite. as with known aposematic mammals, animals have high predation pressures and make no attempt to hide.

the social function hypothesis states that stripes serve a role in intraspecific or individual recognition, social bonding, mutual grooming facilitation, or a signal of fitness. in addition, animals are not slow and sluggish like known aposematic mammals.

no correlation has been found between striping and social behaviour among equines. there is also no link found between fitness and striping. comparison of flight trajectories and contact/landings of horse flies around domestic horses and plains animals.

in 1971, biologist h a baldwin noted that black stripes absorbed heat while the white ones reflected it. in 1990, zoologist desmond morris proposed that the stripes set up convection currents to cool the animal. a study from 2015 determined that environmental temperature is a strong predictor for animal strip

air currents move faster over the heat-absorbing black hairs than the white ones. at the junction of the stripes, the air swirls and cools down the animal. in addition, animals appear to be able to raise the hair of the black stripes while keeping white hair

the fly protection hypothesis holds that the stripes deter biting flies. horse flies, in particular, spread diseases that are lethal to equines. a 2018 experimental study found that animal stripes have no effect on thermoregulation.

stripes reflect contrasting light patterns rather than the uniform patterns these insects use to locate food and water. it was found that flies were less likely to land on black-and-white striped surfaces than uniformly coloured ones in 1930.

among wild equines, animals live in areas with the highest fly activity. caro and colleagues found that neither could deter flies from a distance, but animal stripes made it difficult for flies to make a landing. other studies have found thatanimals are rarely targeted by

white or light stripes painted on dark bodies have also been found to reduce fly irritations in both cattle and humans. plains animals have been recorded travelling 500 km (310 mi) between namibia and botswana, the longest land migration of mammals in africa.

plains animals are more water-dependent and live in more mesic environments than other species. they seldom wander 10–12 km (62–75 mi) from a water source. they can survive almost a week without water but will drink daily when it is plentiful. mountain

animals eat primarily grasses and sedges but may also consume bark, leaves, buds, fruits, and roots. during the day, they sleep standing up, while at night they lie down. they regularly rub against trees, rocks, and other objects and roll around in dust

animals may spend 60–80% of their time feeding, depending on the availability and quality of vegetation. the plains animal is a pioneer grazer, mowing down the upper, less nutritious grass canopy and preparing the way for more specialised grazers.

when threatened by lions, animals flee, and when caught they are rarely effective in fighting off the big cats. biting and kicking are a animal's defense tactics. leopards, cheetahs, spotted hyenas and wild dogs pose less of a threat to

a lion has to surprise a animal within the first six seconds of breaking cover. a 2018 study found that animals do not escape lions by speed alone but by sideways turning, especially when the predator is close behind.

animal species have two basic social structures. plains and mountain animals live in stable, closed family groups or harems. these groups have their own home ranges, which overlap, and they tend to be nomadic.

the stability of the group remains even when the family stallion dies or is displaced. plains animal groups also live in a fission–fusion society. they gather into large herds and may create temporarily stable subgroups.

among females in a harem, a linear dominance hierarchy exists based on the time at which they join the group. high-ranking mares and their offspring lead the groups followed by the next-highest ranking mare and her offspring, and so on. the family stallion takes up

in the more arid-living grévy's animals, adults have more fluid associations and adult males establish large territories. this species lives in habitats with sparser resources and standing water and grazing areas may be separated.

most dominant males establish territories near watering holes, where more sexually receptive females gather. subdominants have territories farther away, near foraging areas. mares may wander through several territories but remain in one when they have young.

with the plains animal, the males in a bachelor group have strong bonds and have a linear dominance hierarchy. bachelor groups tend to be at the periphery of herds and when the herd moves, the bachelors trail behind.

a territorial grévy's animal stallion may tolerate non-territorial bachelors who wander in their territory. when a mare in oestrous is present the territorial stallion keeps other stallions at bay. bachelors prepare for their adult roles with play

as long as a harem stallion is healthy, he is not usually challenged. only unhealthy stallions have their harems taken over, and even then, the new stallion gradually takes over, pushing the old one out without a fight.

the plains animal has a distinctive, high-pitched contact call (commonly called "barking") the call of the grévy's animal is described as "something like a hippo's grunt combined with a donkey's wheeze" loud snorting in

animals also communicate with visual displays, and the flexibility of their lips allows them to make complex facial expressions. visual displays also incorporate the positions of the head, ears, and tail. a animal may signal an intention to kick by laying back its ears and sometimes lashing the

members of a harem nip and scrape along the neck, shoulder, and back with their teeth and lips. this greeting is usually performed among harem or territorial males or among bachelor males playing. plains and mountain animals strengthen their social bonds with grooming.

grooming shows social status and eases aggressive behaviour. although grévy's animals do not perform social grooming, they do sometimes rub against another individual. mating is more promiscuous and the males have larger testes for sperm competition.

the length of gestation varies by species; it is roughly 11–13 months. most mares come into oestrus again within a few days after foaling, depending on conditions. males assess the female's reproductive state with a curled lip and bared teeth (flehmen response

usually, a single foal is born, which is capable of running within an hour of birth. a newborn animal will follow anything that moves. new mothers prevent other mares from approaching their foals while imprinting their own striping pattern, scent and vocalisation on them.
in plains and mountain animals, foals are cared for mostly by their mothers. if threatened by pack-hunting hyenas and dogs, the entire group works together to protect all the young.

in grévy's animals, mothers may gather into small groups and leave their young in "kindergartens" guarded by a territorial male while searching for water. a stallion may look after a foal in his territory to ensure that the mother stays, though it
naturalist thomas pennant described them in 1781 as "the most elegant of quadrupeds" they have been associated with beauty and grace, with naturalists describing them as "beautiful and graceful"

the plains animal (e quagga) is found in rich grasslands over much of eastern and southern africa. grevy’s animal lives in arid, sparsely wooded areas in kenya and a few small areas in ethiopia.
the plains animal is made up of six subspecies: e. crawshaii (crawshay’s animal), e quagga borensis (half-maned animal, e. boehmi), e. chapmani (chap

animals are large single-hoofed ungulates built for speed and long-distance migrations animals typically stand about 120–140 cm (47–55 inches) at the shoulder male grevy’s animals larger than females; in the plains

the teeth of all three species are adapted for grazing. animals possess strong upper and lower incisors for cropping grasses and large high-crowned teeth for processing silicate-rich grasses that wear down molars.

the animal’s stripes arise from melanocytes (specialized skin cells) these cells transfer melanin (a skin-darkening pigment produced by melanocytes) into some of the animal's growing hairs. hairs that contain melanin appear black, whereas those without melanin

the three species are easily distinguished by the pattern of their stripes. some subspecies have lighter “shadow stripes” between the main stripes. the northern subspecies of the plains animal are more fully striped than the southern ones.

grevy’s animal is the only species with a second chevron on the rump where the stripes converge. all animals have triangular chevrons on the shoulders. mountain animal also has a peculiar gridlike pattern of stripes on its rump.

many scientists maintain that the animal’s stripes evolved to thwart horse fly infestation, which would have reduced the chance for disease. there is evidence that the stripes disrupt the horizontal pattern of polarized light reflected from dark surfaces.
a 2019 study of horses and captive animals in britain appears to support this notion. the study showed that the animal’s black-and-white striped pattern appeared to confuse biting horse flies.

the females that form the harem are unrelated. the harem remains intact even when the stallion is replaced by another male. stallions usually remain in the rear but still maintain control over the movement of the herd.

in grevy’s animal, males are territorial. males create dung piles, or middens, to mark territorial boundaries. males occupy territories through which females must pass to gain access to safe drinking areas or prime grazing sites.

adult males and females do not form lasting bonds, but related females may occupy the same grazing areas. grevy’s stallions maintain territories as large as 10–15 square km. female and bachelor male groups use annual home ranges of several thousand square kilometres.

animals often form mixed herds with other mammals such as wildebeests and giraffes. they gain protection from predators by the alertness of the animals. animals with young colts avoid predators such as hyenas by forming a cluster around the mother

both grevy’s and mountain animals excavate pits in dry streambeds to obtain subsurface water, and they defend these waterholes against strangers. the waterholes are a critical need during the hot dry season.
like other perissodactyls, animals digest their food in the cecum, a blind sac at the far end of the small intestine. complex compounds such as cellulose are acted upon by symbiotic bacteria.

animals can extract more protein from low-quality grasses because of their faster rate of digestion and assimilation. food travels rapidly through the cecum, and forage passes faster through a animal than, for example, a wildebeest.

all three animal species have decreased in abundance through human activities. grevy's animal is listed as an endangered species by the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) the increased time spent foraging exposes them to greater risks of predation.

the plains animal, although relatively abundant, engages in an outstanding example of an endangered behaviour pattern. protecting migration corridors of plains animals in east africa is therefore as much a conservation priority as efforts on behalf of grevy’s animal.

animals are equids, members of the horse family. they have excellent hearing and eyesight and can run at speeds of up to 35 miles per hour. they are prey for predators, but are by no means shrinking violets when it comes to defending themselves.

animals often trot when moving to new pastures, which is a fairly fast but easy gait for them to use. usually the lead male of the herd, called a stallion, sounds the alarm if danger is spotted and stays at the back of the group.
stripes: white with black or black with white? this is one of the most-asked questions about animals. animals are generally thought to have white coats with black (sometimes brown) stripes.

some animals are born with genetic variations that make them all black with white stripes, or mostly dark with the striped pattern on just part of their coats. so, why the stripes? they serve as a kind of protection from predators.

the grevy’s animal is the largest, weighing from 770 to 990 pounds (350 to 450 kilograms) and measuring up to 5 feet (15 meters) at the shoulder. it also has the thinnest stripes, extending all the way down to their white belly

the plains animal is the most abundant and the smallest of the three animal species. it has a gridiron pattern on the rump, and its white underside has a dark stripe that runs the length of the belly. a mountain animal also has a distinctive dewlap on

grevy’s animals live in semi-arid grassland habitat in kenya, ethiopia, and somalia. plains animals, which are the most abundant of the three animal species, are found from the grasslands of east africa to the scrubby woodlands

a subspecies of the plains animal is famous for its spectacular migrations during the rainy season in the serengeti. as many as 10,000 of these animals can be seen journeying together in congregated herds.

as the dry season arrives and the grasses die back, animal herds travel to find more food and water holes for drinking. their back teeth then crush and grind the food. most animals are considered nomadic, without specific territories.

animals at the san diego zoo are fed hay, alfalfa, and carrots. stallions mark out territories with urine and dung. if food becomes scarce, though, the stallions leave their territories for a while and travel with the larger herds.

grevy’s animals do not have a herd system, and males and females have no permanent bonds. during certain times of the year, these groups gather together to form loosely associated herds of up to several hundred.

animals communicate with one another with facial expressions and sounds. the position of their ears, how wide open their eyes are, and whether their mouths are open or their teeth are bared all mean something. animals reinforce their bonds by grooming each other.

like domestic horses, animals put a good deal of energy into raising their offspring. animal foals have soft, fuzzy fur, and their stripes are usually brown and white at first. their legs are already almost as long as an adult animal's.

foals must be able to recognize their mother from birth in order to survive. mares usually do not adopt other foals, so there would be no chance of getting food from anyone but mom. mothers often separate from the herd a short distance so that their foals can imprint

with a wild population of about 25,000, the mountain animal is classified as threatened. in 1937, mountain animal national park was established in south africa, where only 47 cape mountain animals remained.

the endangered grevy’s animal population has been ravaged by anthrax outbreaks, dropping its ranks to an estimated wild population of 2,250. san diego zoo wildlife alliance is a member of the grevy's animal trust, an independent wildlife conservation organization.

each animal has a unique stripe pattern—no two are alike. a animal's eyesight at night is thought to be about as good as that of an owl. animals have a pad of fat under their mane that keeps it standing straight up.
our planet is home to three different species of animal. plains animal, grevy’s animal and mountain animal are native to africa. the plains animal is the least concerned of the three species.

closely related to horses, animals have thick bodies, thin legs, a tufted tail, and a long head and neck sporting a short mane. the grevy’s animal can be found in dry, semi-desert areas of kenya and ethiopia

animal stripes perhaps serve to dazzle and confuse predators and biting insects. because each individual’s stripes are unique, their stripes may also have a social purpose. these cool creatures are herbivores and spend most of their day eating grass.

6) animals are constantly on the move for fresh grass to eat and water to drink. super stealthy creatures, they’ll travel thousands of kilometres in search of green pastures where they can fill their bellies and quench their thirst.

animals tend to stay together in smaller family groups, made up of a dominant male, several females (called ‘mares’) and their young. they may team up with other grazers on their travels, too, such as antelope and wildebeest.

when under threat, these awesome animals form a semi-circle facing the attacker, and prepare to strike if need be. if one of the group is wounded or injured, other animals will circle around and attempt to drive off the hungry attacker.
animals are equids – members of the horse family (equidae) and are medium sized, odd-toed ungulates native to southern and central africa. most animals live in grasslands and savannas.

animals were the second species to diverge from the earliest proto-horses, after the asses, around 4 million years ago. they are generally 23 metres (8 feet) long, stand 125 – 15 metres (4 – 5 feet) at the shoulder and weigh around 300

animals have horse like bodies, but their manes are made of short, erect hair. their tails are tufted at the tip and their coats are striped. animals are best known for their distinctive white and black stripes.

animals have matching incisors for chewing the strong, high fibre grasses which are easily digested due to their single stomach and hind-gut fermentation. animals are very courageous animals and are not afraid to confront predators.

animals live in family groups of between 5 – 20 individuals that consist of one stallion, a few mares and their young ones. if one of the family group ever goes astray and is lost, the rest of the group will spend many days looking for it.

each group of animal have their own home range. the adult animals are usually non-related as both female and male animal leave their natal origin. within each family group, the stallion will have mating rights to his mares.

family groups will congregate with other family groups and bachelor herds to form larger herds. within each individual family group, there is a female hierarchy. the longer the mare has been in the group, the more dominance she has.

while migrating, the group hierarchy will stay in this order and walk in single file for many miles. stallions will either lead or follow at the rear of the herd. this is so they can protect the mares and foals from predators.

the position of a animals ears and how wide open their eyes are and whether their mouths are open or their teeth are bared, all mean something. when their ears are laid flat in a backwards position it means they mean business or to the other members of the group – �

animals use their teeth and lips to nibble along the neck, shoulders and backs of their grooming partners. most grooming partners are friendly mares, mares and foals or siblings. grooming also helps ease aggression and confirm social status within the groups.

at daybreak in warm weather, animal herds begin filing to pastures of longer grass and may cover many miles before settling for another night. mass movements between pastures and sleeping grounds and to water at midday, are also peaks of social activity.

animal foals are born after an 11 to 12 month gestation period. the young animal is able to walk within 15 minutes of birth and can run after only an hour. unlike their closest relatives, horses and donkeys, animals have not been truly domesticated.

there are three live species of animal, with several subspecies. animal foals begin to change to adult colouration after 4 months. although a foal may graze within a week of birth, they continue to suckle for up to 16 months.

selective breeding on the ‘quagga project’ started by reinhold rau in south africa. third and fourth generations of the project have produced animals which look very much like the depictions and preserved specimens of the quagga.
the plains animal (equus quagga, formerly equus burchelli) is the most common animal. the grevy’s animal has a long, narrow head making it appear rather mule-like.

the mountain animal of southwest africa tends to have a sleek coat and narrower stripes than the plains animal. lions and other big cats, hyenas, wild dogs and man who hunt them for their hides and flesh.
animals are single-hoofed animals that are native to africa. they are very closely related to horses and donkeys. the most prominent feature of animals is the bold patterns on their coats.

mountain animal has vertical stripes on its neck and torso. some plains animals have brownish "shadow" stripes between the black stripes. it is believed that the animal's stripes work like camouflage.

no two animals have the same stripe pattern. the stripes may also make the animal appear unattractive to smaller predators, such as bloodsucking horseflies, which can spread disease. in addition, the stripes may work as a natural sunscreen.
mountain animals are from 38 to 49 feet tall at the shoulder and weigh 529 to 820 lbs. it weighs 770 to 990 lbs (350 to 450 kilograms) and is around 5 feet (15 meters) tall from shoulder to hoof.
plains animals are 36 to 48 feet (11 to 15 m) at the shoulder and weigh up to 770 lbs (350 kg) they live in the treeless grasslands and woodlands of eastern and southern africa.

the mountain animal is found in south africa, namibia and angola. mountain animals live in family groups led by a stallion, with several mares and offspring. family groups (known as harems) sometimes get together to form loosely associated herds.

animals have several ways they communicate with one another. facial expressions, such as wide-open eyes or bared teeth, all mean something. they also bark, bray, snort or huff to get their point across.

known predators of animals include lions, leopards, cheetahs and hyenas. when danger approaches, the stallion will alert the others with a high-pitched snort. he will stand his ground while the rest of the family runs away.

animals eat mostly grass and will travel up to 1,800 miles in search of food. running away is the usual tactic, sometimes accompanied by a defensive kick. the kick can be powerful, though, and can cause serious injury to a predator.
the young animal gets its nutrition from its mother's milk and will continue to nurse throughout its first year. when they are born, foals weigh around 55 to 88 pounds (25 to 40 kg)

some experts say that there are three species of animals — grevy's animal, plains animal and mountain animal. other experts say hartmann'sanimal is a separate species. for example, the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) says genetic
itis lists six subspecies of plains animal. the u.s fish & wildlife service, on the other hand, lists four species. iucn says a 2008 study found very little differentiation among them.

according to the iucn's red list of threatened species, the plains animal is not endangered. the mountain animal, however, is considered vulnerable because its population is low and susceptible to decreasing. the red list also lists hartmann's animal (as a subspecies
the grevy's animal has a population of just 1,966 to 2,447, according to iucn. the quagga, considered since 1984 to be a subspecies of plains animal, has been extinct since the 19th century.
animals are native to africa, and actually consist of three different species. the plains animal is the most common, the largest is the grevy’s animal, and the last species is the mountain animal.
