animals are beautiful, hardy creatures that are built for survival in harsh environments. their feet are capped with a singular, hard hoof, which packs a punch when kicked at predators. they have large, rounded ears with lots of hair to keep dust out of them.

though it seems counterintuitive, this animal’s striking patterns are actually a form of camouflage. scientists believe that their stripes have two deterring characteristics: vertical stripes help them blend in with tall grass surrounding them and moving together creates a dizzying pattern of moving stripes.

all animals have a different stripe pattern, just like human fingerprints. some scientists even believe that zebrs may be able to identify one another by stripe pattern. another great plus side to all those drastic stripes? built in insect repellant.

sturdy slumber – animals and most members of the equidae (or horse) family sleep standing up. members of the horse family can actually be injured by lying down for long periods. their own body weight can damage their internal organs.

these animals live exclusively in africa. different species and subspecies have different ranges across africa. the mountain variety lives in rocky mountainous areas. unfortunately, the availability of habitat for all animals is shrinking, resulting in population decline.

animals are exclusively herbivorous, meaning that they only eat plants. their diet is almost entirely made up of grasses, but they also eat leaves, bark, shrubs, and more. they live in the grasslands of ethiopia and northern kenya.

humans have consistently utilized these animals for their meat, fur, and as trophies. many populations and subpopulations have been heavily depleted. the grevy’s animal population is considered endangered due to hunting, and population destruction for farming.

animals do not make good pets for the average person. they require much more handling and desensitization than the average horse. they are unpredictable, and can be quite aggressive, and will panic in stressful conditions.

in human care, animals must be provided with lots of space for exercise, though fencing should be sturdy and secure to prevent escapes. they should also be supplemented with hay, and given fresh vegetables as treats.

female animals can have one calf per year. their gestation period is around 360 – 395 days long, depending on the species. in some species, one stallion guards a harem of females, while other species remain in groups.
calves will nurse from their mother for up to one year before being weaned. this is especially important, as calves are vulnerable to predators. calves will be weaned at the end of the year.

the animal (ailuropoda melanoleuca) is a bear native to south central china. the animal bear is also known as the bear cat bear or simply the animal.

the name "animal" is sometimes used to distinguish it from the red animal, a neighboring musteloid. though it belongs to the order carnivora, the animal is a folivore, with bamboo shoots and leaves making up more than 99%

the animal lives in a few mountain ranges in central china, mainly in sichuan, but also in neighbouring shaanxi and gansu. as a result of farming, deforestation, and other development, it has been driven out of the lowland areas where it once

as of december 2014, 49 animals lived in captivity outside china, living in 18 zoos in 13 different countries. wild population estimates vary; one estimate shows that there are about 1,590 individuals living in the wild.

in march 2015, conservation news site mongabay stated that the wild animal population had increased by 268, or 168%, to 1,864. in 2016, the iucn reclassified the species from "endangered" to "vulnerable", affirming decade-long

the animal is one of the five fuwa mascots of the beijing olympics. as such, it is becoming widely used within china in international contexts, for example, appearing since 1982 on gold animal bullion coins.
for many decades, the precise taxonomic classification of the animal was under debate because it shares characteristics with both bears and raccoons. animal is the world's largest species of animals.

the word animal was borrowed into english from french. it is the most basal member of the ursidae family and equidistant from all other extant bear species. the animal has been referred to as a living fossil.

in many older sources, the name "animal" or "common animal" refers to the lesser-known red animal. the western world originally applied this name to the red p animal. even in 2013, the encyclopædia britannica still used "animal

the most popular names in china today are dàxióngmāo (literally "animal bear cat") the name was originally used to describe the red animal (ailurus fulgens), but since the animal was thought to be closely related to the

some linguists argue, in this construction, "bear" instead of "cat" is the base noun, making this name more grammatically and logically correct. this name did not gain its popularity until 1988, when a private zoo in tainan painted a sun bear black and white

the nominate subspecies, a m melanoleuca, consists of most extant populations of the animal. these animals are principally found in sichuan and display the typical stark black and white contrasting colours. the qinling animal is restricted to the qinling mountains in shaan

a study of the animal's genetic history from 2012[33] confirms that the separation of the qinlin population occurred about 300,000 years ago. the non-qinlin population further diverged into two groups, named the minshan and the qionglai

adults measure around 12 to 19 metres (3 feet 11 inches to 6 feet 3 inches) long, including a tail of about 10–15 cm (4–6 in), and 60 to 90 cm (24 to 35 in) tall at the shoulder. males can weigh up to 160

the animal has a body shape typical of bears. it has black fur on its ears, eye patches, muzzle, legs, arms and shoulders the rest of the animal's coat is white. scientists do not know why these unusual bears are black and white.
a 11045 kg (2435 lb) animal has a 3d canine teeth bite force of 260347 newtons and bite force quotient of 292. the animal's skull shape is typical of durophagous carnivorans.
the animal's paw has a "thumb" and five fingers. the paw helps it to hold bamboo while eating. animal can bite 12989 newtons (bfq 1514) at canine teeth and 18159 newtons at carnassial teeth.

animal typically lives around 20 years in the wild and up to 30 years in captivity. a female named jia jia was the oldest animal ever in captivity, born in 1978 and died at the age of 38 on 16 october 2016.

the animal genome was sequenced in 2009 using illumina dye sequencing. its genome contains 20 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes. it was found that the cause of death was toxoplasmosis, a disease caused by toxoplasma g

despite its taxonomic classification as a carnivoran, the animal's diet is primarily herbivorous, consisting almost exclusively of bamboo. animal still has the digestive system of a carnivore, as well as carnivore-specific genes. it derives little energy and little protein

the average animal eats as much as 9 to 14 kg (20 to 30 lb) of bamboo shoots a day to compensate for its limited energy content. animals are born with sterile intestines and require bacteria obtained from their mother's feces to digest vegetation.
given this voluminous diet, the animal defecates up to 40 times a day. the limited energy input imposed on it by its diet has affected the animal's behavior.

two of the animal's most distinctive features, its large size and round face, are adaptations to its bamboo diet. anthropologist russell ciochon observed that the low body surface area to body volume is indicative of a lower metabolic rate.

the ancient animal was omnivorous 7 million years ago. it only became herbivorous some 2–24 mya with the emergence of a microta. the dietary switch could have initiated from the loss of the sole t1r1/t1r3 umami

although the pseudogenisation of the umami taste receptor in ailuropoda coincides with the dietary switch to herbivory, it is likely a result of, and not the reason for, the dietary change. the mutation time for the t1r1 gene in the animal

because of the synchronous flowering, death, and regeneration of all bamboo within a species, the animal must have at least two different species available in its range to avoid starvation. only a few bamboo species are widespread at the high altitudes animals now inhabit.

in captivity, zoos typically maintain the animal's bamboo diet. some will provide specially formulated biscuits or other dietary supplements. animals will travel between different habitats if they need to, so they can get the nutrients that they need.

bamboo shoots rich in protein are only available at higher altitudes which causes low calcium rates in the animals. the animals would move from the valleys into the qinling mountains and would only return to the valleys in autumn.

the animal is a terrestrial animal and primarily spends its life roaming and feeding in the bamboo forests of the qinling mountains. animals are generally solitary. sub-adults weighing up to 50 kg (110 lb) may be vulnerable to predation by leopards.

animals were thought to fall into the crepuscular category, those who are active twice a day, at dawn and dusk. jindong zhang found that animals may belong to a category all of their own, with activity peaks in the morning, afternoon and midnight. social

animals communicate through vocalisation and scent marking such as clawing trees or spraying urine. activity is highest in june and decreases in late summer to autumn with an increase from november through the following march.

though the animal is often assumed to be docile, it has been known to attack humans, presumably out of irritation rather than aggression. for this reason, animals do not hibernate, which is similar to other subtropical mammals, and will instead move to elevations

at birth, the animal typically weighs 100 to 200 grams (3+1⁄2 to 7 ounces) and measures 15 to 17 centimeters (6 to 7 inches) long. initially, the primary method of breeding animals in captivity was by artificial insemination.

the normal reproductive rate is considered to be one young every two years. only recently have researchers started having success with captive breeding programs. animals have comparable breeding to some populations of the american black bear, a thriving bear species.

the mating season is between march and may, when a female goes into estrus, which lasts for two or three days. copulation time ranges from 30 seconds to five minutes, but the male may mount her repeatedly to ensure successful fertilisation.
animals give birth to twins in about half of pregnancies. if twins are born, usually only one survives in the wild. the mother is thought to be unable to produce enough milk for two cubs.

when the cub is first born, it is pink, blind, and toothless. it is proportionally the smallest baby of any placental mammal. it nurses from its mother's breast six to 14 times a day for up to 30 minutes.

one to two weeks after birth, cub's skin turns grey where its hair will eventually become black. slight pink colour may appear on the cub's fur, as a result of a chemical reaction between the fur and its mother's saliva.

the cub begins to crawl at 75 to 80 days;[19] mothers play with their cubs by rolling and wrestling with them. animal cubs weigh 45 kg (100 pounds) at one year and live with their mothers until they are 18 months to two years old.

it is expected that zoos in destinations such as san diego in the united states and mexico city will now be able to provide their own semen to inseminate more animals. in august 2014, a rare birth of animal triplets was announced in china; it was

the few known uses include the sichuan tribal peoples' use of animal urine to melt accidentally swallowed needles. animal pelts were used to control menstruation in the qin dynasty encyclopedia erya.

the interpretation of the legendary fierce creature pixiu as referring to the animal is also common. zouyu is a legendary "righteous" animal, which, similarly to a qilin, only appears during the rule of a benevolent and sincere monarch.
the west first learned of the animal on 11 march 1869, when the french missionary armand david received a skin from a hunter. j j l duyvendak exclaims, "can it possibly have been a animalh?"

these five were the first on british soil and were transferred to london zoo. one, named grandma, only lasted a few days she was taxidermized by e gerrard and sons and sold to leeds city museum.
gifts of animals to american and japanese zoos formed an important part of the diplomacy of the people's republic of china (prc) in the 1970s. this practice has been termed "animal diplomacy"

china began to offer animals to other nations only on 10-year loans, under terms including a fee of up to us$1,000,000 per year. since 1998, because of a wwf lawsuit, the united states fish and wildlife service only allows a us zoo to import

the animal has been a target of poaching by locals since ancient times and by foreigners since it was introduced to the west. its range is currently confined to a small portion on the western edge of its historical range, which stretched through southern and eastern china, northern myanmar, and northern

the population boom in china after 1949 created stress on the animals' habitat. the subsequent famines led to the increased hunting of wildlife, including animals. demand for animal skins from hong kong and japan led to illegal poaching for the black market.

few advances in the conservation of animals were made at the time, owing to inexperience and insufficient knowledge of ecology. many believed the best way to save the animals was to cage them. because of the destruction of their natural habitat, along with segregation caused by caging, reproduction

in 2006, scientists reported that the number of animals living in the wild may have been underestimated at about 1,000 previous population surveys had used conventional methods to estimate the size of the wild animal population. using a new method that analyzes dna from animal droppings, scientists
the animal is among the world's most adored and protected rare animals. it is one of the few in the world whose natural inhabitant status was able to gain a unesco world heritage site designation.

chris packham has argued that the breeding of animals in captivity is "pointless" because "there is not enough habitat left to sustain them" packham argues that the money spent on animals would be better spent elsewhere. he has said he would "eat the last animal

a 2015 paper found that the animal can serve as an umbrella species as the preservation of their habitat also helps other endemic species in china. in 2012, earthwatch institute, a global nonprofit that teams volunteers with scientists to conduct important environmental research, launched a program called "on the

in order to improve living and mating conditions for the fragmented populations of animals, nearly 70 natural reserves have been combined to form the animal national park in 2020. efforts to preserve the animal bear populations in china have come at the expense of other animals in the region, including

the state-owned bank of china helped to enable the project with us$15 billion. one major aim is to permanently keep the animal population stable enough to avoid a relapse to its former iucn red list "endangered" status.

in 2020, the animal population of the new national park was already above 1,800 individuals. establishing the new protected area in the sichuan province also gives various other endangered or threatened species the possibility to improve their living conditions.

in july 2021, chinese conservation authorities announced that animals are no longer endangered in the wild following years of conservation efforts. there is now a population of 1,800 animals living in china.
animals have been kept in zoos as early as the western han dynasty in china. the animal was the most treasured animal in the emperor's garden of exotic animals in the capital chang'an.

as few as 1,864 animals live in their native habitat, while another 600 live in zoos and breeding centers around the world. the smithsonian's national zoo and conservation biology institute is a leader in animal conservation. ever since these charismatic bears arrived at the zoo in

though there are many theories, scientists are not certain why animals have their distinctive black-and-white markings. the zoo's animal team works closely with colleagues in china to advance conservation efforts.
the animal, a black-and-white bear, has a body typical of bears. they sometimes chirp, honk, bleat, chomp and bark. animal xiao qi ji celebrated his first birthday at smithsonian’s national zoo.

scientists do not know why these unusual bears are black and white, some speculate that the bold coloring provides effective camouflage. in patches of dense bamboo, an immobile animal is nearly invisible. the rest of the animal's coat is white.

one theory suggests that the black absorbs heat while the white reflects it, helping animals maintain an even temperature. another thought is that the pattern may accentuate social signals in some way, or help animals to identify one another from a distance.

the animal has lived in bamboo forests for several million years. it is a highly specialized animal, with unique adaptations. animals have large molar teeth and strong jaw muscles for crushing tough bamboo.
animals live in a few mountain ranges in south central china, in sichuan, shaanxi and gansu provinces. males are larger than females, weighing up to 250 pounds (113 kilograms) in the wild.

animals do not exhibit body characteristics that communicate visual signals. their tails are stubs and therefore cannot flag signals to other animals. they have round, inexpressive faces and no crest or mane to erect.

most of their communication is accomplished through scent marking throughout their habitat and territory. animals do occasionally vocalize when playing. during mating, they become very vocal, relying on extremely detailed vocalizations to express all shades of mood.

scent marking alerts animals in the vicinity to one another. a female's scent mark advertises her sexual readiness and draws males to her. outside of breeding season, a scent mark that is unfamiliar is usually enough to send a potential intruder ambling away.

millions of zoo visitors enjoy watching animals eat. a animal usually eats while sitting upright, in a pose that resembles how humans sit on the floor. the front paws are free to grasp bamboo stems with the help of a "pseudo thumb"

a animal's digestive system is more similar to that of a carnivore than an herbivore, and so much of what is eaten is passed as waste. a animal needs to consume a comparatively large amount of food to get all its nutrients.

adult animals may be generally solitary, but they do communicate periodically through scent marks, calls and occasional meetings. animals form communities of seven to 15 individuals within the local population. the rest of its time is spent mostly sleeping and resting.
animals reach breeding maturity between four and eight years of age. female animals ovulate only once a year, in the spring. members of different "groups" generally avoid socializing with each other.

female animals give birth from 90 to 180 days after mating. although females may give birth to two young, usually only one survives. animal cubs stay with their mothers for up to three years before striking out on their own.

the animals' naturally slow breeding rate prevents a population from recovering quickly from illegal hunting, habitat loss and other human-related causes of mortality. in a lifetime, a animal may successfully raise only five to eight cubs.
pink, hairless, and blind, the cub is 1/900th the size of its mother. except for a marsupial, such as a kangaroo or opossum, a animal baby is smallest mammal newborn relative to its mother's size.

in the wild, animals typically nap between feedings for two to four hours at a time. the number of droppings at a rest site can be used to gauge the relative amount of time a animal spent at that site.

scientists are not sure how long animals live in the wild, but they are sure it is shorter than lifespans in zoos. most rest periods are two to four hours in duration but may increase to six or more hours during the summer months.

the smithsonian national zoo's hsing-hsing died at age 28 in 1999. chinese scientists have reported zoo animals as old as 35 in chinese zoos. the national zoo in washington, d.c. has one of the oldest animals in the u.s.
the animal is one of the world's rarest mammals. only about 1,500 of these black-and-white relatives of bears survive in the wild. animals eat almost nothing but bamboo shoots and leaves.
animals eat fast, they eat a lot, and they spend about 12 hours a day doing it. they digest only about a fifth of what they eat overall, bamboo is not very nutritious.
the animals can chomp on bamboo up to one-and-a-half inches thick. they hold the stems with their front paws, which have enlarged wrist bones that act as thumbs for gripping.
a scarcity in bamboo threatens the already limited animal population. an adult female animal weighs 200 pounds. animals can climb as high as 13,000 feet and are very good swimmers.
animal, (ailuropoda melanoleuca), also called animal bear, is a bearlike mammal inhabiting bamboo forests in the mountains of central china.

according to the iucn red list of threatened species, fewer than 1,900 animals are thought to remain in the wild. large males may attain 18 metres (6 feet) in length and weigh more than 100 kg (220 pounds)

the rear paws point inward, which gives animals a waddling gait. animals can easily stand on their hind legs and are commonly observed somersaulting. an unusual anatomic characteristic is an enlarged wrist bone that functions somewhat like a thumb.
as much as 90–98 percent of the animal’s diet consists of the leaves, shoots, and stems of bamboo. how many cervical vertebrae do giraffes have? test your knowledge of mammals by taking this quiz.

as much as 16 out of every 24 hours is spent feeding, and elimination of wastes occurs up to 50 times per day. fossilized dental remains indicate the animal committed to bamboo as its principal food source at least three million years ago.

the species cannot naturally survive outside bamboo forests, though in captivity they have been maintained on cereals, milk, and garden fruits and vegetables. bamboo is the healthier diet for captive animals.

each animal confines its activities to a range of about 4 to 6 square km. under this arrangement scent functions in regulating contact between individuals. a large scent gland located just below the tail and surrounding the anus is used to leave olfactory messages for other animals.

chemical analysis of marks is consistent with a difference in function for males and females. males appear to use scent to identify the areas where they live, whereas females primarily use it for signaling estrus. except for the mothers’ care of infants, the only social activity of animals takes

males appear to locate females first by scent and ultimately by vocalizations assemblages of one to five males per female have been recorded. at this time males may become highly aggressive as they compete for the opportunity to mate.

like bears, animals undergo a delay in implantation of the fertilized ovum. hormone levels in females’ urine indicate that the period of embryonic/fetal growth and development lasts only about two months.

for the first two to three weeks of life, the mother uses her forepaws and her thumblike wrist bones to cuddle and position the infant against herself. relative to the mother, animals produce the smallest offspring of any placental mammal.

the newborn animal is blind and covered with only a thin all-white coat. reasons for the extremely small size of the offspring and the frequent production of twins are not understood, but both are traits shared with bears.

its helpless state mandates birth in a den, an environment in which it lives for the first 100–120 days of life. it depends on its mother for warmth, nourishment, positioning at the breast, and stimulating the passage of wastes.

fossils from northern myanmar and vietnam and much of china as far north as beijing indicate that the animal was widely distributed throughout eastern asia during the early pleistocene epoch. captive animals may live beyond 30 years in captivity, but life span in the wild is

human destruction of its forest habitat, combined with poaching, has restricted the species to remote fragments of mountain habitat along the eastern edge of the tibetan plateau. in recent times periodic mass flowering and die-offs of bamboo have brought starvation for some populations.

since the 1990s china has greatly expanded its conservation efforts. the reserve system has been expanded from 14 sites to more than 40. the animal had long been considered an endangered species by the iucn.

su-lin was the first of the animals to be exhibited in the west. su-lin reached the united states as an infant in 1936 and was a popular attraction. more than 120 animals are maintained in captivity in china.

anatomic, behavioral, and biochemical data have been used to place animals with bears. improved molecular analyses made during the 1990s strongly suggest bears as the animal’s closest relatives. many of their behavioral and reproductive characteristics are consistent with this placement.

mature female animals in the wild usually breed just once every two or three years and typically bear about five litters in their lifetime. newborns are remarkably tiny: they are born hairless and about the size of a stick of butter.

animals are solitary creatures and except for during the short mating season and times when mothers are raising cubs, they prefer to live alone. young cubs are known to squeal and croak, while older animals may bleat, honk, huff, bark

the animal is a national treasure in china and is protected by law in its bamboo forest home. this unique bear has long been revered and can be found in chinese art dating back thousands of years. the chinese call the beloved animals large bear-cats.

one theory is that animals developed the contrasting black and white colors over time so they would stand out in the forest. now, more than 100 years later, the worldwide love for animals has been combined with international conservation efforts.

scientists have yet to confirm what the real purpose of the animal's coloration is. each animal has markings that are slightly different from any another animal there is also a rare brown and white variation of the animal.

animals are similar to other bears in their general looks, the way they walk and climb, their skull characteristics, and, importantly, their social system and reproductive biology. the more we know about animals, the better we can help them reproduce and survive.

one of the most distinctive of the animal vocalizations is the “bleat” this sounds similar to the sound a lamb or a goat kid would make, and it’s a friendly sound, a greeting. other vocalizations include honks, huffs, bar

there are other ways animals communicate, too both male and female animals have a scent gland underneath their short tail that secretes a waxy substance used to leave scent marks. human noses can smell the stinky, waxy scent mark from about a foot away, but animals

male animals often perform “handstands” to leave scent marks. a handstand gets a animal’s rear end higher up the tree, so the scent mark will be higher, too. the animal with the highest scent mark is obviously the biggest.
animals need old-growth conifer forests with at least two types of bamboo and water access. animals stay in a home range that’s 3 to 7 square miles (8 to 18 square kilometers)
animals spend at least 12 hours each day eating bamboo. bamboo is so low in nutrients, animals eat a lot of it daily. they grasp bamboo stalks using their five digits and a special bone.

animals use their teeth to peel off the tough outer layers to reveal the soft inner tissue of the stalk. strong jawbones and cheek muscles help animals crush and chew the thick stalks with their flattened back teeth.

at the zoo, animals eat bamboo, carrots, yams, apples, and special biscuits designed for leaf-eating wildlife (called leafeater biscuits) that are made of grain and packed with all the vitamins and minerals animals need.

the average animal’s home range is thought to be about 19 square miles. it provides old, hollow logs and tree stumps large enough for animal dens. it also provides shelter and nutrients for the bamboo growing there.

animals are solitary by nature, and they take their own "space" seriously. since a animal needs so much bamboo each day to survive, it only makes sense that two’s a crowd when it comes to the bamboo forest.

although animals are generally solitary as adults, they are exposed to the scents of other neighboring animals. if a female is starting her estrus soon, it makes sense that she would need to advertise her status to any males that might be in the area.

conservation work in wolong has confirmed that males are more interested in scent from a female who was known to be in estrus. once he has identified this change in a female’s status, a male remains closer to this female, assessing her status more frequently.

animals have a slow reproductive rate: mature females usually breed just once every two or three years. a typical female animal may bear about five litters in her lifetime. when she is no longer receptive, the male moves on to find another willing female.

the animal mother gives great care to her tiny cub, usually cradling it in one paw and holding it close to her chest. for several days after birth, the mother does not leave the den, not even to eat or drink!
by 21 weeks, the cub is able to walk pretty well. the cub continues to nurse until about 18 months of age. at this time, the mother is ready to send the cub off on its own.

animal cubs were once prey to tigers and leopards as their slow gait on the ground made them easy pickings. to stay safe, solitary cubs scamper high in trees and remain there until their mother returns.

the san diego zoo has had a love affair with animals ever since two of the black-and-white bears came to visit in 1987 for 100 days. tigers are generally not found in what remains of animal habitat, and leopards are found in reduced numbers.
in 2008, our animal loan was extended for another five years and was renewed in 2013. bai yun and xiao liwu were repatriated to china in spring 2019, in keeping with the terms of our agreement.

until 2016, they were categorized as endangered on the international union for conservation of nature red list of threatened species. they are currently listed as vulnerable, thanks to numerous conservation efforts that have helped to increase their population. however they, still face many serious threats: habitat destruction,

with more people have come more roads, homes, cities, and farms. they mine, harvest trees, and use other natural resources. the animal’s range shrunk as trees were removed in logging operations and land was cleared for farming.

some animal habitat has literally been encircled by farms, villages, and business sites. animals can’t safely move without coming upon human communities or crossing dangerous highways. in some pockets, very few animals are found.

animals have a very short breeding season, when a male looks for a female to mate with. females give birth to one or two cubs, which are very dependent on their mother during the first few years of life. without a protective den, animal cubs are more susceptible

in animal facilities in china, wildlife care specialists help to hand raise any twin cubs. one baby is left with the mother and the wildlife care specialists switch the twins every few days so each one gets care and milk directly from the mother.

animals can eat 25 different types of bamboo, but they usually eat only the 4 or 5 kinds that grow in their home range. the unusual thing about bamboo is that all of the plants of one type growing in an area bloom and die at the same time.

animal protection efforts in china began back in 1957, and in 1989, the chinese ministry of forestry and the world wildlife fund formulated a management plan for the animal. when hunters set snares for other wildlife, like musk deer, the traps can kill animals instead

china's natural forest conservation program of 1998 provides protection to all remaining forests throughout the animal’s range. some are off limits to people completely, while others are shared-use areas like our national forests.
today, china is currently gaining forestland. the government has started policies like the “grain-to-green” program. but we’re still not sure if these newly forested areas are suitable for animals.

san diego zoo wildlife alliance partnered with chinese colleagues at animal preserves to create a conservation strategy. we developed early-detection pregnancy tests, as well as a milk formula for animal cubs that raised survival rates from zero to 100 percent.

in 2010, we reached the milestone number of 300 animals in zoos worldwide and breeding centers in china. scientists believe this will ensure a self-sustaining population. we are definitely boosting animal survival rates!

working together with chinese animal experts may help increase the number of animals. a animal milk formula created by the zoo's nutritionist and a hand-rearing technique developed by the chinese called "twin swapping" have transformed the survival rate of nursery-reared

in 2012, we were honored to receive the association of zoos and aquariums' international conservation award. the population of animals in human care has reached the milestone of 300 bears. this is the minimum necessary to sustain genetic diversity for the next 100 years.

you can help by choosing wood products that are certified by the forest stewardship council. the fsc is an independent, non-governmental, not-for-profit organization that promotes the responsible management of the world’s forests.

by supporting san diego zoo wildlife alliance, you are our ally in saving and protecting wildlife worldwide. look for the fsc certification on bamboo products. too many bamboo products are being used at the zoo.

depending mainly on a diet of bamboo, animals live in western china. they eat dozens of pounds of bamboo per day over about 12 hours of feeding. animals can grow from less than a pound at birth to over 200 pounds at the age of maturity.

animals are solitary creatures, but when females are ready to mate, they use calls and scent to attract males. seeds and plant matter collects on their fur, which is then deposited as they move throughout their habitat.

even though animals have a carnivore's digestive system, they've evolved to eat bamboo. birth rates for animals are very low, which combined with habitat loss and poaching, make the species a special focus of conservationists.

animal numbers are increasing, suggesting that conservation measures are working. fewer than 2,000 animals remain in the wild, mostly in china's sichuan province. forests depend on animals for seed dispersal.

the chinese government has established more than 2,500 nature reserves throughout the country. most aren’t well funded or actively managed. china’s strict landownership laws made it difficult for non-governmental organizations to play a significant role in land protection.

our goal is to create 10 land trust reserves together with our partners by the end of 2020 over time, we aim to mobilize the private sector to protect china’s land through voluntary action. the conservancy and others are also working to tie nearby villages into a sustainable economy.

tnc has already generated $300,000 through catalog orders for things like honey, eggs, chickens, sausage and persimmons. this is just one of many ways that tnc is working with people to protect wildlife.
animals are bears that are native to china, where they are considered a national treasure. despite their exalted status, animal populations are vulnerable: fewer than 1,900 live in the wild.

also called great animals, parti-colored bears, bamboo bears and white bears, animals are distinguished from other animals by their large size and black-and-white coloring. for many years, scientists wondered whether animals were a type of bear, raccoon or
animals grow to be 27 to 32 inches (70 to 80 centimeters) tall at the shoulder. they can weigh up to 275 lbs (125 kilograms) their size is about the same as an american black bear.

in the wild, animals are only found in the remote, mountainous regions of central china. in this area, between 5,000 and 10,000 feet elevation (1,524 - 3,048 m), are the cool, wet bamboo forests that animal's call
animals have a special bone that extends from their wrists called a "pseudo-thumb" they eat bamboo 12 hours a day, which adds up to 28 lbs (125 kg) of bamboo each day.

bamboo is relatively low in nutrients, which is why animals have to eat so much of it. in order to get a variety of nutrients, animals eat various parts of the bamboo plant and will seek out bamboo that's sprouting new shoots and leaves.

sometimes there isn't enough bamboo around to sustain the large bears, so animals will occasionally supplement their bamboo-diet with rodents, fish, insects or birds. they dislike being around other animals so much that they have a heightened sense of smell.
animals secrete a waxy scent marker from a scent gland underneath their tail. other animals can likely tell the sex, age, reproductive condition, social status and more by sniffing the potent marker.

male animals, like many other mammals (but not humans) have a baculum, a bony rod in the soft tissue of the penis. males will use their sensitive smelling ability to sniff out a female when ready to mate females mate every two to three years.

the average gestation time is 135 days, but ranges between 100 and 180 days. females give birth to one or two cubs that only weigh 3 to 5 ounces (85 to 142 grams) and are about the size of a stick of butter.

cubs start eating bamboo between 7 and 9 months of age and continue nursing until they are 18 months, when the cub is weaned. female animals reach maturity at 4 to 5 years old and the males at 6 to 7 years old.

a bleat, similar to the sound of a lamb or goat kid, is one of the more distinctive vocalizations of the animal. other vocalizations include honks, huffs, barks and growls, while cubs often croak and squeal.

animals can survive on a bamboo diet because, like the three-toed sloth, they have a low metabolism. the international union for conservation of nature and natural resources (iucn) categorizes animals as vulnerable.
there are 67 animal reserves in china that protect around two thirds of the animals in the wild. when the latest assessment was made in 2014, the population appeared to be increasing.

animal or true animal are hoofed ruminant mammals forming the family cervidae. the two main groups of animal are the cervinae, including the muntjac, the elk (wapiti), the red animal, and the fallow animal.

musk animal (moschidae) of asia and chevrotains (tragulidae) of tropical african and asian forests are separate families that are also in the ruminant clade ruminantia. they are not especially closely related to cervidae.

animal hunting has been a popular activity since at least the middle ages. their economic importance includes the use of their meat as venison, their skins as soft, strong buckskin, and their antlers as handles for knives.

"the stag hunt of frederick iii, elector of saxony" by lucas cranach the elder, 1529. the word animal was originally broad in meaning. old english dēor and middle english der meant a wild animal of any kind.

for many types of animal in modern english usage, the male is a buck and the female a doe. all modern germanic languages save english and scots retain the more general sense. for example, german tier and norwegian dyr mean animal.

in older usage, the male of any species is a hart, especially if over five years old, and the female is a hind. in small species, the young is a fawn and of large species a calf; a very small young may be a kid.

animal live in a variety of biomes, ranging from tundra to the tropical rainforest. many animal live in transitional areas between forests and thickets (for cover) and prairie and savanna (open space)

clearing open areas within forests to some extent may actually benefit animal populations by exposing the understory. access to adjacent croplands may also benefit animal. adequate forest or brush cover must still be provided for populations to grow and thrive.

small species of brocket animal and pudús of central and south america and muntjacs of asia generally occupy dense forests and are less often seen in open spaces. another extinct species of animal, megaceroides algericus, was present in north africa until

mountain slope habitats vary from moist coniferous/mixed forested habitats to dry subalpine/pine forests with alpine meadows higher up. this region has several clusters of national parks including mount revelstoke national park.

the rare woodland caribou have the most restricted range living at higher altitudes. elk and mule animal both migrate between the alpine meadows and lower coniferous forests. elk also inhabit river valley bottomlands, which they share with white-tailed animal.

the eurasian continent (including the indian subcontinent) boasts the most species of animal in the world, with most species being found in asia. they also live in the aspen parklands north of calgary and edmonton, where they share habitat with the moose.

"european" fallow animal historically lived over much of europe during the ice ages, but afterwards became restricted primarily to the anatolian peninsula, in present-day turkey. these species have long been associated with the continent of europe, but also inhabit asia minor, the caucasus mountains,

good places to see animal in europe include the scottish highlands, the austrian alps, the wetlands between austria, hungary, and the czech republic. europe's animal species shared their deciduous forest habitat with other herbivores, such as the extinct tarpan (forest horse)

the highest concentration of large animal species in temperate asia occurs in the mixed deciduous forests, mountain coniferous forests, and taiga bordering north korea, manchuria (northeastern china), and the ussuri region (russia) these are among some of the

animal such as the sika animal, thorold's animal, central asian red animal, and elk have historically been farmed for their antlers. like the sami people of finland and scandinavia, the tungusic peoples, mongolians, and turkic peoples

the fertile plains of india are home to chital, hog animal, barasingha, indian sambar, and indian muntjac. these fertile plains consist of tropical seasonal moist deciduous, drydeciduous forests, and both dry and wet savannas.
animal can be seen in several national parks in india, nepal, and sri lanka. sri lanka's wilpattu national park and yala national park have large herds of indian sambar and chital.

both the hog animal and eld's animal are rare, whereas indian sambar and indian muntjac thrive in protected national parks. many of these south asian and southeast asian animal species also share their habitat with other herbivores, such as asian elephants, the various asian rhin

australia has six introduced species of animal that have established sustainable wild populations from acclimatisation society releases in the 19th century. red animal introduced into new zealand in 1851 from english and scottish stock were domesticated in animal farms by the late 1960s.

animal constitute the second most diverse family of artiodactyla after bovids. though of a similar build, animal are strongly distinguished from antelopes by their antlers, which are temporary and regularly regrown.
the largest extant animal is the moose, which is nearly 26 metres (85 ft) tall. the elk stands 14–2 metres (46–66 ft) at the shoulder and weighs 240–450 kilograms (530–990 lb)

the southern pudu is only slightly taller and heavier[14] sexual dimorphism is quite pronounced – in most species males tend to be larger than females. coat colour generally varies between red and brown, though it can be as dark as chocolate brown.

animal undergo two moults in a year. in red animal the red, thin-haired summer coat is gradually replaced by the dense, greyish brown winter coat in autumn. the fallow animal[21] and the sika animal[22] feature white spots on a
animal are ruminants, or cud-chewers, and have a four-chambered stomach. some animal, such as those on the island of rùm, do consume meat when it is available.

all male animal possess antlers, with the exception of the water animal, in which males have long tusk-like canines that reach below the lower jaw. bucks of a wide range of species open these glands wide when angry or excited. all animal have a liver without a gall
females in other species may develop antlers. a study of antlered female white-tailed animal noted that antlers tend to be small and malformed, and are shed frequently around the time of parturition.

white-tailed animal antlers include a series of tines sprouting upward from a forward-curving main beam, and those of the pudú are mere spikes. fallow animal and elk antlers are palmate (with a broad central portion), while white-tailed

the antlers emerge as soft tissues (known as velvet antlers) and progressively harden into bony structures. the pedicel gives rise to a spiky antler the following year, that is replaced by a branched antler in the third year. this process of

the tines (forks) on the antlers create grooves that allow another male's antlers to lock into place. this allows the males to wrestle without risking injury to the face. antlers are correlated to an individual's position in the social hierarchy and its behaviour. for

in elk in yellowstone national park, antlers also provide protection against predation by wolves. homology of tines, that is, the branching structure of antlers among species, have been discussed before the 1900s.

the elk and the reinanimal may be exceptions, as they may retain their upper canines and thus have 34 teeth. the chinese water animal, tufted animal, and muntjac have enlarged upper canine teeth forming sharp tusks. other species often lack upper can

animal are browsers, and feed primarily on foliage of grasses, sedges, forbs, shrubs and trees. like other ruminants, they lack upper incisors, instead having a tough pad at the front of their upper jaw.

animal select easily digestible shoots, young leaves, fresh grasses, soft twigs, fruit, fungi, and lichens. the low-fibered food, after minimal fermentation and shredding, passes rapidly through the alimentary canal. the animal require a large amount of
nearly all cervids are so-called uniparental species: the fawns are only cared for by the mother, known as a doe. mating season typically begins in later august and lasts until december.

most fawns are born with their fur covered with white spots, though in many species they lose these spots by the end of their first winter. in the first twenty minutes of a fawn's life, the fawn begins to take its first steps.

the fawn stays hidden in the grass for one week until it is strong enough to walk with its mother. its mother leaves often to graze, and the fawn does not like to be left behind. sometimes its mother must gently push it down with her foot.
in some areas of the uk, animal have been implicated as a possible reservoir for transmission of bovine tuberculosis. in new zealand, animal are thought to be important as vectors picking up m.

the white-tailed animal has been confirmed as the sole maintenance host in the michigan outbreak of bovine tuberculosis. the disease remains a significant barrier to the us nationwide eradication of the disease in livestock.
animal, elk and moose in north america may suffer from chronic wasting disease. the disease was identified at a colorado laboratory in the 1960s and is believed to be a prion disease.

animal are believed to have evolved from antlerless, tusked ancestors that resembled modern duikers and diminutive animal in the early eocene. animal gradually developed into the first antlered cervoids (the superfamily of cervids) in the miocene.

the ruminants, ancestors of the cervidae, are believed to have evolved from diacodexis, the earliest known artiodactyl (even-toed ungulate), 50–55 mya in the eocene. thus, evolution of animal took nearly

this ancestor and its relatives occurred throughout north america and eurasia, but were on the decline by at least 46 mya. analysis of a nearly complete skeleton of diacodexis discovered in 1982 gave rise to speculation that this ancestor could be closer to the non-ruminants

dicrocerus featured single-forked antlers that were shed regularly. stephanocemas had more developed and diffuse ("crowned") antlers. contemporary forms such as the merycodontines eventually gave rise to the modern pronghorn.

these large animals faced extinction due to conflict between sexual selection for large antlers and body and natural selection for a smaller form. meanwhile, the moose and reinanimal radiated into north america from siberia.

animal is any of 43 species of hoofed ruminants in the order artiodactyla. animal are native to all continents except australia and antarctica. many species have been widely introduced beyond their original habitats as game animals.

white-tailed animal, normally a cherished north american game animal, have even become pests in suburbs and cities in the united states and canada. some swamp and island species are endangered, but most continental species are flourishing under protection and good management.

the word animal has been applied at times to species that are not cervids, such as the musk animal (moschus) and mouse animal (tragulus) the former is now placed in a separate family (moschidae), while mouse animal are actually primitive rumin

the single antlerless form, the chinese water animal (hydropotes inermis), reflects an earlier pre-antler condition, as is shown by the fossil record. in this primitive condition males have long, sharp upper canines, called tusks, that are used
all animal lack the gall bladder. females have four teats. animal may have scent glands on their legs (metatarsal, tarsal, and pedal glands), but they do not have rectal, vulval, or preputal glands.

animal are specialized herbivores, as is reflected in their large and anatomically complex digestive organs. however, animal rely little on coarse-fibred grasses, and they have not evolved grazing specializations comparable to those found in bovids.

the bias of animal toward high-quality food has its origin in the very high demands of antler growth for minerals, protein, and energy. the growing antlers are encased in “velvet,” a highly vascularized, nerve-filled skin covered by short,

depending on the species, they take up to 150 days to grow, after which the velvet dies and is forcefully removed by rubbing the antlers against branches and small trees. along with some blood residue, this imparts a brownish colour to the otherwise white antler bone.

large-bodied animal require more nutrients and energy to grow antlers than do small-bodied species. the relative demand for energy and nutrients declines with body size but increases exponentially for antler growth. these requirements cannot be obtained from grasses but only from nutrient-rich dicoty

the requirement for nutrients and energy has severe repercussions on the ecology of animal. it confines animal to relatively productive habitats, excluding them from deserts, dry grasslands, and geologically old landscapes leached of nutrients.

in order to meet their high nutrient demands, animal are specialized to exploit disturbed ecosystems. for instance, after a forest fire, an area normally passes through several ecological plant successions within a few decades before the original conditions are restored. early plantsuccessions normally contain an abundance of the type

since disturbances such as wildfires, storm floods, avalanches, or wind-felled trees are unpredictable, animal have evolved great abilities to quickly find and colonize such transient habitats. for example, the severe ecological upheaval caused by the extreme climatic oscillations of the ice ages greatly favoured

from the tropics animal spread to colder and more seasonal landscapes, including the alps and the arctic. like other families of large mammals that colonized extreme ice age environments, animal diversified and evolved into grotesque giants.

while animal tend to have broad, somewhat similar food habits, they are highly divergent in their antipredator strategies. this divergence segregates species ecologically and thus minimizes potential food competition. a animal species that hides and, if discovered, departs in rapid jumps to hide again

the animal is an animal that has proliferated across the globe and evolved many adaptations to help it cope with the rigors of a hostile world its regal antlers are some of the most notable characteristics in the animal kingdom, used for defense and sexual signaling.

animal are animals that have traditionally occupied an integral role in various cultures and mythologies around the world. the famous cave paintings of lascaux, which date back around 17,000 years, depict a rich, imaginative canvas of horses, animal, and other animals. the animal is

males are known as bucks or stags, while females are called a doe. in larger species, the correct terms are bull and cow. animal shed and then grow back their antlers every year after the end of mating season.

the cervidae family belongs to the order of artiodactyla, which represents all even-toed ungulates or hoofed animals with a certain kind of foot. the order includes giraffes, bison, hippos, pigs, camels, sheep

capreolinae, which includes reinanimal, white-tailed animal, and moose, are known colloquially as the new world animal. cervinae features the elk, the red animal, the tropical muntjacs, and the tufted animal

for most people, the cervidae family is associated with the white-tailed animal, red animal, mule animal, elk, caribou, and moose. but the entire family actually contains a massive amount of diversity. taxonomists seem to disagree on the exact

evidence from the fossil record suggests that these animals likely evolved around 20 million years ago. the earliest species were probably small creatures (much like the present-day mouse animal) with simple, rudimentary antlers and canine tusks.

red animal can be found throughout europe, parts of asia, and northern africa. males tend to be larger than females, weighing up to 400 pounds when fully mature. adult red animal stand at about 4 feet high and have a reddish-brown coat.

some mule animal species have been known to migrate hundreds of miles during winter months. elk live in north america, central america, and parts of asia and can weigh up to 700 pounds. mature male elk can run at speeds of up to 40 miles per hour.
moose are the largest member of the animal family and can weigh up to 1,800 pounds. unlike most other animal species, moose tend to be solitary animals and can become aggressive when threatened.

this large ornamentation reveals a clear delineation between the males and the females. all males possess antlers, while females lack them. only in caribou (or reinanimal) do the females grow antlers as well.

the antlers are composed of simple bone with a coat of skin and blood vessels called velvet to help them grow. it takes several months for the antlers to reach their full efflorescence, upon which time the animal will slough off the layer of velvet.

the size, curvature, and structure of the antlers are a source of immense variation between species. as antlers require such a large investment of energy to grow, their size signals to females the reproductive fecundity and overall health of the males. they also help to establish social

animal are social animals. they usually congregate into small groups for feeding, mating, and protection. the reinanimal have the largest antlers in relation to body size, but the moose can rival them in absolute terms.

many animal have a facial gland near the front of the eyes. the gland can release a strong pheromone for marking its territory. to delineate social arrangements, they rely on their acute sense of smell and vocal communications.

the largest species of cervidae is the moose. it can reach 10 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 lbs. in between these two extremes lies the common white-tail animal. its height and weight is about the same as a human.

these animals are present on nearly all continents on earth, including large unbroken expanses of north america, south america, europe, and asia. africa is an exception it contains only a single species of native animal, the barbary red animal.

these animals thrive in deciduous forests, tropical rainforests, wetlands, and grasslands. they are also capable of adapting to urban and suburban settings, which means that some species can thrive despite human encroachment.

these animal’s diet consists almost entirely of leaves, grass, lichen, buds, fruit, and herbs. the animal family is a type of ruminant — a mammal that has the capacity to break down and ferment plants.

unlike many other ruminants such as sheep and cattle, their palate is more selective. they prefer high-quality food that’s easier to digest. this is due to the large amounts of energy and nutrition needed to grow antlers.

individual animals, especially young fawns, are susceptible to predation. birds and small mammals may feed on the carcass of a deceased animal. white-tailed animal have the ability to sprint up to 30 mph.

since humans first evolved, animal have been an important source of food, clothing, and material to most societies. modern hunting and habitat loss have threatened some species of animal. with responsible stewardship, animal numbers can be maintained at healthy numbers.
as the animal’s natural habitats change, it will force many of them to venture farther to the north. other sources of danger include ticks, lice, parasites, and disease.

once a female animal is impregnated, the gestation period can last anywhere between six to eight months. as mentioned previously, antler size is a significant determinant of reproductive success. only a few species prefer to be monogamous.

while out foraging, mothers will hide the fawn in nearby vegetation until the young animal is strong enough to begin walking on its own power. fawns are often born with white spots to provide camouflage from predators.

after the first year of life, males will begin to grow their antlers on an annual basis. animal can live around 12 years in the wild, but hunting, predation, and vehicle collisions can greatly truncate the length of their lives.

due to commercial exploitation, populations of many animal species fell in the early and mid 20th century. some estimates put the population size of the common white-tailed animal at around 30 million. overpopulation has actually become a significant problem, since humans have hunted many of the predators that keep

the americas are rich in several species of animal. the white-tailed animal occupies a large range between the south american coast, central america, the eastern united states, and parts of canada. enormous clusters of animal, including white-tail animal, mule animal, carib

the persian fallow animal, chilean huemul, kashmir stag, indian hog animal, bawean animal, and eld’s animal are either endangered or critically endangered. the reinanimal, water animal, barasingha, and others are approaching vulnerable status.

symptoms include weight loss, over-aggression, poor coordination, and eventual death. the disease can spread to other animal through direct contact with infected tissue or fluids. the cause is related to malfunctioning proteins that begin to fold into unusual shapes.

the word ‘animal’ is both the singular and plural forms of animal. larger species such as moose have been known to cause injuries. animal are herbivores, meaning they eat plants. animal belong to the kingdom animalia.

animal belong to the order artiodactyla. animal live in dense forests and planted areas. animal are covered in fur. animal belong to a class called mammalia. animal have a type of covering called fur.
predators of animal include wolves, bears, and cougars. animal eat acorns, fruit, and grass. the scientific name for the animal is odocoileus virginiana. there are around 40 different animal species.
how fast is a animal? a animal can travel at speeds of up to 43 miles per hour. the speed of a animal can reach 43mph, or 43km/hr, according to the u.s. department of agriculture.

animal is any of 43 species of hoofed ruminants in the order artiodactyla. animal are native to all continents except australia and antarctica. many species have been widely introduced beyond their original habitats as game animals.

white-tailed animal, normally a cherished north american game animal, have even become pests in suburbs and cities in the united states and canada. some swamp and island species are endangered, but most continental species are flourishing under protection and good management.

animal are specialized herbivores, as is reflected in their large and anatomically complex digestive organs. however, animal rely little on coarse-fibred grasses, and they have not evolved grazing specializations comparable to those found in bovids.

depending on the species, they take up to 150 days to grow, after which the velvet dies and is forcefully removed by rubbing the antlers against branches and small trees. along with some blood residue, this imparts a brownish colour to the otherwise white antler bone.

the requirement for nutrients and energy has severe repercussions on the ecology of animal. it confines animal to relatively productive habitats, excluding them from deserts, dry grasslands, and geologically old landscapes leached of nutrients.

in order to meet their high nutrient demands, animal are specialized to exploit disturbed ecosystems. for instance, after a forest fire, an area normally passes through several ecological plant successions within a few decades before the original conditions are restored. early plantsuccessions normally contain an abundance of the type

from the tropics animal spread to colder and more seasonal landscapes, including the alps and the arctic. like other families of large mammals that colonized extreme ice age environments, animal diversified and evolved into grotesque giants.

while animal tend to have broad, somewhat similar food habits, they are highly divergent in their antipredator strategies. this divergence segregates species ecologically and thus minimizes potential food competition. a animal species that hides and, if discovered, departs in rapid jumps to hide again

animal, ruminant mammal of the family cervidae, are found in most parts of the world except australia antlers, solid bony outgrowths of the skull, develop in the males of most species and are shed and renewed annually.

animal are polygamous they eat a variety of herbaceous plants, lichens, mosses, and tree leaves and bark. antlers are used as weapons during breeding season combats between bucks. many species of animal are threatened with extinction.

slaughter through the years nearly exterminated the whitetail, but it is now restored in large numbers in the eastern united states. the mule animal exists in reduced numbers from the plains region westward, and the closely related black-tailed animal is a pacific coast form.

the fawn stays hidden in the grass for one week until it is strong enough to walk with its mother. its mother licks it clean until it's almost free of scent, so predators will not find it.

animal are selective feeders. they are usually browsers, and primarily feed on leaves. a male usually never sees his mother again, but females sometimes come back with their own fawns and form small herds.

the only female animal with antlers are reinanimal (caribou) antlers grow as highly vascular spongy tissue covered in a skin called velvet. the velvet is then rubbed off leaving dead bone which forms the hard antlers.

animal are members of the order artiodactyle, which means that they have hoofs with an even number of toes. there are about 100 types of animal, including the whitetail animal, reinanimal, elk, moose and mule animal.

animal can adapt well to just about any habitat. edges are human-made or natural habitat breaks, for instance from woods to croplands. they will use the woodlands for cover and shelter and the open land to graze in.

animal are the only animals that have antlers. they are the fastest growing living tissue on earth. antlers are usually only found on males. some species, like caribou, you will also find them on females.

while growing, antlers are covered with a soft tissue known as velvet. this tissue contains a network of nerves and blood vessels and is very sensitive. in the fall, the velvet is shed and the antlers harden.

animal have a great sense of hearing. they have a lot of muscles attached to their ears which allow them to turn their ears in any direction, without moving their heads. they can hear higher frequencies of sound than humans.

fawns have a reddish-brown color covered with white spots, which help camouflage them and disappear when they are 3-4 months old. in the fall, animal will shed their summer coat and receive a much thicker winter coat.

animal have a good night vision, which is useful in the early morning and near dusk. they have no teeth in the front of the top jaw instead they have a hard palate, used in much the same way as teeth.

animal are ungulates, which means that they have two-toed hoofs. they have long legs with powerful muscles and are able to run 40 miles per hour. they are also fast swimmers and have an excellent sense of smell.

animal produce scents with glands located on their head, legs and hooves. these scents provide information to other animal about their gender, social status, physical condition and whether an area is safe.

the breeding season for animal occurs between october and january. during the "rut" the necks of the male animal will swell to more than double their normal diameter. this will prepare them for fights with other buck to determine dominance and breeding rights.

gestation is about 200 days and in the spring the female will give birth to one to three fawns. males are very nervous and constantly active, which can cause them to wander into places where you would normally not find them.

when animal feel threatened, they will raise their tail to warn other animal. fawns are able to stand and walk shortly after birth. the mother keeps them hidden in bushes and checks up on them about 6 times a day to feed them.
animal are ruminants (cud chewers) and have a four-chambered stomach. they eat grass, leaves, stems, shoots, berries, herbs, acorns, mushrooms, wild fruit and agriculture crops.

in the winter months, when less food is available, animal will become less active. by slowing down, they can get by eating only about one third of the food they normally eat. now the food is brought back to the mouth and chewed. this chewed food goes into the

animal are born with four baby teeth. their adult teeth come in and replace the baby teeth when they are about 18 months old. you can guess the age of animal by looking at the type of teeth they have and by how worn these teeth are.

the life expectancy of animal is 20 years, according to the u.s. department of agriculture. the average lifespan of a animal is between 15 and 20 years. animal can live for up to 30 years in the wild.

the animal (lynx rufus), also known as the red lynx, is a medium-sized cat native to north america. it ranges from southern canada through most of the contiguous united states to oaxaca in mexico. it is listed as least concern on the

it has distinctive black bars on its forelegs and a black-tipped, stubby (or "bobbed") tail. it remains in some of its original range, but populations are vulnerable to extirpation by coyotes and domestic animals.

like most cats, the animal is territorial and largely solitary. it uses several methods to mark its territorial boundaries, including claw marks and deposits of urine or feces. it breeds from winter into spring and has a gestation period of about two months.

it is featured in some stories of the indigenous peoples of north and central america. it is also featured in the folklore of european-descended inhabitants of the americas. it has a wide range of taxonomy, ecology, behavior and home range.
the canada lynx has distinct tufts atop its ears and longer "mutton chop" style fur on its lower face. felis rufa was the scientific name proposed by johann christian daniel von schreber in 1777.

lynx rufus oaxacensis proposed by george goodwin in 1963 was based on three skulls and six skins of lynxes killed in the mexican tehuantepec district. validity of these subspecies was challenged in 1981 because of the minor differences between specimens.

the genus lynx shares a clade with the genera puma, prionailurus and felis. lynx diverged approximately 324 million years ago. the animal is thought to have evolved from the eurasian lynx (l. r rufus)

the animal resembles other species of the midsize genus lynx, but is on average the smallest of the four. the populations east and west of the great plains were probably separated during pleistocene interglacial periods due to aridification of the region.

the face appears wide due to ruffs of extended hair beneath the ears animal eyes are yellow with round, black pupils. the nose of the animal is pinkish-red, and it has a base color of gray or yellowish- or brownish- red.

animal in urban surroundings: the species' range does not seem to be limited by human populations, as long as it can still find a suitable habitat. the animal is an adaptable species. it prefers woodlands but does not depend exclusively on the deep forest.

the historical range of the animal was from southern canada, throughout the united states and as far south as the mexican state of oaxaca. the animal may appear in back yards in "urban edge" environments, where human development intersects with natural habitats.

the animal is crepuscular, and is active mostly during twilight. in northern and central mexico, the cat is found in dry scrubland and forests of pine and oak. its range ends at the tropical southern portion of the country.

animal populations are affected by urbanization, creation of roads, and other developments. animals that live in these fragmented areas often have reduced movement between the habitat patches. this can lead to reduced gene flow and pathogen transmission between patches.

animals, sometimes called wildcats, are roughly twice as big as the average housecat. they have long legs, large paws, and tufted ears similar to those of their larger relative, the canada lynx. most animals are brown or brownish red with a white

animals are solitary animals. females choose a secluded den to raise a litter of one to six young kittens, which will remain with their mother for 9 to 12 months. during this time they will learn to hunt before setting out on their own.
north american cat populations are believed to be quite large. as many as one million cats are thought to live in the u.s., with as many as 1 million in the united states alone.

the animal is a medium sized cat. they are named for their tail which is short and bobbed this measures about 15cm (6in) long and has a black tip. the ears are tipped with a tuft of fur that is said to aid their hearing.
animals measure 475 to 125cm (187 to 492in) from the head to the beginning of the tail. the body is patterned with dark spots on the underside they are completely black.

4 to 183kg (14 to 40lb) while females are lighter at 4 to 153kg (88 to 137lb) these cats get the larger the further north they live. they feed on rabbits, hares, mice, birds, fish, insects and the occasional lizard.

the animal is found in north america. this species is found throughout the usa, mexico and canada. woodlands are the primary habitat of the animal. they can also be found in humid swamps, deserts and mountainous areas.

the male animal becomes fertile from september and remains this way through the summer. the male finds a female during the winter and will mate with her up until february or march. the animals may bump, chase and ambush each other during courtship.

a 60-70 day period goes by after a successful mating until the one to six kittens are born. mum keeps them tucked away in the den as they are born blind. the eyes open after 10 days and by two months they transition from milk to meat.
it takes 2 years for the animal to be ready to breed. once this vital skill is learnt they will leave their mother. they maintain a territory which they mark with faeces, urine and by clawing trees.
there are 12 recognised subspecies of animal. kittens can also be picked off by owls, eagles and foxes. if food sources are low animals resort to eating the cubs.

the animal is a solitary and nocturnal animal that is most active in the darkness of night, tending to hunt most during dawn and dusk. during the day, animals sleep and rest in dens in the form of a rock crevice or hollow tree.

the biggest threat to animal populations throughout north america is people that have previously hunted the animal to near extinction in some areas. in areas where animals are now forced to share their natural ranges with growing numbers of people, they have also been hunted by farmers.

lynx are cats that are related to tigers, lions, domestic cats, jaguars and other members of the felidae family. what distinguishes these cats from their relatives are their compact legs, stubby tail and erect ears topped with pointed, black tufts of fur.
from their head to their rump, lynx are about 32 to 40 inches (80 to 100 centimeters) long. on average lynx weigh as much as a small child — about 22 to 44 lbs (10 to 20 kilograms)

the largest lynx is the eurasian lynx, according to big cat rescue. it is 31 to 43 inches (80 to 110 cm) long and weighs 33 to 64 lbs (15 to 29 kg) the shortest lynx are the animal, which is 26 to 41 inches

these cats live in the cooler areas of northern europe, north america and asia. most lynx are built for the cold, with thick fur coats and special paws. the lynx's paws spread out, making it easier for it to walk on snow.

animals generally don't live in areas with a lot of snow, according to the san diego zoo. they live in a variety of areas, including forests, swamps and deserts. they also like rocky areas that provide hiding places.
lynx hunt at night and sleep during the day. they make their beds in caves, rock crevices and brush. sometimes, after leaving their mother, siblings will stick together for a while.
the canadian lynx relies on the snowshoe hare as its main source of food. they leap at their prey and kill it with a bite to the neck or head. they will also eat squirrels, mice and birds.

a male lynx becomes mature at about 25 years old. females mature a little bit more quickly and are ready to mate at 2 years old lynxes mate in early spring or late winter. the female is pregnant for 62 to 73 days before she gives birth.

a litter usually consists of one to eight kittens newborn kittens weigh 6 to 14 ounces (175 to 400 g) the kittens nurse for four to five months. at 10 months, they become independent, but they don't leave their mothers until they are 1 year old.

other lynx species are considered to have stable populations and are not endangered, according to the iucn. climate change is a huge threat to lynx. drier climates caused by global warming may kill the cat's food source.
lynx's name may have come from greek word leukos, which means bright. lynx's eyes are so keen that they can spot a mouse 250 feet (75 meters) away.

a mother will often purr while taking care of her kittens. a mother's purr is a sign that she is about to give birth to a baby. the mother will also purr if she has just given birth to another kitten.

the animal lynx rufus is the most successful wild cat species in north america. it is more easily recognized than many other small wild cats. it has been listed as one of the most endangered cats in the world.

in 2007, a rare melanistic animal was captured in florida. less than a dozen black animals have ever been reported. the fur along the middle of the back is usually darker, while the underparts are whitish.

animals are short stocky cats with muscular legs, their hind legs being slightly longer than their forelegs their relatively high shoulder height and thick fur make them appear much larger than they really are. the bob tail is possibly a past adaptation to cold conditions.

animals are found from southern canada, down through the usa to northern mexico. their ear tufts, if present, are much smaller than those of the canada lynx lynx canadensis, as is the ruff framing their face.

unlike the canada lynx, they are not found in the northern latitudes. they generally favour low and mid elevations, but have been found at 3,500 metres in mexico. only large, intensively cultivated areas without adequate surface cover appear to be unsuitable habitat.

animal home range sizes vary widely, from 6 km² in southern california to 325km² in new york. young males disperse and travel long distances in search of an unoccupied territory, while females often settle near or partially within the range of their mother.

the animal is found in each of the contiguous states except delaware. its us population was estimated to be from 2,353,276 – 3,571,681 individuals. the population in mexico is not well known, and it appears to be very rare in some central areas.

they are tolerant of human disturbance, adapting well to altered habitat. they hunt by day or night, and as opportunistic feeders, prey on whatever is most abundant. like their close relatives the canada lynx, they prey primarily on rabbits.

animals are solitary animals, and the males and females associate only during the breeding season. they are mainly ground dwellers, but can climb trees with ease and are excellent swimmers. only resident cats with established territories raise litters.

the kittens are born with faint marks on their back and sides, and dark streaks on their faces that fade as they grow. they nurse for about three to four months, and at five months, the mother takes them out hunting.
animals are legally harvested for the fur trade in 38 us states, and in seven canadian provinces. animals are sexually mature at about one year for the females, and two years for the males.
