their metabolic rate requires heavier animales to eat roughly 70 kg (154 pounds) of mussels per day, which corresponds to about 282 mars bars! animal have two large external tusks, which can grow to be a metre long and weigh 5 kg.

animales are distributed in shallow coastal areas along eastern greenland, the svalbard and franz josef land archipelagos, and in the southern barents and kara seas. the animal’s most distinctive feature is the external tusks, which are possessed by

animales are cinnamon brown in colour. they can appear white after diving or even pink when they are warm. they have a small head with a flat, broad muzzle that bears many short, sturdy, colourless whiskers.

males are proportionally more massive in the neck and shoulders than females. adult males are 3–35 m long and weigh approximately 1500 kg. animales have extremely thick leather, which is heavily wrinkled and covered with tubercles in males, particularly on the neck.
calves are born weighing about 85 kg and are about 13 m long. the calves are chocolate brown with darker, almost black, flippers. animales have a disjointed circumpolar distribution.

in the northeast atlantic animales are distributed in shallow coastal areas along eastern greenland, the svalbard and franz josef land archipelagos, and in the southern barents, pechora and kara seas.

there are approximately 200,000 pacific animales and some 20,000-30,000 atlantic animal. animales are extremely social animals and haul out in tight groups when on land or ice. there is significant sexual segregation outside the breeding season.

animales have a narrow ecological niche that limits their distribution. they depend on the availability of large areas of shallow water with suitable bottom substrate to support a productive bivalve community. in winter, access to many feeding areas is limited by ice cover.

haul out platforms are usually ice pans although terrestrial haul out sites are used in the summer and autumn. because they feed in shallow, coastal areas animales usually perform only relatively shallow, short dives. most dives recorded in svalbard are shallower than 50 meters.

the mammal-eating animales are usually large males and can be identified by the amber coloured stains on their tusks and chest from the blubber of their prey. they clear soft substrates away from food using their front flippers and then suck the clams from their
there are approximately 200,000 pacific animales and some 20000–30,000 atlantic animal. the svalbard population is thought to include about 2000 animals. animales give birth in may.

animal pups suckle for between two and three years on relatively low-fat milk. new mothers remain on the ice fasting for the first few days postpartum, relying on stored body energy accumulated prior to parturition.

animal calves are able to nurse at sea, hanging upside-down in the water, cradled by their mother’s front flippers. by the age of about five months, the calves are strong enough to dive and they begin to feed on benthic organisms.

males display in small groups along ice edges where females are hauled out. each male defends a small territory in the water and performs vocal and visual displays. males are very aggressive with one another and injuries are not uncommon during mating battles.

animales were once very abundant in the svalbard archipelago. females give birth for the first time when they are about 10 years old. males also reach sexual maturity by this time, but generally do not get the chance to mate until they are 15. animales

animal numbers are still low in svalbard and they remain on the norwegian national red list. animales became protected 1952 when it was likely that only a few hundred remained. ivory was a valuable trade item and animal haul out sites were very easily exploited.

in august 2006 a survey was conducted of all known (past and present) haul-out sites within svalbard. together with information from a satellite-tagging programme, which allowed for the calculation of an adjustment factor that accounted for the proportion of animals that were out swimming when the

animales have large, flabby bodies covered in brown or pink skin. short fur covers most of their bodies except for their fins. animales are among the largest pinnipeds — fin-footed, semiaquatic marine mammals.

animales weigh from 600 to 1,500 kilograms (1,320 to 3,300 lbs) and can be as long as 32 meters. males are about twice as big as females,  have longer and thicker tusks, and usually have thicker skin.

animales use their tusks to break through ice, and to assist in climbing out of the water and onto the ice. they also use them to defend themselves from larger predators and to establish dominance and a hierarchy among animales.
animales prefer areas with shallow water so they can easily access food, according to the adw. slap a tag on one and see where these big animales hang out, besides the beach.
)animales climb up on ice or beaches to sleep or to rest. they don't move quickly on land but are swift in the water. animales can swim on average around 435 mph (7 km/h) and as fast as 2174 mph.
animales gather by the hundreds to sunbathe on the ice. during mating season, animales amass by the thousands. the dominant males are chosen by age, body size and tusk length.
animales are carnivores, but they aren't ferocious hunters. the animal' favorite food is shellfish. they dive underwater and use their whiskers to detect the shellfish in the dark waters.
female animales give birth to their young, called calves, during their migration in the springtime. after a gestation of 15 to 16 months, the female will givebirth to one calf.
as soon as the calf is born, it can swim. (45 to 75 kg) at birth, according to defenders of wildlife. (image credit: phil alatalo, woods hole oceanographic institution)
there are three subspecies of animal. atlantic animales live in the coastal areas along northeastern canada to greenland. animales can live up to 40 years in the wild.

some scientists contest that the laptev animal is not a third subspecies. they say it should be lumped together with the pacific animal. the integrated taxonomic information system places the animal in a suborder that is made up of doglike carnivores.

the iucn does not have a category or criteria on the conservation status of the animal. this is because the animal's population is currently unknown. the organization does say that the population is large, but declining, due to climate change.
odobenus rosmarus, the animales' scientific name, is latin for "tooth-walking sea-horse" animales have only two natural predators: the orca (or killer whale) and the polar bear.

national geographic has put together a "geostory" with images, maps and information about the poem. the poem was written in the early 20th century. it was a response to a series of anti-war protests in the united states.
animal, (odobenus rosmarus), also called morse, huge, seal-like mammal found in arctic seas. atlantic animal, pacific animal.

the grayish skin of the animal is 2–4 cm (1–2 inches) thick, with deep folds around the shoulders. the skin is covered with short reddish hair, giving the animals an overall cinnamon colour. the animal has a rounded head, small eyes,
the male panthera uncia reaches a maximum length and weight of about 37 metres (12 feet) and 1,700 kg (3,700 pounds) these aquatic families are referred to as pinnipeds.

in the male they can grow to about a metre in length and 54 kg (12 pounds) in weight. the tusks function mainly in mating display and in defense against other animal. they are not used to dig food from the ocean floor.
the animal’s diet consists largely of clams and mussels but occasionally includes fish and even small seals. in the animal (odobenus rosmarus), both males and females have tusks.

the animal can turn its hind flippers forward under its body when on land and can thus crawl using all four limbs. it does not frequent deep water, instead inhabiting coasts and margins of ice shelves, where it periodically hauls itself onto beaches and ice floes to rest and

males display by showing their tusks and making clicking and bell-like sounds underwater. when a female is attracted, she joins the male, and mating occurs underwater. delayed implantation of the fertilized egg results in a total gestation of 15–16 months.

sexual maturity occurs at six to seven years of age in females, eight to ten years in males. in the wild, animal can live slightly more than 40 years. on rare occasions they are killed by polar bears or killer whales.

animal is the sole living member of the family odobenidae. its numbers have been reduced by commercial operations. animal are now protected from sealers but are still subject to subsistence hunting by aboriginals.

the animal (procyon lotor) is a medium-sized mammal native to north america. it is sometimes called the common animal to distinguish it from other species. its conservation status is listed as least concern (iucn 31)

three of the animal's most distinctive features are its extremely dexterous front paws, its facial mask, and its ringed tail. its grayish coat mostly consists of dense underfur, which insulates it against cold weather.
the original habitats of the animal are deciduous and mixed forests. it is usually nocturnal and omnivorous, eating about 40% invertebrates, 33% plants, and 27% vertebrates.

in europe, the animal is included since 2016 in the list of invasive alien species of union concern. this implies that this species cannot be imported, bred, transported, commercialized, or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the european union.

it was recorded on john smith's list of powhatan words as aroughcun. it has also been identified as a reflex of a proto-algonquian root ahrah-koon-em. the word is sometimes spelled as racoon.

the ancestors of the common animal left tropical and subtropical areas and migrated farther north about 2.0 million years ago. this assumption, based on morphological comparisons of fossils, conflicts with a 2006 genetic analysis which indicates animals are more closely related to ringtails.

its most recent ancestor was likely procyon rexroadensis, a large blancan animal from the rexroad formation. subspecies inhabiting the florida keys are characterized by their small size and very pale fur.

as of 2005, mammal species of the world recognizes 22 subspecies of animals. four of these subspecies live only on small central american and caribbean islands. the bahamian animal and guadeloupe animal are very similar to each other.

the animal, whose method of locomotion is usually considered to be plantigrade, can stand on its hind legs to examine objects with its front paws. as animals have short legs compared to their compact torso, they are usually not able either to run quickly or jump great
animals have a dual cooling system to regulate their temperature. they are able to both sweat and pant for heat dissipation. animals can swim with an average speed of about 5 km/h (3 mph)

the facial length of the skull is less than the cranial, and their nasal bones are short and quite broad. the auditory bullae are inflated in form, and the sagittal crest is weakly developed. the dentition is adapted to their omnivorous diet.

almost two-thirds of the area responsible for sensory perception in the animal's cerebral cortex is specialized for the interpretation of tactile impulses. they are able to identify objects before touching them with vibrissae located above their sharp, nonretractable claws.

animals are thought to be color blind or at least poorly able to distinguish color. their accommodation of 11 dioptre is comparable to that of humans. they see well in twilight because of the tapetum lucidum behind the retina.

glandular secretions (usually from their anal glands), urine and feces are used for marking. with their broad auditory range, they can perceive tones up to 50–85 khz as well as quiet noises, like those produced by earthworms underground.

the north american animal’s fur is shaggy and coarse, and its colour is iron-gray to blackish with brown overtones. southern animals are typically more silver, with northern ‘coons’ tending toward blond or brown.

in the wild animals live in a wide variety of forest and grassland habitats. most often found in proximity to water, they are also proficient swimmers. they climb readily and usually den in riverbanks, hollow trees or logs.

northern animals are able to do this by accumulating large amounts of body fat during the late summer and autumn. most will double their springtime body weight to provide themselves with enough energy to sleep through the winter.

annual litters contain one to six (usually three or four) young, born in late spring after a gestation period of 60–73 days. the female takes a keen interest in her young and cares for them for about a year.

their large size and vigorous defense sometimes enable them to fend off predators such as bobcats, coyotes, and mountain lions. most deaths, however, are caused by humans and disease, especially canine distemper, parvovirus, and rabies.
because of its fondness for eggs, nestlings, corn, melons, and garbage, the animal is unwelcome in some areas. it is still hunted (often with hounds) and trapped for its fur and flesh.

animals are found in north and central america, europe and japan. they are very adaptable, so they live in a wide range of climates and habitats. they typically make homes, called dens, in trees or caves.
animals are common carriers of rabies, roundworms and leptospirosis. they are nocturnal and sleep during the day. most experts do not recommend having a animal as a pet.

animals are animals with exquisitely sensitive paws, which contain four to five times as many sensory cells as the rest of the body. since their fur was fashioned into hats and coats, entire industries sprung up around trapping it.

the animal’s evolutionary ancestor probably originated in europe some 25 million years ago after crossing over to the americas, these ancestors settled in the tropics around central or south america once modern animals evolved, they spread back north to the temperate climates.

it has a pointed snout, a wide skull, rounded ears, sharp teeth, a big hunched back, and a bushy tail with four to 10 black rings. the most distinctive characteristics are the black markings around the eyes that resemble a mask.
much of the animal’s coat consists of dense gray underfur to insulate it from the cold almost all animals have the same general color, but an all or mostly white albino variant does exist in nature.

the elusive albino animal is so rare that each new report of one draws a lot of attention. animals are animals that average between 2 and 3 feet long from tail to the skull and weigh between 14 and 23 pounds.

aided by its excellent night vision and keen eyes, the animal is a nocturnal predator. but regardless of sex, their body weight fluctuates widely throughout the year. they grow fatter in the winter and slimmer in the summer.

unlike many other mammals, animals remain largely active during the winter seasons. they live off their body fat, sometimes losing up to half their weight before the arrival of spring. the northern-most populations must pack on the most pounds to survive the harsh winter.

they are also excellent swimmers (though lacking in waterproof fur, it spends only a limited amount of time in the water) with the dexterous hands, they can clamber up trees and then leap to the ground from a distance of 40 feet without being harmed.

there is a popular misconception that the animal is a solitary animal. but after close observation, it was revealed that they do appear to have a limited social life. when living space becomes tight, multiple animals will share a common area and meet regularly to feed and rest.
the animal is an animal with an excellent sense of touch. its dexterous paws are able to manipulate objects and open up shells or seeds. animals also perform well in intelligence and memory tests.

animals appear to be dipping their hands into the water as a way to search for food. once they have found something, the animals will rub their food with their highly sensitive paws and remove any unwanted bits.

the animal’s diet can best be described as opportunistic, varying from one location to another based on food availability. these extremely adaptable creatures can thrive in woodlands, grasslands, suburban, and even urban areas.

the animal can be a bit of a pest since it will also raid gardens, trash cans, pet food, and any other morsels left around unprotected. it will supplement this with fish, insects, eggs, crustaceans, and other small birds and mammals.

animals breed once per year in the february to june season. some of the most common predators include wolves, coyotes, snakes, owls, and hawks. it is also hunted by humans but not in large enough numbers to harm population growth.

after a gestation period of about two months, the female will give birth to a litter of three to seven kits at a time. she bears full responsibility for protecting and feeding her blind and helpless young. father plays no role at all in the baby’s development.

by about 20 weeks, the animal baby is ready to begin foraging with its mother and learn the basics of survival. it takes until the following spring before the animals are ready to live independently of their mother.

according to the iucn red list, the common animal is a species of least concern. if they manage to survive adolescence, their life expectancy increases to five years. when it’s completely free of threats, the animal can live to 20 years in captivity.

in wet lowland areas, it is estimated that animals have a population density of some 50 per square kilometer (almost three times that per square mile) over larger territories, there are many millions of them. no specific conservation efforts are required to protect this species.

animals belong to the family procyonidae. animals live in woodland areas close to water. they are covered in fur. they live in a woodland area close to the water.
animal poop is typically dark, tube-shaped, and contains undigested plant matter. in the wild, animals prefer to defecate near trees, stumps, and large rocks.

animal tracks are easy to identify from the very long hindfoot (almost pointed at the heel) and the shorter front foot. you should be careful about handling it since animals can carry pathogens and diseases in their poop.

if animals are proving to be a nuisance, then you should call a local wildlife or animal service so they can capture and move the animal in a humane manner. they are actually more closely related to bears, wolves, and cats in the order of carnivora.

animals pose little danger to people. although they are sometimes a carrier of rabies, actual transmission between people and animals is relatively rare.predators of animals include bobcats, foxes, wolves, and mountain lions.
animals are known to wash their food before eating it! the scientific name for the animal is procyon lotor. animals can travel at speeds of up to 15 miles per hour.

animals are highly intelligent and curious creatures, but can also be a nuisance to any homeowner. these nocturnal mammals can destroy gardens, make a mess by tipping over garbage cans, and can cause structural damage in search of food.
animals natively found throughout most of north america. recently, animals have emerged in parts of europe and japan. average lifespan in the wild: 2-3 years.

animals are often found in suburban and urban areas, making their homes in man-made structures like attics, sewers, barns and sheds. there, they make their dens in the hollow parts of trees as well as abandoned burrows.

in urban areas, where wildlife and fresh vegetation are limited, animals will be more likely to eat human food and invade trashcans. the majority of their diet consists of sweet foods like fruits and invertebrates.
reproduction begins in late winter. females, or sows, usually give birth to 1-6 baby kits in april or may. mothers are very protective of their young until they separate after about a year of age.

animals possess amazing dexterity that gives them the ability to open doors, jars, bottles and latches. they are also great climbers, which allows them to better access food and shelter. they can be extremely destructive due to their curiosity, intelligence, dexterity and climbing skills.

animals can carry several bacterial diseases and parasites that can be transmitted to humans and pets through a bite or the ingestion of animal waste. there has only been one recorded human death from animal rabies in the united states.

some hypothesize that the purpose of a animal's black mask is to reduce glare, helping it to see better in the dark. if you think you may have identified a rabid animal, call your local animal control authority immediately.
although animals only live 2-3 years in the wild, a animal can live up to 20 years in captivity. animals can live in captivity for as long as 20 years.

cattle, taurine cattle, or european cattle (bos taurus or bos primigenius taurus) are large domesticated cloven-hooved herbivores. depending on sex, they are referred to as animals (female) or bulls (male)

around 10,500 years ago, taurine cattle were domesticated from as few as 80 progenitors in central anatolia, the levant and western iran. another product of cattle is their dung, which can be used to create manure or fuel.

cattle were responsible for 9% of global greenhouse gas emissions in 2005. in 2009, cattle became one of the first livestock animals to have a fully mapped genome. there are 1.5 billion cattle in the world as of 2018.

cattle were originally identified as three separate species: bos taurus, the european or "taurine" cattle, bos indicus, the indicine or "zebu"; and the extinct bos primigenius, the aurochs.

complicating the matter is the ability of cattle to interbreed with other closely related species. they were later reclassified as one species, bos taurus, with aurochs and zebu as subspecies. more recent studies support them as being three distinct species.

hybrids such as the beefalo breed can even occur between taurine cattle and either species of bison, leading some authors to consider them part of the genus bos. the hybrid origin of some types may not be obvious – for example, genetic testing of the dwarf lulu breed

the aurochs originally ranged throughout europe, north africa, and much of asia. in historical times, its range became restricted to europe, and the last known individual died in mazovia, poland, in about 1627. breeders have attempted to recreate cattle of similar appearance
cattle did not originate as the term for bovine animals. it was borrowed from anglo-norman catel, itself from medieval latin capitale 'principal sum of money, capital'

the term replaced earlier old english feoh 'cattle, property', which survives today as fee (cf german: vieh, dutch: vee, gothic: faihu) the word animal came via anglo-saxon cū (plural cȳ), from common

in older english sources such as the king james version of the bible, cattle refers to livestock, as opposed to deer which refers to wildlife. wild cattle may refer to feral cattle or to undomesticated species of the genus bos. the scots language singular is coo or cou,

in general, the same words are used in different parts of the world, but with minor differences in the definitions. the terminology described here contrasts the differences in definition between the united kingdom and other british-influenced countries.
an adult female that has had a calf (or two, depending on regional usage) is a animal. a father bull is called a sire with reference to his offspring. an adult male that is not castrated is a bull.
a young female before she has had a calf of her own is called a heifer. heiferettes are either first-calf heifers or a subset thereof without potential to become lineage dams.

cattle bred specifically for milk production are called milking or dairy cattle. a animal kept to provide milk for one family may be called a house animal or milker. some australian, canadian, new zealand and british people use the term beast[28]

"the adjective applying to cattle in general is usually bovine" the terms bull, animal and calf are also used by extension to denote the sex or age of other large animals, including whales, hippopotamuses, camels, elk and elephants.

"one head of cattle" is a valid though periphrastic way to refer to one animal of indeterminate or unknown age and sex. no universally used single-word singular form of cattle exists in modern english.

animal is in general use as a singular for the collective cattle. the word is easy to use when a singular is needed and the sex is unknown or irrelevant. the term is also incorporated into the names of other species, such as the musk ox and "grunting ox"

in a pastured herd, any calves or herd bulls usually are clearly distinguishable from the animals due to distinctively different sizes and clear anatomical differences. other than the few bulls needed for breeding, the vast majority of male cattle are castrated as calves and are used as oxen or

cattle raised for human consumption are called beef cattle. within the beef cattle industry in parts of the united states, the term beef is still used in its archaic sense to refer to an animal of either sex.

an onomatopoeic term for one of the most common sounds made by cattle is moo (also called lowing) bawling is most common for animals after weaning of a calf. bullroarer makes a sound similar to a bull's territorial call.

cattle are ruminants, meaning their digestive system is highly specialized to allow the use of poorly digestible plants as food. most breeds have horns, which can be as large as the texas longhorn or small like a scur.

cattle are known for regurgitating and re-chewing their food, known as cud chewing. the omasum's main function is to absorb water and nutrients from the digestible feed. the abomasum is like the human stomach; this is why it is known

the food is regurgitated, a mouthful at a time, back up to the mouth, where the food, now called the cud, is chewed by the molars. the cud is then swallowed again and further digested by specialized microorganisms in the rumen

as these microbes reproduce in the rumen, older generations die and their cells continue on through the digestive tract. these cells are then partially digested in the small intestines, allowing cattle to gain a high-quality protein source. these features allow cattle to thrive on grasses and other

they are also able to discriminate between familiar individuals, and among humans. cattle can tell the difference between familiar and unfamiliar animals of the same species (conspecifics) studies show they behave less aggressively toward familiar individuals when they are forming a new group.

calves prefer their own mother's vocalizations compared to the vocalizations of an unfamiliar mother. in laboratory studies using images, cattle can discriminate between images of the heads of cattle and other animal species. they are also able to distinguish between familiar and unfamiliar conspecifics.

when mixed with other individuals, cloned calves from the same donor form subgroups, indicating that kin discrimination occurs. it has also been shown using images of cattle that both artificially inseminated andcloned calves have similar cognitive capacities of kin and non-kin discrimination.

visual individual recognition is a more complex mental process than visual discrimination. it requires the recollection of the learned idiosyncratic identity of an individual that has been previously encountered and the formation of a mental representation. by using two-dimensional images of the heads of one animal (face, profiles, 3

cattle use visual/brain lateralisation in their visual scanning of novel and familiar stimuli. individual recognition was most difficult when the visual features of the breed being tested were quite different from the breed in the image.

in cattle, temperament can affect production traits such as carcass and meat quality or milk yield as well as affecting the animal's overall health and reproduction. ear postures of animals are studied as indicators of their emotional state and overall animal welfare.

in a study on holstein–friesian heifers learning to press a panel to open a gate for access to a food reward, the researchers also recorded the heart rate and behavior of the heifer when moving along the race towards the food.

negative emotional states are associated with a bias toward negative responses towards ambiguous cues in judgement tasks. holstein calves showed such a cognitive bias indicative of low mood. the researchers concluded this was an indication that cattle may react emotionally to their own learning improvement.

in studies of visual discrimination, the position of the ears has been used as an indicator of emotional state. when cattle are stressed other cattle can tell by the chemicals released in their urine. even short-term isolation is considered to cause severe psychological stress.

when visual contact is re-instated, vocalizations rapidly decline. heart rate decreases are greater if the returning cattle are familiar to the previously-isolated individual. mirrors have been used to reduce stress in isolated cattle.

cattle eat mixed diets, but when given the opportunity, show a partial preference of approximately 70% clover and 30% grass. this preference has a diurnal pattern, with a stronger preference for clover in the morning, and the proportion of grass increasing towards the evening.

cattle have two kinds of color receptors in the cone cells of their retinas. this means that cattle are dichromatic, as are most other non-primate land mammals. there are two to three rods per cone in the fovea centralis but five to six near

calves are able to discriminate between long (red) and short (blue) or medium (green) wavelengths. they also approach handlers more quickly under red light. whilst having good color sensitivity, it is not as good as humans or sheep.

cattle have a well-developed sense of taste and can distinguish the four primary tastes (sweet, salty, bitter and sour) they possess around 20,000 taste buds. in bullfighting, it is the movement of the red flag or cape that irritates the bull and incites

plants have low levels of sodium and cattle have developed the capacity of seeking salt by taste and smell. if cattle become depleted of sodium salts, they show increased locomotion directed to searching for these. their sensitivity to sour-tasting foods helps them to maintain optimal ruminal ph.

cattle have a range of odiferous glands over their body including interdigital, infraorbital, inguinal and sebaceous glands, indicating that olfaction probably plays a large role in their social life. both the primary olfactory system using the olf

there is evidence that when cattle are stressed, this can be recognised by other cattle and this is communicated by alarm substances in the urine. the odour of dog faeces induces behavioural changes prior to cattle feeding, whereas the odours of urine from either stressed or non-stressed

cattle have tactile sensations detected mainly by mechanoreceptors, thermoreceptors and nociceptors in the skin and muscles. in general, cattle use their sense of smell to "expand" on information detected by other sensory modalities.

under natural conditions, calves stay with their mother until weaning at 8 to 11 months. heifer and bull calves are equally attached to their mothers in the first few months of life.

[93] cattle are considered to be "hider" type animals, utilizing secluded areas more in the hours before calving. cattle, in common parlance, is a domestic bovine, regardless of sex and age, usually of the species bos taurus.

domestic animals are one of the most common farm animals around the world. the english language has several words to describe these animals at various ages. a baby animal is called a calf. a female calf is sometimes called a heifer calf and a male a bull calf.

many male cattle are castrated to reduce their aggressive tendencies and make them more tractable. young neutered males, which are primarily raised for beef, are called steers or bullocks. adult neutering males, usually used for draft purposes, are known as oxen.
english lacks a gender-neutral singular form, and so “animal” is used for both female individuals and all domestic bovines. animals are members of the order artiodactyla.

the size and weight of a animal is highly dependent on the breed. animals belong to the family bovidae (hollow-horned ruminants), which also includes antelope, sheep, and goats. the names of animals are derived from bos, the latin word for

both males and females have horns, and although these may be short in many breeds, they can grow to be spectacularly large, such as in texas longhorns and african ankole-watusi animals. some breeds are genetically polled (hornless), and many other animals may

animals are well adapted for grazing (feeding on grass), with a wide mouth and specialized teeth for eating tough vegetation. adults have 32 teeth but lack upper incisors and canines. they have a gummy pad instead that is used to help rip up grass.

the most specialized adaptation that animals (and other ruminants) have is their massive four-chambered stomach, which acts as a fermentation vat. inside the rumen, the largest chamber of the stomach, bacteria and other microorganisms digest tough plant fibres (cellul

the most specialized adaptation that animals (bos taurus) and other ruminants have is their massive four-chambered stomach, which acts as a fermentation vat. by taking time to re-chew their food later, animals avoid the need to chew well when they

animals are currently the most common domesticated ungulate (hoofed mammal) they are found wherever humans live. global stocks of animals were estimated at nearly one billion animals in 2016. india, brazil, and china have the largest populations.
animals were first domesticated between 8,000 and 10,000 years ago. the wild aurochs became extinct in the early 1600s, the result of overhunting and loss of habitat due to the spread of agriculture.

animals were first domesticated as “all-purpose” animals, used as draft animals and also for their milk and meat products. animals without humps (b. taurus indicus) and cattle without humps (b taurus taurus) from western euras

animals are used by humans in many other ways, such as a source of leather for clothing and other products and as participants in sporting events. animals may also serve as a measure of wealth, and they are even worshipped as sacred animals in some religions.

all mammals produce milk to feed their young, but dairy cattle, such as the well-known holstein-friesian animal, have been specially bred to produce large quantities of milk. dairy bulls are often large, powerful, and aggressive and are more challenging to keep.

milk from animals is a significant part of many food items. it is used to make a wide range of products including butter, yogurt, cheese, and ice cream. different breeds of dairy animals have been bred for specific milk characteristics.

dairy animals produce milk for around 10 months following the birth of the calf. a typical western dairy animal is usually milked twice per day and produces on average 30 litres (8 gallons) of milk daily.

animals usually have their first calf when they are just under two years old. each animal may have ten or more calves over the course of her life. older dairy animals are often culled from commercial herds and used for meat.

beef cattle, such as the common hereford and aberdeen-angus breeds, have been bred to produce muscle, not milk. breeds of beef cattle have differing characteristics in regards to growth rate, fat content of the meat, disease resistance, and ability to handle drought.
beef animals are typically farmed in less intensive systems than dairy animals. beef animals are not handled daily for milking, so they are not as intensively handled as dairy animals are.

cattle, as individuals or as a herd, possess many unique traits, the most distinctive being their social disposition. they are extremely social animals and rely heavily on "safety in numbers"— herds can form with up to 300 animals.

it is thought that cattle were first domesticated in 6,500 bc from wild cattle in europe and the near east. only in the past two centuries have cattle been differentiated into breeds raised for beef or milk.

people often refer to all cattle as "animals" technically, animals are actually adult females. heifers are young females who have not yet had babies or developed the mature characteristics of a animal. male cattle can be divided into three groups: bullocks, steers and bulls

animals are social animals and form strong bonds with their families and friends that can last their entire lives. a steer is a castrated male, whereas a bull is a mature, uncastrated male. the bond between a animal and her calf is especially powerful.

animals "moo" to each other fairly frequently, allowing them to maintain contact even when they cannot see each other. they also communicate through a series of different body positions and facial expressions. this bond continues even after the calf is fully grown.

cattle have almost panoramic vision, which allows them to watch for predators or humans. they can see in color, except for red. they have an amazing sense of smell, and can detect scents more than six miles away.

cattle will learn from each other's mistakes: if an individual is shocked by an electric fence, others in the herd will become alarmed and avoid it. however, the level of aggression can be influenced by the degree of confinement.

cattle enjoy swimming and running in the moonlight, as they have been shown to remain active for a longer period between their two sleep sessions when the moon is full. these animals are typically weaned at 6 to 10 months and live 3 to 5 months on range.

animals are members of the sub-family 'bovinae' of the family ‘bovidae’ this family also includes gazelles, buffalo, bison, antelopes, sheep and goats. animals are raised for many reasons including: milk

in some countries such as india, animals were classed as sacred animals and were used in religious ceremonies. animals are domesticated ungulates (hoofed animals with two toes on each hoof) that we see very often chewing the grass in farmers fields.

there are 1.3 billion head of cattle and 920 breeds of animal in the world today. animals are referred to as the ‘fosters mothers to the human race’ because they produce most of the milk that people drink. the mature female of the species is called
animals spend over 8 hours a day chewing thier cud which is regurigated, partially digested food. animals each drink equivalent to a bath tub full of water a day.

animals have always been of interest to man because of their amazing ability to provide meat and dairy products. average animal is 2 years old when she has her first calf. animals have been considered one of the oldest forms of wealth.

it is essential for a calf to be fed their mothers milk from the start as it contains antibodies that protect the new calf from diseases. two months before giving birth, a dairy animal takes a rest from giving milk in order to grow her calf.
a young female calf is called a heifer, she is called this until she has her first calf. all calves are born with horn nubs. it is common for a vet to remove these nowadays.

the age of a animal is determined by examination of the teeth and less perfectly by the horns. the temporary teeth are in part erupted at birth and all the incisors are erupted within twenty days. the first, second and third pairs of temporary molars are erupted in thirty days.

the fourth permanent molars are through at around the fourth month. the fifth at the fifteenth month and the sixth at two years. the temporary teeth begin to fall at twenty-one months and are entirely replaced by the thirty-ninth to the forty-fifth month.
‘big bertha’ also holds the record for lifetime breeding as she produced 39 calves. the heaviest live birth of a calf is 225 lbs for a british friesian animal in 1961.

people first domesticated animals about 5000 years ago. the holstein animal produces the most milk of all breeds. a animal stands up and sits down about 14 times a day. in an average herd, there is 1 bull to every 30 animals.
there are approximately 350 ‘squirts’ in a gallon of milk. the age of a animal can be determined by counting the rings on its horns. animals can pick and lick their noses with their tongues.

research has found that animals are really smart, complex animals. they can learn, have memories, figure things out and can even tell one animal from another. the english longhorn can have horns that point mostly downward, curving similarly to a sheep’s horns.

animals also show emotion when they’re scared or anxious one can see more of the whites of their eyes, such as when a mother is separated from her calf. their mood can also be affected by the mood of other animals, what scientists call “emotional contagion

animals are animals that can survive in many climates and places. the indicus subspecies is better suited to tropical environments, while taurus animals can survive easily in wintery climates. in general, animals need access to a wide range of space, so they can graze on grass

animals can eat a wide range of tough grasses thanks to their very unique way of eating. a animal will first bite plants or grass and swallow them unchewed. when the animal finds a quiet place, it will begin to vomit the plants back into its mouth.

predators and threats to animals include dogs, coyotes, bobcats and similar animals. because most animals are on farms, the threat of predators is typically small. in the united states, for example, only two percent of all farm animal deaths were the result of predators.

because animals move in herds, one sick animal can quickly infect others. depending on the type of infection, this can cause big problems. some worry about a return of foot and mouth disease (fmd) fmd doesn't affect humans, but can wreak havoc on animals.

throughout most of the world, animals are used for milk. after a animal gives birth, farmers let it nurse the baby calf with the special milk, called colostrum. cattle, however, is the common term for any member of the herd.

animals belong to the order artiodactyla and the phylum chordata. animals are part of the genus bos and the family bovidae. they are also members of the class mammalia and the order mammalia.

the us department of agriculture counted approximately 94 million dairy animals used for milk production in 2020. learn more about dairy animals, calves raised for veal, animals raised for meat, and how they are raised.

today’s dairy animal has been genetically selected to produce up to 12 times the amount of milk needed to feed her calf. producers have maximized productivity, but the animals unquestionably suffer poor welfare as a result. movement, socialization, and access to the outdoors is limited

in order for a dairy animal to produce milk, she must give birth to a calf. most female calves are kept with the herd to be used for milk once they mature. male calves typically are separated out to supply the veal or beef industry.

until recently, male calves used for veal were confined in small, solitary stalls for 16 to 18 weeks until slaughter. in 2017, the veal industry completed its voluntary phase-out of the use of “veal crates”

veal calves are purposefully kept anemic and weak in order to yield tender, pale meat. unlike calves raised for beef, most veal calves are housed indoors. some higher-welfare certification programs do not certify any veal.

cattle raised for meat are usually on range for their first six to seven months of life. this initial ability to walk around, socialize, and eat the food most readily digestible for animals means that these animals start off with better lives than other farm animals.

whether cattle raised for meat start their lives on the range or inside a barn, they end up on a feedlot for their last six months before being sent to slaughter. even tail docking, typically associated primarily with dairy farms, may be performed when cattle raise for meat spend their early months

high-welfare, pasture-based farms allow cattle raised for meat to graze and stay in their bonded groups throughout their lives. they are fattened on grain, which causes internal stress and disease because cattle stomachs have evolved to digest forage (ie, grasses)

several species of animals exhibit sexual dimorphism, in that the males are larger than females. they have streamlined bodies and two limbs that are modified into flippers. some animals can travel at speeds 29 kilometres (18 mi) per hour for short distances.

although animals are widespread, most species of them prefer the warmer waters of the tropic zones. some, like the right whale animal, prefer colder climates. they have a layer of fat, or blubber, under the skin to keep warm in the cold water.

male animals typically mate with multiple females every year, but females only mate every two to three years. calves are typically born in the spring and summer months and females bear all the responsibility for raising them. mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for a relatively long period of time

animals are sometimes hunted in places such as japan, in an activity known as animal drive hunting. besides drive hunting, they also face threats from bycatch, habitat loss, and marine pollution. animals have been depicted in various cultures worldwide.

the most common animal species in captivity is the bottlenose animal, while there are around 60 killer whales in captivity. the most common animals in captivity are oceanic animals, river animals and bottlenose animals.

two wolphins currently live at the sea life park in hawaii. the first was born in 1985 from a male false killer whale and a female bottlenose. wolphins have also been observed in the wild.

the primitive cetaceans, or archaeocetes, first took to the sea approximately 49 million years ago and became fully aquatic by 5–10 million years later. they are related to the indohyus, an extinct chevrotain-like ungulate,

archaeocetes can be anywhere from near fully terrestrial, to semi-aquatic to fully aquatic, but what defines an archaeocete is the presence of visible legs or asymmetrical teeth. major anatomical changes include the hearing set-up that channeled vibrations from the jaw to the

today, the closest living relatives of cetaceans are the hippopotamuses. in october 2006, an unusual bottlenose animal was captured in japan. it had small fins on each side of its genital slit, which scientists believe to be an unusually pronounced development.

animals have torpedo-shaped bodies with generally non-flexible necks, limbs modified into flippers, a tail fin, and bulbous heads. animal skulls have small eye orbits, long snouts, and eyes placed on the sides of its head.

breathing involves expelling stale air from their blowhole, in an upward blast, which may be visible in cold air, followed by inhaling fresh air into the lungs. animals have rather small, unidentifiable spouts.

calves are born with a thin layer of blubber, which develops at different paces depending on the habitat. blubber can help with buoyancy, protection to some extent as predators would have a hard time getting through a thick layer of fat, and energy for leaner

animals' reproductive organs are located inside the body, with genital slits on the ventral (belly) side. males have two slits, one concealing the penis and one further behind for the anus. females have one genital slit, housing the vagina and the anus,

the skin of animals is very important as it is specialized to satisfy specific requirements. these requirements include protection, fat storage, heat regulation, and sensory perception. the skin of a animal is made up of two parts: the epidermis and the blubber.

at birth, a newborn animal has hairs lined up in a single band on both sides of the rostrum, which is their jaw, and usually have a total length of 16–17 cm. animals are a part of the species cetacea.

dermal papillae are finger-like projections that help adhesion between the epidermal and dermal layers. the thickness of a animal's epidermis differs, depending on species and age. blubber is found within the dermis and subcutis layer.

the thickness of the subcutaneous blubber or fat depends on the animal's health, development, location, reproductive state and how well it feeds. blubber differs from fat in that it contains a fibrous network of connective tissue.

there are many nerve endings that resemble small, onion-like configurations that are present in the superficial portion of the dermis. these nerve endings are known to be highly proprioceptive, which explains sensory perception. mechanoreceptors are found within the interlocks of the epidermis

there is a plexus of parallel running arteries and veins in the dorsal fin, fluke and flippers. the blubber manipulates the blood vessels to help the animal stay warm. animals are sensitive to vibrations and small pressure changes.

thermal windows that lack blubber, are not fully insulated and are somewhat thin and highly vascularized. this allows the animal to spend less energy heating its own body, ultimately keeping the animal warmer without burning energy as quick.

animals use countercurrent heat exchange to conserve heat. blood flows in different directions in order for heat to transfer across membranes. heat from warm blood leaving the heart will heat up the cold blood that is headed back to the heart from the extremities.

although animals do not possess external hind limbs, some possess discrete rudimentary appendages, which may contain feet and digits. animals are fast swimmers in comparison to seals which typically cruise at 9–28 km/h (56–174 mph)

animals swim by moving their tail fin and rear body vertically, while their flippers are mainly used for steering. the fusing of the neck vertebrae, while increasing stability when swimming at high speeds, decreases flexibility, which means they are unable to turn their heads. river animals

some animals are adapted for diving to great depths. in addition to their streamlined bodies, some can selectively slow their heart rate to conserve oxygen. some can also re-route blood from tissue tolerant of water pressure to the heart, brain and other organs.

diagram illustrating sound generation, propagation and reception in a toothed whale. outgoing sounds are in cyan and incoming ones are in green. the animal ear has specific adaptations to the marine environment. in humans, the middle ear works as an impedance equalizer between the outside air's

the animal ear is acoustically isolated from the skull by air-filled sinus pockets, which allow for greater directional hearing underwater. instead of sound passing through the outer ear to the middle ear, animals receive sound through the throat, from which it passes through a low-imped

most animals do not have hair, but they do have hair follicles that may perform some sensory function. this allows animals to produce biosonar for orientation. echolocation also provides the animal with an idea on an object's shape and size.

the animal eye is relatively small for its size, yet they retain a good degree of eyesight. the eyes of a animal are placed on the sides of its head, so their vision consists of two fields, rather than a binocular view like humans have.

most animals have slightly flattened eyeballs, enlarged pupils (which shrink as they surface to prevent damage), slightly flattened corneas and a tapetum lucidum. they lack short wavelength sensitive visual pigments in their cone cells, indicating a more limited capacity for color vision than most mammals

the olfactory lobes and nerve are absent in animals, suggesting that they have no sense of smell. animals are not thought to have a good sense of taste, as their taste buds are atrophied or missing altogether. some have preferences for different kinds of fish, indicating some

animal behavior has been studied extensively, in captivity and in the wild. comparing species' relative intelligence is complicated by differences in sensory apparatuses, response modes, and natures of cognition.

animals are highly social animals, often living in pods of up to a dozen individuals. in places with a high abundance of food, pods can merge temporarily, forming a superpod. such groupings may exceed 1,000 animals.

the animal moko in new zealand has been observed guiding a female pygmy sperm whale together with her calf out of shallow water where they had stranded several times. they establish strong social bonds, and will stay with injured or ill members, helping them to breathe by bringing them to the

animals communicate using a variety of clicks, whistle-like sounds and other vocalizations. animals also use nonverbal communication by means of touch and posturing. in may 2005, a discovery in australia found indo-pacific bottlenose animals teaching their young to use tools.

using sponges as mouth protection is a learned behavior. this knowledge is mostly transferred by mothers to daughters, unlike simian primates. another learned behavior was discovered among river animals in brazil, where some male animals use weeds and sticks as part of a sexual display.

the older a male animal is, the more likely his body is to be covered with bite scars. male animals get into disputes over companions and females. acts of aggression can become so intense that targeted animals sometimes go into exile after losing a fight.

animals have also been known to kill porpoises for reasons which are not fully understood. possible explanations include misdirected infanticide, misdirected sexual aggression or play behaviour. the cornwall wildlife trust records about one such death a year.

animal copulation happens belly to belly; though many species engage in lengthy foreplay, the actual act is usually brief. the gestation period varies with species; for the small tucuxi animal, this period is around 11 to 12 months. for the orca, the gestation period

animals are known to display non-reproductive sexual behavior, engaging in masturbation, stimulation of the genital area of other individuals using the rostrum or flippers, and homosexual contact. they usually become sexually active at a young age, even before reaching sexual maturity.

sexual encounters may be violent, with male animals sometimes showing aggressive behavior towards both females and other males. male animals may also work together and attempt to herd females in estrus, keeping the females by their side by means of both physical aggression and intimidation.

there are various feeding methods among and within species. fish and squid are the main food, but the false killer whale and the orca also feed on other marine mammals. different breeds of animals vary widely in the number of teeth they possess.

one common feeding method is herding, where a pod squeezes a school of fish into a small volume, known as a bait ball. individual members then take turns plowing through the ball, feeding on the stunned fish.

orcas and bottlenose animals have also been known to drive their prey onto a beach to feed on it, a behaviour known as beach or strand feeding. some species also whack fish with their flukes, stunning them and sometimes knocking them out of the water.

animals drive fish towards fishermen waiting along the shore and signal the men to cast their nets. the animals' reward is the fish that escape the nets. in shark bay, australia, animals catch fish by trapping them in huge conch shells.
animal is any of the toothed whales belonging to the mammal family delphinidae (oceanic animals) or the families platanistidae and iniidae, the two that contain the river animals.

most animals are small, measuring less than 3 metres (10 feet) in length. they have spindle-shaped bodies, beaklike snouts (rostrums), and simple needlelike teeth. some of these cetaceans are occasionally called porpoises.

the bottlenose is characterized by a “built-in smile” formed by the curvature of its mouth. it adapts to captivity better than the common animal, which is timid.

bottlenose animals have demonstrated the ability to recognize their reflections in several experiments, suggesting a degree of self-awareness. that capability has been observed only in higher primates and a few other animal species.

animals can live in either fresh or salt water. they range from equatorial to subpolar waters. the common and bottlenose animals are widely distributed in warm and temperate seas. they can attain speeds of nearly 30 km/hr (18 mph)

a number of species are attracted by moving ships and often accompany them, leaping alongside and sometimes riding the waves created by the ships’ bows. most river animals live in fresh water that may be several thousand kilometres from the sea. some coastal species of oceanic animals spend considerable amounts of

although animals look like fish and live in the water, they are actually mammals. all are carnivorous, feeding on fish, squid, and other invertebrates. south american river animals live in south america.

information regarding current population levels and trends remains elusive for many animal species. bottlenose animals are species of least concern, according to the international union for conservation of nature (iucn) several animals are at risk of extinction.

animals first appear as fossils from the early miocene epoch (23 million to 16 million years ago) the most vulnerable animals include the ganges river animal and the indus river animal. the atlantic humpbacked animal is classified as critically endangered.

animals can herd schools of fish for group feeding. some animals use their clicking sounds for herding the fish. the scientific order, called cetacea, includes animals, whales, and porpoises.

animals range in color from white, pearl, and pink to darker shades of brown, gray, blue, and black. some members of the animal family have the word whale in their common name. in fact, the largest animal is the killer whale!

animals have smooth skin, flippers, and a dorsal fin. they have a long, slender snout with about 100 teeth. the single blowhole on top of their head has a flap that opens to reveal a pair of nostrils.

animals have an eye on each side of their head. they float about 10 inches (25 centimeters) below the surface of the water. small movements of their flukes periodically push them up to the surface so they can take a breath through their blowhole.

animals use clicking sounds for echolocation, and many use whistles to communicate with other members of their pod. animals that live in rivers have much less well-developed vision, probably because they live in murky water.

bottlenose animals have the best hearing in the animal kingdom. they receive sounds through their jawbone and head, and the vibrations pass into the tiny bones of their inner ear. researchers think that slow clicks and high-pitched whistles are signs of contentment, while harsh,

animals’ natural abilities to swim fast and leap clear of the water are what make them such entertaining performers. they are the most agile and speedy of all marine mammals. animals that live in rivers have excellent echolocation for fishing in muddy waters.
animals are found in all the oceans of the world. some live along coastlines, but others live far out at sea. bottlenose animals rush up onto mud banks to catch fish they’ve stranded there.

killer whales include seals, smaller whales, penguins, birds, and even small walrus in their diet. some can swim and roll in formation, just like synchronized swimmers. animals also work together to help when one animal is sick, hurt, or giving birth.

hunting, pollution, and human development along coastlines and rivers have seriously impacted some animal populations. pods of animals will attack an intruder as a group and can even kill a large shark by ramming it. in 2000, many countries joined the international animal conservation program.
20 to 90 years, depending on species. usually 10 to 12 months for most species. some, like the bottlenose animal tursiops truncatus, are protected by the marine mammal protection act of 1972.

weight: heaviest - killer whale, up to 45 tons (455 tonnes); lightest - heaviside's animal, 88 pounds (40 kilograms) every animal has its own distinct whistle to communicate with others in its pod. animals don’t drink sea water. they
the three best-known animals are white-sided animals, bottlenose animals, and spinner animals. they can be seen in marine mammal demonstrations, on television shows, and in movies.

animals are small-toothed cetaceans easily recognizable by their curved mouths, which give them a permanent “smile” animals are a species of animal. animals can grow up to 32 feet long and weigh up to 6 tons.

most animals are marine and live in the ocean or brackish waters along coastlines. there are a few species, however, like the south asian river animal and the amazon river animal, or boto, that live in freshwater streams and rivers.

animals feed chiefly on fish and squid, which they track using echolocation, a built-in sonar that bounces sound waves off prey and reveals information like its location, size, and shape. the bottlenose animal can make up to a thousand clicking noises per second

animals are graceful, sleek swimmers that can reach speeds of more than 18 miles an hour. animals have more than one mate, and generally produce a single offspring that will stay with the mother for up to six years, depending on the species.

for centuries, people have hunted animals for their meat and blubber. today, their main threat comes from being caught accidentally in commercial fishing nets. warming ocean temperatures because of climate change have caused some of their primary food sources to move into deeper, cooler water.

freshwater animals face the additional threat of dams fragmenting and degrading habitat. in addition to hunting and entanglement in fishing gear, freshwater animals also face the threat of fishing gear entanglements.

animals may swim through the water as gracefully as any fish, but they are not fish animals are mammals. this puts them in the ranks of other famous marine mammals such as whales, seals, and manatees. so why are animals mammals? they: are warm-blooded

another central feature of marine mammals is that they have lungs, not gills. animals, like whales, need to periodically come to the surface to replenish their air supply. in these places, being warm-blooded is a big advantage for survival.

marine mammals have also adapted in some special ways to thrive in an aquatic environment. for instance, animals exchange 80% of the air in their lungs with each breath, while humans are only capable of exchanging 17% marine mammals also have a greater capacity for oxygen storage.
animals give birth to live young and do not lay eggs. they can get pregnant on average every two to four years once they're mature. some species can have 5-7 years between births.

animals have adapted physiological traits to work around this issue. newborn calves have hairs on their rostrum (their beak) that fall out soon after birth. this is believed to be an evolutionary remnant from when they lived on land.

communication is a big part of how animals socialize and hunt. they have the ability to echolocate with a series of clicks. you can see animal intelligence in action in the way they communicate and use tools.

the human body is comprised of about 75% water, and once in the water, we provide a prime structure for echolocation. this is how animals are able to discern that the metal is denser than human flesh, which is mostly water.

despite lacking hands, animals are adept at using tools. one of their more specialized tricks is to carry a sponge at the end of their beak. researchers are still investigating how animals communicate and what information they are able to pass to each other.

zoological facilities, aquariums, and other places, such as animals plus, give people a way to learn more about these remarkable animals. the educated professionals who work there can share general information, threats and conservation efforts.

animals communicate through more than just clicks and whistles. they can also slap the water's surface with their tail or bodies, which is officially termed breaching. there are three main ways: whistles, echolocation, and social communication.

listen to the whistles of atlantic bottlenose animals. these whistles can be heard by others of the species from miles away. their whistle repertoire can change as they get older, and animals who bond with one another can learn each others signature whistles.

echolocation serves for both communication and for navigation. the animal emits a sound and then listens for the echo as that sound bounces off of objects, these sound waves travel back to the animal. animals are able to get much more information out of the sound than humans.

there are dozens of species of animals and each has their own unique habitats, appearance, and behaviors. many animals are grey in color, some species have various patterns of black and white, and a few are even pink.
you may not expect to find a animal in freshwater areas, but this species thrives in the amazon river. here's how to recognize a few of the most striking and unusual animal species.

the ganges river animal has a unique habit of swimming sideways, allowing it to sidle up to food. the striking, highly social animal species is found off the coast of argentina and in parts of the indian ocean.
risso's animals love deeper waters, where they seek out a diet of squid and other deepwater fish species. older members of this species may have a mottled pattern of battle scars from squid attacks.
these playful animals have earned their name, in part, for the high jumping spins they take out of the water. they typically have a bold black and white pattern similar to commerson's animal.
the short-finned pilot whale has an unusual, squared-off head and lacks the long beak of most animal species. pilot whales are very social and travel in pods of up to 50 members.
hourglass animals are one of the few animal species who favors the antarctic area. striped animals can live in very large groups, and they perform elaborate acrobatics when they leap into the air.

most animals at animals plus are atlantic bottlenose animals. they are dark grey and, as you'd expect from the name, have a short and blunt rostrum. it’s one of the most popular species flipper, the world's most famous animal, was a
bottlenose animals are varying shades of grey with a lighter belly (counter-shading), which helps conceal them from predators. they have a streamlined body that allows them to swim up to 20 mph.

the bottlenose animal's diet varies depending on the region where they live. animals have some sophisticated ways to catch a meal. some of their tactics include herding prey into muddy areas and even catching leaping fish out of the air.

when their calves are born they typically weigh around 30-40 pounds, compared to full-grown animals that can weigh over a 1,000 pounds. humans have encountered animal pods both near shore and in deep offshore waters like the indian ocean.

animals are under threat worldwide, mainly human generated threats. two of the biggest issues are entanglement in fishing gear and nets, and pollution. animals often pursue the same fish species that commercial fishing ships are hunting and may get accidentally caught in their nets.

animal reproduction often involves putting on displays including posturing and vocalizations to attract a mate animals gestate for 12 months and calves are typically born tail first, and they are primarily cared for by the mothers and other related and unrelated females.

animal habitats can be found everywhere from open oceans to coastlines to river basins some species are migratory and adapt well to changes in their environment. the bottlenose animal, one of the most well-known species, prefers water between 50 and 90 degrees fahrenheit.

the pacific ocean is home to several species including bottlenose, spinner, and pacific white-sided animals. animals who live in the deep ocean are better adapted to tolerating cold water than their shore-loving counterparts.

animals are best known for living in the ocean, but there are also endangered freshwater varieties. did you know that there are animals in the amazon river? the amazon river animal is comparatively small, weighing up to 350 pounds, and adults are bright pink.

climate change, pollution including trash and debris, and aggressive fishing operations are impacting all species of animals. this is why marine mammal facilities are important for protecting and researching these animals. they are able to educate the public about these remarkable mammals.

the yangtze river animal is not officially extinct, but there have been no confirmed sightings for nearly 20 years. the maui animal, the ganges river animal, and the short-beaked common animal face significant challenges for their future.

the species decline is due to many issues, one of which is that they are very slow breeders. most animals reproduce an average of every couple of years, but for this species, it's 6-7 years. they also face threats to their habitats and food sources.

the short-beaked common animal is found in the mediterranean in declining numbers. some major threats include river pollution, lowered levels of river water, and dam building. even small changes can have a big impact on the future of animals in the world.

some animals are friendly and curious while others are skittish and avoid human contact. don't do this in the wild; appreciate them from a distance. if you want this experience, go to a marine facility and have a safe encounter there.

if you see someone feeding animals in the wild, report them to the authorities. they may think they're helping, but they're causing more harm in the long run. do not touch or pet animals, even if they come close.

if you want to view animals from an aircraft, check with the company ahead of time to make sure they stay at least 1,000 feet above the water to avoid disorienting the animals. never use a drone to take picture of a animal from above.

fishing lines, fish hooks, and discarded netting are one of the bigger threats to animals. don't throw unused bait into the water. discard unwanted or waste fishing lines safely. you can also fish with specially designed dissolving hooks instead of stainless steel varieties.

the animal is a small to medium-sized marine mammal, which are found all over the world. they usually inhabit shallow seas and continental shelves. they are members of the order cetacea, of which there are four families.

animal facts overview encompasses all oceans, seas and many rivers, although they avoid polar zones. size: 5 – 31 ft (15 to 95 m) weight: 110 – 22,000 pounds (50 – 9,980 kg) color: light grey / white / black
the 40 different species can be found in a vast geographic region. around 35 of the species live in oceans, while five live in rivers. the smallest, the maui animal, grows to an average 5 years old.
animals are meat eaters and have a steady diet of squid, fish and crustaceans. the largest animal is the killer whale, which can grow up to 310 ft (95 m) in length, weighing 22,000 lb (9,980 kg)

agile swimmers, animals are a favorite for wildlife watchers as their playful activities and aerobatics in the water are a delight to see. they are also highly intelligent and can learn to do different tasks just through observation.

2 animals evolved from land mammals. cetaceans adapted from land to water with streamlined body shape, blowholes, a layer of blubber to provide insulation and flippers. animals belong to the toothed whale group.
scientists have found evidence that animals call each other by ‘name’, with a unique whistle for each member of a pod. animals and bats share the same superpower, ‘echolocation’

bats and animals send out high-pitched sounds and listen for them to echo as the sounds bounce off of objects. this allows bats and animals to move about freely knowing instantly where hazards exist and are capable to changing their path to avoid them.
pods can vary in size from as few as five all the way up to several hundred animals in a group. animals have been used by both us & soviet militaries. they are extremely social and playful mammals.

when animals hunt in groups, they will often trap a school of fish and will take turns slicing through the school to catch a meal. animals have been observed looking after the old, sick and injured in a pod.

in order to keep from drowning or safe from predators when sleeping, animals have the ability to shut off half of their brain, which goes to sleep. the other half stays active so that the mammal can continue to breathe and even swim.
the animal mating season runs throughout the year. there are peaks in spring and fall. gestation can be as little as nine months and as long as 17 months. the female gives birth in an unusual manner.

as soon as a calf is born, it is taken to the surface of the water quickly in order to catch its first breath. nursing will last between 11 months and two years and following that, the calf will remain with its mother for up to six more.

the word animal is actually an unspecific term. the word animal actually identifies several marine mammals. the toothed whale group that animals belong to include oceanic animals (delphinidae), river animals (iniidae) and indian river animals.

animals do not have actual ear holes or openings to hear with instead, they ‘listen’ with the small slits that are located behind their eyes. they have specially adapted lenses and corneas which allow them to see well both in and out of the water.

the fin located on the back of a animal is the dorsal fin. it provides directional control and stability when swimming. some species of animals do not have this feature. their pectoral flippers are not used for swimming.

based on their anatomy, animals are without olfactory lobes and nerves like all other toothed whales. as they do not have these anatomical features, scientists have concluded that animals very likely have little if any sense of smell.

some oceanic animals have a beak thanks to an elongated jaw. their teeth are used merely to catch their prey. animals have two stomachs, the first stores food and the second is where digestion takes place.
animals are usually larger than porpoises, with longer beaks and curved dorsal fins. the oldest known animal lived to 61 years old, and was captive living at florida’s marineland park.

the baiji animal, which is a river animal found in the yangtze river, has suffered a severe drop in population over the past few decades. the main cause happens to be pollution that has filled the river with contaminants.

animals have been known to protect humans from shark attacks. in one infamous encounter, they drove off the great white shark, and formed a ring of protection around the injured surfer until he managed to get back to shore and safety.

animals belong to the same zoological order as whales. they are mammals and breathe through a blowhole on the top of their head. most animals have acute eyesight, both in and out of the water. their sense of hearing is superior to that of humans.

the animal's sense of touch is also well developed. hearing is also used for echolocation, which is an ability all animals have. the tucuxi is the smallest of the animal species. it is about five feet in length and weighs about 100 pounds.

all but five of the 34 animal species live in tropical and temperate oceans. the baiji (chinese river animal) has been declared functionally extinct. some individuals may have lived for more than 100 years.

animals often hunt together, surrounding a school of fish, trapping the fish and taking turns swimming through the school and catching fish. animals will also follow seabirds, other whales and fishing boats to feed opportunistically on the fish they scare up or discard.

animals often leap above the water surface, sometimes performing acrobatic figures. scientists aren't quite certain about the purpose of this behavior, but it may be to locate schools of fish by looking at above water signs, like feeding birds.

play is a very important part of animals' lives and they can often be observed playing with seaweed or playfighting with other animals. animals also seem to enjoy riding waves and are frequently seen 'surfing' coastal swells and the bow waves of boats.

there are many stories of animals protecting shipwrecked sailors against sharks by swimming circles around the swimmers. a school of animals is also said to have pushed a fishing boat that was returning back out to sea after sensing the 2004 asian tsunami.

the individuals communicate using a variety of clicks, whistles and other vocalizations. they also use ultrasonic sounds for echolocation. membership in schools is not rigid; interchange is common. however, animals can establish strong bonds between each other.

technology to use sponges as mouth protection is not genetically inherited, but a taught cultural behavior. threats to animals include marine pollution, habitat degradation, harvesting, low frequency sonar and entrapment in fishing gear.

pesticides, heavy metals, plastics, and other pollutants concentrate in predators such as animals. injuries or deaths due to collisions with boats, especially their propellers, are also common. various fishing methods, most notably purse seine fishing for tuna, kill many animals.

hundreds of orcas, animals and other members of the animal family are held in captivity in the united states. while the marine mammal protection act (mmpa), passed in 1972, makes it more difficult to capture marine mammals from the wild, aquariums can still apply for permits or

captured orcas and animals are confined to tanks as small as 24 feet by 24 feet wide and 6 feet deep. tanks are kept clean with chlorine, copper sulfate, and other harsh chemicals that irritate animals' eyes. in tanks, the reverberations from their own sonar
marine parks may withhold up to 60 percent of food before shows so that the animals will be "sharp" for performances. the stress of captivity is so great that some animals commit suicide.
